('93', 0, 2, 3, 74) CHANDPUR, November 7, 1946
('93', 0, 3, 4, 101) GANDHIJI: What goes against my grain is that a single individual can be converted or a single woman can be kidnapped or raped.
('93', 0, 3, 5, 228) So long as we feel we can be subjected to these indignities, we shall continue to be so subjected.
('93', 0, 3, 6, 327) If we say we cannot do without police or military protection, we really confess defeat even before the battle has begun.
('93', 0, 3, 7, 448) No police or military in the world can protect people who are cowards.
('93', 0, 3, 8, 519) Today you say thousands of people are terrorizing a mere handful, so what can the latter do?
('93', 0, 3, 9, 612) But even a few individuals are enough to terrorize the whole mass, if the latter feel helpless.
('93', 0, 3, 10, 708) Your trouble is not numerical inferiority but the feeling of helplessness that has seized you and the habit of depending on others.
('93', 0, 3, 11, 840) The remedy lies with you.
('93', 0, 3, 12, 866) That is why I am opposed to the idea of your evacuating East Bengal en masse.
('93', 0, 3, 13, 944) It is no cure for impotence or helplessness.
('93', 0, 4, 14, 989) A WORKER: East Bengal is opposed to such a move.
('93', 0, 5, 15, 1038) G. They should not leave.
('93', 0, 5, 16, 1064) 20,000 able bodied men prepared to die like brave men non violently might today be regarded as a fairy tale, but it would be no fairy tale for every able bodied man in a population of 20,000 to die like stalwart soldiers in open fight.
('93', 0, 5, 17, 1300) They will go down in history like the immortal three hundred of Leonidas who made Thermopylae :
('93', 0, 6, 18, 1396) Stranger!
('93', 0, 6, 19, 1406) Tell Sparta, here her sons are laid,
('93', 0, 7, 20, 1443) Such was her law and we that law obeyed.
('93', 0, 7, 21, 1484) I will proclaim from the housetops that it is the only condi tion under which you can live in East Bengal.
('93', 0, 7, 22, 1591) You have asked for Hindu officers, Hindu police and Hindu military in the place of Muslim.
('93', 0, 7, 23, 1682) It is a false cry.
('93', 0, 7, 24, 1701) You forget that Hindu offi cers, Hindu police and Hindu military have in the past done all these things—looting, arson, abduction, rape.
('93', 0, 7, 25, 1838) I come from Kathiawar—the land of petty principa lities.
('93', 0, 7, 26, 1895) I cannot describe to you to what depths of depravity human

('93', 1, 11, 27, 3793) He should refuse to live as a serf and a slave.
('93', 1, 11, 28, 3841) He might not have the non violent strength to die without fighting.
('93', 1, 11, 29, 3909) But he could command their admiration if he had the courage not to submit to wrong and died fighting like a man.
('93', 1, 11, 30, 4022) There is not a man, however cruel and hard hearted, but would give his admiration to a brave man.
('93', 1, 11, 31, 4120) A goonda is not the vile man he is imagined to be.
('93', 1, 11, 32, 4171) He is not without his noble traits.
('93', 1, 12, 33, 4207) W. A goonda does not understand reason.
('93', 1, 13, 34, 4247) G. But he understands bravery.
('93', 1, 13, 35, 4278) If he finds that you are braver than he, he will respect you.
('93', 1, 13, 36, 4340) You will note that for the purposes of our present discussion I have not asked you to discard the use of arms.

('93', 2, 1, 2, 4497) can’t provide you with arms.
('93', 2, 1, 3, 4526) It is not for me to provide arms to the Chittagong Armoury Raid 1 men.

('93', 2, 5, 16, 5150) If they had shown the same fearlessness and courage to face death in the present crisis as they did when they made that raid, they would have gone down in history as heroes.
('93', 2, 5, 17, 5324) As it is, they have only inscribed a small footnote in the page of history.
('93', 2, 5, 18, 5400) You will see I am not, as I have already said, asking you just now to unlearn the use of arms or to follow my type of heroism.
('93', 2, 5, 19, 5527) I have not made it good even in my own case.
('93', 2, 5, 20, 5572) I have come here to test it in East Bengal.
('93', 2, 5, 21, 5616) I want you to take up the conventional type of heroism.
('93', 2, 5, 22, 5672) You should be able to infect others— both men and women—with courage and fearlessness to face death when the alternative is dishonour and humiliation.
('93', 2, 5, 23, 5823) Then the Hindus can stay in East Bengal, not otherwise.
('93', 2, 5, 24, 5879) After all, the Mussalmans are blood of our blood and bone of our bone.
('93', 2, 6, 25, 5950) W. Here the proportion of Mussalmans and Hindus is 6 to 1. How can you expect us to stand against such heavy odds?
('93', 2, 7, 26, 6065) G. When India was brought under British subjection, there were 70,000 European soldiers against 33 crores of Indians.
('93', 2, 8, 27, 6183) W. We have no arms.
('93', 2, 8, 28, 6203) The Government backs them with its bayonets.
('93', 2, 9, 29, 6248) G. The odds were much heavier against the Indians in South Africa.
('93', 2, 9, 30, 6315) The Indian community there was a mere hand ful in the midst of an overwhelming majority of Europeans and Negroes.
('93', 2, 9, 31, 6429) The Europeans had arms.
('93', 2, 9, 32, 6453) We had none.
('93', 2, 9, 33, 6466) So we forged the weapon of satyagraha.
('93', 2, 9, 34, 6505) Today the Indian is respected by the White man in South Africa, not so the Zulu with all his fine physique.
('93', 2, 10, 35, 6613) A WORKER: So we are to fight with arms anyhow?
('93', 2, 11, 36, 6660) G. Not anyhow.
('93', 2, 11, 37, 6675) Even violence has its code of ethics.

('93', 3, 1, 2, 6810) instance, to butcher helpless old men, women and children is not bravery but rank cowardice.
('93', 3, 1, 3, 6903) Chivalry requires that they should be protected even at the cost of one’s life.
('93', 3, 1, 4, 6983) The history of early Islam is replete with such instances of chivalry and Islam is all the stronger for them.

('93', 3, 2, 10, 7462) 1 I have heard it said that the retaliation in Bihar has ‘cooled’ the Muslims down.
('93', 3, 2, 11, 7546) They mean it has cowed them down for the time being.

('93', 3, 2, 15, 7923) The Independence of India is today at stake in Bengal and Bihar.
('93', 3, 2, 16, 7988) The British Government entrusted the Congress with power not because they are in love with the Congress but because they had faith that the Congress would use it wisely and well, not abuse it.
('93', 3, 2, 17, 8181) Today Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru finds the ground slipping from under his feet.

('93', 3, 2, 26, 8595) But for a thousand Hindus to fall upon a handful of Mussalmans—men, women and children —living in their midst is no retaliation but just brutality.
('93', 3, 2, 27, 8743) It is the privilege of arms to protect the weak and helpless.
('93', 3, 2, 28, 8805) The best succour that Bihar could have given to the Hindus of East Bengal would have been to guarantee with their own lives the absolute safety of the Muslim population living in their midst.
('93', 3, 2, 29, 8997) Their example would have told.
('93', 3, 2, 30, 9028) And I have faith that they will still do so with due repentance when the present madness has passed away.
('93', 3, 2, 31, 9134) Anyway that is the price I have put upon my life if they want me to live.
('93', 3, 2, 32, 9208) Here ends the first lesson.

('93', 4, 1, 2, 9311) 2. DISCUSSION WITH MUSLIM LEAGUE LEADERS 1
('93', 4, 2, 3, 9354) CHANDPUR, November 7, 1946
('93', 4, 3, 4, 9381) One of them remarked that no disturbances had taken place in Chandpur sub division.
('93', 4, 3, 5, 9465) The rush of refugees to Chandpur was due to panic caused by false Press propaganda.
('93', 4, 3, 6, 9549) The number of Hindus killed by the Muslims was only 15 while double that number of Muslims had died as a result of firing by the military who were mostly Hindus.
('93', 4, 4, 7, 9711) Another member of the deputation who was an M. L. A. was even more bitter about the fact that the Hindus were still evacuating and their rehabilitation was being ‘obstructed’ by the Hindu workers who encouraged them to migrate in order to discredit the Muslim League Government and paralyse the administration.
('93', 4, 5, 8, 10022) Shamsuddin Saheb who was present at the meeting along with Nasrullah Saheb 2 and Abdul Rashid Saheb interposed that it was no use isolating Chandpur sub division and ignoring what had taken place elsewhere in the district.
('93', 4, 5, 9, 10245) Equally irrelevant to their present argument was their reference to the military firing.
('93', 4, 6, 10, 10334) When they had finished, Gandhiji replying remarked that if what they had said was to be taken at its face value, then it amounted to this: that the Muslims had committed no excesses.
('93', 4, 6, 11, 10517) The mischief had all been provok ed by the excesses of the police and the military who were harassing the Mussalmans and it was they, therefore, who together with the panic monger ing Hindus were the real culprits.
('93', 4, 6, 12, 10732) That was too big a pill for anybody to swallow.
('93', 4, 6, 13, 10780) Why had it become necessary to call the military, if no disturbances had taken place?
('93', 4, 6, 14, 10866) A deputation of 20 to 25 Hindus had a meeting with him in the morning.
('93', 4, 6, 15, 10937) 3 They had told him awful tales of what had happened in Tippera and Noakhali.
('93', 4, 6, 16, 11015) Similar tales had been pouring into his ears ever since he had set foot in Bengal.
('93', 4, 6, 17, 11098) Even Muslim Leaguers had admitted that terrible things had been done.
('93', 4, 6, 18, 11168) They disputed the figures which they feared were exaggerated.
('93', 4, 6, 19, 11230) He was not concerned with numbers.
('93', 4, 6, 20, 11265) Even if there was a single case of abduction, forcible conversion or forcible marriage, it was enough to make every godfearing man or woman hang down his or her head in shame.
('93', 4, 7, 21, 11441) He was not going to keep anything secret, Gandhiji proceeded.
('93', 4, 7, 22, 11503) He would place all the information which he might receive before the Ministers.
('93', 4, 7, 23, 11583) He had come to
('93', 4, 8, 24, 11598) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Overproof is Admission”.
('93', 4, 8, 25, 11652) Several prominent Muslim League leaders of Tippera District met Gandhiji at Chandpur on board the Kiwi before he left for Chaumuhani.
('93', 4, 8, 26, 11786) 2 K. Nasrullah, M. L. A. and Parliamentary Secretary in the Home Department of the Muslim League Ministry in Bengal 3 Vide the preceding item.

('93', 5, 1, 2, 11969) promote mutual goodwill and confidence.
('93', 5, 1, 3, 12009) In that he wanted their help.
('93', 5, 1, 4, 12039) He did not want peace to be established with the help of the police and the military.
('93', 5, 1, 5, 12125) An imposed peace was no peace.
('93', 5, 1, 6, 12156) He did not wish to encourage people to flee from their homes in East Bengal either.
('93', 5, 1, 7, 12240) If the mass flight of the refugees had been deliberately planned to discredit the Muslim League Ministry, it would recoil on the heads of those who had done so.
('93', 5, 1, 8, 12401) To him it seemed hardly credible.
('93', 5, 1, 9, 12435) He suggested that the right course would be to make a clean breast of the matter.
('93', 5, 1, 10, 12517) It is far better to magnify your own mistake and proclaim it to the whole world than leave it to the world to point the accusing finger at you.
('93', 5, 1, 11, 12661) God never spares the evil doer.
('93', 5, 2, 12, 12693) The gentleman who had spoken first thereupon admitted that he had heard of some cases of arson and looting but the looting had taken place after the occupants had fled.
('93', 5, 2, 13, 12862) The deserted houses offered too strong a temptation to the hooligans.
('93', 5, 3, 14, 12932) GANDHIJI: But why should people flee from their homes?
('93', 5, 3, 15, 12987) People do not do so normally.
('93', 5, 3, 16, 13017) Everybody knows that an unoccupied and unprotected house is bound to be looted by someone or the other.
('93', 5, 3, 17, 13121) Would anyone risk the loss of all he owns just to discredit the League?
('93', 5, 4, 18, 13193) Still another member of the deputation remarked that only one per cent of the people had indulged in acts of hooliganism.
('93', 5, 4, 19, 13315) The rest of the 99 per cent were really good people and in no way responsible for the happenings.
('93', 5, 5, 20, 13413) That was not a correct way of looking at it, Gandhiji replied.
('93', 5, 5, 21, 13476) If 99 per cent were good people and had actively disapproved of what had taken place, the one per cent would have been able to do nothing and could easily have been brought to book.
('93', 5, 5, 22, 13658) Good people ought actively to combat the evil, to entitle them to that name.
('93', 5, 5, 23, 13735) Sitting on the fence was no good.
('93', 5, 5, 24, 13769) If they did not mean it, they should say so and openly tell all the Hindus in the Muslim majority areas to quit.
('93', 5, 5, 25, 13882) But that was not their position as he understood it.
('93', 5, 5, 26, 13935) The Qaid e Azam had said that the minorities in Pakistan would get unadulterated justice.
('93', 5, 5, 27, 14025) Where was that justice?
('93', 5, 5, 28, 14049) Today the Hindus asked him if Noakhali was an indication of what they were to expect in Pakistan.
('93', 5, 5, 29, 14147) He had studied Islam.
('93', 5, 5, 30, 14169) His Muslim friends in South Africa used to say to him: “Why not recite the Kalama and forget Hinduism?” He used to say in reply that he would gladly recite the Kalama but forget Hinduism never.
('93', 5, 5, 31, 14363) His respect and regard for Hazrat Mohammed was not less than theirs.
('93', 5, 5, 32, 14432) But authoritarianism and compulsion was the way to corrupt religion, not to advance it.
('93', 5, 6, 33, 14520) Shamsuddin Saheb agreeing with Gandhiji quoted a verse from the Koran to the effect that there can be no compulsion in religion.
('93', 5, 6, 34, 14649) He had told the Mussalmans, he said, that if they wanted Pakistan they must mete out justice to the minority community and win its confidence.
('93', 5, 6, 35, 14792) “By doing what you have done, you have killed Pakistan,” he had told them.
('93', 6, 0, 1, 14867) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 7
('93', 6, 1, 2, 14913) G. Mr. McInerny, the District Magistrate of Noakhali, in a leaflet he has issued, has said that he will assume, unless the contrary is conclusively proved, that anyone who accepted Islam after the beginning of the recent disturbances was forcibly converted and in fact remained a Hindu.
('93', 6, 1, 3, 15200) If all the Muslims made that declaration, it would go a long way to settle the question.
('93', 6, 1, 4, 15289) Why should there be a public show of it, if anybody genuinely felt inclined to recite the Kalama?
('93', 6, 1, 5, 15387) A heart conversion needs no other witness than God.
('93', 6, 2, 6, 15439) Mere recitation of the Kalama while one continued to indulge in acts which are contrary to elementary decency was not Islam but a travesty of it.
('93', 6, 2, 7, 15585) That reminded him of the Plymouth Brothers 1 who had invited him to embrace Christianity because then he would be free to do anything he liked since Christ redeemed the sins of those who accepted him.
('93', 6, 2, 8, 15786) As against that there was the conclusive verse of the New Testament: “Not everyone who says Lord, Lord, with his lips comes to me.” 2 It was therefore up to the leaders of the Muslims to declare that forcible repetition of a formula could not make a non Muslim into a Muslim.
('93', 6, 2, 9, 16062) It only shamed Islam.
('93', 6, 3, 10, 16084) “All that has happened is the result of false propaganda,” argued one member of the deputation who had not hitherto spoken.
('93', 6, 4, 11, 16208) G. Let us not make a scapegoat of false propaganda.
('93', 6, 4, 12, 16260) False propaganda would fall flat if we are all right.
('93', 6, 5, 13, 16314) Finally one of the deputationists remarked that they were all prepared to go into the interior along with the Hindu leaders to restore peace and confidence but the latter distrusted them.
('93', 6, 6, 14, 16502) Gandhiji replied that that did not matter.
('93', 6, 6, 15, 16545) He would gladly accept their offer.
('93', 6, 6, 16, 16581) He said : You and I will visit every village and every home in the interior and restore peace and confidence.
('93', 6, 6, 17, 16691) Harijan, 24 11 1946

('93', 7, 1, 2, 16797) 3. TALK TO REFUGEES 1
('93', 7, 2, 3, 16819) LAKSHAM, November 7, 1946 I have not come on a whirlwind propaganda visit.
('93', 7, 2, 4, 16894) I have come to stay here with you as one of you.
('93', 7, 2, 5, 16943) I have no provincialism in me.
('93', 7, 2, 6, 16974) I claim to be an Indian and therefore a Bengali even as I am a Gujarati.
('93', 7, 2, 7, 17047) I have vowed to myself that I will stay on here and die here if necessary, but I will not leave Bengal till the hatchet is finally buried and even a solitary Hindu girl is not afraid to move freely about in the midst of Mussalmans.
('93', 7, 2, 8, 17279) The greatest help you can give me is to banish fear from your hearts.
('93', 7, 2, 9, 17349) And what is the talisman that can do that for you.
('93', 7, 2, 10, 17400) It is the unfailing mantra of Ramanama.
('93', 7, 2, 11, 17440) You may say, you do not believe in Him.
('93', 7, 2, 12, 17480) You do not know that but for His will you could not draw a single breath.
('93', 7, 2, 13, 17554) Call Him Ishwar, Allah, God, Ahura Mazda.
('93', 7, 2, 14, 17596) His names are as innumerable as there are men.
('93', 7, 2, 15, 17643) He is one without a second.
('93', 7, 2, 16, 17671) He alone is great.
('93', 7, 2, 17, 17690) There is none greater than He.
('93', 7, 2, 18, 17721) He is timeless, formless, stainless.
('93', 7, 2, 19, 17758) Such is my Rama.
('93', 7, 2, 20, 17775) He alone is my Lord and Master.
('93', 7, 3, 21, 17807) Gandhiji touchingly described to them how as a little boy he used to be usually timid and afraid of even shadows and how his nurse Rambha had taught him the secret of Ramanama as an antidote to fear.
('93', 7, 3, 22, 18007) “When in fear, take Ramanama.
('93', 7, 3, 23, 18037) He will protect you,” she used to tell him.
('93', 7, 3, 24, 18081) Ever since then Ramanama had been his unfailing refuge and shelter from all kinds of fear.
('93', 7, 4, 25, 18172) He resides in the heart of the pure always.
('93', 7, 4, 26, 18216) Tulsidas, that prince of devotees, whose name had become a household word among the Hindus from Kashmir to Cape Comorin as Shri Chaitanya’s and Shri Ramakrishna Paramahansa’s in Bengal, had presented the message of that name to us in his immortal Ramayana.
('93', 7, 4, 27, 18473) If you walked in fear of that name, you did not need to fear any man on earth, be he a prince or a pauper.
('93', 7, 5, 28, 18580) Why should they be afraid of the cry of “Allaho Akbar”?
('93', 7, 5, 29, 18636) The Allah of Islam was the protector of innocence.
('93', 7, 5, 30, 18687) What had been done in East Bengal had not the sanction of Islam as preached by its Prophet.
('93', 7, 6, 31, 18779) Who could dare to dishonour their wives or daughters if they had faith in God?
('93', 7, 7, 32, 18858) 1 According to a report in Hindustan Standard, 8 11 1946, Gandhiji addressed a gathering of about 10,000 people—Hindus and Muslims—waiting from early morning at Laksham Junction—en route to Chaumuhani, which he reached shortly after midday.
('93', 8, 0, 1, 19099) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 9
('93', 8, 1, 2, 19145) He, therefore, expected them to cease to be afraid of Mussalmans.
('93', 8, 1, 3, 19211) If they believed in Ramanama, they must not think of leaving East Bengal.
('93', 8, 1, 4, 19285) They must live where they were born and brought up and die there if necessary, defending their honour as brave men and women.
('93', 8, 1, 5, 19411) To run away from danger instead of facing it is to deny one’s faith in man and God and even one’s own self.
('93', 8, 1, 6, 19519) It were better for one to drown oneself than live to declare such bankruptcy of faith.
('93', 8, 1, 7, 19606) If you ask the military, they will tell you that God is their protector.

('93', 8, 2, 13, 20174) The only way to save oneself was to rely on one’s fellowmen, no matter whether they were Hindus or Muslims.
('93', 8, 2, 14, 20282) It was the gospel of love that he had come here to preach.

('93', 15, 1, 2, 33474) 12. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('93', 15, 2, 3, 33501) CHAUMUHANI, November 9, 1946
('93', 15, 3, 4, 33530) Two telegrams from Patna reprove me on my “threatened” fast.
('93', 15, 3, 5, 33591) “Threatened” is the word used in one of the wires.
('93', 15, 3, 6, 33642) My proposed fast is not meant to coerce anyone; it is meant to quicken the dead conscience into life.
('93', 15, 3, 7, 33744) Those who act from fear harm themselves and the cause they profess to serve.
('93', 15, 3, 8, 33821) Surely, it is as plain as A. B. C. that the action of the Biharis in injuring the very small minority of Muslims in Bihar must postpone the day of India’s independence and ultimately sour Muslims all over India unless Bihar repents her folly of senseless and cowardly violence.
('93', 15, 3, 9, 34099) Rashtrapati Acharya Kripalani, whom every Bihari knows for his sterling services, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Dr. Rajendra Prasad and now Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and Shri Jayaprakash Narayan are now in Bihar and expect to show fair Bihar that their terrible ill treatment of the Muslims is communalism of the worst type and is calculated to defeat the growing nationalism of Bihar.
('93', 15, 3, 10, 34478) I, therefore, warn everyone from abusing my contemplated fast which is in no way intended to deflect anyone from what he believes is the course of duty for him.
('93', 15, 3, 11, 34639) The Hindu, 11 11 1946

('93', 16, 3, 10, 35811) 14. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 16, 4, 11, 35842) DATTAPARA, November 10, 1946 Whether you believe me or not, I want to assure you that I am a servant of both the Hindus and the Mussalmans.
('93', 16, 4, 12, 35982) I have not come here to fight Pakistan.
('93', 16, 4, 13, 36022) If India is destined to be partitioned, I cannot prevent it.
('93', 16, 4, 14, 36083) But I wish to tell you that Pakistan cannot be established by force.
('93', 16, 4, 15, 36152) In the bhajan that was just sung ‘the poet has likened God to the philosophers’ stone.
('93', 16, 4, 16, 36239) The proverbial philosophers’ stone is said to turn iron into gold.
('93', 16, 4, 17, 36306) That is not always desirable.
('93', 16, 4, 18, 36336) For instance, if all the rails of the railway track were turned into gold by the touch of the stone, the trains would not be able to run over them.
('93', 16, 4, 19, 36484) But the touch of God purifies the soul.
('93', 16, 4, 20, 36524) That is always desirable.
('93', 16, 4, 21, 36550) That philosophers’ stone is within us all.
('93', 16, 4, 22, 36593) All that I wish to tell my Muslim brethren is that, whether they live as one people or two, they should live as friends with the Hindus.
('93', 16, 4, 23, 36730) If they do not wish to do so, they should say so plainly.
('93', 16, 4, 24, 36788) I would in that case confess myself defeated.
('93', 16, 4, 25, 36834) The refugees cannot stay on as refugees for ever.
('93', 16, 4, 26, 36884) The Government cannot go on feeding them.
('93', 16, 4, 27, 36926) And what sort of feed are they getting?
('93', 16, 4, 28, 36966) Less than half the daily ration of cereals to keep an able bodied man alive, no fish, no vegetables, nor anything else to
('93', 16, 5, 29, 37088) 1 This appeared under the title “An Appeal to Conscience” as reported by Pyarelal.
('93', 17, 0, 1, 37171) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 17, 1, 2, 37212) supplement it.
('93', 17, 1, 3, 37227) It is not possible for them to exist like this for any length of time.
('93', 17, 1, 4, 37298) If, therefore, the Muslims do not want them back in their villages, they must go elsewhere.
('93', 17, 1, 5, 37390) But even if every Hindu of East Bengal went away, I will still continue to live amidst the Muslims of East Bengal and eat what they give me and what I consider lawful for me to partake of.
('93', 17, 1, 6, 37579) I will not bring my food from outside.
('93', 17, 1, 7, 37618) I do not need fish or flesh.
('93', 17, 1, 8, 37647) All that I need is a little fruit, vegetables and some goat’s milk.
('93', 17, 1, 9, 37715) As far as goat’s milk and cereals are concerned, I would take them again only when it pleases God that I should do so.
('93', 17, 1, 10, 37834) I have given it up and would not resume it till the Hindus are really penitent of what they have done in Bihar.
('93', 17, 1, 11, 37946) For a thousand Hindus to surround a hundred Mussalmans or for a thousand Mussalmans to surround a hundred Hindus and oppress them is not bravery but cowardice.
('93', 17, 1, 12, 38106) Fair fight means even numbers and previous notice.
('93', 17, 1, 13, 38157) That does not mean that I approve of their fighting.
('93', 17, 1, 14, 38210) It has been said that the Hindus and Mussalmans cannot stay together as friends or co operate with each other.
('93', 17, 1, 15, 38321) No one can make me believe that, but if that is your belief, you should say so.
('93', 17, 1, 16, 38401) I would in that case not ask the Hindus to return to their homes.

('93', 26, 1, 3, 55840) Gandhiji replied that he did not see how that could stand in the way of their establishing good relations with the Hindus.
('93', 26, 1, 4, 55963) On the contrary, it ought to provide an incentive for cultivating their friendship and winning their confidence so that there would be no motive left to get innocent Muslims implicated.
('93', 26, 1, 5, 56149) The issue was really irrelevant to the proposition before them.
('93', 26, 1, 6, 56213) When large numbers have participated in crime, it is but natural that some innocent men will be implicated with the guilty ones.
('93', 26, 1, 7, 56342) It is so all the world over.
('93', 26, 1, 8, 56371) That does not mean that the guilty ones should not be proceeded against.
('93', 26, 2, 9, 56444) The remedy was for the Muslims to confer with the Hindus and produce agreed lists of those who had been really guilty.
('93', 26, 2, 10, 56563) No innocent person would then suffer.
('93', 26, 2, 11, 56601) To bring to book the really guilty ones was the acid test of the sincerity of the authorities and the local Muslims alike.
('93', 26, 2, 12, 56724) Addressing the members of the Muslim League in the gathering, Gandhiji proceeded: I have come here to seek your co operation.
('93', 26, 2, 13, 56850) You are a pow erful party.
('93', 26, 2, 14, 56877) What has happened here does not show Islam at its best or even at its worst.
('93', 26, 2, 15, 56954) It is the very negation of Islam.
('93', 26, 2, 16, 56988) The first question we have got to settle is whether there can be co operation between the Hindus and Muslims.
('93', 26, 2, 17, 57098) I have apprised Shaheed Shurawardy of the things that have prevented the refugees from returning to their villages.
('93', 26, 2, 18, 57214) The havoc which I saw yesterday was appalling.
('93', 26, 2, 19, 57261) These things cannot be whitewashed.
('93', 26, 2, 20, 57297) Energetic steps have to be taken.

('93', 29, 0, 1, 62021) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 29, 1, 2, 62062) 32. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING 1
('93', 29, 2, 3, 62093) SHAHPUR, November 14, 1946
('93', 29, 3, 4, 62120) Gandhiji had been told that there would be a big gathering at Shahpur.
('93', 29, 3, 5, 62191) But someone had spread the rumour that he would be accompanied by the Superintendent of Police, the District Magistrate and an armed guard who would utilize the occasion for making arrests, with the result that very few people were in evidence when Gandhiji arrived there.
('93', 29, 4, 6, 62464) “It is a cruel joke,” remarked Gandhiji.
('93', 29, 4, 7, 62505) For so far as he was concerned, he had never wanted any police or district authorities to accompany him.
('93', 29, 4, 8, 62610) But the authorities said they could not take the risk of letting him go about unprotected.
('93', 29, 5, 9, 62701) It had been brought to his notice that in several places, while the local Mussalmans professed to be anxious that peace should be re established, they were not prepared to do anything for it or give any guarantee unless the Muslim League leaders asked them to.
('93', 29, 5, 10, 62962) Gandhiji, recognizing the reasonableness of their suggestion, referred to a statement of Qaid e Azam Jinnah which he had read that morning.
('93', 29, 5, 11, 63102) He did not like everything in that statement but there were some things in it which should commend themselves to all.
('93', 29, 5, 12, 63220) In that statement Qaid e Azam Jinnah had said:
('93', 29, 6, 13, 63267) “If the Mussalmans lose their balance and give vent to the spirit of vengeance and retaliation and prove false to the highest codes of morality and preachings of our great religion Islam, they will not only lose their title to the claim of Pakistan but also it will start of a most vicious circle of bloodshed and cruelty which will at once put off the day of our freedom and we shall only be helping to prolong the period of slavery and bondage.”
('93', 29, 7, 14, 63715) He had further said :
('93', 29, 8, 15, 63737) “We must prove politically that we are brave, generous and trustworthy .
('93', 29, 8, 16, 63810) that in the Pakistan areas the minorities will enjoy the fullest security of life, property and honour just as the Mussalmans themselves, nay, even greater.”
('93', 29, 9, 17, 63968) He would like them, remarked Gandhiji, to ponder over that statement, if, on examination, they found that his quotation was correct.
('93', 29, 9, 18, 64101) Murder, loot, arson, abduction, forcible marriages and forcible conversions could not but prolong India’s slavery.
('93', 29, 9, 19, 64216) If they kept on quarrelling among themselves, if they looked to the police and the military for protection, they would be inciting the third party to rule over them.
('93', 29, 9, 20, 64382) Harijan, 1 12 1946
('93', 29, 10, 21, 64401) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('93', 29, 10, 22, 64446) Gandhiji left Dattapara for Kazirkhil in the afternoon.
('93', 29, 10, 23, 64502) En route he addressed a public meeting at Shahpur.
('93', 30, 0, 1, 64553) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 31
('93', 30, 1, 2, 64600) 33. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 30, 2, 3, 64631) KAZIRKHIL, November 14, 1946
('93', 30, 3, 4, 64660) Gandhiji said he found indescribable peace in the natural scenery around him but he found that peace missing on the faces of the men and women.
('93', 30, 3, 5, 64804) And how could they have peace after all that they had been through?
('93', 30, 3, 6, 64872) He found a number of guards standing there to protect him and his party.
('93', 30, 3, 7, 64945) Against whom were they to protect him?
('93', 30, 3, 8, 64984) He was not used to going about with a guard.
('93', 30, 3, 9, 65029) He had toured in Bengal unprotected before this.
('93', 30, 3, 10, 65078) He said: But today the authorities would not let me do so.
('93', 30, 3, 11, 65137) It is a matter of sorrow and shame for me and more than me it should be a matter of shame for the Mussalmans of East Bengal.
('93', 30, 4, 12, 65262) Even the schools and temples had been destroyed, he proceeded.
('93', 30, 4, 13, 65325) Shamsuddin Saheb, their Minister, did not like it.
('93', 30, 4, 14, 65376) The happenings in East Bengal, he said, had hurt him deeply.
('93', 30, 4, 15, 65437) The hearts of the people had to be purged of hatred.
('93', 30, 4, 16, 65490) For that their help and co operation was necessary.
('93', 30, 5, 17, 65542) This fratricide was more awful than anything in his experience.
('93', 30, 5, 18, 65606) He had carried on a grim struggle for 20 years in South Africa and for the last 30 years in India.
('93', 30, 5, 19, 65705) But this mutual slaughter had nonplussed him.
('93', 30, 5, 20, 65751) He did not know how he could induce the two communities to live in peace and harmony again.
('93', 30, 5, 21, 65843) He had come to Bengal to find out a solution for the problem.
('93', 30, 5, 22, 65905) Bengal was a big province.
('93', 30, 5, 23, 65932) If the communal problem could be solved here, it would be solved elsewhere also.
('93', 30, 5, 24, 66013) If he succeeded here, he would go away from Bengal with a new lease of life.
('93', 30, 5, 25, 66090) If not, he wished God to remove him from this earth.
('93', 30, 5, 26, 66143) He did not wish to leave Bengal empty handed.
('93', 30, 5, 27, 66189) The word “pessimism” was not to be found in his dictionary.
('93', 30, 6, 28, 66249) The Muslims butchered the Hindus and did worse things than butchery in Bengal and the Hindus butchered the Muslims in Bihar.
('93', 30, 6, 29, 66374) When both acted wickedly it was no use making comparisons or saying one was less wicked than the other, or who started the trouble.
('93', 30, 6, 30, 66506) If they wished to take revenge they should learn the art from him.
('93', 30, 6, 31, 66573) He also took revenge, but it was of a different type.
('93', 30, 6, 32, 66627) He had read a Gujarati poem in his childhood which said: “If to him who gives you a glass of water, you give two, there is no merit in it.
('93', 30, 6, 33, 66766) Real merit lies in doing good to him who does you evil.” Gandhiji concluded: That I consider noble revenge.
('93', 30, 7, 34, 66874) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('93', 30, 7, 35, 66919) At Kazirkhil, Gandhiji had been lodged in a partially destroyed house which had been cleaned up and made habitable.
('93', 30, 7, 36, 67035) Prayers were held in the compound of the house.
('93', 31, 0, 1, 67083) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 31, 1, 2, 67124) I read a story about one of the earlier Caliphs.
('93', 31, 1, 3, 67173) A man attacked the Caliph with a sword.
('93', 31, 1, 4, 67213) The Caliph wrested the sword from the assailant’s hands and was going to kill him when the assailant spat on his face.
('93', 31, 1, 5, 67332) The Caliph thereupon let him go free because the indignity had filled him with personal anger.
('93', 31, 1, 6, 67427) This produced a great impression upon the assailant and he embraced Islam.
('93', 31, 1, 7, 67502) One who is forcibly converted to Islam ceases to be a man.
('93', 31, 1, 8, 67561) To recite the Kalma through fear is meaningless.
('93', 31, 1, 9, 67610) Harijan, 1 12 1946

('93', 32, 1, 2, 68442) 36. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 32, 2, 3, 68473) RAMGANJ, November 15, 1946
('93', 32, 3, 4, 68500) Gandhiji reiterated and emphasized his previous day’s appeal.
('93', 32, 3, 5, 68562) He could talk to them of nothing but sorrow and suffering these days.
('93', 32, 3, 6, 68632) Wherever he went he saw awful sights of destruction.
('93', 32, 3, 7, 68685) There were no tears in his eyes.
('93', 32, 3, 8, 68718) He who shed tears could not wipe those of others, but his heart did weep.
('93', 32, 3, 9, 68792) He had come with the hope that he could have a frank talk with the Mussalmans and that they would repent of their misdeeds and request the Hindus not to leave their homes.
('93', 32, 3, 10, 68964) If the repentance was genuine, the Hindus would recognize their sincerity and regain lost confidence.
('93', 32, 3, 11, 69066) But he could see that the Hindus and the Muslims of East Bengal had been embittered against one another.
('93', 32, 3, 12, 69171) He would not go into the reasons thereof.
('93', 32, 3, 13, 69213) But the Muslim brethren would permit him to say that so far as he knew, in East Bengal they had been the aggressors.
('93', 32, 3, 14, 69330) The Hindus were mortally afraid of them.
('93', 32, 3, 15, 69371) At Chaumuhani Muslims came to his meeting in larger numbers than the Hindus did.
('93', 32, 3, 16, 69452) But he did not know why they were avoiding him after the first meeting at Dattapara.
('93', 32, 3, 17, 69537) It hurt him.
('93', 32, 3, 18, 69550) He wanted the few Mussalmans who were present at the meeting to carry his message to the rest.
('93', 32, 3, 19, 69645) A Muslim sister who had been going about meeting leading Muslims in these parts had said that the Muslims told her plainly that they wanted orders from the League leaders before they could promise to befriend the Hindus or attend Gandhiji’s meetings.
('93', 32, 3, 20, 69896) The exodus of the Hindus was still continuing.
('93', 32, 3, 21, 69943) If the Muslims assured them that they were neighbours, friends and brothers, sons of the same soil, breathing the same air and drinking the same water, that the Hindus had nothing to fear from them, the exodus would stop and even those who had left their homes would return.
('93', 32, 3, 22, 70218) Even animals were friendly to those who befriended them.
('93', 32, 3, 23, 70275) But man was made in the image of God.
('93', 32, 3, 24, 70313) To justify his inheritance, man had to return good for evil.
('93', 32, 3, 25, 70374) Whosoever was at fault, this truth applied to both the parties.
('93', 32, 3, 26, 70438) The Muslims wanted orders from the League.
('93', 32, 3, 27, 70481) He could understand it.
('93', 32, 3, 28, 70505) There was a League Government in the province.
('93', 32, 3, 29, 70552) But that did not mean that the Government should be inimical to those outside the League.
('93', 32, 4, 30, 70642) He reiterated what he said 2 about Qaid e Azam Jinnah’s message on the previous day.
('93', 32, 4, 31, 70727) They should search their hearts and ask themselves if they had lived up to that message.
('93', 32, 4, 32, 70816) He concluded: So far as I know, Islam does not permit forcible conversion and atrocities on women.
('93', 32, 4, 33, 70915) What good can a mere repetition of the Kalma do to one whose heart does not accept Islam?
('93', 32, 4, 34, 71005) You should ask your leaders, therefore, whether you are to be friends with the Hindus or

('93', 33, 1, 4, 71366) For myself, I have come to stay in East Bengal till there is reconciliation between the two.

('93', 34, 1, 2, 72569) 39. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 34, 2, 3, 72600) KAZIRKHIL, November 16, 1946
('93', 34, 3, 4, 72629) Gandhiji, addressing the meeting after Goffran Saheb 2, began by referring to Shamsuddin Saheb’s speech 3 at Chaumuhani a few days ago.
('93', 34, 3, 5, 72765) They had now heard Goffran Saheb.
('93', 34, 3, 6, 72799) The Ministers wanted them to live together as friends.
('93', 34, 3, 7, 72854) The police and the military could not protect them.
('93', 34, 3, 8, 72906) God alone could protect them.
('93', 34, 3, 9, 72936) They had, therefore, to look to each other for their safety.
('93', 34, 3, 10, 72997) Goffran Saheb had told them that the Government did not wish the Hindus to leave East Bengal.
('93', 34, 3, 11, 73091) Awful things had no doubt happened but they should let bygones be bygones.
('93', 34, 3, 12, 73166) They must turn a new leaf.
('93', 34, 3, 13, 73193) When one had suffered as they had, one was liable to become filled with suspicion.
('93', 34, 3, 14, 73276) But that had to be overcome.

('93', 41, 3, 20, 88242) 50. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('93', 41, 4, 21, 88273) KAZIRKHIL, [November 19, 1946] 2
('93', 41, 5, 22, 88306) QUESTION: Will the new experiment, which you propose to inaugurate tomorrow, of going and living singly in affected villages, infuse courage into the hearts of refugees and succeed in persuading them to return to their villages?
('93', 41, 5, 23, 88535) What is the significance underlying this experiment?
('93', 41, 5, 24, 88588) GANDHIJI: This question would not arise if you knew that I was going to a village for my own sake, that is, to test my ahimsa.
('93', 41, 5, 25, 88715) I am not going singly; there will be Nirmal Kumar Bose as my Bengali interpreter and my stenographer Parasuram from the South.
('93', 41, 5, 26, 88842) If I have the requisite courage and capacity to undergo a comparatively hard life and to encourage inner ahimsa, I should expect to affect both Hindus and Muslims in the right manner.
('93', 41, 5, 27, 89026) You should also know that all members of my original party will similarly distribute themselves, taking with them a local Bengali
('93', 41, 6, 28, 89156) 1 The report said that Gandhiji’s interview to “a special correspondent” was on “the eve of his departure for Srirampur”.

('93', 42, 1, 2, 89370) worker.
('93', 42, 1, 3, 89378) The choice of village will rest with Satis Chandra Das Gupta.
('93', 42, 2, 4, 89440) Asked whether Bengal Government would not feel that his action was aimed at bringing ridicule on them, Gandhiji replied: I think not, only because I have not the remotest idea of bringing ridicule on them, assuming of course that Bengal Govern ment have meant every word of what they have said.
('93', 42, 2, 5, 89735) Indeed, I am in search of a League Muslim who will harbour me in his house as a member of his family.

('93', 42, 5, 10, 90199) 51. A TALK 1
('93', 42, 6, 11, 90212) [On or before November 20, 1946] 2
('93', 42, 7, 12, 90247) When I was in detention in the Aga Khan Palace, I once sat down to write a thesis on India as a protagonist of non violence.
('93', 42, 7, 13, 90372) But as I proceeded with my writing, I could not go on.
('93', 42, 7, 14, 90427) I had to stop.
('93', 42, 7, 15, 90442) There are two aspects of Hinduism.
('93', 42, 7, 16, 90477) There is, on the one hand, the historical Hinduism with its untouchability, superstitious worship of stocks and stones, animal sacrifice and so on.
('93', 42, 7, 17, 90625) On the other, we have the Hinduism of the Gita, the Upanishads and Patanjali’s Yoga Sutra which is the acme of ahimsa and oneness of all creation, pure worship of one immanent, formless imperishable God.
('93', 42, 7, 18, 90829) Ahimsa which to me is the chief glory of Hinduism has been sought to be explained away by our people as being meant for sannyasis only.
('93', 42, 7, 19, 90965) I do not share that view.
('93', 42, 7, 20, 90991) I have held that it is the way of life and India has to show it to the world.
('93', 42, 7, 21, 91069) Where do I stand?
('93', 42, 7, 22, 91087) Do I represent this ahimsa in my person?
('93', 42, 7, 23, 91128) If I do, then deceit and hatred that poison the atmosphere should dissolve.
('93', 42, 7, 24, 91204) It is only by going into isolation from my compa nions, those on whose help I have relied all along, and standing on my own feet that I shall find my bearings and also test my faith in God.
('93', 42, 7, 25, 91394) Harijan, 8 12 1946

('93', 46, 4, 8, 95481) 58. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('93', 46, 5, 9, 95508) November 20, 1946 I find myself in the midst of exaggeration and falsity.
('93', 46, 5, 10, 95582) I am unable to discover the truth.
('93', 46, 5, 11, 95617) There is terrible mutual distrust.
('93', 46, 5, 12, 95652) Oldest friendships have snapped.
('93', 46, 5, 13, 95685) Truth and ahimsa by which I swear, and which have, to my knowledge, sustained me for sixty years, seem to fail to show the attributes I have ascribed to them.
('93', 46, 5, 14, 95844) To test them, or better, to test myself, I am going to a village called Srirampur, cutting myself away from those who have been with me all these years, and who have made life easy for me.
('93', 46, 5, 15, 96033) I am taking Prof.
('93', 46, 5, 16, 96051) Nirmal Kumar Bose as my Bengali teacher and interpreter and Shri Parasuram, who has been my most devoted, selfless and silent stenographer.
('93', 46, 5, 17, 96191) The other workers, whom I have brought with me, will each distribute themselves in other villages of Noakhali to do the work ofpeace, if it is at all possible, between the two communities.
('93', 46, 5, 18, 96380) They are, unfortunately, all non Bengalis except little Abha 1. They will, there fore, be accompanied by one Bengali worker each as teacher and interpreter, even like Prof.
('93', 46, 5, 19, 96553) N. K. Bose will be to me.
('93', 46, 5, 20, 96579) Distribution work and selection work will be done by Shri Satis Chandra Das Gupta of the Khadi Pratishthan.
('93', 46, 5, 21, 96687) My ideal is to live in a local Muslim League family, but I see that I must not wait for that happy day.
('93', 46, 5, 22, 96791) I must meanwhile establish such contacts with the Muslims as I can in their own villages.
('93', 46, 5, 23, 96881) My suggestion to the League Ministers is that they should give me one honest and brave Muslim to accompany one equally honest and brave Hindu for each affected village.
('93', 46, 5, 24, 97050) They should guarantee, at the cost of their lives if need be, the
('93', 46, 6, 25, 97116) 1 Abha Gandhi, wife of Kanu Gandhi
('93', 47, 0, 1, 97151) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 47, 1, 2, 97192) safety of the returning Hindu refugees.
('93', 47, 1, 3, 97232) I am sorry to have to confess that without some such thing it seems to me difficult to induce them to return to their villages.
('93', 47, 1, 4, 97360) From all accounts received by me, life is not as yet smooth and safe for the minority community in the villages.
('93', 47, 1, 5, 97473) They, therefore, prefer to live as exiles from their own homes, crops, plantations and surroundings, and live on inadequate and ill balanced doles.
('93', 47, 1, 6, 97621) Many friends from outside Bengal have written to me to allow them to come for peace work but I have strongly dissuaded them from coming.
('93', 47, 1, 7, 97758) I would love to let them come if and when I see light through this impenetrable darkness.
('93', 47, 1, 8, 97848) In the meantime, both Pyarelal and I have decided to suspend all other activities in the shape of correspondence, including the heavy work of the Harijan and the allied weeklies.
('93', 47, 1, 9, 98027) I have asked Shri Kishorelal, Shri Kakasaheb, Shri Vinoba and Shri Narahari Parikh to edit the weeklies jointly and severally.
('93', 47, 1, 10, 98154) Pyarelal and I may, if our work permits, send stra contributions from our respective villages.
('93', 47, 1, 11, 98249) Corresp ondence will be attended to from Sevagram.
('93', 47, 1, 12, 98300) How long this suspense will last is more than I can say.
('93', 47, 1, 13, 98357) This much, however, I can.
('93', 47, 1, 14, 98384) I do not propose to leave East Bengal till I am satisfied that mutual trust has been established between the two communities and the two have resumed the even tenor of their life in their villages.
('93', 47, 1, 15, 98582) Without this there is neither Pakistan nor Hindustan— only slavery awaits India, torn asunder by mutual strife and engrossed in barbarity.
('93', 47, 1, 16, 98721) No one need at present be disturbed about my low diet.
('93', 47, 1, 17, 98776) On receipt of the following wire from Dr. Rajendra Prasad :“Letter received.
('93', 47, 1, 18, 98853) Have already wired quiet.

('93', 47, 1, 20, 98924) Situation satisfactory.
('93', 47, 1, 21, 98948) Most earnestly desire resumption of normal diet.
('93', 47, 1, 22, 98997) Myself going Delhi 19th”, I resumed goat’s milk from yesterday and propose to revert to normal diet as early as the system permits.
('93', 47, 1, 23, 99129) The future is in God’s keeping.
('93', 47, 1, 24, 99161) Harijan, 1 12 1946
('93', 48, 0, 1, 99180) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 49
('93', 48, 1, 2, 99227) 59. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 48, 2, 3, 99258) SRIRAMPUR, November 20, 1946
('93', 48, 3, 4, 99287) Speaking after the prayer at Srirampur to an audience of about a thousand persons, Gandhiji said that he had never imagined he would be able to come and settle down in a devastated village in Noakhali so soon.
('93', 48, 3, 5, 99497) This had become possible through Satish Babu’s efforts.
('93', 48, 3, 6, 99553) He had come here alone, with two companions only.
('93', 48, 3, 7, 99603) One was to act as his interpreter and teach him Bengali, while the other, Shri Parasuram, who was from Malabar, had been brought along because he knew no Bengali and little Hindustani and so could not be set up in a village alone.
('93', 48, 3, 8, 99834) For all practical purposes he had thus come here alone.
('93', 48, 3, 9, 99890) His companions had been left behind at Kazirkhil, and each of them was likewise to choose one village for himself.
('93', 48, 3, 10, 100005) His idea was that every Hindu worker thus sent should be accompanied by a single Mussalman worker, and both of them together should mix with the local people and gradually create an atmosphere in which the refugees would shed their fear and be able to come back and live in peace and friendship once more.
('93', 48, 3, 11, 100311) For a Mussalman worker he depended on Shaheed Saheb and Shamsuddin Saheb.
('93', 48, 3, 12, 100385) But he could not afford to wait until such a worker was available.
('93', 48, 3, 13, 100452) He had, therefore, come here as soon as he found the opportunity.
('93', 48, 3, 14, 100518) It was good that some Mussalmans were present in the meeting and two local Mussalman friends had already invited him to visit their homes.
('93', 48, 3, 15, 100657) They had assured him that they also wanted the Hindus back in the village, but the Hindus were not yet in the proper frame of mind to do so.
('93', 48, 4, 16, 100798) Fear is a thing which he disliked.
('93', 48, 4, 17, 100833) Why should one man be afraid of another man?
('93', 48, 4, 18, 100878) Man should stand in fear of God alone, and then he can shed all other fears.
('93', 48, 4, 19, 100955) Pyarelal had come to the meeting a short while ago.
('93', 48, 4, 20, 101007) On his way, he had met about 150 refugees who were going away from the village with their belongings.
('93', 48, 4, 21, 101109) On enquiry the refugees had told him that they were afraid that when the military and police left there would be fresh trouble.
('93', 48, 4, 22, 101237) Whilst the roads were safe, therefore, they took the opportunity of moving away to some place of safety.
('93', 48, 4, 23, 101342) But the man who is possessed by fear will not find safety anywhere.
('93', 48, 4, 24, 101410) What help can the military or the police give to such a man?
('93', 48, 4, 25, 101471) To depend on military and police aid is to add to one’s helplessness.
('93', 48, 4, 26, 101541) He would therefore like these refugees to develop personal courage so that they would consider it beneath their dignity to fly from fancied danger merely for fear of losing their lives.
('93', 48, 4, 27, 101727) Therefore, the better course for intending refugees would be to derive personal courage from men like him who went to the affected villages, assuming of course that these had the requisite courage.
('93', 48, 5, 28, 101925) But whether he could personally infuse such courage in another man or not he
('93', 48, 6, 29, 102002) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”, which was “prepared from Press messages in newspapers .
('93', 48, 6, 30, 102094) to make handy for the reader Gandhiji’s utterances.
('93', 49, 0, 1, 102146) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 49, 1, 2, 102187) did not know.
('93', 49, 1, 3, 102201) So long he had lived amidst a number of companions.
('93', 49, 1, 4, 102253) But now he had begun to say to himself, “Now is the time.
('93', 49, 1, 5, 102311) If you want to know yourself, go forth alone.” It was therefore that he had come practically alone like this to the present village.
('93', 49, 1, 6, 102444) With unquenchable faith in God he proposed to persevere so as to succeed in disarming all opposition and inspiring confidence.
('93', 49, 2, 7, 102571) He would live here amidst the Muslim villagers, form intimate acquaintance with each family, know their mind, and help them also to know his mind.
('93', 49, 2, 8, 102718) When they thus knew one another intimately, then would perhaps come the time when the atmosphere would change and sweetness prevail in the relations between Hindus and Mussalmans, where sourness was prevailing today.
('93', 49, 2, 9, 102935) Harijan, 5 1 1947
('93', 49, 3, 10, 102953) 60. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('93', 49, 4, 11, 102984) SRIRAMPUR, November 20, 1946
('93', 49, 5, 12, 103013) When I asked him whether he did not feel he was living alone as in jail, Gandhiji said : Yes, but with this difference.,In jail I had willy nilly to live alone.
('93', 49, 5, 13, 103174) Here I have deliberately imposed it on myself.
('93', 49, 5, 14, 103221) There are now two with me and they are too many.
('93', 49, 5, 15, 103270) While Nirmal Babu will be my interpreter, Parasuram will help me in other ways.
('93', 49, 5, 16, 103350) I want to reduce my correspondence to the minimum and I may write for the Harijan if I feel the urge.
('93', 49, 6, 17, 103452) When asked whether he was not putting too great a physical strain on himself, he said : People have been pampering me too much.
('93', 49, 6, 18, 103580) I would not have felt free until I was severely alone.
('93', 49, 7, 19, 103635) Asked how long he proposed to stay in the village, he said that it all depended on how things shaped in the coming days.
('93', 49, 8, 20, 103756) Explaining his programme of activity in the village, Gandhiji said that he had already seen local Muslims and explained the object of his visit.
('93', 49, 8, 21, 103901) He proposed to go every morning to the houses of local Muslims and talk to them in order to ascertain their real views on the present situation.
('93', 49, 8, 22, 104046) He would invite them to attend his prayer meetings and would influence them in every way so as to bring about friendly relations between the two communities.
('93', 49, 8, 23, 104204) The Hindu, 24 4 1946
('93', 49, 9, 24, 104225) 1 The correspondent reported that he saw Gandhiji in the “evening in his new abode in Srirampur, sitting calmly in a half burnt house amidst ruins”.

('93', 50, 4, 6, 104678) 62. NOTE TO PYARELAL 3
('93', 50, 5, 7, 104701) [On or after November 20, 1946] You are not to proceed to your village.
('93', 50, 5, 8, 104773) Those who go to village have to go there with the determination to do or die.
('93', 50, 5, 9, 104851) If they fall ill, they must get well or die there.
('93', 50, 5, 10, 104902) Then alone would their going have any meaning.
('93', 50, 5, 11, 104949) In practice, this means that in case of illness, they must be content to do with home remedies or the therapy of nature’s elements.
('93', 50, 5, 12, 105081) Sushila’s medical services are not supposed to be available to the members of our party.
('93', 50, 5, 13, 105170) Her services are all premortgaged to the village folk of East Bengal.
('93', 50, 5, 14, 105240) She has her work cut out in her village.
('93', 50, 5, 15, 105281) 4 It won’t do to live in the villages like a jinn.
('93', 50, 5, 16, 105332) We must learn to live and move with the proverbial cautiousness and wisdom of a she elephant.
('93', 50, 5, 17, 105426) Then alone shall we have the fitness to live there.
('93', 50, 5, 18, 105478) To live in the villages of Bengal calls for a special knack.
('93', 50, 5, 19, 105539) We have all to cultivate it.
('93', 50, 5, 20, 105568) You and I have to pass that test.
('93', 50, 5, 21, 105602) Come to me when you are well and I shall further explain the meaning of ‘Do or Die’.

('93', 52, 4, 11, 108476) 66. EXTRACT FROM DIARY 3
('93', 52, 5, 12, 108501) SRIRAMPUR, November 21, 1946 Conducted the morning prayer myself with the exception of the Gita chapters.
('93', 52, 5, 13, 108607) After prayer, wrote letters to X, Y and Z. A Maulvi attached to the Howrah mosque (Noakhali) had a talk with me during the morning walk.
('93', 52, 5, 14, 108744) A and B (two Hindu workers) came afterwards and had a long talk.
('93', 52, 5, 15, 108809) 4 Told them that people ought to take their courage in both hands and return to their villages, especially where there is a good Hindu with a good Muslim to give guarantee of safety and protection.
('93', 52, 5, 16, 109007) Massaged the body with my own hands but had to forgo a shave (for lack of time).
('93', 52, 5, 17, 109088) Had curdled milk with vegetable soup for midday meal.
('93', 52, 5, 18, 109142) Some Muslims .
('93', 52, 5, 19, 109157) saw me before the evening prayer; some more followed after the prayer.

('93', 53, 1, 2, 109707) 67. TALK WITH NALINI MITRA AND RASHAMOY SUR 1
('93', 53, 2, 3, 109753) SRIRAMPUR, November 22, 1946
('93', 53, 3, 4, 109782) Gandhiji told them that if Noakhali set any precedent in the transfer of population to other districts in Bengal, other provinces might follow it, and such a policy would be suicidal for the whole country.
('93', 53, 3, 5, 109988) He could never approve of such a scheme.
('93', 53, 3, 6, 110029) He would not advise the people to leave their homes and go away somewhere else.
('93', 53, 3, 7, 110109) The Bengalees were always in the forefront of civilized life in bravery and sacrifice and it was really shocking to find that people would run away in fear giving up their hearths and homes.
('93', 53, 3, 8, 110300) He wanted to see every Hindu family settle down in its own village and face the situation fearlessly and with courage.
('93', 53, 4, 9, 110419) Concluding, Gandhiji told them that the present problem was not the question of Noakhali alone; it was a problem for the whole of Bengal and the whole of India.
('93', 53, 4, 10, 110580) Hindustan Standard, 24 11 1946
('93', 53, 5, 11, 110611) 68. SPEECH AT MEETING OF REPRESENTATIVES OF HINDUS AND MUSLIMS 2
('93', 53, 6, 12, 110676) RAMGUNJ, November 22, 1946
('93', 53, 7, 13, 110703) Consenting to the formation of the Committees, Mahatma Gandhi said that
('93', 53, 8, 14, 110775) 1 The U. P. I. report said: “On behalf of Noakhali Central Relief, Rescue and Rehabilitation Committee, they met Gandhiji during his morning walk to place before him concrete suggestions about the temporary removal of refugees to West Bengal or outside for rehabilitation on a planned scheme.” 2 In Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Pyarelal says: “A conference of about 30 representatives of both the communities and Government spokesmen was held at Ramgunj Dak Bungalow on the evening of November 22, when a plan for the establishment of peace, based on the Bengal Government’s proposals, was finally hammered out, and a nucleus of the Peace Committee for Ramgunj police station was formed.
('93', 53, 8, 15, 111465) The formula adopted was that there should be Peace Committees, with equal number of Hindus and Muslims, for the village, the village union, and the police station.
('93', 53, 8, 16, 111629) The Muslims would be selected by the Hindus and an official would be the chairman.
('93', 53, 8, 17, 111712) The Government would undertake to implement the recommen dations of the Peace Committees.
('93', 53, 8, 18, 111802) The functions of the Peace Committees were defined to be (a) to do intensive propaganda work to restore confidence, (b) to help in constructing shelters for the returning refugees, and in procuring and distributing relief, e.g., food, clothing, etc., (c) to draw up lists of culprits and disturbers of peace, who should be rounded up, and (d) to prepare a list of houses destroyed or damaged during the disturbances.”
('93', 54, 0, 1, 112220) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 55
('93', 54, 1, 2, 112267) the Committees’ decisions should be accepted by the Government if they called themselves a people’s government.
('93', 54, 1, 3, 112379) He again stressed the need for one honest Muslim and one honest Hindu to stand as sureties for the protection of the villagers and these two men must be prepared to die if necessary.
('93', 54, 1, 4, 112562) Even if they died the result would be good, he added.

('93', 54, 7, 29, 113639) 70. MALAVIYAJI 3
('93', 54, 8, 30, 113656) There is a saying in English, “The King is dead, Long Live the King”.
('93', 54, 8, 31, 113726) The same may be said with reference to Malaviyaji.
('93', 54, 8, 32, 113777) Malaviyaji was born for India and lives in the works he did for India.
('93', 54, 8, 33, 113848) They were many.
('93', 54, 8, 34, 113864) They were great works.
('93', 54, 8, 35, 113887) The most magnificent among them is the Hindu Vishva Vidyalaya.
('93', 54, 8, 36, 113950) We erroneously call it the Benares Hindu University.
('93', 54, 8, 37, 114003) For this, not Malaviyaji but his followers are to blame.
('93', 54, 9, 38, 114060) 1 The report said that after three hours’ discussion, the representatives agreed to form and join peace committees.
('93', 54, 9, 39, 114176) 2 Homestead or a cluster of homesteads 3 A translation of this also appeared in Harijan, 8 12 1946.
('93', 55, 0, 1, 114276) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 55, 1, 2, 114317) Malaviyaji was a servant of his servants.
('93', 55, 1, 3, 114359) He let his followers do as they liked.
('93', 55, 1, 4, 114398) I know he was full of such magnanimity.
('93', 55, 1, 5, 114438) He had it to the point of a fault.
('93', 55, 1, 6, 114473) But the saying ‘no blame attaches to the mighty’ applies equally to Malaviyaji.
('93', 55, 1, 7, 114553) He cherished the name Hindu Vishva Vidyalaya.
('93', 55, 1, 8, 114599) The correction is even now due.
('93', 55, 1, 9, 114631) Every stone of this University should reflect Hindu dharma.
('93', 55, 1, 10, 114691) Not a single building should symbolize the materialism of the West, rather, it should stand for spirituality.
('93', 55, 1, 11, 114801) The same should go for the teachers and scholars.
('93', 55, 1, 12, 114851) Is that so today?
('93', 55, 1, 13, 114869) Can it be said that every scholar of the University is a living embodiment of pure religion?
('93', 55, 1, 14, 114962) If not, why not?
('93', 55, 1, 15, 114979) The University will be judged not by the number of its scholars but by the degree to which they exemplify Hindu dharma, however small their number.
('93', 55, 1, 16, 115127) I know the task is an arduous one.
('93', 55, 1, 17, 115162) But this is of essence for the University.
('93', 55, 1, 18, 115205) If this be not so, the University is no thing.
('93', 55, 1, 19, 115252) The duty, therefore, of Malaviyaji’s sons and followers is clear.
('93', 55, 1, 20, 115318) What place does Hinduism occupy in the world today?
('93', 55, 1, 21, 115370) What are its blemishes?
('93', 55, 1, 22, 115394) How can they be removed?
('93', 55, 1, 23, 115419) It is for the devotees of Malaviyaji to answer these questions.
('93', 55, 1, 24, 115483) Malaviyaji has left us his bequest.
('93', 55, 1, 25, 115519) To make it lasting and to develop it would be the right memorial for him.
('93', 55, 1, 26, 115593) Malaviyaji collected a great deal of money for the University, but a great deal still remains to be collected.
('93', 55, 1, 27, 115704) Everyone can make his contribution to this work.
('93', 55, 1, 28, 115753) So much for his outward activity.
('93', 55, 1, 29, 115787) His inner life was of the purest.
('93', 55, 1, 30, 115821) He was an ocean of kindness.
('93', 55, 1, 31, 115850) His knowledge of the Shastras was immense.
('93', 55, 1, 32, 115893) Bhagavata was his most favourite book.
('93', 55, 1, 33, 115932) He was a competent preacher.
('93', 55, 1, 34, 115961) His memory was prodigious.
('93', 55, 1, 35, 115988) His life was clean and simple.
('93', 55, 1, 36, 116019) I leave out his politics and his other manifold activities.
('93', 55, 1, 37, 116079) He whose life was dedicated to selfless service and who was endowed with so many gifts, could not be confined in his activities.
('93', 55, 1, 38, 116208) I have wanted to draw attention only to the most abiding of his works.
('93', 55, 1, 39, 116279) Those who wish to make of the University an institution full of purity, would better study, ponder and follow the ideals of Malaviyaji.
('93', 55, 1, 40, 116415) SRIRAMPUR, November 23, 1946 Harijan Sevak, 8 12 1946
('93', 56, 0, 1, 116469) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 57
('93', 56, 1, 2, 116516) 71. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('93', 56, 2, 3, 116543) SRIRAMPUR, [November 23, 1946] 1
('93', 56, 3, 4, 116576) Beyond feeling still weak 2 and having skin eruptions I am feeling no ill effects of the recent reduction in diet.
('93', 56, 3, 5, 116691) This is the fourth day since I resumed taking milk.
('93', 56, 3, 6, 116743) Dr. Sushila Nayyar thinks that normal diet will remove skin eruptions which, she thinks, are due to lowered vitality, and restoration of normal strength is a matter of days now if I take care of myself otherwise.
('93', 56, 3, 7, 116956) Like the rest of my companions she has gone to a village near by.
('93', 56, 3, 8, 117022) I may add that my work has not suffered and I hope it will not have to suffer for my physical weakness.
('93', 56, 3, 9, 117126) Hindustan Standard, 26 11 1946
('93', 56, 4, 10, 117157) 72. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 56, 5, 11, 117186) CHANDIPUR, November 23, 1946
('93', 56, 6, 12, 117215) Gandhiji said his advice to them was that all must help in the work of the Peace Committee 3 that had been formed and strengthen its hands.
('93', 56, 6, 13, 117355) By staying out of the Committee and carrying on Press propaganda they would not be helping the cause.
('93', 56, 6, 14, 117457) He wanted to tell them his own experience in Champaran.
('93', 56, 6, 15, 117513) As a result of the struggle there, a Commission of Enquiry was appointed.
('93', 56, 6, 16, 117587) He was requested to become a member of the Commission unconditionally.
('93', 56, 6, 17, 117658) He consulted his friends and accepted the offer.
('93', 56, 6, 18, 117707) The result was that the indigo monopoly ended.
('93', 56, 6, 19, 117754) It was probably a century old wrong.
('93', 56, 6, 20, 117791) Seven times the labourers had rebelled before.
('93', 56, 6, 21, 117838) Each time the rebellion was put down ruthlessly, so that their condition was worse than before.
('93', 56, 7, 22, 117934) Similarly, let everyone join the Peace Committee and air his views before it.
('93', 56, 7, 23, 118012) Probably there would be redress of every legitimate grievance.
('93', 56, 8, 24, 118075) They had heard the speeches of Minister Shamsuddin Saheb, Parliamentary Secretary Hamiduddin Saheb and others.
('93', 56, 8, 25, 118186) They had requested the refugees to return to
('93', 56, 9, 26, 118231) 1 According to the report, Gandhiji made the statement “prior to departure to Chandipur” on this date.
('93', 56, 10, 27, 118334) 2 A report said that Gandhiji had had an attack of diarrhoea and vomiting while going by boat to Chandipur.
('93', 56, 10, 28, 118442) 3 Vide “Extract from Diary”, 22 11 1946. For a more detailed report of Gandhiji’s views on the subject, Vide “Talk with Hindu Workers”, 21 11 1946
('93', 57, 0, 1, 118589) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 57, 1, 2, 118630) their villages and had assured them that they would guarantee their safety and honour.
('93', 57, 1, 3, 118717) They should accept their assurance.
('93', 57, 2, 4, 118753) They might say all this was mere talk.
('93', 57, 2, 5, 118792) They had been deceived before.
('93', 57, 2, 6, 118823) It was beneath one’s dignity to distrust a man’s word without sufficient ground.
('93', 57, 2, 7, 118904) If all Muslims were liars, Islam could not be a true religion.
('93', 57, 2, 8, 118967) But his knowledge of history contradicted such a theory.
('93', 57, 2, 9, 119024) A false thing could not last long in this world.
('93', 57, 3, 10, 119073) Islam spread amongst crores of people all over the world.
('93', 57, 3, 11, 119131) It spread mostly because of its own intrinsic merits.
('93', 57, 3, 12, 119185) Here were elected Muslims who were running the Government of the Province who gave them their word of honour.
('93', 57, 3, 13, 119295) His advice to Hindus was to believe their word and give them a trial.
('93', 57, 3, 14, 119365) This did not mean that there would not be a single bad Mussalman left in East Bengal.
('93', 57, 3, 15, 119451) There were good and bad men amongst all communities.
('93', 57, 3, 16, 119504) Dishonourable conduct would break any ministry or organization in the end.
('93', 57, 3, 17, 119579) Shamsuddin Saheb had told them plainly that Pakistan could not be achieved by cruel deeds.
('93', 57, 3, 18, 119670) It was clear to him as daylight that if they kept quarrelling amongst themselves, a third power was bound to rule over them.
('93', 57, 3, 19, 119795) Whether it was British or Allied Powers, it made no difference.
('93', 57, 3, 20, 119859) They would remain slaves.
('93', 57, 4, 21, 119885) There was a time when Hindus and Muslims had been united.
('93', 57, 4, 22, 119943) There was the pact of unity between the League and the Congress in 1916. Whether it was good or bad was not the question.
('93', 57, 4, 23, 120065) He was a newcomer in India at that time and hardly knew anybody or affairs in this country.
('93', 57, 4, 24, 120157) Then came the Khilafat Movement and there was a communal unity that had never been seen before that.
('93', 57, 4, 25, 120258) Today Hindus were frightened when they heard the cries of “Allah o Akbar”.
('93', 57, 4, 26, 120333) In those days, these were the slogans repeated at all meetings: “Vande mataram”, “Allah o Akbar” and “Sat Sri Akal”.
('93', 57, 4, 27, 120450) Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs in their thousands shouted these slogans with one voice.
('93', 57, 4, 28, 120533) They were the same people today.
('93', 57, 4, 29, 120566) Those who were youngsters in those days were grown up men today.
('93', 57, 4, 30, 120631) Why could not they live together as friends now?
('93', 57, 4, 31, 120680) Gandhiji was not prepared to admit that bitterness had gone so deep that it could not be overcome.
('93', 57, 5, 32, 120779) The Peace Committee could not function without their help.
('93', 57, 5, 33, 120838) If they wanted real peace there was no other way except to have mutual trust and confidence.
('93', 57, 5, 34, 120931) Bihar, they said, had avenged Noakhali.
('93', 57, 5, 35, 120971) Supposing Muslims in East Bengal or Muslims all over India made up their minds to avenge Bihar, where would India be?
('93', 57, 6, 36, 121089) Gandhiji said that where houses had been burnt and destroyed, Government was, he understood, raising new ones.
('93', 57, 6, 37, 121200) If there were any difficulties or they were harassed in any way after they returned to their villages, they should place their complaints before the Peace Committee.
('93', 57, 7, 38, 121366) The speaker referred to a letter that had been handed to him during the meeting.
('93', 57, 7, 39, 121447) It was said that in Chandipur the damage amounted to a crore of rupees and it should be compensated.
('93', 57, 7, 40, 121548) He did not know whether it was a crore or a lakh.
('93', 57, 7, 41, 121598) But the Government
('93', 58, 0, 1, 121617) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 59
('93', 58, 1, 2, 121664) was bound to do what it could in such matters.
('93', 58, 2, 3, 121711) Then it was said in the letter that the Chief Minister’s speeches breathed fire.
('93', 58, 2, 4, 121792) God alone knew the hearts of men.
('93', 58, 2, 5, 121826) He could not say whether Suhrawardy Saheb was a good man or a bad one.
('93', 58, 2, 6, 121897) But he knew that he was elected by the voters.
('93', 58, 2, 7, 121944) Hindus and Muslims had to live under his Government just as those in Bihar had to live under the rule of the Congress Government.
('93', 58, 2, 8, 122074) If people did not like a particular Government the electorate could change it.
('93', 58, 2, 9, 122153) But it was not in his power to do so.
('93', 58, 3, 10, 122191) The letter further said that the Superintendent of Police was a bad man and should be sent away from Noakhali.
('93', 58, 3, 11, 122302) Again, he did not know whether the Police Superintendent was a good man or bad.
('93', 58, 3, 12, 122382) But he had the confidence of his chief.
('93', 58, 3, 13, 122422) Gandhiji himself had come into contact with him fairly frequently during the last few days and he felt that the Superintendent would deny those charges if they were false, and express regret for his mistake if they were true.
('93', 58, 3, 14, 122648) But he wanted to tell them this.
('93', 58, 3, 15, 122681) If he was bad, it was so because the people of Noakhali were bad.
('93', 58, 3, 16, 122747) There were very few men who remained good in the midst of bad people.
('93', 58, 3, 17, 122817) All those in the Congress were not angels.
('93', 58, 4, 18, 122860) Then there was a request that the military must stay on.
('93', 58, 4, 19, 122917) According to the present constitution, the military had to act under the orders of the Ministers.
('93', 58, 4, 20, 123015) That was democracy.
('93', 58, 4, 21, 123035) When the Ministers themselves were offering to become their soldiers, why should they ask for the military?
('93', 58, 4, 22, 123143) After all, if the worst came to the worst they could only lose their lives.
('93', 58, 4, 23, 123219) They must do so as brave men and women.
('93', 58, 4, 24, 123259) By running away from East Bengal they would become the worst cowards.
('93', 58, 4, 25, 123329) He could never wish that for anybody.
('93', 58, 5, 26, 123367) If all Hindus were bad, Hinduism must be bad.
('93', 58, 5, 27, 123413) If all Muslims were bad, Islam must be bad.
('93', 58, 5, 28, 123457) But neither Hinduism nor Islam was bad.
('93', 58, 5, 29, 123497) Christ had said that he alone was His disciple who did His work, not he who merely called him ‘Lord, Lord’.
('93', 58, 5, 30, 123605) That applied to all religions.
('93', 58, 6, 31, 123636) If Shamsuddin Saheb and his companions did not mean what they said they would know.
('93', 58, 6, 32, 123720) Gandhiji for one did not wish to be a living witness of such a tragedy.
('93', 58, 6, 33, 123792) The Hindu, 28 11 1946

('93', 59, 7, 28, 125292) 75. FOREWORD TO “SATYAGRAHA WA SWARAJYA” Appasaheb Patwardhan 4 is one of my few co workers who have thought over my views in an independent way.
('93', 59, 7, 29, 125438) I have known him for the last several years.
('93', 59, 7, 30, 125483) His thought is reflected in his behaviour.
('93', 59, 7, 31, 125526) That is why his articles have a great impact.
('93', 59, 7, 32, 125572) I have gone through this book, but not thoroughly.

('93', 61, 7, 13, 127472) SRIRAMPUR, [November 24, 1946] 3
('93', 61, 8, 14, 127505) Gandhiji agreed that the leaders had sunk to the lowest level, but not the common people.
('93', 61, 8, 15, 127595) Their hearts were still sound.
('93', 61, 8, 16, 127626) He added : Even in this village I have noticed some response.
('93', 61, 8, 17, 127688) But, of course, I do not build upon it.
('93', 61, 9, 18, 127728) BOSE: We believe your attempt is to raise humanity from the lowest level.
('93', 61, 9, 19, 127802) But we are sceptical as to whether you will succeed.
('93', 61, 10, 20, 127855) GANDHIJI: I myself am sceptical about it.
('93', 61, 10, 21, 127897) I may succeed, I can perish in the attempt.
('93', 61, 10, 22, 127941) Success or failure is not the final test.
