('93', 62, 1, 4, 128838) But as for the change of heart, it is for you and me to make a contribution to that consummation.
('93', 62, 2, 5, 128936) The interviewer remarked that it was painful to see how listless the Hindus had become.
('93', 62, 2, 6, 129024) Gandhiji replied : It is no prerogative of the Hindus.
('93', 62, 2, 7, 129079) Listlessness is common to us all.
('93', 62, 2, 8, 129113) Even if I am the only one, I shall fight this listlessness that has come over the Hindus of East Bengal.
('93', 62, 2, 9, 129218) I have not come here to do a good turn to this community or that.
('93', 62, 2, 10, 129284) I have come to do a good turn to myself.
('93', 62, 2, 11, 129325) Non violence is not meant to be practised by the individual only.
('93', 62, 2, 12, 129391) It can be and has to be practised by society as a whole.
('93', 62, 2, 13, 129448) I have come to test that for myself in Noakhali.
('93', 62, 2, 14, 129497) Has my ahimsa become bankrupt?
('93', 62, 2, 15, 129528) If I fail here, it won’t be any proof that the theory is wrong.
('93', 62, 2, 16, 129592) It will simply mean that my sadhana has been imperfect, that there is some fault somewhere in my technique.
('93', 62, 3, 17, 129700) B. If the League leaders were to take the Noakhali situation as seriously as you and Jawaharlal took Bihar, order would be restored in a day.
('93', 62, 3, 18, 129842) To make such comparisons is to degrade oneself.
('93', 62, 3, 19, 129890) What is called for is introspection and more introspection.
('93', 62, 3, 20, 129950) I have come here not only to speak to the Mussalmans but to the Hindus as well.
('93', 62, 3, 21, 130030) Why are they such cowards?
('93', 62, 3, 22, 130057) The Harijans, the Namashudras, have been relatively better so far as courage and physical prowess is concerned.
('93', 62, 3, 23, 130169) They are brave.
('93', 62, 3, 24, 130185) But the other Hindus must shed utterly the caste distinctions.
('93', 62, 3, 25, 130248) If this calamity would open the eyes of the Hindus and result in eradicating untouchability root and branch, it will have served a good purpose.
('93', 62, 4, 26, 130393) Narrating his earlier experiences in India he recalled how during the Champaran Satyagraha, in Rajendra Babu’s absence, he could only sit in the outhouse in Rajendra Babu’s house and how Rajendra Babu’s servant would not let the speaker bathe at the well.
('93', 62, 4, 27, 130649) Things had improved, but much more remained to be done.
('93', 62, 5, 28, 130705) The visitor agreed that Hinduism had still to go a long way to eradicate the evil.
('93', 62, 5, 29, 130788) Talking of forced conversions in Noakhali, the interviewer remarked that unless those who had been converted were brought back to the Hindu fold quickly, the cleavage between the Hindus and the Muslims might become permanent.
('93', 62, 6, 30, 131014) G. Many had returned.
('93', 62, 6, 31, 131036) But all must.
('93', 62, 7, 32, 131050) The question was put to him whether by taking up an unbending attitude on conversion, he was not identifying himself with one particular community.
('93', 63, 0, 1, 131198) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 63, 1, 2, 131239) could his stand in this respect be squared with his claim that he regarded all religions as equal?
('93', 63, 2, 3, 131338) G. I have, of course, always believed in the principle of religious tolerance.
('93', 63, 2, 4, 131417) But I have even gone further.
('93', 63, 2, 5, 131447) I have advanced from tolerance to equal respect for all religions.
('93', 63, 2, 6, 131514) All religions are branches of the same mighty tree, but I must not change over from one branch to another for the sake of expediency.
('93', 63, 2, 7, 131648) By doing so, I cut the branch on which I am sitting.
('93', 63, 2, 8, 131701) Therefore, I always feel the change over from one religion to another very keenly, unless it is a case of spontaneous urge, a result of inner growth.
('93', 63, 2, 9, 131851) Such conversions by their very nature cannot be on a mass scale and never to save one’s life or property or for temporal gain.
('93', 63, 3, 10, 131978) He narrated his meeting with a South Indian Bishop who was a Harijan converted to Christianity and retained all his original weakness in spite of the change of religion.
('93', 63, 3, 11, 132148) He had told the late Charlie Andrews that to his mind he was no bishop at all.
('93', 63, 4, 12, 132227) B. There is no end to the monstrosities that have been committed here and that too in the name of religion.
('93', 63, 4, 13, 132335) It is enough to fill one with blank despair.
('93', 63, 5, 14, 132380) G. I have met human monsters from my early youth.
('93', 63, 5, 15, 132430) I have found that even they are not beyond redemption if we know how to touch the right chord in their soul.
('93', 63, 6, 16, 132539) And he cited two instances within his recent experience of the milk of human kindness welling up in hard boiled, sun baked functionaries at the sight of stark human misery and devastation.
('93', 63, 7, 17, 132728) G. The whole thing is so ghastly.
('93', 63, 7, 18, 132762) You do not need to exa ggerate it.
('93', 63, 7, 19, 132797) I have told the authorities I do not care for numbers.
('93', 63, 7, 20, 132852) Has a single case of abduction, rape, forcible marriage, or forcible conver sion occurred?
('93', 63, 7, 21, 132943) If so, it is enough for me.
('93', 63, 7, 22, 132971) It is admitted that such things have happened.
('93', 63, 8, 23, 133018) B. What about the rescue of abducted women?
('93', 63, 8, 24, 133062) It was complained that as soon as information was received about such cases and the rescue party with the military police set out on their assignment, the miscreants received intimation and removed the victim to some other place.
('93', 63, 9, 25, 133292) G. I have told our people :‘Do not depend on military and the police help.’ You have to uphold democracy, and democracy and dependence on the military and the police are incompatible.
('93', 63, 9, 26, 133476) You cannot say it is good in one place and bad in another.
('93', 63, 9, 27, 133535) Military help

('93', 64, 3, 16, 134877) It does not permit interference with provincial autonomy.
('93', 64, 3, 17, 134935) But in Bihar, Pandit Nehru and Rajendra Babu have a standing and responsibility as Congressmen.

('93', 64, 5, 19, 135131) Bengal is in the forefront today because Bengal is Bengal.

('93', 64, 5, 21, 135244) It was here that the heroes of the Chittagong Armoury Raid were born, however misguided their action might have been in my eyes.
('93', 64, 5, 22, 135373) No, you must understand it.
('93', 64, 5, 23, 135401) If Bengal plays the game, it will solve all India’s problem.
('93', 64, 5, 24, 135462) That is why I have made myself a Bengali.
('93', 64, 5, 25, 135504) 3 I have seen enough of ravages in Noakhali to make me weep my eyes out but I am not going to shed a tear for what has happened.

('93', 68, 8, 15, 143503) 84. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA November 26, 1946
('93', 68, 9, 16, 143547) GHANSHYAMDAS, You know I am staying at Srirampur all by myself, with only Prof.
('93', 68, 9, 17, 143627) Nirmal Kumar 1 Bose and Parasuram as my companions.
('93', 68, 9, 18, 143679) The people with whom I am putting up are gentlemen.
('93', 68, 9, 19, 143731) There is only one Hindu family in the entire village, the rest are all Muslims.
('93', 68, 9, 20, 143811) They all stay widely separated from each other.
('93', 68, 9, 21, 143859) The hundreds of villages here do not maintain much contact with each other through any convey ance after the water dries up.
('93', 68, 9, 22, 143984) The result is that work is possible only on foot.
('93', 68, 9, 23, 144034) Therefore, only desperadoes, hooligans, or able bodied men can maintain contact among themselves.
('93', 68, 9, 24, 144132) I am living in one such village at present and intend to spend more time in another village similar to this.
('93', 68, 9, 25, 144241) It is my intention to stay on here so long as the Hindus and Muslims do not start living together as sincere friends.
('93', 68, 9, 26, 144359) God alone

('93', 70, 5, 11, 147169) 86. INTERVIEW TO MEMBERS OF COMMUNIST PARTY AND STUDENTS’ FEDERATION 1
('93', 70, 6, 12, 147240) November 26, 1946
('93', 70, 7, 13, 147258) Gandhiji stated that he was personally cast in a different mould; when he had no confidence in a particular step, he never took it.
('93', 70, 7, 14, 147390) Under the present circumstances, he did not think that the step suggested by the friends would be of any use.
('93', 70, 7, 15, 147500) Personally, he was trying to have everything done through the Ministry.
('93', 70, 7, 16, 147572) He had also undertaken a programme here all by himself and this was without the co operation of the tallest in Bengal.
('93', 70, 7, 17, 147691) The Hindu population in Bengal could co operate by utterly forgetting caste, not as mere lip profession but in actual practice.
('93', 70, 7, 18, 147819) They had also to purge themselves of all fear.
('93', 70, 7, 19, 147866) For, it is only when a man’s heart is freed from fear that the flower of religion can find a place in it.
('93', 70, 7, 20, 147972) Finally he added : I do not want to retire from Bengal as a defeated coward.
('93', 70, 7, 21, 148049) I would like to die here, if need be, at the hands of an assassin.
('93', 70, 7, 22, 148116) But I do not want to court such death.
('93', 70, 8, 23, 148155) My Days with Gandhi, p.

('93', 71, 1, 2, 148819) 87. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 71, 2, 3, 148848) SRIRAMPUR, November 26, 1946
('93', 71, 3, 4, 148877) Gandhiji said that even if a solitary refugee had to return to his village populated by Muslims, he would unhesitatingly advise his return.
('93', 71, 3, 5, 149017) Whe ther they were men or women, if they were to become brave people, this cour age was indispensable.
('93', 71, 3, 6, 149120) Numerous letters had been coming to him in which people had questioned the wisdom of thus tempting faith, but he held that this was necessary if they were to become a self respecting nation.
('93', 71, 3, 7, 149311) He made no distinction between men and women.
('93', 71, 3, 8, 149357) The latter should feel just as independent as men.
('93', 71, 3, 9, 149408) Bravery was not man’s monopoly.
('93', 71, 3, 10, 149440) The art of self defence excluded all outside help.
('93', 71, 3, 11, 149491) What he saw and heard showed him that people were apt to forget self respect in order to save themselves.
('93', 71, 3, 12, 149597) There was no swadesh and swaraj for persons who would not sacrifice themselves or their belongings for their honour.
('93', 71, 3, 13, 149714) As his hearers knew, the Ministers and the Parliamentary Secretaries, who had come to Noakhali, had been proclaiming that for the sake of their honour and the influence of Islam, they were anxious that the refugees should return to their villages and feel perfectly safe and serene in the midst of the majority of Muslims living there.
('93', 71, 3, 14, 150050) The speaker had no hesitation in trusting their pledged word and asking the people to do likewise.
('93', 71, 3, 15, 150149) Those who trusted were never the losers; deceivers ever were.
('93', 71, 3, 16, 150211) There was no room for goondaism in any religion worth the name, be it Islam, Hinduism or any other.
('93', 71, 3, 17, 150311) He was trying to become a Bengali in order that if God gave him strength, he might try to live the life in the midst of the people of East Bengal and induce them to do likewise.
('93', 71, 3, 18, 150489) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 73, 6, 15, 153770) 91. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('93', 73, 7, 16, 153797) SRIRAMPUR, November 27, 1946
('93', 73, 8, 17, 153826) QUESTION: How do you think lasting peace can be achieved by your new plan, unless the Muslim League itself which presumably guides the majority of the Muslim intelligentsia, sincerely co operates in creating such atmosphere by their words and deeds?
('93', 73, 9, 18, 154076) GANDHIJI: My new plan does contemplate the necessity for a lasting peace and sincere co operation of the Muslim League in establishing friendly relations between the two communities, irrespec tive of the merits or otherwise of Pakistan.
('93', 73, 10, 19, 154313) Asked as to what was the guarantee that some months later this sort of calamity would not be repeated in places like Noakhali, where Hindus were in a minority, Gandhiji said : The only real guarantee is to be sought in the personal courage of individuals.
('93', 73, 10, 20, 154569) Everything else depends on it.
('93', 73, 11, 21, 154600) The next question asked was whether he should not advise people in those areas where one or two houses were Hindu and the rest Muslim, to migrate to areas inside a district where the Hindus were in comparatively larger numbers, so that in case of emergencies they could put up some sort of resistance if they did not believe in non violence.
('93', 73, 11, 22, 154942) Gandhiji’s reply was:
('93', 73, 12, 23, 154964) 1 Minister for Development and Transport, Government of Bihar
('93', 74, 0, 1, 155026) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 75
('93', 74, 1, 2, 155073) There is no such safety as you imagine in numbers in imagined conditions.
('93', 74, 1, 3, 155147) Migration is no remedy whilst there is hope of co operation.
('93', 74, 1, 4, 155208) It will become a necessity when the majority party wishes it, if a clash is to be avoided.
('93', 74, 1, 5, 155299) All this is a matter of mutual adjustment, not arbitrary action.
('93', 74, 1, 6, 155364) What is needed is that barbarities must cease, if we are to survive as one nation or two, or many free nations still living in friendly co operation.

('93', 75, 1, 2, 156655) 94. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 75, 2, 3, 156684) SRIRAMPUR, November 28, 1946
('93', 75, 3, 4, 156713) Gandhiji related the story of how the Ashram prayer had taken its present shape.
('93', 75, 3, 5, 156794) When he came to India in 1915, Gurudev invited him through the late Deenabandhu Andrews to stay at Santiniketan along with the inmates of the Phoenix Settlement.
('93', 75, 3, 6, 156956) Kaka Saheb and Harihar Sharma were there and so were the late Deenabandhu Andrews and Pearson.
('93', 75, 3, 7, 157051) These friends had created a sort of South African group at the place.
('93', 75, 3, 8, 157121) The prayer which was recited at that early time by the small group practically continues to this day so far as the Sanskrit part is concerned.
('93', 75, 4, 9, 157264) While on his Harijan tour in Travancore, he added the first Hindu verse of the Ishopanishad to it, as, in his opinion, it contained the cream of spiritual thought.
('93', 75, 4, 10, 157428) Later on, Raihana Tyabjee, daughter of the late Abbas Tyabjee, who is noted for her musical talents, proposed the incorporation of a passage from the Koran, and this was done.
('93', 75, 4, 11, 157604) Lastly, on Kasturba’s death 1 at the Aga Khan Palace, Dr. Gilder 2 had recited a passage from the Zoroastrian scripture.
('93', 75, 4, 12, 157725) Since then that prayer has been a part of the Ashram prayer.
('93', 75, 4, 13, 157786) In addition there was a bhajan in an Indian language or an English hymn and Ramdhun.
('93', 75, 5, 14, 157871) The prayer which has thus taken shape can, on no account, be considered as belonging to any single community or religion.
('93', 75, 5, 15, 157993) It is of universal appeal; and no one, whatever his denomination may be, should have hesitation in sharing it.
('93', 75, 5, 16, 158104) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 78, 9, 16, 162449) 101. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 3
('93', 78, 10, 17, 162481) SRIRAMPUR, November 29, 1946
('93', 78, 11, 18, 162510) Gandhiji explained to the audience the object of his visit which he said was not to cause the ill feeling between the two communities go deeper, but to cement their fellow feeling so that Hindus and Muslims could live as brothers as before.

A SIGN OF PROGRESS Though I have noticed it in the Gujarati columns of the Harijanbandhu from a different source, at the risk of repetition in another form, I must quote 1 from a touching letter from Shri Parikshitlal Majumdar addressed to Shyamlalji 2, a copy of which has been sent by the latter.
('93', 79, 8, 13, 163974) I am writing this from Bardoli .
('93', 79, 8, 14, 164007) This year, during the Gandhi Jayanti week, nearly 40 public wells have been freely opened for the Harijans.
('93', 79, 8, 15, 164115) People have taken to this programme of their own will .
('93', 79, 8, 16, 164171) local people have invited Harijans and taken them to the public wells.
('93', 79, 8, 17, 164242) I myself have attended some functions and personally have become a witness to the marvellous change.
('93', 79, 8, 18, 164343) No doubt, it is Gandhiji’s efforts and the recent writings that have brought this change.
('93', 79, 8, 19, 164433) Numerous inter communal dinners have been held.
('93', 79, 8, 20, 164481) There was one such big dinner at Nadiad, the real capital of the Kaira District.
('93', 79, 8, 21, 164562) One prominent well has been opened in Kadi, a citadel of orthodoxy and 150 people dined with Harijans at Padra in Baroda.
('93', 79, 8, 22, 164684) There are numerous such incidents but I cannot enumerate them at present.
('93', 79, 8, 23, 164758) Of course, compared to what we want to achieve, this pro gress is a miserable show.
('93', 79, 8, 24, 164842) But seeing that Gujarat has been so far behindhand in this matter of removal of untouchability, the little progress of which Shri Parikshitlal takes note with pardonable
('93', 79, 9, 25, 165012) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('93', 79, 9, 26, 165049) 2 Secretary of Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund, Sevagram
('93', 80, 0, 1, 165113) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 81
('93', 80, 1, 2, 165160) satisfaction is pleasant, if it is permanent and is a precursor of better things to come.
('93', 80, 1, 3, 165250) Every nail driven into the coffin of untouchability is a step in the right direction towards the purification of Hinduism.
('93', 80, 1, 4, 165373) SRIRAMPUR, November 30, 1946 Harijan, 15 12 1946

('93', 81, 3, 12, 167788) 106. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SRIRAMPUR, November 30, 1946
('93', 81, 4, 13, 167847) Gandhiji explained the meaning of the first mantra recited in the Ashram prayer: Namyo Horenge Kyo.
('93', 81, 4, 14, 167947) Its purport is, “Salutation to the Enlightened Ones.” A Japanese Buddhist monk 1 who had happened to stay in Sevagram for two or three years was responsible for its introduction.
('93', 81, 4, 15, 168126) He had come to India with the object of mastering the secrets of the religion which had its origin in India.
('93', 81, 4, 16, 168235) The monk had a sweet nature and had endeared himself to every member of the Sevagram Ashram by unostentatiousness, affableness and silence.
('93', 81, 4, 17, 168375) Every morning he used to walk round the Ashram grounds for full one hour, while beating upon a drum and reciting the above mantra in a deep musical voice which sent a thrill into all those who heard him.
('93', 81, 4, 18, 168579) He used to recite it at the prayer meeting.
('93', 81, 4, 19, 168623) The recitation continued even after he was removed by the Government after hostilities with Japan began.
('93', 81, 4, 20, 168728) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 90, 1, 2, 181848) 122. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('93', 90, 2, 3, 181878) SRIRAMPUR, [December 2, 1946] 2
('93', 90, 3, 4, 181910) The question of the exchange of population is unthinkable and impracticable.
('93', 90, 3, 5, 181987) This question never crossed my mind.
('93', 90, 3, 6, 182024) In every province, everyone is an Indian, be he a Hindu, a Muslim or of any other faith.
('93', 90, 3, 7, 182113) It would not be otherwise even if Pakistan came in full.
('93', 90, 3, 8, 182170) For me any such thing will spell bankruptcy of Indian wisdom or statesmanship or both.
('93', 90, 3, 9, 182257) The logical consequence of any such step is too dreadful to contemplate.
('93', 90, 3, 10, 182330) Is it not that India should be artificially divided into so many religious zones?
('93', 90, 4, 11, 182412) When asked if, in view of the unsettled situation, it was not better to adopt a migration policy, Gandhiji said : I see nothing to warrant such a policy.
('93', 90, 4, 12, 182566) It is one of despair and, therefore, to be adopted in rare cases as a last resort.
('93', 90, 5, 13, 182649) QUESTION: You said the other day that there was no limit to your stay in East Bengal.
('93', 90, 5, 14, 182735) Do you think that by confining yourself to Srirampur you will be able to send your message of peace to other villages of Noakhali?
('93', 90, 5, 15, 182866) GANDHIJI: Of course, I am not burying myself long in Sriram pur.
('93', 90, 5, 16, 182931) I am not idle here.
('93', 90, 5, 17, 182951) I am seeing people of the surrounding villages and others.
('93', 90, 5, 18, 183010) I am studying things and regaining lost physical strength meanwhile.
('93', 90, 5, 19, 183079) The idea ultimately is to go on foot, when possible and necessary, from village to village and induce the evacuees to return.
('93', 90, 5, 20, 183205) This I can only do with effect when I have seen things myself.
('93', 90, 5, 21, 183268) It is quite clear to me that my mere word carries very little weight.
('93', 90, 5, 22, 183338) Distrust has gone too deep for exhortation.
('93', 90, 6, 23, 183382) Gandhiji was next asked regarding the report that he found himself in darkness, and why and when the darkness came over him and whether he saw any release from it.
('93', 90, 6, 24, 183546) Gandhiji said : I am afraid the report is substantial.
('93', 90, 6, 25, 183601) Outside circumstances have never overwhelmed me.The reason for the present daness lies within me.
('93', 90, 6, 26, 183699) I find that my ahimsa does not seem to answer in the matter of Hindu Muslim relations.
('93', 90, 6, 27, 183786) This struck me forcibly when I came to learn of the events in Noakhali.
('93', 90, 7, 28, 183858) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary” 2Hindustan Standard, 4 12 1946, reported the interview under the dateline “Srirampur, December 2”.
('93', 91, 0, 1, 183992) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 91, 1, 2, 184033) The reported forcible conversions and the distress of the Bengali sisters touched me deeply.
('93', 91, 1, 3, 184126) I could do nothing through pen or speech.
('93', 91, 1, 4, 184168) I argued to myself that I must be on the scene of action and test the soundness of the doctrine which has sustained me and made life worth living.
('93', 91, 1, 5, 184315) Was it the weapon of the weak as it was often held by my critics or was it truly the weapon of the strong?
('93', 91, 1, 6, 184422) The question arose in me when I had no ready made solution for the distemper of which Noakhali was such a glaring symptom.
('93', 91, 1, 7, 184545) And so setting aside all my activities, I hastened to Noakhali to find out where I stood.
('93', 91, 1, 8, 184635) I know positively that ahimsa is a perfect instrument.
('93', 91, 1, 9, 184690) If it did not answer in my hands, the imperfection was in me.
('93', 91, 1, 10, 184752) My technique was at fault.
('93', 91, 1, 11, 184779) I could not discover the error from a distance.
('93', 91, 1, 12, 184827) Hence I came here trying to make the discovery.
('93', 91, 1, 13, 184875) I must, therefore, own myself in darkness till I see light.
('93', 91, 1, 14, 184935) God only knows when it will come.
('93', 91, 1, 15, 184969) More I cannot say.
('93', 91, 1, 16, 184988) Harijan, 19 1 1947
('93', 91, 2, 17, 185007) 123. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 91, 3, 18, 185039) SRIRAMPUR, December 2, 1946
('93', 91, 4, 19, 185067) Speaking after prayer, Gandhiji chose as his theme the story referred to in the bhajan which had just been sung.
('93', 91, 4, 20, 185180) The chief of the elephants had gone for a drink to the river when he was caught hold of by an alligator.
('93', 91, 4, 21, 185285) A furious struggle ensued, but in spite of his strength, the elephant was dragged into deeper waters.
('93', 91, 4, 22, 185387) When he was on the point of being drowned, the elephant realized that his huge strength was of no avail, and he prayed to God for succour.
('93', 91, 4, 23, 185526) God, the help of the helpless, came to his rescue and saved him from the jaws of death.
('93', 91, 4, 24, 185614) The moral was obvious.
('93', 91, 4, 25, 185637) The strength of the strong without God’s help had been often found to be useless.
('93', 91, 4, 26, 185719) Therefore, he advised dependence not on outside sources but upon the inner strength which came to all who sincerely sought it from God.
('93', 91, 4, 27, 185855) This was the lesson which the people in Noakhali sorely needed to learn.
('93', 91, 4, 28, 185928) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 92, 1, 2, 186196) 125. NOTE ON THE CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY 1
('93', 92, 2, 3, 186236) SRIRAMPUR, NOAKHALI, December 3, 1946 I am quite clear that if there is a boycott by the Muslim League of the Constituent Assembly, 2it should not meet under the Cabinet Mission’s statement 3 of May 16. It clearly contemplates the co operation of the two major parties, viz., the Congress and the League.
('93', 92, 2, 4, 186541) Therefore, if one of them proclaims a boycott, the Consti tuent Assembly cannot with propriety meet under that Paper.
('93', 92, 2, 5, 186659) If the Government convene the Constituent Assembly in spite of the boycott, they can legitimately do so only under some other statement which they can draw up in consultation with the Congress.
('93', 92, 2, 6, 186853) It should never be forgotten that however powerful the Congress has become, Constituent Assembly as contemplated today can only meet by action of the British Government.
('93', 92, 2, 7, 187023) 2. Even if the Constituent Assembly meets in spite of the boycott, but with the willing co operation of the British Gover nment, it will be under the visible or invisible protection of the British forces, whether Indian or European.
('93', 92, 2, 8, 187256) In my opinion, 94 we shall never reach a satisfactory constitution under these circumstances.
('93', 92, 2, 9, 187350) Whether we own it or not, our weakness will be felt by the whole world.
('93', 92, 2, 10, 187422) 3. It may be said that not to meet as a Constituent Assembly under these circumstances will amount to a surrender to Qaid e Azam Jinnah or the Muslim League.
('93', 92, 2, 11, 187580) I do not mind the charge because the waiver will not be an act of weakness, it will be one of Congress strength because it would be due to the logic of facts.
('93', 92, 2, 12, 187739) If we have attained a certain degree of status and strength to warrant us in
('93', 92, 3, 13, 187816) 1 In My Days with Gandhi, N. K. Bose explains that Gandhiji dictated this in the afternoon for the Working Committee.
('93', 92, 3, 14, 187934) 2 The Muslim League had refused to attend the Constituent Assembly unless the Congress gave up its reservations on the question of grouping.
('93', 92, 3, 15, 188075) The British Government, in an attempt to bring about a compromise, invited the leaders of the two parties to London for negotiations from December 3 to 6. No headway was made.
('93', 92, 3, 16, 188251) For the British Cabinet’s statement dated December 6, vide “British Cabinet’s Statement on Grouping”,6 12 1946 3 Vide “Statement of Cabinet Delegation and Viceroy”, 16 5 1946
('93', 93, 0, 1, 188426) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 93, 1, 2, 188467) convening our own Constituent Assembly irrespective of the British Government, it will be a proper thing.
('93', 93, 1, 3, 188573) We will have then to seek the co operation of the Muslim League and all the parties including the Princes, and the Constituent Assembly can meet at a favourable place even if some do not join.
('93', 93, 1, 4, 188766) Thus it may be only the Congress Provinces plus Princes who may care to join.
('93', 93, 1, 5, 188844) I think this would be dignified and wholly consistent with facts.
('93', 93, 2, 6, 188910) From a photostat: C. W. 10535. Courtesy: N. K. Bose.

('93', 93, 3, 8, 188979) 126. EXTRACTS FROM LETTER TO H. S. SUHRAWARDY December 3, 1946 Having waited some time for the return of Shamsuddin Saheb as he had led me to expect, I write this to you and that in English in order the better to enable you to deal with the matter referred to herein.
('93', 93, 3, 9, 189247) 1. Somehow or other the Committees that were being formed do not appear to be functioning properly.
('93', 93, 3, 10, 189347) As yet, they have failed to inspire confidence.
('93', 93, 3, 11, 189395) 2. In spite of all my efforts exodus continues and very few persons have returned to their villages.
('93', 93, 3, 12, 189496) They say the guilty parties are still at large, some finding a place on the Peace Committees, that sporadic cases of murder and arson still continue, that abducted women have not all been returned, that forcibly converted persons have not all returned, that burnt houses are not being rebuilt and generally the atmosphere of goodwill is lacking.
('93', 93, 3, 13, 189842) How far these charges are true or can be proved I do not know.
('93', 93, 3, 14, 189905) My object just now is to bring these to your notice.
('93', 93, 3, 15, 189958) It might be that a summary impartial inquiry is necessary to restore confidence.
('93', 93, 3, 16, 190039) 3. Restrictions are being placed on volunteers irrespective of the organizations to which they belong.
('93', 93, 3, 17, 190142) I can understand illegal activities being restricted, but no other restriction would be advisable.
('93', 93, 3, 18, 190241) 4. Adequate food and warm clothing and fit habitation is surely necessary while there are bona fide refugees.
('93', 93, 3, 19, 190351) To deny these amenities would create suspicion and defeat the purpose of sending them back to their villages.
('93', 93, 3, 20, 190461) I am of opinion that if the Government are unable to provide adequate food and clothing, facility should be readily given to benevolent persons to supply them.

('93', 96, 1, 2, 194437) 130. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('93', 96, 2, 3, 194461) SRIRAMPUR, NOAKHALI DISTRICT, December 4, 1946
('93', 96, 3, 4, 194508) MIRA, Your letter dated November 18 reached me only yesterday.
('93', 96, 3, 5, 194571) You know I am in a more inaccessible place than you are in.
('93', 96, 3, 6, 194631) 1 The distance is not too great but there is no cart road even.
('93', 96, 3, 7, 194695) When the overflow canal water dries up, as it will in about ten days, all but walking to and fro will be out of place.
('93', 96, 3, 8, 194814) The post is taken by runners as it was in Kathiawar only a few years ago and is in some places even now.
('93', 96, 3, 9, 194919) Don’t worry about me.
('93', 96, 3, 10, 194941) Put your faith and trust in God.
('93', 96, 3, 11, 194974) I am in His safe keeping.
('93', 96, 3, 12, 195000) He will make or mar me.
('93', 96, 3, 13, 195024) For Him it will be all making, never marring.
('93', 96, 3, 14, 195070) Newspapers do not come here regularly.
('93', 96, 3, 15, 195109) When they come, they come behind time and what does come is local newspapers.
('93', 96, 3, 16, 195187) Therefore, one does not know what appears in the Press.
('93', 96, 3, 17, 195243) My pres cription i“Don’t believe what appears in the Press”, and remember that no news is good news.
('93', 96, 3, 18, 195344) Do you know that A. J. Balfour 2 when he was Prime Minister used to boast that he never read newspapers and lost nothing.
('93', 96, 3, 19, 195466) Then I suppose you know that all my companions are distributed in different villages.
('93', 96, 3, 20, 195552) Pyarelal sees me often but he is not with me.
('93', 96, 3, 21, 195598) He is in a village by himself assisted by a Bengali interpreter.
('93', 96, 3, 22, 195663) I have Parasuram with me and therefore am able to dictate.
('93', 96, 3, 23, 195722) The original idea was that I should take and want no assistance except a Bengali interpreter.
('93', 96, 3, 24, 195816) Parasuram always helped Pyarelal but here he could not be placed by himself in a village.
('93', 96, 3, 25, 195906) He was naturally anxious to be with me directly but he could not when I had all other assistance and was doing another class of work.
('93', 96, 3, 26, 196040) Now that he is here, in addition to looking after me personally, he does my shorthand
('93', 96, 4, 27, 196126) 1 In Bapu’s Letters to Mira, “Note to Manu Gandhi”, 19 1 1947, Mirabehn explains: “In April, I had become Honorary Adviser to the United Provinces Government in connection with the ‘Grow More Food’ campaign.

('93', 97, 0, 1, 196495) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 97, 1, 2, 196536) work, which enables me to go through what I had not expected or bargained for.
('93', 97, 1, 3, 196615) And the Bengali assistant is a Professor who has for years made a deep study of my writings.
('93', 97, 1, 4, 196708) Therefore, I have got most desirable assistance, but that assistance cannot cope with newspapers.

('93', 97, 1, 13, 197239) Now I see you resumed the thread you left on November 18, on 22. Your problems are extraordinary but they are all of your own making.Therefore you can, as you must, reduce them to a manageable degree.
('93', 97, 1, 14, 197440) You will not find the men or the man by searching.

('93', 101, 6, 17, 204369) 136. DISCUSSION WITH AMIYA CHAKRAVARTY 1
('93', 101, 7, 18, 204410) [December 4, 1946] 2
('93', 101, 8, 19, 204431) At meal time Prof.
('93', 101, 8, 20, 204450) Amiya Chakravarty of the Calcutta University, who had come to him on a visit, asked him the question as to what should be the technique for approaching the wrongdoers so that their resistance should be dissolved.
('93', 101, 8, 21, 204663) “The chief difficulty with the callous perpetrators of crimes is,” Dr. Chakravarty remarked, “that they are not only unrepentant but defiant and even jubilant over their misdeeds.” Gandhiji replied : Yes, they have their own reason to be jubilant and the only way to meet their attitude is not to succumb to it but to live in their midst and retain one’s sense of truth.
('93', 101, 8, 22, 205034) Goodness must be joined with knowledge.
('93', 101, 8, 23, 205074) Mere goodness is not of much use as I have found in life.
('93', 101, 8, 24, 205132) One must cultivate the fine, discriminating quality which goes with spiritual courage and character.
('93', 101, 8, 25, 205233) One must know, in a crucial situation, when to speak and when to be silent, when to act and
('93', 101, 9, 26, 205325) 1 Extracted from “Do or Die at Work” by Pyarelal 2 From Hindustan Standard, 9 12 1946
('93', 102, 0, 1, 205411) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 103
('93', 102, 1, 2, 205459) when to refrain.
('93', 102, 1, 3, 205476) Action and non action in these circumstances become identical instead of being contradictory.
('93', 102, 1, 4, 205570) I am groping for light.
('93', 102, 1, 5, 205594) I am surrounded by darkness; but I must act or refrain as guided by truth.
('93', 102, 1, 6, 205669) I find that I have not the patience and the technique needed in these tragic circumstances; suffering and evil often overwhelms me and I stew in my own juice.
('93', 102, 1, 7, 205828) Therefore, I have told my friends that they should bear with me and work or refrain as guided by wisdom which is now utterly demanded of us.
('93', 102, 1, 8, 205969) This darkness will break and, if I see light even those who created the tragedy of the recent communalism in Bengal, will.
('93', 102, 2, 9, 206092) The new basis has to be built here in the villages where the Hindus and the Muslims have lived and suffered together in the land of their forefathers and must live together in the future.
('93', 102, 2, 10, 206280) For the time being I have become a Bengali and a Noakhali man.
('93', 102, 2, 11, 206343) I have come to live and share their task, to cement the two together or to perish in the attempt.
('93', 102, 2, 12, 206441) I am in the midst of a raging fire and will stay here till it is put out.
('93', 102, 2, 13, 206515) For this reason, I do not want to leave these parts.
('93', 102, 2, 14, 206568) Life must be made livable for the sorely afflicted men and women.
('93', 102, 2, 15, 206634) The work of organization must go on and the physical as well as moral rescue achieved.
('93', 102, 3, 16, 206721) Dr. Chakravarty next suggested that the reports from Gandhiji’s associates who are now working separately in the different villages should be collected and collated so that fellow workers could gain new light on the technique of the non violence of the strong that was being evolved and experimented within East Bengal.
('93', 102, 3, 17, 207041) Gandhiji replied : The time is not yet ripe for that.
('93', 102, 3, 18, 207095) 2 They have gone with my best wishes but to an atmosphere which is still unhelpful.
('93', 102, 3, 19, 207179) They are following not a beaten path but a trackless route.
('93', 102, 3, 20, 207239) Their work lies in the midst of a Muslim population.
('93', 102, 3, 21, 207292) They do not know the language and are not familiar with local problems.
('93', 102, 3, 22, 207364) I myself don’t know what the next step is and cannot guide them.
('93', 102, 3, 23, 207429) They are unable to send reports now.
('93', 102, 3, 24, 207466) If I made a chart for them, they would be able to keep a log book.
('93', 102, 3, 25, 207533) Even the great Thakkar Bapa, as old as myself, a seasoned worker and utterly selfless, is working away without knowing what he is doing—a thing he has never done before in his life.
('93', 102, 3, 26, 207715) But I am hopeful that order will come out of what is for us the necessary chaos.
('93', 102, 3, 27, 207796) Then what you wish, and I also, will be forthcoming and will be a most

('93', 103, 7, 17, 209423) 137. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 103, 8, 18, 209455) SRIRAMPUR, December 4, 1946
('93', 103, 9, 19, 209483) As Gandhiji began his daily discourse, he gave unstinted praise to the musicians.
('93', 103, 9, 20, 209565) 2 Indeed, he said, he had never heard the Bengal mridanga (drum) played so well as was done at the meeting.
('93', 103, 9, 21, 209673) When played well it had a sweetness all its own.
('93', 103, 9, 22, 209722) He had also appreciated the namasankirtan; but he hoped that it did not come merely from the throat but from their heart.
('93', 103, 9, 23, 209844) For, a parrot also can repeat what it learns from its master.
('93', 103, 9, 24, 209906) There is hardly any virtue when we take the name of God when we live in safety.
('93', 103, 9, 25, 209986) It becomes real only when taken in danger.
('93', 103, 10, 26, 210029) He would never mind if a Hindu recited the kalma willingly and with a full
('93', 103, 11, 27, 210104) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary” 2 The report said: “Shortly before prayer, a group of people from the neighbouring villages arrived, singing the namasankirtan to the accompaniment of the khol (drum) and the karatala (cymbals).
('93', 103, 11, 28, 210334) When the Ramdhun was being sung, they kept time by means of the khol.”
('93', 104, 0, 1, 210405) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 105
('93', 104, 1, 2, 210453) But if he did so out of fear of losing his life or possessions, then he took the name of God in vain, for it was the voice of Satan which then spoke through him.
('93', 104, 1, 3, 210615) As he understood Islam, it had never prospered nor could prosper by means of force.
('93', 104, 1, 4, 210699) Any man who pretended to serve Islam in that manner only did a disservice to the noble religion.
('93', 104, 2, 5, 210796) Every religion today had become tainted by unwanted accretions.
('93', 104, 2, 6, 210860) In Hinduism we treated a large part of our brethren as untouchables, and Gandhiji said he had no doubt that we were paying sorrowfully for that sin.
('93', 104, 3, 7, 211009) The first verse of the Ishopanishad contained the essence of Hindu spiritual experience.
('93', 104, 3, 8, 211098) The purport of the verse was that all that existed in the universe was pervaded by and had its being in God.
('93', 104, 3, 9, 211207) Therefore, no man could claim anything as his own.
('93', 104, 3, 10, 211258) He should dedicate his body, mind and all that he possessed to that Universal Being and use only what he received through His grace.
('93', 104, 3, 11, 211391) The moral of it was that we should deprive no man of his wealth, whether it be in the shape of life, honour or religion.
('93', 104, 3, 12, 211512) A believer in this truth, living up to it, shed all fear and lived in perfect peace.
('93', 104, 4, 13, 211597) The verses 1 of the Bhagavad Gita were then referred to as they formed the next item in the Ashram’s evening prayer.
('93', 104, 4, 14, 211714) They described the characteristics of one who had attained knowledge and brought his senses under full control.
('93', 104, 4, 15, 211826) The lesson of the Bhagavad Gita was meant not for those who had forsaken the world, but for every householder, irrespective of his birth and state.
('93', 104, 4, 16, 211974) Everybody’s duty should be to attain the state described therein and this could only be done if life was built on the rock of fearlessness.
('93', 104, 4, 17, 212114) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 105, 1, 2, 212911) 139. LETTER TO HANNAH LAZAR
('93', 105, 2, 3, 212939) AS FROM SEVAGRAM, “VIA” WARDHA, INDIA, CAMP: SRIRAMPUR, EAST BENGAL, December 5, 1946
('93', 105, 3, 4, 213025) DEAR HANNAH 1, I have your letter full of pathos and also full of news which I would not have got otherwise.
('93', 105, 3, 5, 213134) I like your frankness.
('93', 105, 3, 6, 213157) Who does not like life?
('93', 105, 3, 7, 213181) Therefore, it is no fault in you that you should like life and that you should have also likes and dislikes.
('93', 105, 3, 8, 213290) But though these are common to mankind we have got to overcome them if life is to become rich in reality, and the memory of departed dear ones is to become a treasure.
('93', 105, 3, 9, 213458) It can only be to the extent that it enables us to translate in our own lives the best parts of dear ones and Hermann undoubtedly had many such parts which we may copy with advantage.
('93', 105, 3, 10, 213642) You should therefore try to do so.
('93', 105, 3, 11, 213677) I am glad you went to Phoenix to help Manilal when he was so much in need of your help.
('93', 105, 3, 12, 213765) I am glad Isele has qualified as a doctor and that she has got a permanent job as house physician in the General Hospital.
('93', 105, 3, 13, 213888) Are you otherwise at peace with yourself?
('93', 105, 3, 14, 213930) Manilal will tell you that I am at present engaged in tackling the most difficult piece of work in my life and I am staying in a most inaccessible part of India at the present moment.
('93', 105, 3, 15, 214114) Do not hesitate to write to me whenever the spirit moves you.
('93', 105, 3, 16, 214176) It is easy enough for me to promise not to write in reply every time I hear from you.
('93', 105, 3, 17, 214262) This time I feel like writing in order to encourage you to write to me regularly and also to tell you that you have in me your best friend who will try somewhat to do what Hermann used to do so fully.
('93', 105, 3, 18, 214463) You are bound to miss him as we all do.
('93', 105, 3, 19, 214503) He certainly expected to come back to me had he lived.
('93', 105, 3, 20, 214558) But God willed otherwise.
('93', 105, 3, 21, 214584) Love, BAPU HANNAH LAZAR JOHANNESBURG
('93', 105, 4, 22, 214621) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('93', 106, 1, 2, 214851) 140. LETTER TO T. PRAKASAM
('93', 106, 2, 3, 214878) SRIRAMPUR, NOAKHALI DISTT., December 5, 1946
('93', 106, 3, 4, 214923) DEAR PRAKASAM, I have your letter with enclosures.
('93', 106, 3, 5, 214974) I have studied all the papers you have sent to me.
('93', 106, 3, 6, 215025) Your statement appears to me to be in order so far as it goes.
('93', 106, 3, 7, 215088) But I do feel that if the new policy 1 becomes popular with the masses, the concentrated production of cotton will become decentralised and distributed like khadi cloth itself and to that extent the Presidency will be the gainer, as the whole of India will, if it takes up the Madras policy, as it will, if Madras succeeds, as it ought to if the villagers take up khadi with zest.
('93', 106, 3, 8, 215469) They will, if khadi becomes cheaper than unprotected mill cloth, as Shri Manu Subedar has shown from the figures, which I have printed in Harijan.
('93', 106, 3, 9, 215616) The argument in the cuttings you have been good enough to send me makes no appeal to me and if I get time from the heavy Noakhali work before me I shall write in Harijan.
('93', 106, 3, 10, 215787) But I know nothing about the legal argument which, of course, you will get properly examined by the Advocate General and other lawyers expert in the matter and, if the legal argument is against you, naturally you will resile from the position taken up by you.But I take it that you had the legal position carefully examined before you took the plunge.
('93', 106, 3, 11, 216139) But apart from the question of establishing new mills or expan ding the old ones, how is the scheme progressing?
('93', 106, 3, 12, 216252) Have you already made the commencement?
('93', 106, 3, 13, 216292) How are the people concerned taking it?
('93', 106, 3, 14, 216332) Is the legislature overwhelmingly with you?
('93', 106, 3, 15, 216376) I am in such an inaccessible place that I get very few newspapers and they are local ones.
('93', 106, 3, 16, 216467) I, therefore, know very little of what is going on outside Noakhali.
('93', 106, 3, 17, 216536) Therefore Noakhali at present is my world and it is large enough for me.
('93', 106, 3, 18, 216609) Please keep me informed of what is going on about the scheme and do not hesitate to make concrete suggestions if you expect me to do anything concrete.
('93', 106, 4, 19, 216761) Yours, BAPU

('93', 107, 1, 2, 216951) 141. LETTER TO H. S. SUHRAWARDY
('93', 107, 2, 3, 216983) SRIRAMPUR, December 5, 1946 A special messenger from the District Magistrate, Comilla, delivered your packet containing your two letters dated 2nd and 3rd instant respectively.
('93', 107, 2, 4, 217160) I am glad that you are going to issue some such statement as suggested by me.
('93', 107, 2, 5, 217238) In these days of fear, sometimes not without ground and sometimes groundless, no contradiction should be superfluous, much less appear foolish.
('93', 107, 2, 6, 217382) 2. If “some mischievous Hindu young men have been throwing crackers and missiles at Muharrum processions”, I would suggest that they should be brought to book.
('93', 107, 2, 7, 217542) 3. I note that you have devoted a considerable portion of your letter of the 2nd December and the whole of the 3rd December to Bihar, and you have repeated the advice you have given me often enough that my place is rather in Bihar than in Noakhali.
('93', 107, 2, 8, 217791) If I find any confirmation of the most serious statements made by you about Bihar, I confess that I have egregiously blundered by resuming normal diet.
('93', 107, 3, 9, 217943) But I am loath to reject the testimony of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, then of Dr. Rajendra Prasad, both responsible men and persons who had gone specially for the purpose of seeing things for themselves andallaying mob fury.
('93', 107, 3, 10, 218165) They admit that the behaviour of the Hindu crowds was bad enough in all conscience but they do not bear out the statements made in your letter.
('93', 107, 3, 11, 218309) Nor do they uphold the figure given by you.
('93', 107, 3, 12, 218353) They also tell me that mob fury has subsided and that the Government have regained control undoubtedly with the assistance of the military.
('93', 107, 3, 13, 218493) If I could feel that my presence was at all necessary in Bihar, I assure you that I would not need any encouragement from you to do so.
('93', 107, 3, 14, 218629) On the contrary, my informants assure me that my presence is not required in Bihar.
('93', 107, 3, 15, 218713) In these circumstances, unless I feel sure of my ground, I know that I must go to Bihar.
('93', 107, 3, 16, 218802) But I would like to make the assurance doubly sure and with that end in view I would be glad to get your permission to send copies of your letters to the Prime Minister of Bihar and know his reaction.
('93', 107, 3, 17, 219003) There too you will pardon me, will you not, for not taking your statements as gospel truth.
('93', 107, 3, 18, 219095) For one thing, you have no first hand knowledge of events.
('93', 107, 3, 19, 219154) I suggest that
('93', 107, 4, 20, 219169) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 20,11 1946
('93', 108, 0, 1, 219212) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 109
('93', 108, 1, 2, 219260) there should be an impartial commission, appointed with the consent of the two Governments, to go into the disturbances both in Noakhali and Bihar.
('93', 108, 1, 3, 219408) 1 If your statements are true and the callous behaviour of the Bihar Government, which you so graphically describe, can be sustained, it is a bad day for the Bihar Government, a bad day for the Hindus and good bye to restoration of friendly relations between the two communities, and it would be a serious question for me to consider where I stand.
('93', 108, 1, 4, 219757) The least I can permit myself to say is that then I should have no hesitation in publicily denouncing the Bihar Ministers and Bihar Hindus.
('93', 108, 1, 5, 219897) I would plead with you to suspend, if you at all can, final judgment in the matter.
('93', 108, 1, 6, 219981) 4. Now I come to Noakhali.
('93', 108, 1, 7, 220008) I sent you a longish letter yesterday and I asked Satis Babu to arrange for its quickest delivery through a special messenger.
('93', 108, 1, 8, 220135) I tried even to see if there was possibility of sending it by air but I failed.
('93', 108, 1, 9, 220215) You have painted a rosy picture of things in Noakhali.
('93', 108, 1, 10, 220270) I wish I could share your estimate.
('93', 108, 1, 11, 220306) I have formed no judgment.
('93', 108, 1, 12, 220333) I have passed on to you the purport of much of what is handed to me in writing and what is given to me by word of mouth.
('93', 108, 1, 13, 220454) If the information imparted to me is correct, things are not safe enough in Noakhali.
('93', 108, 1, 14, 220540) Hindus have not shed their fear and from what you say even the Muslims are not free from it.
('93', 108, 1, 15, 220633) My business in coming here is not to sow or promote dissensions between the two.
('93', 108, 1, 16, 220714) I regard myself, as I have ever been, an equal friend of both.
('93', 108, 1, 17, 220777) I know that through no fault of which I am conscious I have lost caste in the Muslim League circles.
('93', 108, 1, 18, 220878) No Muslim friend has yet been able to tell me what I have done to deserve that fate.
('93', 108, 1, 19, 220963) I am in Noakhali to be judged by my conduct.
('93', 108, 1, 20, 221008) My non violence is at stake.
('93', 108, 1, 21, 221037) Bear with me whilst I am groping.
('93', 108, 1, 22, 221071) I am the same person as I was when we met in Faridpur and later in Deshbandhu’s house after his death.
('93', 108, 1, 23, 221174) This much is enough for time being.
('93', 108, 1, 24, 221210) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] Wish you could show me a quicker way of reaching my letters to you, as they are likely to be important and probably frequent.
('93', 108, 2, 25, 221372) M. K. G.

('93', 109, 1, 2, 221616) 142. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('93', 109, 2, 3, 221647) AS FROM KHADI PRATISHTHAN, SODEPUR, CAMP: SRIRAMPUR, December 5, 1946
('93', 109, 3, 4, 221717) DEAR AGATHA, Ramakrishna Bajaj has sent me your welcome letter.
('93', 109, 3, 5, 221781) Carl Heath did write to me and I wrote to him at once.
('93', 109, 3, 6, 221836) I have no doubt he will share that letter with you.
('93', 109, 3, 7, 221888) I, therefore, say no more about the subject matter of the letter, important though it is.
('93', 109, 3, 8, 221978) Here I am in an inaccessible part of Bengal and dealing with the most difficult part of my mission in life.
('93', 109, 3, 9, 222086) I have never been in such darkness as I am in today.
('93', 109, 3, 10, 222139) And the darkness does not come from outside.
('93', 109, 3, 11, 222184) It is due to my limitations.
('93', 109, 3, 12, 222213) My faith in ahimsa has never burned brighter and yet I feel that there is something wanting in my technique of it that I feel as though I were on an unbeaten track.
('93', 109, 3, 13, 222378) As you must have known, my fast has blown over just now.
('93', 109, 3, 14, 222435) Bihar is quiet and I am therefore trying to take the usual diet though I have still to be cautious.
('93', 109, 3, 15, 222535) I hope soon to get over the physical weakness which was inevitable with no protein and no starch and no fat diet.
('93', 109, 3, 16, 222649) The most satisfactory thing about this reduced diet was that I was able to do full amount of mental work and a fair amount even of physical work.
('93', 109, 3, 17, 222795) If this letter reaches while Amrit is still in Europe, please tell her that I have received all her letters but I have written none to her purposely, feeling that she was soon to return and there was every danger of my letters missing her, especially as I am in an out of the way place where there is no post office worth the name and no telegraph office at all.
('93', 109, 3, 18, 223158) Naturally I am not in touch with what is going on in Delhi.
('93', 109, 3, 19, 223218) If my mission succeeds here I shall be fit enough for further work.
('93', 109, 3, 20, 223286) Anyway, so far as I know, I have to bury myself here till mutual confidence and friendship between the communities are restored.
('93', 109, 3, 21, 223415) What happens here will happen throughout India, because Bengal is the nerve centre.
('93', 109, 4, 22, 223499) From a photostat: G. N. 1527

('93', 111, 4, 30, 226171) There is no cause for worry.
('93', 111, 4, 31, 226200) He himself is quite cheerful.

('93', 113, 1, 3, 228472) Today Nirmal Babu is my ears and is indisp ensable, but when I learn enough Bengali, he will be free to go.
('93', 113, 2, 4, 228580) Then he explained his own plan—how he had already posted one worker in each village, with a Bengali interpreter where necessary, in order to “steal the hearts of the inhabitants”.
('93', 113, 2, 5, 228760) It did not matter if there was only one or many Hindus in a village; his prescription was that they should stick to their posts and even face death, if necessary, with courage and willingness.
('93', 113, 2, 6, 228953) If they lived in clusters, it would really mean accepting the Muslim League’s mischievous two nation theory.

('93', 113, 2, 8, 229136) I am not going to be a willing party to Pakistan.
('93', 113, 2, 9, 229186) Even if I fail to prevent it and all Hindus go away, I shall still remain here; and shall not make a single change in my religious practice.
('93', 113, 3, 10, 229327) Nirmal Babu remarked that no one had taken to this advice so far, as the scheme was beyond the strength of the average individual.
('93', 113, 3, 11, 229458) Gandhiji replied : If some could die like this, the few shall become many.
('93', 113, 3, 12, 229533) I am not a visionary as I am generally supposed to be.
('93', 113, 3, 13, 229588) I am an idealist, but I claim to be a practical idealist.
('93', 113, 3, 14, 229646) I have been born a Hindu and I shall die a Hindu, a sanatanist Hindu.
('93', 113, 3, 15, 229716) If there is salvation for me, it must be as a Hindu.
('93', 113, 3, 16, 229769) Hinduism absorbs the best in other religions, and there is scope for expansion in it.
('93', 113, 4, 17, 229855) Nirmal Babu thanked him for his kindness in thus taking up the cause of Bengal.
('93', 113, 4, 18, 229935) Gandhiji immediately replied that it was no kindness and if it was, it was kindness to himself.
('93', 113, 4, 19, 230031) He said : My own doctrine was failing.
('93', 113, 4, 20, 230070) I don’t want to die a failure but as a successful man.
('93', 113, 4, 21, 230125) But it may be that I may die a failure.

('93', 114, 4, 8, 231152) 148. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 114, 5, 9, 231184) SRIRAMPUR, December 6, 1946
('93', 114, 6, 10, 231212) Gandhiji began his after prayer speech by saying that true prayer never went unanswered.
('93', 114, 6, 11, 231301) It did not mean that every little thing we asked for from God was readily given to us.
('93', 114, 6, 12, 231388) It was only when we shed our selfishness with conscious effort and approached God in true humility that our prayers found a response.
('93', 114, 7, 13, 231522) In the Ashram prayer nothing was asked.
('93', 114, 7, 14, 231562) The prayer was for God to make them better men and women.
('93', 114, 7, 15, 231620) If the prayer came truly from the heart, God’s grace would surely descend upon them.
('93', 114, 7, 16, 231705) There was not a blade of grass which moved without his will, not one single true thought which did not leave a mark on character.
('93', 114, 7, 17, 231835) It was good, therefore, to develop the daily habit of prayer.

('93', 116, 1, 2, 234099) 151. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 116, 2, 3, 234131) SRIRAMPUR December 7, 1946
('93', 116, 3, 4, 234158) Gandhiji referred in his few words to a writing by a Mussalman.
('93', 116, 3, 5, 234222) In it the writer had rightly contended that a man of God was never afraid to die or to lose his possessions for the sake of his self respect or religion.
('93', 116, 3, 6, 234376) God had given us life and could take it away.
('93', 116, 3, 7, 234422) That teaching was universal and applied to all, Hindus as well as Mussalmans.
('93', 116, 3, 8, 234500) Those who had in God their sole refuge cast out all fear.
('93', 116, 3, 9, 234558) Then there could be lasting friendship between the two.
('93', 116, 3, 10, 234614) He had been trying all these days to din this lesson into the ears of his listeners.
('93', 116, 3, 11, 234699) There was a time when Mussalmans also listened to him; but now things seemed to have changed and even among Hindus there were not many who would follow his advice.
('93', 116, 3, 12, 234863) But he felt sure lasting peace could come only when men of whatever community refused to surrender to any fear save the holy fear of God.
('93', 116, 3, 13, 235001) Harijan, 5 1 1947

('93', 123, 4, 7, 246630) 165. INTERVIEW TO DEOBHANKAR 1
('93', 123, 5, 8, 246661) December 9, 1946
('93', 123, 6, 9, 246678) When Deobhankar asked him as to how the Muslim masses could be won over and unified under the Congress and if this could not be achieved best through some form of economic struggle along class lines, Gandhiji replied that so far such a plan had not succeeded in respect of the people whose communal sentiment had proved too strong.
('93', 123, 6, 10, 247010) What we had to do was to prevent the Congress from turning into a Hindu communal organization.
('93', 123, 6, 11, 247105) Anyone who had made India his home should be protected by the Congress.
('93', 123, 6, 12, 247177) Hindus should never think that Hindustan belonged exclusively to them.
('93', 123, 6, 13, 247248) The Parsis had come centuries ago, and the Syrian Christians were Christians ever since the time of St. Thomas.
('93', 123, 6, 14, 247360) Every one of them had to be treated as an Indian enjoying the same rights as any other Indian.
('93', 123, 7, 15, 247455) Congressmen should not however approach Muslims in a spirit of appeasement or flattery.
('93', 123, 7, 16, 247543) Although something like that had been done, and it might even be justifiably said that he himself had partly been responsible for such an attitude, yet, his eyes were now opened and he held that it had been unwise to do so.
('93', 123, 7, 17, 247767) It was by safeguarding every person’s legitimate interests that Congressmen could prove their genuine love of nationalism.
('93', 123, 7, 18, 247890) He did not mind even if the Congress were manned by Hindus alone.
('93', 123, 7, 19, 247956) If its members placed the cause of the whole nation above everything else, then their idealism would ultimately triumph over communalism.
('93', 123, 8, 20, 248094) What the Hindus or Mussalmans had exhibited so far in Bengal or Bihar was violence mixed with cowardice; there was no element of bravery in it.
('93', 123, 8, 21, 248238) To those who did not believe in non violence, he could hypothetically suggest a more civilized form of revenge than what they had actually been guilty of.
('93', 123, 8, 22, 248393) Supposing there were a Government in Bihar which believed in violence and not in non violence, they could have written to the Government in Bengal after the Calcutta riots, ‘Now, here are the inhabitants of this province who have returned from Calcutta.
('93', 123, 8, 23, 248647) They have become
('93', 123, 9, 24, 248664) 1 Deobhankar, Shridhar Purushottam Limaye and Rai Bajrang Bahadur, Raja of Bhadri in Partapgarh, U. P., had come with letters from Kripalani, Mridula Sarabhai and Ram Manohar Lohia.
('93', 124, 0, 1, 248846) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 125
('93', 124, 1, 2, 248894) furious and are bent upon taking revenge on the 14 per cent of Mussalmans in Bihar.
('93', 124, 1, 3, 248978) But we will prevent them from doing so, if we can.
('93', 124, 1, 4, 249029) In the meanwhile, you should do everything to stop the riot which is even now going on in Bengal.’
('93', 124, 2, 5, 249128) Along with sending such a letter to the Muslim League Government in Bengal, the Government of Bihar should have kept the Muslims of Bihar informed about their efforts.
('93', 124, 2, 6, 249296) If conditions in Bengal did not improve, they could have notified the Bengal Government that unless the Bihar Muslims left the province for Bengal within, say, eight days, they would have to send the latter forcibly over to Bengal rather than allow them to be butchered in Bihar.
('93', 124, 2, 7, 249576) And when the eight days had passed, they might have taken necessary steps for evacuating the Muslims of Bihar.
('93', 124, 3, 8, 249687) It was quite likely that the Muslims of Bihar would have refused to move and declared that they were with the Congress rather than with the League in the policy that the latter had been pursuing in Bengal.
('93', 124, 3, 9, 249893) That would have meant a victory for the Congress not only in Bihar but in all those provinces where the Government was run by the Congress.
('93', 124, 4, 10, 250033) Such action, though fully violent, would have been better than that to which Bihar had lowered herself today.
('93', 124, 4, 11, 250143) Violence, when cowardly, only served to degrade and did not yield the desired political result.
('93', 124, 4, 12, 250239) Gandhiji lastly said that today he was seeking for a non violent solution for his own sake alone.
('93', 124, 4, 13, 250337) For the time being, he had given up searching for a non violent remedy applicable to the masses.
('93', 124, 4, 14, 250434) He had yet to see if non violence would prove successful in the present crisis or not.
('93', 124, 4, 15, 250521) He expected that things would take a definite turn one way or the other within two months and not remain uncertain as they were at the present moment.
('93', 124, 5, 16, 250672) My Days with Gandhi, pp.

('93', 125, 5, 14, 251891) 168. TALK TO WOMEN 1
('93', 125, 6, 15, 251912) SRIRAMPUR, [December 10, 1946] 2
('93', 125, 7, 16, 251945) Gandhiji told them that since his arrival in Noakhali he had been telling them all to be fearless.
('93', 125, 7, 17, 252044) If they acted accordingly and were fearless in all their work, they could live in peace.

('93', 125, 11, 23, 252325) If Hindus and Muslims in India gathered courage and cast from their hearts the fear of loss of possessions and life the face of India would change in no time, Gandhiji said.
('93', 125, 11, 24, 252499) But the reformed social relations must be based upon character built on the rock of fearlessness; only thus could true mutual trust be generated.

('93', 126, 1, 2, 253066) religion there was a common fund of spiritual experience which applied all over the world.
('93', 126, 2, 3, 253157) Whatever differences struck our eyes were the results of requirements limited to particular epochs of time and place.
('93', 126, 2, 4, 253275) Indeed there were as many religions as there were men on earth; for the needs of no two men were wholly alike.
('93', 126, 2, 5, 253386) In spite of that, the commonness underlying all the religions could never be missed.
('93', 126, 2, 6, 253471) A tree had a single stem, many branches and innumerable leaves, no two of which were wholly alike; it was even so in the case of religion.
('93', 126, 3, 7, 253610) No religion today was without blemishes.
('93', 126, 3, 8, 253651) Islam had given rise to the noblest of characters and he counted among his friends men who stood tall and high over their neighbours.
('93', 126, 3, 9, 253785) But unwanted accretions had gathered in the practice of Islam, which ran counter to the fundamental teachings of that religion.
('93', 126, 4, 10, 253913) Similarly, Christian nations, who followed their Master, who taught mankind to love their enemies, had been responsible for two major wars during our generation, which had blighted the face of earth and had left a legacy of suspicion, hatred and violence from which the whole world was suffering today.
('93', 126, 5, 11, 254216) In Hinduism too, diabolical wrong had been perpetrated in the name of religion.
('93', 126, 5, 12, 254296) Our so called untouchable brethren had been reduced to a condition which was the very opposite of human dignity.
('93', 126, 5, 13, 254409) Indeed this very charge had been laid against us by General Smuts at the United Nations Assembly in America when Shrimati Vijayalakshmi Pandit demanded justice against the treatment meted out to us in South Africa.
('93', 126, 6, 14, 254624) Gandhiji wound up by saying that both Hindus and Muslims were like blood brothers.
('93', 126, 6, 15, 254707) They were nourished by food grown from the same soil, quenched their thirst by water of the same river and finally laid themselves to rest in the same earth.
('93', 126, 6, 16, 254865) If they feared God, they would fear no one else.

('93', 132, 5, 17, 265137) 178. WHAT WILL SOUTH AFRICA DO?
('93', 132, 6, 18, 265169) The deputation headed by Shrimati Vijayalakshmi Pandit and sent to the U. N. O. Conference by the Interim Government has undoubtedly done very effective work with marked ability and success.
('93', 132, 6, 19, 265360) That is clear from the following cablegram sent by Shrimati Vijayalakshmi Pandit from New York :
('93', 132, 7, 20, 265457) Today with your blessings justice of South African Indian cause was vindicated.
('93', 132, 7, 21, 265537) Committee voting twenty four to nineteen in our favour.
('93', 132, 7, 22, 265593) Went to General Smuts after meeting and shook hands.
('93', 132, 7, 23, 265646) He expressed appreciation at manner in which I had conducted case.
('93', 132, 8, 24, 265713) It remains now to be seen how the Parliament of the Union of South Africa and its European public respond.
('93', 132, 8, 25, 265820) Field Mar shal Smuts was able to hurl at the Indian deputation the taunt that India treated her so called untouchables, legally described as the “Scheduled Classes”, much worse than the Union treated her Asiatics or for that matter the Africans.
('93', 132, 8, 26, 266066) There would be much to be said for
('93', 132, 9, 27, 266101) 1 Pyarelal explains : “After the morning walk he felt so utterly exhausted that he had to lie in bed.
('93', 132, 9, 28, 266203) It must have been about midnight when he got up to visit the chamber pot.” 2 According to a report in The Bombay Chronicle, 30 11 1946, Vijayalakshmi Pandit, in her reply to Heaton Nichols of South Africa before the U. N. General Assembly had said : “When I was coming here I saw Mahatma Gandhi, who is very much interested in this whole case.
('93', 132, 9, 29, 266547) He said to me as I was leaving : “I do not mind whether you come back having won your case or having suffered defeat; but you must come back as a friend of General Smuts.’ And that is not what any man in Mahatma Gandhi’s position would have said.”
('93', 133, 0, 1, 266795) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 133, 1, 2, 266837) the Field Marshal’s taunt if it was true.
('93', 133, 1, 3, 266879) It is true of South Africa that her treatment of Asiatics has legally deteriorated from time to time, so much so that it has now become well nigh unbearable.
('93', 133, 1, 4, 267037) Almost every promise made by the Union Government to the Government of India has now been broken.
('93', 133, 1, 5, 267135) In India, on the other hand, there never has been any law carrying the bar sinister against the Scheduled Classes.
('93', 133, 1, 6, 267250) It can be proved up to the hilt that the law has always sought to protect the Scheduled Classes.
('93', 133, 1, 7, 267347) There is no legal bar, so far as I am aware, against any of the Scheduled Classes being regarded as equal in status to the tallest Indian.
('93', 133, 1, 8, 267486) What is however true to the shame of orthodox Hinduism and the Sanatani Hindus is that religious custom has denied to these untouchables the rights which the law has allowed, and it is unfortunately also true that sometimes custom overrides the law.
('93', 133, 1, 9, 267736) But public opinion is progressively rising against this barbarous custom and it is merely a question of time when the custom will be swept out of existence.
('93', 133, 1, 10, 267893) Let us, therefore, hope that instead of taking doubtful advantage of the things in India which no one defends and against which public opinion is pro gressively rising, the Europeans of the Union of South Africa will recog nize that if the U. N. O. Conference is any index of world opinion, it is decidedly against the European prejudice which has hardened into law.
('93', 133, 1, 11, 268260) SRIRAMPUR, December 12, 1946 Harijan, 29 12 1946
('93', 133, 2, 12, 268309) 179. FRAGMENT OF LETTER TO JAGNESWAR GHOSH 1
('93', 133, 3, 13, 268354) December 12, 1946
('93', 133, 4, 14, 268372) Your suggestion is that people of the same culture should be brought together in a common territory and placed under a common government.
('93', 133, 4, 15, 268510) Of course, for administrative purposes, men have to be divided into groups.
('93', 133, 4, 16, 268586) This is best done on economic grounds or on the basis of linguistic unity.
('93', 133, 4, 17, 268661) What Gandhiji objects to is the redistribution of population on the basis of religion.
('93', 133, 4, 18, 268748) That would mean an admission that people of different faiths cannot live on friendly terms within the same State.
('93', 133, 4, 19, 268862) The Muslim League has suggested a similar remedy for the present Hindu Muslim tension, when the minority who remain over in each Province will be held as hostages for the good behaviour of the majority in the
('93', 133, 5, 20, 269071) 1 N. K. Bose who wrote this on behalf of Gandhiji, explains : “A correspondent named Jagneswar Ghosh has sent a letter from Chinsurah in which he proposes that Bengal should be partitioned, because, after all, the cultures of the Hindus and Muslims of this Province are incompatible with one another.”
('93', 134, 0, 1, 269373) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 135
('93', 134, 1, 2, 269421) neighbouring Province.
('93', 134, 1, 3, 269444) This would amount to an armed truce and not peace on terms of equality, friendship and mutual trust.
('93', 134, 1, 4, 269545) To cut up India into specifically religious zones, and then redistribute population to fit in with such an artificial scheme would, in Gandhiji’s opinion, be monstrous.
('93', 134, 1, 5, 269714) For it will cut across many of the linguistic, cultural and fundamental bonds of co operation which have held together our people in the past.
('93', 134, 2, 6, 269857) My Days with Gandhi, pp.

('93', 134, 4, 8, 269963) Gandhiji can only ask an evacuee to return to his house if he can do so with full reliance upon God.
('93', 134, 4, 9, 270064) Those who do not feel the necessary confidence in themselves, can certainly not be advised to return.
('93', 134, 5, 10, 270166) Gandhiji keenly feels that any word from his mouth cannot bring courage to anyone; and he would not therefore advise any person to return home by relying upon such a frail reed.

('93', 135, 4, 20, 272362) 182. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SRIRAMPUR, December 12, 1946 Indeed this 1 is the meaning of hymns wherever they are sung by saints and devotees.
('93', 135, 4, 21, 272506) They always say: “Lead us from darkness to light, from untruth to truth.” The Ramdhun has also a story behind it.
('93', 135, 4, 22, 272620) Once Saint Tulsidas was touring on foot different shrines even as Chaitanya Mahaprabhu had walked to Puri and Brindavan, and reached the temple of Dakore.
('93', 135, 4, 23, 272775) That temple is dedicated to Vishnu.
('93', 135, 4, 24, 272811) Tulsidas said to himself that unless God revealed himself in the form of his favourite Rama, his head would not bow in obeisance.
('93', 135, 4, 25, 272941) The story has it that this happened and the devout pilgrim saw before him seated in all their glory Rama and Sita surrounded by Lakshmana, Shatrughna and Hanuman.
('93', 135, 4, 26, 273104) Hence the Ramdhun, meaning intoxication of God.
('93', 135, 5, 27, 273152) 1 The report said : “Two friends who had joined the day’s evening prayer had sung a song which Gandhiji had chosen as the theme of his after prayer speech.
('93', 135, 5, 28, 273308) The purport of the song was prayer to God to light the lamp of truth in the heart after it had been freed from the blemishes by the abundance of God’s love.”
('93', 136, 0, 1, 273466) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 137
('93', 136, 1, 2, 273514) It is enough if the prayer springs from the heart and leads us from darkness to light and from fear to fearlessness.

('93', 136, 2, 4, 273662) 183. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA December 13, 1946
('93', 136, 3, 5, 273715) BHAGWANJI, You have asked why the progress of anti untouchability work is so slow.
('93', 136, 3, 6, 273798) The reason is plain.
('93', 136, 3, 7, 273819) The problem has one feature not to be found in any other, namely, that in this case adharma has been assumed to be dharma.
('93', 136, 3, 8, 273942) It takes time to explain and understand this.
('93', 136, 3, 9, 273988) Moreover, it requires great tapascharya to convince the people that what is known as dharma is in fact adharma.
('93', 136, 3, 10, 274100) Those who would do so effectively must themselves be perfect embodiments of dharma.
('93', 136, 3, 11, 274184) None of us are that.
('93', 136, 3, 12, 274205) We are full of liking and aversion, yearn for worldly pleasures, lack the capacity to love even our enemies, are without courage and self control.
('93', 136, 3, 13, 274352) Who will, therefore, listen to us?
('93', 136, 3, 14, 274387) This work requires not so much intellectual ability as spiritual strength.
('93', 136, 3, 15, 274462) If you think over the other items of the constructive programme, the difference I have explained will become clear to you.
('93', 136, 3, 16, 274585) Please have patience and do your utmost to cultivate the virtues I have mentioned above.

('93', 137, 4, 24, 276045) 185. ADVICE TO WORKERS 2
('93', 137, 5, 25, 276070) SRIRAMPUR, December 13, 1946
('93', 137, 6, 26, 276099) The name Rakshi Dal did not appeal to Gandhiji.
('93', 137, 6, 27, 276147) Who could pretend to be the “protector” of another?
('93', 137, 6, 28, 276199) Each one had to learn the art of self protection whether it was a child of ten, a young girl or a grown up man.
('93', 137, 6, 29, 276311) If they felt they could protect themselves and others by means of violence alone, they should learn the art of warfare and the use of arms.
('93', 137, 6, 30, 276451) But in such an enterprise he could give them little aid.
('93', 137, 6, 31, 276508) Not only that, it had been his uniform experience that those who set out to protect others with the sword ended by turning oppressors themselves.
('93', 137, 6, 32, 276654) Under his plan, not many men were needed in a village for the protection of the few against many.
('93', 137, 6, 33, 276752) One or two would be enough.
('93', 137, 6, 34, 276780) If they laid down their lives in the performance of their duty without flinching and without anger in their hearts, their example would probably inspire others to exhibit non violent courage likewise, so that they would either be able to melt the hearts of their oppressors or die in the act of defending their self respect and honour in a non violent way.
('93', 137, 6, 35, 277137) He, therefore, advised the workers to turn themselves into Sevaks or servants rather than “protectors”.
('93', 137, 7, 36, 277241) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book II, pp.
('93', 137, 8, 37, 277293) 1 Ganga P. Bhatt 2 Pyarelal explains : “About a hundred workers from villages around Srirampur came to consult Gandhiji; they wanted to organize themselves into a Rakshi Dal — Protection League.”
