('93', 139, 11, 23, 280258) Gandhiji in his speech said that although hospital work was not in his line, he had responded 2 to Dr. Das Gupta’s invitation because he was given to understand that
('93', 139, 12, 24, 280424) 1 From Chandulal Dalal, Gandhi—1915 1948 : A Detailed Chronology 2 According to Chandulal Dalal, Gandhiji was opening a hospital which the Indian Medical Association had started under the guidance of Dr. J. N. Das Gupta.
('93', 140, 0, 1, 280645) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 141
('93', 140, 1, 2, 280693) the workers were actuated solely by a spirit of service.
('93', 140, 1, 3, 280750) He knew that the task was a very delicate one today.
('93', 140, 1, 4, 280803) Refugees had gathered together in camps and it was up to the workers to create an atmosphere when they could safely return to their deserted homes.
('93', 140, 1, 5, 280951) Moreover, work here was not city work but lay in the villages where insanitation and wretched water supply had to be dealt with.
('93', 140, 2, 6, 281080) Those who read his writings in the Harijan knew that for some time past he had been advocating nature cure methods.
('93', 140, 2, 7, 281196) He confessed, this was an old love for him.
('93', 140, 2, 8, 281240) His experience, as years rolled by, had been that there could be no greater healer than God Himself.
('93', 140, 2, 9, 281341) It was only when man departed from the laws of Nature as set by Him that he became subject to diseases of body and mind.
('93', 140, 2, 10, 281462) It was usual for the medical profession to pay heed to the body exclusive of the mind and the spirit.
('93', 140, 2, 11, 281564) The result was bad.
('93', 140, 2, 12, 281584) The health of all the three was their supreme concern.
('93', 140, 2, 13, 281639) Here the chief malady was fear—a feeling which not only benumbed their senses, but also inhibited every attempt to restore conditions of healthy normal living.
('93', 140, 3, 14, 281799) The speaker had heard that Muslim villagers would not go to Hindu doctors.
('93', 140, 3, 15, 281874) He hoped it was wrong.
('93', 140, 3, 16, 281897) Medical profession knew no distinction between man and man, no matter to what faith he or she belonged.
('93', 140, 4, 17, 282001) It should be the aim of doctors posted here not to depend on foreign remedies.
('93', 140, 4, 18, 282080) The countryside was teeming with potent herbs.
('93', 140, 4, 19, 282127) Ayurvedic and Unani physicians made wide use of them.
('93', 140, 4, 20, 282181) Why should not doctors with Western learning make use of these cheap remedies?
('93', 140, 4, 21, 282260) Acharya Profulla Roy 1 , Gandhiji had noticed one day, used plain mustard oil and salt, instead of depending on many oils and pastes turned out by the Bengal Chemical Works.
('93', 140, 4, 22, 282434) When asked about it, Acharya Roy laughingly replied that those things were meant for simpletons and he was not going to add to their number by using them.

('93', 143, 5, 24, 288814) G. Here there is no question of exception.
('93', 143, 5, 25, 288857) Assam rebelled and that civilly.
('93', 143, 5, 26, 288890) But we have that slavish mentality.
('93', 143, 5, 27, 288926) We look to the Congress and then feel that if we do not follow it slavishly, something will go wrong with it.
('93', 143, 5, 28, 289036) I have said that not only a Province but even an individual can rebel against the Congress and by doing so save it, assuming that he is in the right.
('93', 143, 5, 29, 289186) I have done so myself.
('93', 143, 5, 30, 289209) Congress has not attained the present stature without much travail.
('93', 143, 5, 31, 289277) I remember in 1918, I think, there was the Provincial Confer ence of the Congress workers of Gujarat at Ahmedabad.
('93', 143, 5, 32, 289392) The late Abbas Tyabjee was in the chair.
('93', 143, 5, 33, 289433) All the old guards were there.
('93', 143, 5, 34, 289464) The Ali Brothers had not yet joined hands with me fully then, as they did later on.
('93', 143, 5, 35, 289548) The late Shri Vithalbhai Patel was there, and I moved the non co operation resolution.
('93', 143, 5, 36, 289635) I was a nonentity then.
('93', 143, 5, 37, 289659) A constitutional question arose.
('93', 143, 5, 38, 289692) Could a Provincial Conference anticipate the decision
('93', 144, 0, 1, 289746) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 145
('93', 144, 1, 2, 289794) of the Congress?
('93', 144, 1, 3, 289811) I said, “Yes.” A Provincial Conference and even a single individual could anticipate the Congress for its own benefit.
('93', 144, 1, 4, 289930) In spite of opposition of the old hands, the resolution was carried.
('93', 144, 1, 5, 289999) That paved the way for the Congress to pass a similar resolution at Calcutta.
('93', 144, 1, 6, 290077) India was dumbfounded at the audacity of a Provincial Conference passing the revolutionary resolution.
('93', 144, 1, 7, 290180) We had formed a Satyagraha Sabha outside the Congress.
('93', 144, 1, 8, 290235) It was joined by Horniman 1, Sarojini Devi 2, Shankarlal 3, Umar Sobhani and Vallabhbhai.
('93', 144, 1, 9, 290325) I was ill.
('93', 144, 1, 10, 290336) The Rowlatt Act was passed.
('93', 144, 1, 11, 290364) I shook with rage.
('93', 144, 1, 12, 290383) I said to the Sardar I could do nothing unless he helped me.
('93', 144, 1, 13, 290444) Sardar was willing.
('93', 144, 1, 14, 290464) And the rest you know.
('93', 144, 1, 15, 290487) It was rebellion, but a healthy one.

('93', 146, 1, 2, 293422) 199. SPEECH AT WORKERS’ MEETING 1
('93', 146, 2, 3, 293456) SRIRAMPUR, December 16, 1946 The chief duty of a servant of a village is purification.
('93', 146, 2, 4, 293543) Today the villages are a festering sore upon the countryside.
('93', 146, 2, 5, 293605) It is no use blaming the British Government for all our ills.
('93', 146, 2, 6, 293667) The latter are going to quit India and we have already got a Government manned 2 by our own people.
('93', 146, 2, 7, 293767) When the British first established themselves firmly in India their idea was to build cities where all rich people would gravitate and help them in exploiting the countryside.
('93', 146, 2, 8, 293943) These cities were made partially beautiful; service of all kinds were made available to their inhabitants while the millions of villagers were left rotting in hopeless ignorance and misery.
('93', 146, 2, 9, 294133) Now that we have a Government manned by our own people let it not be said that they also care for the city people at the expense of the villagers.
('93', 146, 2, 10, 294280) There is a saying in Gujarati: ‘Dawn is whenever one wakes up.’ Let it be so with us.
('93', 146, 2, 11, 294366) Let the popular Government in the Provinces, whether Congress or League, wake up to the urgency of renovating India’s rural life.
('93', 146, 2, 12, 294496) But this can never be the work of the Government alone; every citizen has to take his due share in public work before we can become a great nation.
('93', 146, 3, 13, 294644) Gandhiji then drew the attention of local workers to the pitiable condition of the villages.
('93', 146, 3, 14, 294737) Clean drinking water was nowhere available, roads were in miserable condition, while the canals were choked up by water hyacinth.
('93', 146, 3, 15, 294867) Every village seemed to have more than its share of dysentery, cholera and smallpox, all of which were preventable diseases.
('93', 146, 3, 16, 294992) There were plenty of men of bad character who took every opportunity of fishing in troubled water for personal gain.
('93', 146, 3, 17, 295109) Purification of this dreadful double disease of mind and body is a task to which workers should address themselves.
('93', 146, 3, 18, 295225) India is not lacking in manpower; what is necessary is collective effort rightly directed.
('93', 146, 3, 19, 295316) Government can do much but they can only do so if there is enlightened public opinion behind them.
('93', 146, 3, 20, 295415) Men are now living like
('93', 146, 4, 21, 295439) 1 The source reported that about a couple of hours before prayer, Gandhiji had addressed a workers’ meeting and at the end of the prayer the same subject was further continued.
('93', 146, 4, 22, 295616) The text has been edited.
('93', 146, 4, 23, 295642) 2 The Interim Government had assumed office on September 2, 1946.
('93', 147, 0, 1, 295708) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 147, 1, 2, 295750) worms in villages.
('93', 147, 1, 3, 295769) Darkness will give way only to patient and persevering endeavour.
('93', 147, 1, 4, 295835) Bad men will then no longer find the environment in which they can grow or thrive.
('93', 147, 1, 5, 295918) Harmonious relations will be restored among communities when poverty and ignorance have disappeared.
('93', 147, 1, 6, 296019) It was with that object Gandhiji said that he had come to Noakhali.
('93', 147, 1, 7, 296087) He could not leave the place until his task was done.
('93', 147, 1, 8, 296141) He did not mind laying down his life in that attempt.

('93', 147, 2, 10, 296226) 200. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SRIRAMPUR, December 16, 1946
('93', 147, 3, 11, 296285) Mahatma Gandhi, making his first reference to the Constituent Assembly, mentioned the resolution 1 moved by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru at the Constituent Assembly defining the objectives which the Constituent Assembly should have.
('93', 147, 3, 12, 296513) Gandhiji said that the resolution was placed by the mover after mature consideration of every aspect of the complicated issue facing the country and with due regard to justice to all communities.
('93', 147, 4, 13, 296709) Gandhiji was sure that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru would stick to that resolution, whatever be the criticism advanced or opinion held by others.
('93', 147, 5, 14, 296850) Gandhiji also referred to Pandit Nehru’s recent visit to London where he had gone and from where he had returned not happily.
('93', 147, 5, 15, 296976) This taught the lesson that we should make our decision after careful deliberation and having full regard to truth and justice and then stick to that decision, whatever the consequences.
('93', 147, 5, 16, 297163) Gandhiji said that he felt that he must stay on here until the situation had completely improved.
('93', 147, 5, 17, 297261) His determination was inflexible, whatever other people might say or feel about it.
('93', 147, 5, 18, 297345) In this connection, Gandhiji cited the story of an artist who had painted a picture.
('93', 147, 5, 19, 297430) The artist placed it at a road corner and invited opinion on his work.
('93', 147, 5, 20, 297501) Later the artist found that his picture had been marked in every place with remarks of disapproval.
('93', 147, 5, 21, 297601) But this, Gandhiji continued, should not be taken by the artist in the light that his work was really not good.
('93', 147, 5, 22, 297713) What one thinks best one should pursue.
('93', 147, 5, 23, 297753) One should know what the wise say and see what the saints practise and then one should search one’s own heart whether it wants that thing.
('93', 147, 5, 24, 297892) One should accept immediately what others might say or do.
('93', 147, 5, 25, 297951) One must look to one’s own conscience and see if one is prepared for it.
('93', 147, 6, 26, 298024) Therefore, Gandhiji’s advice to people was not to return to their homes simply because he asked them to do so.
('93', 147, 6, 27, 298135) They should know what the wise men say, what the saints do and also what was in their own mind or heart.
('93', 147, 6, 28, 298240) Hindustan Standard, 19 12 1946
('93', 147, 7, 29, 298271) 1Vide “Constitution Assembly Resolution”

('93', 148, 3, 6, 298734) 202. NOTE ON CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY 1
('93', 148, 4, 7, 298770) SRIRAMPUR, December 17, 1946 In my opinion, it will be a grave mistake if the Constituent Assembly attempts, in the face of the boycott by the Muslim League, to frame a constitution for the whole of India.
('93', 148, 4, 8, 298976) If and when the Muslim League boycott becomes an established fact, the Constituent Assembly should have a right to frame a constitution of independence for all the Provinces, States and units that may be represented at the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 148, 4, 9, 299221) This will be an honourable and consistent position for the Constituent Assembly as it is at present constituted.
('93', 148, 4, 10, 299334) There should be no fear of another or for that matter more constituent assemblies sitting, if the attitude advised by me is taken up.
('93', 148, 4, 11, 299468) No other such constituent assembly can sit or function except under the aegis of the British Government whilst the latter functions in India.
('93', 148, 4, 12, 299610) If the British Government wills it, such other constituent assemblies cannot [be] prevented except through a terrible struggle put up by the Congress, whether of a violent or non violent nature.
('93', 148, 4, 13, 299805) I feel too that the Congress can subscribe to the contention of the British Government about Grouping if it allows Assam and the Frontier Province to secede from the Congress for the purposes of the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 148, 4, 14, 300026) The Congress has no power save the moral to compel obedience by a Province or a group such as Sikhs.
('93', 148, 5, 15, 300127) Sardar Patel’s Correspondence, Vol. 3, p.

('93', 151, 1, 2, 303917) You write that my confession was such a heavy punishment for Sushila that compared to that her keeping away without notice should be considered real mercy.
('93', 151, 1, 3, 304073) This I cannot swallow.
('93', 151, 1, 4, 304096) If that is so, then what I did in the case of Ba, my father and many other dear ones should be considered a mistake, is that not so ?

('93', 151, 1, 11, 304699) Suppose that A who is innocent is assaulted and abused by B. Then B repents and makes a public apology.

('93', 151, 1, 17, 305212) And anyone who has accepted my moral standard will say that it would be only proper that A also makes a public confession of his guilt.

('93', 153, 3, 11, 308988) Gandhiji was glad that members of the small Sikh community in far off Punjab considered that the problem facing East Bengal was an all India problem and that no part of the country could afford to remain indifferent to happenings in other parts.
('93', 153, 3, 12, 309234) This was a correct example which every one should emulate.
('93', 153, 3, 13, 309293) Gandhiji was particularly glad that these bold Sikh soldiers who joined the Azad Hind Fouj and fought had now come without even their kirpans 3 to work non violently for the promotion of communal harmony.
('93', 153, 3, 14, 309498) This perhaps explained the futility of violence in contrast to the efficacy and potentiality of non violence.
('93', 153, 4, 15, 309608) Introducing Mr. Asaf Ali, Member of the Interim Government, to the prayer

('93', 153, 6, 18, 309816) Gandhiji said that the Interim Government thought it desirable to have a representative in America for the purpose of interpreting India to the American people and Mr. Asaf Ali had been chosen to hold that high office and fulfil the mission entrusted to him.

('93', 154, 2, 3, 310731) Gandhiji then referred to his anger which had overcome him on Mon day night.
('93', 154, 2, 4, 310808) 2 He did not have even proper rest that night, but from half past two at night he began his work.
('93', 154, 2, 5, 310906) In this connection Gandhiji related how once his father was angry when Gandhiji went to see a theatre.
('93', 154, 2, 6, 311009) But his angry father did not say anything to him.
('93', 154, 2, 7, 311059) Instead, he (his father) began to weep and beat his head.
('93', 154, 2, 8, 311117) Similarly, he at the time of his anger that night began to beat his own head.
('93', 154, 2, 9, 311195) But he did not like to weep like others.
('93', 154, 2, 10, 311236) Instead he wanted to unburden his heavy heart by placing before the whole world what mistake he had committed by being angry.
('93', 154, 2, 11, 311362) For he knew that a man of ‘ahimsa’ like him should not be angry.
('93', 154, 2, 12, 311427) But he tried his best to suppress his own anger, but so far he had not completely succeeded.
('93', 154, 2, 13, 311520) He said : 3
('93', 154, 3, 14, 311532) I am not a Mahatma; I am an alpatma.
('93', 154, 3, 15, 311569) I am an ordinary mortal like you all and I am strenuously trying to practise ahimsa.
('93', 154, 3, 16, 311654) Today I lost my temper and, therefore, I am not a perfect man.
('93', 154, 3, 17, 311717) If an imperfect man like me can try to practise ahimsa, all of you also can do so.
('93', 154, 3, 18, 311800) I have come here with the determination to put my ahimsa to test and in that process either succeed or perish.
('93', 154, 4, 19, 311911) He said that every personal act had to be dominated by truth and non violence if they were to be evidenced in big things.
('93', 154, 4, 20, 312033) These were not wooden things but living organisms.
('93', 154, 4, 21, 312084) He felt that he had not attained the necessary stage of detachment described in the Gita.
('93', 154, 5, 22, 312174) He asked his hearers to discard the thought that what one man could do was not possible for all human beings even if a persistent attempt was made.
('93', 154, 5, 23, 312322) It was simple wisdom to remember that man’s vocation was to make the attempt and God’s grace alone could bless it with success.
('93', 154, 6, 24, 312450) Hindustan Standard, 20 12 1946 and 22 12 1946; and The Hindu, 20 12 1946 and 21 12 1946

('93', 156, 1, 2, 314862) 211. LETTER TO N. G. RANGA
('93', 156, 2, 3, 314889) SRIRAMPUR, NOAKHALI, December 18, 1946
('93', 156, 3, 4, 314928) MY DEAR RANGA 1, I have your letter of the 11th instant and the enclosures.
('93', 156, 3, 5, 315004) You ask me not to wade through the latter but ask my Secretary to go through them and bring to my notice the most important things.
('93', 156, 3, 6, 315136) You do not know what I am doing and where I am staying.
('93', 156, 3, 7, 315192) If you did, you would not have dictated that letter, but I see that you are too busy to look at the daily papers or my poor doings in this part of the world.
('93', 156, 3, 8, 315350) Well, I am in an out of the way village hamlet where many dwellings have been burnt down and the contents looted.
('93', 156, 3, 9, 315464) I have deprived myself of secretarial assistance.
('93', 156, 3, 10, 315514) I have a Bengali professor who has elected to become my interpreter and teacher and even gives me massage, etc.
('93', 156, 3, 11, 315626) Parasuram of Malabar is with me by accident, and as he came to me as an expert short hand writer and typist I make occasional use of him for taking down letters such as this.
('93', 156, 3, 12, 315801) But generally he is in the charge of everything pertaining to my personal wants and I am sorry to confess that this business is so taxing and exacting that it takes the bulk of his time.
('93', 156, 3, 13, 315988) But he is an uncomplaining, tireless worker, and as he had not had the opportunity of coming in personal touch with me during the two years he has been with me, he loves the work that he is doing now and I love him.
('93', 156, 3, 14, 316204) Other fellow workers have been distributed at the peril of their lives in various burnt and looted villages in the attempt to bring the two warring elements together and bring, if human effort can, peace to this unhappy portion of India.
('93', 156, 3, 15, 316442) I confess that it is not the only unhappy portion of India, but Destiny chose it for putting me or rather my ahimsa and truth on their trial and here am I undergoing that stiff but self imposed test.
('93', 156, 3, 16, 316642) Therefore, you see that either I must myself wade through your papers or neglect them for the time being.
('93', 156, 3, 17, 316748) But I dare not take the second course for the reason that I invited the task, and I must not complain.
('93', 156, 3, 18, 316851) I am half through the long documents.
('93', 156, 3, 19, 316889) It is deeply human and interesting and for the love I have towards you I will like to give much more than cursory attention to the papers you have prepared with such
('93', 156, 4, 20, 317055) 1 President, All India Kisan Sabha; President, Andhra Provincial Congress Committee; Member, Congress Parliamentary Party; Founder President, Swatantra Party.

('93', 157, 1, 2, 317256) elaboration.
('93', 157, 1, 3, 317269) As so many trustworthy servants of the nation are up against you, I wish to suggest that you should, for the time being, neglect me and go your way honestly and therefore fearlessly, reposing the fullest trust in your honesty rather than on friends like me of doubtful value because of their national preoccupations and limited capacity for grasping and understanding facts, figures and statements.
('93', 157, 1, 4, 317668) I however promise that I shall pursue such inquiry as I can during the moments that I can snatch from my present work, and if I can say anything useful I shall write to you.
('93', 157, 1, 5, 317842) You on your part will not hesitate to give me all the facts you can.

('93', 160, 9, 12, 322430) In view of the Muslim League revolt, I would go so far as to question the prudence of flying in America the Congress flag as our National Flag.

('93', 160, 9, 15, 322823) These he can neither diminish nor extend.
('93', 160, 9, 16, 322865) 2. As to the second, India as she is at present cannot omit the Union Jack in foreign countries.
('93', 160, 9, 17, 322962) Take instructions.

('93', 161, 5, 12, 324573) DEAR FRIEND, I wrote to you three letters–one dated 3 12 46 1 on the general situation, a second dated 4 12 46 regarding Sardar Bahadur Sir Datar Singh’s suggestion and a third in reply to your letters of 2nd and 3rd December.
('93', 161, 5, 13, 324800) 2 I am sorry that all the letters have remained unanswered.
('93', 161, 5, 14, 324860) I can only ascribe to heavy pressure on you the absence of any communication from you.
('93', 161, 5, 15, 324947) I took the liberty of sending to Abdulla Saheb three complaints which had come under my notice—one of very recent murder, another of rape and third of loot.
('93', 161, 5, 16, 325104) He was good enough to call on me yesterday and to tell me the result of his investigation which he was good enough to hold very promptly.
('93', 161, 5, 17, 325242) The first one he said was true as to the event itself but not sustained about the culprits named.
('93', 161, 5, 18, 325340) I believe the guilty parties are being traced.
('93', 161, 5, 19, 325387) The second has been found by him to be a concoction.
('93', 161, 5, 20, 325440) The third is found to be true and is being pursued.

('93', 162, 1, 2, 325663) For me the relevance for the purpose of this letter lies in the fact that the trouble is not over and the fear is not wholly without foundation.
('93', 162, 1, 3, 325808) Indeed, complaints have been almost daily coming to me showing how difficult the problem is.
('93', 162, 1, 4, 325901) If you can possibly regard me as a well wisher of your Ministry and of the Muslim League, you will please continue as you began to let at least one Minister to be on the spot and keep himself in touch with me.
('93', 162, 1, 5, 326111) If this expectation is too great or cannot be fulfilled, you will please tell me whether you approve of my keeping in touch with the District Magistrate and the Superintendent of Police to whom I could directly refer the matters which come under my notice and which I consider to be worthy of being put before them.

('93', 162, 5, 13, 326792) 221. LETTER TO D. B. KALELKAR SRIRAMPUR, December 20, 1946
('93', 162, 6, 14, 326851) KAKA, Your letter of the 6th arrived at Kazirkhil on the 12th.
('93', 162, 6, 15, 326914) It seems to have been given to me on the 16th.
('93', 162, 6, 16, 326961) I have been meaning to reply to it every day since then, but could manage to dictate this only now at 5.15 (local time) after the morning prayer.

('93', 165, 5, 9, 331982) 225. INTERVIEW TO RAYMOND CARTIER 2
('93', 165, 6, 10, 332018) December 20, 1946
('93', 165, 7, 11, 332036) As soon as the French gentleman entered the room Gandhiji greeted him in French “Comment allez vous?” 3 And then added with a loud laughter that he had exhausted his entire stock of French !
('93', 165, 8, 12, 332227) The visitor was surprised and was all smiles on hearing Gandhiji greeting him in French.
('93', 165, 9, 13, 332316) Gandhiji then told him that he had learnt some French in his school days.
('93', 165, 9, 14, 332390) Gandhiji then referred to Victor Hugo and said that he could still picture before his mind “Jean Valjean” crawling through the lanes of Paris.
('93', 165, 10, 15, 332533) Gandhiji then told Cartier that he had been to Paris thrice and had on every occasion wanted to stay in the quarters inhabited by the poor.
('93', 165, 10, 16, 332673) It was surprising, he said, that the first city of the world in regard to fashion, luxury and certain other things should have miserable slums lying in the heart of the city.
('93', 165, 11, 17, 332848) On being asked by Cartier as to what Gandhiji thought about the present condition of Europe, Gandhiji said that people of Europe were talking of peace but harboured war in their hearts.
('93', 165, 11, 18, 333034) Unless they shed violence from their hearts, it was not possible for them to have peace.
('93', 165, 12, 19, 333123) 1The subscription is in Gujarati.

('93', 165, 12, 21, 333309) He arrived in the afternoon when Gandhiji was taking nature cure treatment with an earth bandage on forehead and eyes closed.

('93', 166, 0, 1, 333518) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 167
('93', 166, 1, 2, 333566) When the last war began, Gandhiji said, he had felt that unless Europe changed its ways this war would only be a prelude to a third and more disastrous war.
('93', 166, 2, 3, 333723) Raymond Cartier asked: “We who are children of violence in Europe, how do you expect us to become non violent?”
('93', 166, 3, 4, 333835) In reply, Gandhiji said that if they continued like this, they were sure to perish.
('93', 166, 3, 5, 333919) What had happened in Europe was that Hitlerism had only been destroyed by super Hitlerism and this chain was endless.
('93', 166, 3, 6, 334037) It would go on like that.
('93', 166, 4, 7, 334063) Raymond Cartier asked if the remedy lay in a new form of education.
('93', 166, 5, 8, 334131) Gandhiji said that education must be of a new type for the sake of the creation of a new world.
('93', 166, 5, 9, 334227) He referred to Aldous Huxley 2, who, he observed, represented a new type of thought which was working in the mind of Europe today.
('93', 166, 5, 10, 334358) It might be in a minority today but if Europe was to save itself from suicide, something along the lines of non violence had to be adopted.
('93', 166, 6, 11, 334498) Asked as to how it would be possible to destroy Hitlerism by non violence, Gandhiji said that was what we had to find out.
('93', 166, 6, 12, 334621) Otherwise, if one depended upon superior violence in order to destroy violence of the Hitlerism type, then small nations would have hardly any chance of survival.
('93', 166, 6, 13, 334784) It was only when a nation individually refused to be beaten by Hitlerism or any combination of forces of violence, and stuck to its post at the cost of its life, but not at the cost of its honour, that it had a chance of survival.
('93', 166, 6, 14, 335015) So, non violence was the only guarantee of protection against the heaviest odds.
('93', 166, 6, 15, 335096) Unless we could develop this courage and this type of resistance, democracy could never survive.
('93', 166, 7, 16, 335193) Cartier next asked, how France could have at all survived if it had not defended itself against the Nazi hordes.
('93', 166, 8, 17, 335306) Gandhiji replied that for that matter even the Maginot Line had not availed them much.
('93', 166, 8, 18, 335393) Hitler had reduced it to nothingness.
('93', 166, 9, 19, 335431) Cartier said that the fault lay not in the principle; it was a technical flaw in the Maginot Line to which military strategists attributed its collapse.
('93', 166, 9, 20, 335584) Gandhiji rejoined : Maybe; but beyond that there is a deeper flaw which is funda mental to the whole philosophy of the Maginot Line.
('93', 166, 9, 21, 335717) Unless you can better Hitler in violence, you cannot gain victory.
('93', 166, 9, 22, 335784) But the moment you

('93', 170, 4, 11, 342828) 230. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 170, 5, 12, 342860) SRIRAMPUR, December 21, 1946
('93', 170, 6, 13, 342889) Gandhiji began by saying that he held very strong views on the question of charity.
('93', 170, 6, 14, 342973) It was wrong both to accept as well as to offer anyone a free gift.
('93', 170, 6, 15, 343041) In our land irreligion often masqueraded in the name of religion.
('93', 170, 6, 16, 343107) India was said to have a contingent of 56 lakhs of religious mendicants, not many of whom could be considered worthy in any sense.
('93', 170, 6, 17, 343238) Even the hateful custom of untouchability had been given sanction of religion in this land of sorrow.
('93', 170, 7, 18, 343340) The problem of relief and rehabilitation, Gandhiji went to say, had become a serious one.
('93', 170, 7, 19, 343430) People from all over India were eager to help the afflicted inhabitants of Noakhali with money or free gifts of all kinds, and there was a chance that the latter might slip into a mentality of willing dependence on public charity.
('93', 170, 7, 20, 343661) This had to be combated as much as the complacence of those who might feel they were acquiring religious merit through charitable gifts.
('93', 170, 8, 21, 343798) Referring to the attitude which the Government should exercise with regard to the refugees in comparison with that held by public charitable bodies, Gandhiji proceeded to explain that it was true that people had gathered in the refugee camps for no fault of theirs.
('93', 170, 8, 22, 344064) Their homes had been burnt and they were without shelter; others had been robbed of all their belongings although their cottages might still be standing, while a third group had deserted their homes mainly from a feeling of insecurity.
('93', 170, 8, 23, 344300) It should be the object of the Government to deal with each case on its merits and help the people to return home with a feeling of security.
('93', 170, 9, 24, 344442) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”
('93', 171, 0, 1, 344477) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 171, 1, 2, 344519) Before necessary conditions were created, it would not be right for the authorities to stop rations unless the evacuees went back home with their whole families.
('93', 171, 1, 3, 344681) If the evacuees were expected to brave hardships and perhaps even death in order to reinstate themselves in their homes, then there would be no need of a state; it would be a condition of enlightened anarchy where every man would be able to protect himself by his own strength in the face of the greatest danger.
('93', 171, 1, 4, 344994) But as things stood today, much of the necessary work of social service had to be conducted by Governmental organizations.
('93', 171, 2, 5, 345117) Adequate protection had to be given and an atmosphere created where the people might once more pursue their life’s work in peace.
('93', 171, 2, 6, 345247) So long as the conditions were not forthcoming, arrangements for relief had to continue.
('93', 171, 3, 7, 345336) But the case of public charitable societies stood on an entirely different footing.
('93', 171, 3, 8, 345420) Gandhiji held it was wrong for any man to live on public doles.
('93', 171, 3, 9, 345484) While the South African satyagraha was going on, large sums of money were donated to cover the expenses of the satyagrahis.
('93', 171, 3, 10, 345608) The Tolstoy Farm near Lawley in the Transvaal was established to accommodate the families and dependents of satyagrahis who worked to the best of their ability for their upkeep.
('93', 171, 3, 11, 345786) Consequently, the satyagraha organization was able to refund large sums of money at the end of the campaign.
('93', 171, 4, 12, 345895) In accordance with the same principles, the charitable institutions now working here should plainly tell the people that everyone should deem it a dishonour to eat a single meal without honest labour.
('93', 171, 4, 13, 346096) If we could shed the aversion to labour and adapt ourselves to unexpected changes of fortune, we would go a long way towards the acquisition of fearlessness and thus towards an upliftment of our national character.
('93', 171, 5, 14, 346311) He would venture to tell the refugees that whether they were poor or rich, they should say to the authorities that they would consider it below human dignity to accept doles from the Government.
('93', 171, 5, 15, 346506) Poor or rich had nothing left to them.
('93', 171, 5, 16, 346545) Therefore, they were in need of food, clothing, shelter and medical assistance.
('93', 171, 5, 17, 346625) Therefore, they had a claim upon the State for providing these vital necessities of life.
('93', 171, 5, 18, 346715) But they would be robbing society if they accepted this aid without each healthy man, woman, boy or girl, labouring to the extent of his or her ability and therefore he would like the Government to provide such useful work for society which they were capable of doing.
('93', 171, 5, 19, 346984) Harijan, 19 1 1947
('93', 172, 0, 1, 347003) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 173

('93', 181, 1, 2, 364459) 244. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 181, 2, 3, 364491) SRIRAMPUR, December 23, 1946
('93', 181, 3, 4, 364520) Gandhiji first referred to certain personal letters addressed to him as well as a number of articles or comments published in newspapers in which the opinion had been expressed that his continued presence in Noakhali was acting as a deterrent to the restoration of cordial relations between the Hindus and Muslims for his intention was to bring discredit upon the League Ministry in Bengal.
('93', 181, 4, 5, 364911) Two days ago he had tried to refute a rumour that a satyagraha movement of an extensive character was secretly planned by him in Noakhali.
('93', 181, 4, 6, 365050) He had already said that nothing could be done by him in secret.
('93', 181, 4, 7, 365115) If recourse were taken to secrecy and falsehood, satyagraha would degenerate into duragraha.
('93', 181, 5, 8, 365208) Today he found it necessary to answer the second charge levelled against him, to which reference had already been made.
('93', 181, 5, 9, 365328) He would like to proclaim that he had come to Bengal solely with the object of establishing heart unity between the two communities, who had become estranged from one another.
('93', 181, 5, 10, 365504) When that object was satisfactorily achieved, there would no longer be any necessity for him to prolong his stay.
('93', 181, 6, 11, 365618) His intention could never be to embarrass the League Government in Bengal, Gandhiji added.
('93', 181, 6, 12, 365709) On the other hand, his relations with the Ministry, as well as with the officials, had been very cordial and he had been able to gather the impression that all of them looked with favour upon his peace mission.
('93', 181, 6, 13, 365920) He had discovered no indication yet of his presence causing embarrassment to anyone.
('93', 181, 6, 14, 366005) It was open to the Government to ask the Magistrate and the Superintendent of Police to convince him of his error if they were themselves convinced.
('93', 181, 6, 15, 366154) As yet they had said not a word to that effect.
('93', 181, 6, 16, 366202) If he felt convinced of any error on his part, he would leave.
('93', 181, 7, 17, 366265) Gandhiji said that he had enough work to do elsewhere which demanded his attention.
('93', 181, 7, 18, 366349) There was Uruli Kanchan, the seat of his nature cure experiments, and Sevagram, and there was Delhi again, where he might be of some service.
('93', 181, 7, 19, 366491) He would love to spare trouble to the leaders who had to come to this out of the way place in order to consult him.
('93', 181, 7, 20, 366607) But personally he felt convinced that the work undertaken by him here was of the greatest importance for all India.
('93', 181, 7, 21, 366723) If he succeeded in his present mission, it was bound to have a profound influence on the future of India, and, if he might be permitted to say so, even on the future peace of the world, for it was to be a test of faith in non violence.
('93', 181, 8, 22, 366959) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”
('93', 182, 0, 1, 366994) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 183
('93', 182, 1, 2, 367042) A copy of the Bihar Provincial Muslim League Report on the Bihar atrocities had been sent to him.
('93', 182, 1, 3, 367140) He had gone through it with care and had felt that it bristled with over statements.
('93', 182, 1, 4, 367225) Nevertheless, he was making inquiries on the basis of the report.
('93', 182, 1, 5, 367291) It was certainly true that much that had happened in Bihar was brutal enough and deserved the severest condemnation.
('93', 182, 1, 6, 367408) The overstatement blurred the gruesomeness of the reality.
('93', 182, 1, 7, 367467) He was assured that calm had been restored.
('93', 182, 1, 8, 367511) It was on that assurance that normal diet was resumed by him.
('93', 182, 2, 9, 367573) The reason why he had not proceeded to Bihar, Gandhiji explained, was that he could exercise his personal influence effectively even from a distance.
('93', 182, 2, 10, 367723) But if there were any reason to suspect that things still continued in Bihar in the manner described in the League report and that he had been misled by false assurance of his friends, then his place would surely be in that Province and he might even confess that this might imply that the life in the present body was now over and that there was no longer any room for him in the land of the living.
('93', 182, 3, 11, 368124) But he could not help uttering a word of warning that leaders of public opinion had a serious responsibility.
('93', 182, 3, 12, 368234) Their word would be believed by the credulous public, and they all knew the tragic consequences.
('93', 182, 3, 13, 368331) This he said irrespective of whether the leaders belonged to the Congress or the Muslim League.
('93', 182, 4, 14, 368427) Harijan, 19 1 1947

('93', 183, 4, 8, 370098) 246. LETTER TO H. S. SUHRAWARDY
('93', 183, 5, 9, 370130) December 24, 1946
('93', 183, 6, 10, 370148) MY DEAR SHAHEED, I remind you of our pleasant meeting in Faridpur when Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das was still in his physical case.
('93', 183, 6, 11, 370279) If I remember rightly, you were the only one sitting in front of me spinning assiduously, though you were unable to pull an even or fine thread.
('93', 183, 6, 12, 370424) And then, if I remember rightly, when I applied to you some distant adjective of affection, you corrected me by saying that you felt as son to me.
('93', 183, 6, 13, 370571) I would like to think still that you are the same Shaheed and to feel proud that my son has become Chief Minister of Bengal.
('93', 183, 7, 14, 370696) I wish you had Bengal on the brain rather than Bihar.
('93', 183, 7, 15, 370750) Assume the truth of all that has been said in the Bihar provincial Muslim League's reports.
('93', 183, 7, 16, 370842) You do not want to satisfy yourself by thanking God for Bengal being as bad as Bihar.
('93', 183, 7, 17, 370928) You seem to believe the stories of Bihar cruelties with which you have been regaled.
('93', 183, 7, 18, 371013) I frankly confess to you that these reports do not carry conviction to me.
('93', 183, 7, 19, 371088) If even 50 per cent of the stories are true, life would become a burden for me.
('93', 183, 7, 20, 371168) You should know that though here, I was able to affect events in Bihar by my putting myself on protein and fat free diet and by my proposal, if things did not mend, to undertake complete fast.
('93', 183, 8, 21, 371361) Though I have not come out publicly, and I hope I shall

('93', 184, 4, 14, 372536) 247. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 184, 5, 15, 372568) SRIRAMPUR, December 24, 1946
('93', 184, 6, 16, 372597) Gandhiji began his speech by saying that complaints had been pouring in that people were unable to shed their fear because persons known to be guilty were freely moving about.
('93', 184, 6, 17, 372773) He said that although this might be true, his advice to them would still be to take courage in both hands and return to their homes.
('93', 184, 6, 18, 372906) When several persons had complained that the amount offered by the Government for rebuilding was inadequate for the erection of any kind of shelter, he felt sure that the Government which was determined on repatriation would extend their aid to the necessary extent.
('93', 184, 7, 19, 373173) What Gandhiji would personally prefer was that the refugees should be resourceful enough to tide over the present difficulty.
('93', 184, 7, 20, 373299) He would honour a man who begged nothing for himself nor depended on outside aid for protection.
('93', 184, 7, 21, 373396) If anyone depended on him for that purpose, he was depending on a broken reed.

('93', 189, 6, 18, 383885) 252. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 189, 7, 19, 383915) SRIRAMPUR, December 25, 1946
('93', 189, 8, 20, 383944) Sailen Chatterjee who appeared to Gandhiji more as a fellow worker in the cause of independence than a journalist, asked him whether he would, in his post prayer remarks, say something about Christianity because it was Christmas Day and reminded him that he had done some such thing on the previous Christmas Day.
('93', 189, 8, 21, 384258) Gandhiji said he had not thought of it though he should have .
('93', 189, 9, 22, 384321) He said he was thankful for the reminder and he informed the audience that he had accepted the suggestion without the slightest hesitation.
('93', 189, 9, 23, 384461) Then he had to think about what he should say.
('93', 189, 9, 24, 384508) He was baffled about his choice for he said that it was almost universally realized that everywhere irreligion masqueraded as religion.
('93', 189, 10, 25, 384644) Whilst he was searching for something apposite for the occasion he thought of two beautiful note books in which Rajkumari had copied out gems from the Bible and Christian hymns.
('93', 189, 10, 26, 384822) Rajkumari had been chosen by Pandit Nehru, their Foreign Minister at the Centre, as a member of the deputation on behalf of the Government of India to represent it in the Educational Conference that was held in Paris.
('93', 189, 10, 27, 385040) She was a member of the ruling family of Kapurthala.
('93', 189, 10, 28, 385093) Her father would have occupied the gadi,
('93', 190, 0, 1, 385134) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 191
('93', 190, 1, 2, 385182) but for his being a Christian.
('93', 190, 2, 3, 385213) Rajkumari was proud of being considered a Sikh, a Hindu and a Christian and had chosen to throw in her lot with those who were downtrodden.
('93', 190, 2, 4, 385353) He would invite the audience to give thought to the best from Christianity which he had selected from Rajkumari's collection.
('93', 190, 2, 5, 385479) Only a few days ago he commended to their attention two of the best sayings from Prophet Mohammed.
('93', 190, 3, 6, 385578) He believed in equal regard for all religions.
('93', 190, 3, 7, 385625) Mere tolerance was not of much value.
('93', 190, 3, 8, 385663) No religion worth the name stood in need of patronage.
('93', 190, 3, 9, 385718) It should command respect.
('93', 190, 3, 10, 385745) He added that Jesus Christ might be looked upon as belonging to Christians only but he really did not belong to any community inasmuch as the lesson that Jesus Christ gave belonged to the whole world 1 .
('93', 190, 3, 11, 385949) So saying, he asked Prof.
('93', 190, 3, 12, 385975) Nirmal Bose to translate the following 2 from the New Testament on love, which he preferred to render as ahimsa.
('93', 190, 4, 13, 386088) Hindustan Standard, 30 12 1946; and Harijan, 26 1 1947

('93', 191, 4, 8, 387725) 254. LETTER TO MANILAL B. DESAI
('93', 191, 5, 9, 387757) SRIRAMPUR, December 26, 1946
('93', 191, 6, 10, 387786) MANILAL, I got your letter and the supplement.
('93', 191, 6, 11, 387833) I cannot recollect the letter which you mention, and am not bothering to search for it.
('93', 191, 6, 12, 387921) Strictly speaking, the suggestion about cows does not fall within the scope of the Trust.
('93', 191, 6, 13, 388011) You can establish contact with the Goseva Sangh.
('93', 191, 6, 14, 388060) If you try to do that work, you will not be able to do the work you have undertaken.
('93', 191, 6, 15, 388145) In attempting an ambitious plan, you may fail in both the tasks like the sadhu who lost both this world and the next.
('93', 191, 6, 16, 388263) Or you may undertake the work in consultation with somebody who knows it.
('93', 191, 6, 17, 388337) The idea of making the Arogyabhavan self supporting is not a bad one.
('93', 191, 6, 18, 388407) But if you engage two persons for that work, no work will be done and your plan for starting cultivation will have to be abandoned.
('93', 191, 6, 19, 388539) The difficulty about money can be met.
('93', 191, 6, 20, 388578) It is not necessary to employ some persons specially for that purpose.
('93', 191, 6, 21, 388649) As soon as I know the final decision, I shall be able to find the money.
('93', 191, 6, 22, 388722) You will of course need a well.
('93', 191, 6, 23, 388754) Get one sunk.
('93', 191, 6, 24, 388768) I think you mean a deep well to be sunk at a cost of Rs. 4,000. I am inclined towards a well of that type.
('93', 191, 6, 25, 388875) Or, we can have the type of water works constructed by the military and can draw the water in the same way as they do.
('93', 191, 6, 26, 388994) I think we can get enough water from the water works built by them.
('93', 191, 6, 27, 389062) We cannot have a buffalo in the goshala.
('93', 191, 6, 28, 389103) I have no doubt on this point.
('93', 191, 6, 29, 389134) If we do not insist on having cows only, you may rest assured that they will die out.
('93', 191, 6, 30, 389220) And the cow will always be followed by the buffalo.
('93', 191, 6, 31, 389272) Animal husbandry experts have finally come to this conclusion.
('93', 191, 6, 32, 389335) I cannot judge about buying the plot belonging to Patangiya.
('93', 191, 6, 33, 389396) All that I can say is that you may do what you think best.
('93', 192, 0, 1, 389455) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 193
('93', 192, 1, 2, 389503) I think this answers all your questions.
('93', 192, 1, 3, 389544) It is, therefore, not necessary for you to travel all this distance.
('93', 192, 1, 4, 389613) I am dictating this letter after waking up at three in the morning.
('93', 192, 1, 5, 389681) I don't have the courage, therefore, to try to write to Dr. Bhagwat, Dhirubhai and others, as it is nearing four o'clock now and I have to start preparing for the prayer.

('93', 196, 2, 4, 396483) He was soon going to make the greatest experiment of his life .
('93', 196, 2, 5, 396547) That would be perhaps his last experiment.
('93', 196, 2, 6, 396590) He was not a holder of any Degree—B.A. or M.A. But if he succeeded in the examination he was taking in Noakhali, he would think he had received his highest Degree of life—his M.A. And if he succeeded in this examination of his, he would share all that he achieved together with his Degree with the forty crores of people of this country.
('93', 196, 3, 7, 396928) Continuing, Gandhiji said that the task he had undertaken in Bengal was most serious.
('93', 196, 3, 8, 397014) Here a community which had been friendly to him previously now looked upon him as its enemy.

('93', 196, 8, 19, 398448) There is falsehood all round.
('93', 196, 9, 20, 398478) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book II, p.114
('93', 196, 10, 21, 398532) 1 This paragraph is reproduced from The Hindu.
('93', 197, 0, 1, 398579) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 197, 1, 2, 398621) 263. LETTER TO HAMIDUDDIN AHMED 1
('93', 197, 2, 3, 398655) December 27, 1946
('93', 197, 3, 4, 398673) DEAR HAMIDUDDIN SAHEB, Nirmal Babu read to me your writing in the Azad of the 14th instant.
('93', 197, 3, 5, 398765) It staggered me and I asked him kindly to give me its literal translation.
('93', 197, 3, 6, 398840) If there is any incorrectness, you will please send me your correction.
('93', 197, 3, 7, 398912) I say it staggered me, because you had left an impression on me that you had entirely realized my sincerity and my usefulness not merely for the Hindu inhabitants of the district but equally for the Muslim inhabitants.
('93', 197, 3, 8, 399131) Assuming the accuracy of the translation, your article is an indictment against me.
('93', 197, 3, 9, 399215) Indeed, most of us were under the impression that while Shamsuddin Saheb was leaving for a few days to meet the Chief Minister, You would be staying behind to continue his work and help the Peace Committees that were just then being formed.
('93', 197, 3, 10, 399456) But the next day, I learned with sorrow that owing to some affliction of your eyes you had to leave abruptly with Shamsuddin Saheb.
('93', 197, 3, 11, 399588) What had happened in the meanwhile to warrant what I have called your indictment I do not know.
('93', 197, 3, 12, 399684) Why do you in common with many advisers advise me to leave Noakhali and go to Bihar or somewhere else?
('93', 197, 4, 13, 399787) I have not come to East Bengal to hold an enquiry.
('93', 197, 4, 14, 399838) I have come to make my humble contribution to a lasting and heart peace between the two communities.
('93', 197, 4, 15, 399939) I think that I made this statement during the speeches I had made in your presence.
('93', 197, 4, 16, 400023) Why then the sudden change betrayed by the article in question ?
('93', 197, 4, 17, 400088) Do you not think that after the exuberant regard you showed for me, I had the right to expect from you a friendly and personal enquiry from me, to inform me of the change and giving the grounds for the change?
('93', 197, 4, 18, 400298) Perhaps, on reflection, you will discover in your very article valid reason for my longing to be in Noakhali in preference to Bihar.
('93', 197, 4, 19, 400431) How can I test the efficacy and soundness of my ahimsa except in a place where even the loudest protestations of trust in my professions can be so short lived as in your case ?
('93', 197, 4, 20, 400608) You are right when you say: "In Mr. Gandhi's opinion, the
('93', 197, 5, 21, 400666) 1 Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Commerce, Government of Bengal 2Vide also “Letter to Members of Feni Sub Division Muslim League”, 25 12 1946
('93', 198, 0, 1, 400821) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 199
('93', 198, 1, 2, 400869) condition in Noakhali is not yet such that Hindus can shoulder the responsibility of returning to their homes." I have chapter and verse to show why the Hindu refugees who proved themselves deficient in personal courage are reluctant to go back to their homes.
('93', 198, 1, 3, 401130) The peace Committees which you left in the process of formation are not in working order.
('93', 198, 1, 4, 401220) The Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries would not return to their work of seeing the Committees doing their duty.
('93', 198, 1, 5, 401338) I urge you for the sake of the League Ministry in whose efficiency and goodness I am at least as much interested as you ever can be.
('93', 198, 1, 6, 401471) Believe me, I have not come to East Bengal for the purpose of finding fault with the League.
('93', 198, 1, 7, 401564) I have come in order to induce it by my conduct to shed its complacency and give solid work for the sake of itself and india.
('93', 198, 1, 8, 401690) For I believe that if you and I can produce in Bengal the right atmosphere, the whole of India will follow.
('93', 198, 1, 9, 401798) You say, again :“If he (Gandhi) had issued a statement about the real nature of the happenings, perhaps the atmosphere would have cleared to a large extent.
('93', 198, 1, 10, 401955) His silence with reference to this matter raises suspicion in the minds of many .” Why this insinuation when the fact stares you in the face that I am not in a position to speak in praise of what has been and is being done on behalf of the Bengal Government?
('93', 198, 1, 11, 402214) If you will care to study the thing, you will appreciate restraint instead of coaxing me to speak.
('93', 198, 1, 12, 402313) You are again right when you say: “Mr. Gandhi does not wish to leave for Bihar.” But your reasons for reluctance are wholly wrong.
('93', 198, 1, 13, 402444) My “trusted Bihari followers” have indeed kept me informed of the happenings there.
('93', 198, 1, 14, 402528) The information they give is wholly contrary to what you believe.
('93', 198, 1, 15, 402594) In common with all, the Bihar Government deplore the tragic happenings.
('93', 198, 1, 16, 402666) But they claim that they have acquired control over the turbulent elements and are straining every nerve to give satisfaction to the afflicted.
('93', 198, 1, 17, 402810) It will not serve the cause of peace if I went to Bihar and found the Bihar Muslim League’s report to be largely imaginary and the Bihar Government’s conduct substantially honourable, humane and just.
('93', 198, 1, 18, 403011) I am not anxious to give them a certificate of good conduct as I am to give you, much though you may not want it.
('93', 198, 1, 19, 403125) My spare diet and contemplated fast, you know well, were against the Bihar misdoings.
('93', 198, 1, 20, 403211) I could not take such a step in the matter of Noakhali misdoings.
('93', 198, 1, 21, 403277) It pains me to think that you, a seasoned lawyer, should not see the
('93', 199, 0, 1, 403346) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 199, 1, 2, 403388) obvious.
('93', 199, 1, 3, 403397) I assure you that I am not guilty of “importing numberless volunteers from outside to serve his (mine) object”.
('93', 199, 1, 4, 403509) In the first place, I have not imported numberless volunteers.
('93', 199, 1, 5, 403572) In the second place, my object is not what you have been pleased to insinuate in the same paragraph.
('93', 199, 1, 6, 403673) Let me tell you that for the fulfilment of my object, I do not need any volunteers here except myself.
('93', 199, 1, 7, 403776) If you really think that their presence is a menace to the peace of Noakhali, the Government have but to say that they are a danger and to serve a notice on them to quit, and I assure you that without a murmur they would leave this district.
('93', 199, 1, 8, 404018) From this undertaking, I and one of my company, whose name I need not disclose at this stage, are excepted.
('93', 199, 1, 9, 404126) You will be astonished to learn that, dear as they are all to me, and valuable as I count their services to the nation, I told them in this mission of mine I had no need to have any associate with me; for the quickest way to fruition required no protection or co operation save what God sent.
('93', 199, 1, 10, 404419) Such is my conception of the working of ahimsa.
('93', 199, 1, 11, 404467) I hope that before the Government takes the adumbrated action they will depute an officer of their choice or trust to find out from me or them the kind of work they are doing.
('93', 199, 1, 12, 404643) Their life is an open book.
('93', 199, 1, 13, 404671) There is nothing hidden or underground about their activities.
('93', 199, 1, 14, 404734) Permit me to give you my impression that your writing bristles with unprovable and reckless statements without regard to facts.
('93', 199, 1, 15, 404862) I have noticed only some of them.
('93', 199, 1, 16, 404896) As it is, my letter has become much longer than I had sketched in my mind but as I proceeded I could not shorten it if I was to give you some conception of my deep grief.
('93', 199, 1, 17, 405067) If you will know more.
('93', 199, 1, 18, 405090) I suggest to you that you should take the trouble of coming to me and passing with me half an hour or so and cross examine me on the charges you have framed against me.
('93', 199, 1, 19, 405259) This letter is not an open letter as yours is.
('93', 199, 1, 20, 405306) I have written only for you, cherishing the hope that it may perhaps appeal to you as coming from a well wisher open to conviction.
('93', 199, 2, 21, 405438) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('93', 199, 3, 22, 405468) My Days with Gandhi, pp.

('93', 201, 6, 12, 407469) 267. DISCUSSION WITH SWAMI JNANANANDA 1
('93', 201, 7, 13, 407509) December 27, 1946
('93', 201, 8, 14, 407527) There was nothing tangible to be shown yet, but non violence sometimes
('93', 201, 9, 15, 407598) worked in unexpected ways.
('93', 201, 10, 16, 407625) Gandhiji's advice to the Swamiji was that violence should be eschewed
('93', 201, 11, 17, 407695) altogether.
('93', 201, 11, 18, 407707) There should not even be a trace of it among the workers entrusted with
('93', 201, 12, 19, 407779) organizations.
('93', 201, 12, 20, 407794) He emphasized the need for constructive work which could bring food
('93', 201, 13, 21, 407862) to the hungry millions as well as anti untouchability work to remove the disabilities
('93', 201, 14, 22, 407948) which had crippled the Hindu society to a very large extent.
('93', 201, 15, 23, 408009) Hindustan Standard, 28 12 1946
('93', 201, 16, 24, 408040) 268. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 201, 17, 25, 408072) SRIRAMPUR, December 27, 1946
('93', 201, 18, 26, 408101) Gandhiji in his address said that a friend had been telling him that his reference 3 to “darkness” surrounding him was very confusing to many.
('93', 201, 18, 27, 408244) The friend thought that people at a distance saw light shimmering through his plan, and there was enough proof that the confidence was slowly returning in that affected area.
('93', 201, 19, 28, 408419) 1 The report said : “Swami Jnanananda of Shakti Math, Dacca .
('93', 201, 19, 29, 408481) discussed with Gandhiji the situation prevailing in rural areas of Dacca and also the possibilities of constructive work in those places.” 2 Extracted form “Srirampur Diary” 3 Vide “Extract From Diary”, 26 12 1946
('93', 202, 0, 1, 408695) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 203
('93', 202, 1, 2, 408743) Gandhiji said he would tell this friend and others who thought like him that they had misunderstood him to some extent.
('93', 202, 1, 3, 408863) The darkness in which he was surrounded was of a character the like of which had never faced him before.
('93', 202, 1, 4, 408968) It was indeed now a vital test that his ahimsa was passing through.
('93', 202, 1, 5, 409036) He would not be able to say that he had come out successful until the object was reached.
('93', 202, 2, 6, 409126) It was true that night was darkest before dawn.
('93', 202, 2, 7, 409174) He himself felt that and although friends at a distance could see glimpses of the breaking dawn, he himself felt that he was surrounded by complete darkness.
('93', 202, 3, 8, 409332) Gandhiji said that many years ago a friend of his used to carry Patanjali's Yogasutra constantly in his pocket.
('93', 202, 3, 9, 409444) Although Gandhiji did not know Sanskrit yet the friend would often come to him to consult about the meaning of some of the sutras.
('93', 202, 3, 10, 409575) In one of the sutras it was stated that when ahimsa had been fully established it would completely liquidate the forces of enmity and evil in the neighbourhood.
('93', 202, 3, 11, 409736) Gandhiji felt that the stage had not been reached in the neighbourhood about him and this led him to infer that his ahimsa had not yet succeeded in the present test.
('93', 202, 3, 12, 409902) That was the reason why he was saying that there was still darkness all round him.
('93', 202, 4, 13, 409985) Referring to a statement of Mr. Suhrawardy, Premier of Bengal, Gandhiji said it seemed to him that he was beginning to see glimpses of light.
('93', 202, 4, 14, 410127) The Bengal Premier had said that he hoped Mahatma Gandhi's mission would be successful and bring results beneficial not only to Bengal but to the whole of India.
('93', 202, 4, 15, 410289) The Bengal Premier had also said that he must provide escort to protect Mahatma Gandhi on his walking tour.
('93', 202, 4, 16, 410397) Gandhiji said that Mr. Suhrawardy had only been doing his duty in offering him protection.
('93', 202, 4, 17, 410488) He knew that military and police had been posted round about his cottage.
('93', 202, 4, 18, 410562) He sometimes exchanged greetings with them.
('93', 202, 4, 19, 410606) Beyond that he thought none could do so if God willed it otherwise.
('93', 202, 5, 20, 410674) Referring to his walking tour Gandhiji said in a couple of days details would be settled.
('93', 202, 5, 21, 410764) As soon as the programme was ready he would communicate it to the Bengal Premier, for he felt he should do nothing without his knowledge.
('93', 202, 6, 22, 410902) Gandhiji said that his plan was to proceed with the least number of companions on his march, and that he would prefer to stay in the houses of Muslim friends.
('93', 202, 6, 23, 411061) He had reduced his needs and these could be met even by the poorest villagers.
('93', 202, 6, 24, 411140) He would like to go absolutely unprotected if it was to prove that in his heart he had nothing but love and friendship for the Muslims.
('93', 202, 7, 25, 411276) Gandhiji said that if he was absolutely alone on his mission his services would have gained considerably in quality.
('93', 202, 7, 26, 411393) He would also have been able to assess in that case his ability for facing the present problem of Bengal.
('93', 202, 8, 27, 411499) 1 The following three paragraphs are reproduced from Hindustan Standard.
('93', 202, 8, 28, 411572) 2 What follows is reproduced from The Sunday Hindustan Standard.
('93', 203, 0, 1, 411637) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 203, 1, 2, 411679) Numerous friends had for some years past placed their services unreservedly at Gandhiji 's disposal.
('93', 203, 1, 3, 411780) When he first came on his mission to Noakhali, he had intended to dispense with the services of those friends.
('93', 203, 1, 4, 411891) His idea was to place himself absolutely in God's hands.
('93', 203, 1, 5, 411948) Of course God helped his devotees through human agency but in that case it would come naturally and without his asking.
('93', 203, 2, 6, 412068) If the original plan of coming here alone had been followed to the letter, complaints that were now being made against him would have been neutralized to a large extent.
('93', 203, 2, 7, 412238) Even now his advice to anyone who wished to serve in Noakhali would be not to seek his advice, far less to depend on his directions.
('93', 203, 3, 8, 412371) Those who would like to come here should instead contact the League Ministry and secure their written permission.
('93', 203, 3, 9, 412485) Moreover, they should place before the Ministry in detail the nature of work they propose to do and while working here they should confine their activities within that scheme and on no account go beyond it.
('93', 203, 3, 10, 412692) He was suggesting this course, because it was the League Ministry's authority which prevailed in this Province.
('93', 203, 4, 11, 412804) Today he was regarded as enemy number one by the League and if people from outside came to help him they were bound to be regarded as helping an enemy.
('93', 203, 4, 12, 412956) But he was very anxious that this should be avoided.
('93', 203, 5, 13, 413009) There were men and organizations who were of the opinion that Hindus who were numerically weak should learn self defence in terms of violence.
('93', 203, 5, 14, 413152) Muslims on the other hand also felt that they could swamp Hindus by means of their overwhelming numbers.
('93', 203, 5, 15, 413257) But he had no doubt about it that both of them were not only injuring their own communities but also acting against the interests of India as a whole.
('93', 203, 6, 16, 413408) Concluding, Gandhiji prayed to God that he might be successful in cementing differences between the two communities which had unhappily been estranged from one another and said that in this great experiment he would like to march all alone with God as his sole guide.
('93', 203, 7, 17, 413676) Harijan, 26 1 1947; and The Sunday Hindustan Standard, 29 12 1946, and Hindustan Standard, 30 12 1946

('93', 206, 3, 17, 417847) It was sure to come if we made wise use of our strength.

('93', 208, 1, 2, 420100) 278. INSTRUCTIONS FOR CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE
('93', 208, 2, 3, 420149) SRIRAMPUR, [December 28/30, 1946] 1
('93', 208, 3, 4, 420185) During its unbroken career of sixty years, the Congress has been invariably and progressively representative of all the communities— Hindus, Muslims and others.
('93', 208, 3, 5, 420346) It has been also progressively represen tative of the masses.
('93', 208, 3, 6, 420408) That it has always had a number of hypocrites is but an ode to these two among its many virtues.
('93', 208, 3, 7, 420505) If those who repr esent these two virtues are found to be in a hopeless minority, they should lodge their protest and leave the Congress and influence public opinion from outside.
('93', 208, 3, 8, 420685) Then only will they be true servants of the nation.
('93', 208, 3, 9, 420737) Therefore at this critical period I hold it to be necessary for the Working Committee to give the proper, unequivocal lead to the Congress by laying down these propositions : 1.It is now perhaps late to cry off the Constituent Assembly though I still hold it to be the best course to make the Congress position absolutely clear.
('93', 208, 3, 10, 421066) 2.The second best is to accept the Cabinet Mission’s statement with the joint interpretation of it between themselves and Qaid e Azam Jinnah.
('93', 208, 3, 11, 421208) 3.It must be clearly understood that it is open to any Congress individual or unit to declare his or Group’s or Province’s secession from the Congress stand which the Congress should be free to accept whilst still openly guiding the seceding elements.
('93', 208, 3, 12, 421460) This will be in accordance with the Cabinet’s position that they will not compel any Group or Province.
('93', 208, 3, 13, 421564) The result of this would be that the members of Section A would prepare a full constitution in terms of the Cabinet Mission’s statement and B and C Sections would have to frame what they can in spite of the seceders, i.e., as at present conceived, Assam in the East and Frontier Province in the West, the Sikhs in the Punjab and may be Baluchistan.
('93', 208, 4, 14, 421913) 1 From My Days with Gandhi, p.
('93', 208, 4, 15, 421944) 128,in which N. K. Bose explains: “During these three days the Congress leaders held long discussions with Gandhiji.
('93', 208, 4, 16, 422061) After discussion with the leaders, Gandhiji prepared instructions for the Working Committee.
('93', 208, 4, 17, 422154) This was .
('93', 208, 4, 18, 422165) handed over to Jawaharlal Nehru and others.”
('93', 209, 0, 1, 422210) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 209, 1, 2, 422252) It may be that the British Government will recognize or set up another Constituent Assembly.
('93', 209, 1, 3, 422345) If they do, they will damn themselves for ever.
('93', 209, 1, 4, 422393) They are bound when a constitution is framed in terms of the Cabinet Mission’s stand to leave the rest to fate, every vestige of British authority being wiped out, British soldiers retiring from India never to return.
('93', 209, 1, 5, 422611) This position of the Congress is in no way to be interpreted as playing completely into Qaid e Azam Jinnah’s hand.
('93', 209, 1, 6, 422726) And if this he considers to be what he meant, the Congress will be thanked by the world for giving Qaid e Azam Jinnah a universally acceptable and inoffensive formula for his Pakistan.
('93', 209, 1, 7, 422911) The Congress dare not shirk the right thing because it completely coincides with his view.
('93', 209, 1, 8, 423002) The constitution will be for whole India.
('93', 209, 1, 9, 423044) It will have to contain a specific clause showing in what way it will be open to the boycotters to avail themselves of the constitution.

('93', 212, 3, 4, 428376) PYARELAL, You certainly should have proper food.
('93', 212, 3, 5, 428425) A soldier must keep his body fit.
('93', 212, 3, 6, 428459) You must always keep with you roti or biscuits.
('93', 212, 3, 7, 428507) If you take with it some coconut it makes a complete diet.
('93', 212, 3, 8, 428566) If you add to it some gur it will make a complete diet (I have tried all this).
('93', 212, 3, 9, 428646) So, even while being on the march, it can be eaten at fixed times.
('93', 212, 3, 10, 428713) You will have read in the History of [Satyagraha in] South Africa that during the march to the Transvaal, I ate while walking.
('93', 212, 3, 11, 428840) If you do this you will never have to depend on anyone.
('93', 212, 3, 12, 428896) You can take whatever fruit is locally available.
('93', 212, 3, 13, 428946) You have agreed that you and I should never talk keeping Manu apart.
('93', 212, 3, 14, 429015) You cannot entertain any doubt about her at all.
('93', 212, 3, 15, 429064) Hence I advise you to convey to her the purport of our talk.
('93', 212, 3, 16, 429125) Show this also to her.
('93', 212, 3, 17, 429148) Then whatever bad feelings she may be having will automatically come to the surface.
('93', 212, 3, 18, 429233) Affection can never last till the end.
('93', 212, 3, 19, 429272) It certainly did not last in this case.
('93', 212, 3, 20, 429312) Hence you must be cheerful and confident and inspire in her as much confidence as possible.
('93', 212, 3, 21, 429404) Letting her know of your doubt will be an act of loyalty.
('93', 212, 3, 22, 429462) Then you must do whatever you can without entertaining any doubt.
('93', 212, 3, 23, 429528) God belongs to everyone.
('93', 212, 3, 24, 429553) He will do as He wills.
('93', 212, 3, 25, 429577) I am doing only that.
('93', 212, 3, 26, 429599) I am having her sleep close to me.
('93', 212, 3, 27, 429634) She sleeps naked but sleeps soundly.
('93', 212, 3, 28, 429671) She has to be woken up whenever there is work, be it at 2 o’clock or 3 o’clock.
('93', 212, 3, 29, 429751) I consider it a very good sign that she is able to sleep like that.
('93', 212, 3, 30, 429819) I have known it since the Aga Khan Palace days that she is quite unself conscious.
('93', 212, 3, 31, 429902) The main thing was that she should be with me, in my care and associate with you and learn.
('93', 212, 3, 32, 429994) That has happened.
('93', 212, 3, 33, 430013) Now we must all wish that only what spontaneously occurs to her will happen.
('93', 212, 3, 34, 430090) Only then will she be completely free from fear.
('93', 212, 3, 35, 430139) That you want to conquer is my own expression.
('93', 212, 3, 36, 430186) You must learn to understand my language.

('93', 212, 3, 38, 430274) I can never utter the word in that sense.

('93', 218, 4, 9, 439418) SRIRAMPUR, December 31, 1946 If the Hindus and Muslims cannot live side by side in brotherly love in Noakhali, they will not be able to do so over the whole of India, and Pakistan will be the inevitable result.

('93', 218, 4, 11, 439703) Therefore, I say that if India is to remain undivided, Hindus and Muslims must live together in brotherly love, not in hostile camps organized either for defensive action or retaliation.

('93', 221, 9, 24, 445464) 300. ADVICE TO WEAVERS 3
('93', 221, 10, 25, 445489) SRIRAMPUR, January 1, 1947
('93', 221, 11, 26, 445516) Gandhiji advised them to depend on hand spun yarn from the charkha which would be available at cheaper rates and in any quantity.
('93', 221, 11, 27, 445646) The hand spun yarn he said, suffered from mill competition, but while the latter produced one very low grade and another very fine grade, hand spun yarn could be varied to intricate designs to meet the change of fashion.
('93', 221, 11, 28, 445867) Gandhiji further told them that if they wanted to survive, they must depend on hand spun yarn.

('93', 222, 2, 6, 446598) 301. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING SRIRAMPUR, January 1, 1947
('93', 222, 3, 7, 446655) Gandhiji began by saying that his stay in that village had been amply enriched by the abundance of love showered upon him by the members of the household in whose midst he had been living.
('93', 222, 3, 8, 446844) But God had so designed that he had never had the fortune of staying at any one place for a very long time.
('93', 222, 3, 9, 446952) His travels had now been crowded by experiences both bitter and sweet.
('93', 222, 3, 10, 447023) He added that the people were requesting him to prolong his stay in this village because they said that they were gaining courage by his continued presence in their midst.
('93', 222, 4, 11, 447195) As a matter of fact both contact and separation were normal parts of a man’s life.
('93', 222, 4, 12, 447278) So the daily prayer of the Ashramites was that God should give them strength enough to pass through life’s varying experiences in a state of equipoise.
('93', 222, 4, 13, 447430) Verses from the second chapter of the Gita which were recited every evening described the characteristics of the man who had actually attained that mental state.
('93', 222, 4, 14, 447592) Its appeal was not to men of any particular status or calibre alone, but the lesson was of universal significance.
('93', 222, 5, 15, 447707) That he was going to leave the village of Srirampur on the following morning was because his duty now called him away from that place.
('93', 222, 5, 16, 447842) He had now to roam from one village to another in order to contact people in their homes and carry the message of love and friendship to them.
('93', 222, 5, 17, 447985) On other occasions, such as that of Dandi march, he had been followed by lakhs of people, but this time he would be going alone.
('93', 222, 5, 18, 448114) It was his heart’s prayer that when he left any place, people should be able to say of him that now one had left them who was their friend and not an enemy.
('93', 222, 6, 19, 448271) Today was the New Year’s Day for the Christians.
('93', 222, 6, 20, 448320) It was curious that they celebrated this day in India with more enthusiasm than they did the coming of Samvat or Hijra era.
('93', 222, 6, 21, 448444) That was due to their long association with the ruling class who were Christians by faith.
('93', 222, 7, 22, 448535) But as he looked upon all religions as equal, being derived from one source, there was no harm in observing the Christian New Year’s Day.
('93', 222, 7, 23, 448673) At first Gandhiji’s idea was that he would give them a reading of two choice sayings from Prophet Mohammad.
('93', 222, 7, 24, 448781) But later he changed his mind and thought of presenting portions from Christian hymns which had been collected and presented to him by Rajkumari Amrit Kaur.
('93', 223, 0, 1, 448938) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 223, 1, 2, 448980) There was another matter which had exercised his mind for some time past.
('93', 223, 1, 3, 449054) Friends, he added were friends only when they helped a person to progress in life.
('93', 223, 1, 4, 449137) If they discovered any faults in him, it was their clear duty to acquaint him with them so that he might be able to correct himself.
('93', 223, 1, 5, 449270) But this had to be done in a sweet manner and with a spirit of helpfulness.
('93', 223, 2, 6, 449346) It was the beginning of the New Year and his prayer was that the audience and he might be ushered into it free from impurities of the lower self, and thus rendered fitter instruments of service to a common cause.
('93', 223, 2, 7, 449559) Hindustan Standard, 3 1 1947 and 4 1 1947

('93', 225, 0, 1, 453054) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 225, 1, 2, 453096) 305. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 225, 2, 3, 453128) CHANDIPUR, January 2, 1947
('93', 225, 3, 4, 453155) Gandhiji said that his mission was for the establishment of friendship between the sister communities living here and not to organize any one community against the rest.
('93', 225, 3, 5, 453325) So far the non violence which had been practised was the non violence of the weak but the new experiment in which he had been engaged here was the non violence of the strong.
('93', 225, 3, 6, 453500) If it were to be successful, it should succeed in creating a moral atmosphere helpful to both the communities around him.
('93', 225, 3, 7, 453622) Only when the Hindus and Muslims shed their fear and mutual suspicion could real unity of heart come.
('93', 225, 3, 8, 453724) There should not be any cause for hostility when their hearts were one.
('93', 225, 4, 9, 453796) Referring to the task of village reorganization, Gandhiji said that East Bengal was a land of gold but unfortunately the life of the people was not as it should be.
('93', 225, 4, 10, 453961) The water in the tanks was so dirty that he could not dare even wash his hands in them.
('93', 225, 4, 11, 454049) The villages were also unclean.
('93', 225, 4, 12, 454081) The rich were growing richer and the poor were getting poorer.
('93', 225, 4, 13, 454144) That was not forced upon them by nature.
('93', 225, 4, 14, 454185) That was a Satanic state of affairs.
('93', 225, 4, 15, 454222) But although the social arrangements were Satanic, individuals were not so.
('93', 225, 4, 16, 454298) Individuals should raise their organization and shape it according to new ideas of equality and comradeship.
('93', 225, 5, 17, 454407) Gandhiji pointed out that the rule that they were going to establish in India in the near future should be free from defects which marked the old system.
('93', 225, 5, 18, 454561) Hindus and Muslims today found themselves estranged from one another here, but if both of them devoted themselves to the noble task of reorganizing the village life and improving their economic conditions through development of their cottage industries, they would find themselves working in a common task and unity would grow among them.
('93', 225, 6, 19, 454900) Workers who had been sent here by Satis Babu, Gandhiji said, had faced many dangers.
('93', 225, 6, 20, 454985) Gandhiji’s advice to all workers was that they should shed fear of death from their hearts and try to win over those who opposed them.
('93', 225, 6, 21, 455120) In that attempt some might die, but Gandhiji had the faith that however impossible it might appear, the oppressor’s heart would surely be touched if love and courage from their side was of an unfailing character.
