('93', 229, 2, 6, 462099) 311. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 229, 3, 7, 462131) CHANDIPUR, January 3, 1947
('93', 229, 4, 8, 462158) Gandhiji began by saying that what he had undertaken was comparable to pilgrimage which people undertook to places like Kashi or Badrinath.
('93', 229, 4, 9, 462298) God did not reside in any particular place to the exclusion of another but in the heart of man.
('93', 229, 4, 10, 462394) If one undertook pilgrimage in the right spirit, one would grow purer and purer.
('93', 229, 5, 11, 462475) What did it matter to them, said Gandhiji, if their house had been burnt and their properties looted so long as they had the will to face any calamity with courage and determination to build up their lives once again on their own labour?
('93', 229, 5, 12, 462713) Refugees should bravely face the reality and learn some craft by which they could maintain their families and earn their bread.
('93', 229, 5, 13, 462841) Gandhiji said that those who did not labour but lived on the toil of others were thieves.
('93', 229, 5, 14, 462931) No man was free from obligation of voluntary labour in order to support himself.
('93', 229, 5, 15, 463012) One might feel tempted to ask what a few individuals could do.
('93', 229, 5, 16, 463075) The speaker’s answer was that if 40 crores of small bits of wood were tied together, it would be enough to build a bridge over which the mightiest army could pass.
('93', 229, 5, 17, 463239) Similarly, if in India 40 crores of men developed new bonds of sympathy and mutual help, they would be able to build a new life in which every man, woman and child could prosper.
('93', 229, 6, 18, 463418) Fear of hard work and of sudden calamities being thus removed from their hearts, they would march a long way towards freedom.
('93', 229, 6, 19, 463544) If they could shed fear, they would be able to stand up before their assailants.
('93', 229, 7, 20, 463625) Gandhiji added that the fulfilment of his mission would come only when those who were left behind were able to say that now they had got rid of impurities which had been corrupting their lives so far and would go forward to rebuild their own lives on the basis of labour courageously and joyfully undertaken.

('93', 231, 1, 6, 466416) If such be the argument I would hold that the interest of the masses as conceived by them must prevail over that of the classes.
('93', 231, 1, 7, 466545) It is conceivable that in certain cases the opinion of the classes may be intrinsically right and that of the masses intrinsically absurd.
('93', 231, 1, 8, 466684) This to my mind is the crux of democracy.
('93', 231, 1, 9, 466726) Hence, as the Government, if I am confident about the backing of the masses, I would tell the Centre that my Government would pay damages for breach of contract if that be the legal result.

('93', 233, 4, 7, 469967) 319. DISCUSSION WITH MEMBERS OF CHANDIPUR CHANDIRGAON GRAM SEVA SANGH 2
('93', 233, 5, 8, 470039) January 4, 1947
('93', 233, 6, 9, 470055) QUESTION: What should the Sangh do to appease the aggressive mentality of the majority community?
('93', 233, 7, 10, 470153) ANSWER: Appeasement has become a word of bad odour.
('93', 233, 7, 11, 470205) In no case can there be any appeasement at the cost of honour.
('93', 233, 7, 12, 470268) Real appeasement is to shed all fear and to do what is right at any cost.
('93', 233, 7, 13, 470342) Blood for blood is a played out game and non violence of the brave is the only real approach to the problem.
('93', 233, 8, 14, 470451) In answer to a question whether the refugees should accept monetary assistance from the Government even if it was quite insufficient for the erection of temporary shelter, Gandhiji said: Refugees must honestly find out what they need for the least kind of temporary shelter.
('93', 233, 8, 15, 470726) If their basic requirements are not covered by the proposed Government grants, they should refuse to accept them but should still return to their homes even if it meant no cover over their heads.
('93', 233, 8, 16, 470922) This has to be done in a spirit of sports manship
('93', 233, 9, 17, 470972) Q. In the course of rehabilitation, should the members of the minority community be lodged together in sufficient numbers for the purpose of safety ?
('93', 233, 10, 18, 471122) A. Such concentration of population is an unthinkable pro position.
('93', 233, 10, 19, 471190) It would imply that the whole country would be divided into hostile sections, perhaps enjoying a sort of armed peace.
('93', 233, 10, 20, 471308) The manly thing to do is for every individual, of whatever sect, whether young or old, to derive protection from his inner strength which comes from
('93', 233, 11, 21, 471457) 1 This sentence is reproduced from Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('93', 233, 11, 22, 471514) 2 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”.
('93', 233, 11, 23, 471550) The Hindu, 6 1 1947, reported that the Gram Seva Sangh was organized by Souren Bose, in accordance with Gandhiji’s instructions.
('93', 233, 11, 24, 471679) 3 This sentence is reproduced from Hindustan Standard.
('93', 234, 0, 1, 471734) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 235
('93', 234, 2, 2, 471782) Asked what arrangements for the safety of the refugees could be made in view of the fact that miscreants were moving freely in the affected areas, Gandhiji said: No place in the world today is free from miscreants.
('93', 234, 2, 3, 471997) So villagers should fall back on their own strength for protection.
('93', 234, 2, 4, 472065) The strength which will give them lasting protection is the strength of the heart.
('93', 234, 2, 5, 472148) For those who accepted God as their protector, what did it matter if miscreants roamed about?
('93', 234, 2, 6, 472242) People should do what was right for them and leave the rest to God.
('93', 234, 3, 7, 472310) His immediate advice to the refugees would be that they should brave all risks and come back home.
('93', 234, 3, 8, 472409) It did not matter to him that some might suffer in the attempt due to exposure or shortage of supplies, but the attempt was still worth while.
('93', 234, 4, 9, 472552) Q. If Government and private relief is stopped, what work can we give to the refugees so that they can earn their daily bread?
('93', 234, 5, 10, 472679) A. Although personally I should be tempted to suggest hand spinning as a universal occupation, I would not necessarily do so in the present case.
('93', 234, 5, 11, 472825) Instead, I would suggest that the workers should find out on the basis of detailed local enquiries what occupation could be undertaken in each village.
('93', 234, 5, 12, 472977) And when such information is available, I would love to give advice in greater detail.
('93', 234, 5, 13, 473064) It is certain that the work must be done in co operation.
('93', 234, 6, 14, 473122) Gandhiji said that there were a number of tanks in this part of Bengal but he had not yet seen a single tank sufficiently clean to wash his hands in.
('93', 234, 6, 15, 473272) This villagers were in the habit of using the same tank for all purposes without any scruple whatsoever.
('93', 234, 6, 16, 473377) A clean water supply was the prime necessity of life.
('93', 234, 6, 17, 473431) He suggested there should be natural filters sunk near the tanks and also artificial filters for corporate use.
('93', 234, 6, 18, 473543) Certain tanks could also be reserved for drinking purposes only.
('93', 234, 6, 19, 473608) If no suggestion was found workable, tube wells should be sunk in every village.
('93', 234, 6, 20, 473689) A second alternative would be to have filters in each household made with a number of earthen vessels, set one over another, some of them half filled with charcoal and sand as was done at some big railway stations.
('93', 234, 6, 21, 473904) The third alternative was tube wells.
('93', 234, 6, 22, 473942) He did not favour the last so much as it could not be prescribed for the rich and the poor alike.
('93', 234, 6, 23, 474040) It was, however, all right as an expedient and should be resorted to at once in this area.
('93', 234, 6, 24, 474131) If there were any difficulties with regard to the supply of materials, he would try to help them in securing these from the Government.

('93', 235, 0, 1, 474464) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 235, 1, 2, 474506) 320. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 235, 2, 3, 474538) KAZIRBAZAR, January 4, 1947
('93', 235, 3, 4, 474566) Gandhiji began his speech by stating that the two sister communities had become estranged from one another today and he was even looked upon as enemy number one by some members of the Muslim community.
('93', 235, 3, 5, 474768) His object in confining himself to Noakhali was to test himself.
('93', 235, 3, 6, 474833) In all his long life he had never harboured enmity against Muslim community.
('93', 235, 3, 7, 474910) In fact plenty of the best years of his life had been spent among Muslim friends in South Africa.
('93', 235, 4, 8, 475008) Gandhiji said that it was continually being impressed upon him that his place was no longer in this Province but in Bihar where infinitely worse things were alleged to have taken place.
('93', 235, 4, 9, 475194) The audience should be aware that he had all along been in correspondence with the popular Government in Bihar and all influence possible was being exercised by him over that Government from here; but he did not want to leave Noakhali because his task there was of an entirely different order.
('93', 235, 4, 10, 475488) He had to prove by living among the Mussalmans that he was as much their friend as of the Hindus or any other community.
('93', 235, 4, 11, 475609) This could evidently not be done from a distance or by mere word of mouth.
('93', 235, 5, 12, 475684) A Bihar Minister and several responsible officials who had come to him yesterday had placed before him all the facts within their knowledge without any reservation.
('93', 235, 5, 13, 475849) They had admitted that brutal things had taken place in the course of one fateful week and that they were prepared to bear all justifiable censure passed on them on that account.
('93', 235, 6, 14, 476028) They knew their duty as a responsible Government.
('93', 235, 6, 15, 476078) The charge of complicity or failure in doing all that was humanly possible was denied by them and they said they were prepared to undergo any ordeal in order to prove their innocence.
('93', 235, 6, 16, 476262) They had been trying to answer the charges made by the Muslim League against them.
('93', 235, 6, 17, 476345) Gandhiji said he would like to assure the audience that he would not rest until he was satisfied personally about the Bihar case and had done all that was humanly possible.
('93', 235, 6, 18, 476518) Gandhiji thought ‘that the attendance of both Hindus and Muslims at prayer meetings was dwindling and one day he would be left without anybody to listen to him at all’.
('93', 235, 6, 19, 476687) 2 But he said that even then there would be no reason for him to give up
('93', 235, 7, 20, 476760) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”.
('93', 235, 7, 21, 476796) The date line and the first paragraph are reproduced from Hindustan Standard, which reported that the meeting was “specially held at the request of a local leader, Maulvi M. Fazlul Huq”.
('93', 235, 7, 22, 476983) 2 In Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, Book II, p.
('93', 235, 7, 23, 477040) 135, Pyarelal explains that this was a reference to a statement by Hamiduddin, Parliamentary secretary.
('93', 236, 0, 1, 477144) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 237
('93', 236, 1, 2, 477192) his mission in despair.
('93', 236, 1, 3, 477216) He would then roam from village to village taking his spinning wheel.
('93', 236, 1, 4, 477286) With him it was an act of service to God.
('93', 236, 1, 5, 477328) Such labour undertaken with an unselfish mind would speak for itself among those who were around him.
('93', 236, 1, 6, 477430) A worker, he said, who travelled from village to village teaching the people how to clean their ponds effectively and teaching them other arts and crafts so as to enrich the life of the villagers, should be able to make the villagers long for his company rather than shun him.
('93', 236, 2, 7, 477707) Continuing, Gandhiji said that news had just reached him that the evacuees were now returning in fair numbers and the question of rehabilitation was becoming more and more acute.
('93', 236, 2, 8, 477886) His advice to the evacuees would be that they should brave all hardships and return home quickly.
('93', 236, 2, 9, 477984) By means of their own labour they must determine to rebuild their homes as well as their own lives.
('93', 236, 2, 10, 478084) Government should extend all necessary help and they should be approached by the evacuees.
('93', 236, 2, 11, 478175) He was aware of the fact that various relief organizations were prepared to help the evacuees with finances and other material assistance.
('93', 236, 2, 12, 478314) But why should they undertake a task which rightly belonged to the Government set up by the people themselves?
('93', 236, 2, 13, 478425) If the Government failed to extend it either quickly enough or to a satisfactory extent, then it was for them to say so and seek supplementary aid of public charities in order to rehabilitate the people.
('93', 236, 2, 14, 478629) But whatever shape these arrangements might take, the evacuees must be prepared to return home in the face of all possible dangers and difficulties.
('93', 236, 3, 15, 478778) Harijan, 26 1 1947; and Hindustan Standard, 8 1 1947

('93', 237, 6, 10, 479643) 323. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 237, 7, 11, 479675) CHANDIPUR, January 5, 1947 I have not come here to talk politics.
('93', 237, 8, 12, 479741) His purpose, Gandhiji said, was not to reduce the influence of the Muslim League or to increase that of the Congress, but to speak to the people of the little things about their daily life, things which, if properly attended to, would change the face of the land and create a heaven out of the pitiable conditions in which they were all living today.
('93', 237, 9, 13, 480092) Bengal, said Gandhiji, was a land full of verdure, with plenty of water and fertile soil.
('93', 237, 9, 14, 480182) Nature had showered her abundance on Bengal, but through ignorance, the people were suffering from poverty and disease.
('93', 237, 9, 15, 480302) They appeared to be content with what little could be earned from betel nut and coconut gardens and a little of agriculture.
('93', 237, 9, 16, 480427) But with more knowledge, they could increase the productivity of the land many times and convert their villages into cleaner abodes of peace and pros perity.
('93', 237, 9, 17, 480585) If all the villagers joined together, the face of the land would be changed in no time.
('93', 237, 10, 18, 480673) Referring to the evacuees, Gandhiji said that they must come back home and face all dangers and difficulties.
('93', 237, 10, 19, 480783) Anyone who had committed a sin should likewise make a clean confession to God, and then depend upon God for whatever He might choose to do.
('93', 237, 10, 20, 480923) Truly religious men who made a confession to God did not repeat their errors.
('93', 237, 10, 21, 481001) Gandhiji said that only in the morning he had visited a house where the owner had been assured that if he divulged his secret hoard of gold, his life would be spared.
('93', 237, 11, 22, 481168) 1 This is a slip—January 5 was a Sunday.
('93', 237, 11, 23, 481209) 2 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”.
('93', 237, 11, 24, 481245) The date line and the last paragraph are reproduced from Hindustan Standard, which reported that “the meeting was held near Harishchar School, a mile from Chandipur”.
('93', 238, 0, 1, 481412) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 239
('93', 238, 1, 2, 481460) But when the man did so, the miscreants killed him and looted the gold.
('93', 238, 1, 3, 481532) No man is free from sin and his advice to the miscreants would be to come forward and depend on God and live like brave honest men

('93', 238, 3, 5, 481716) 324. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('93', 238, 4, 6, 481740) AS FROM KAZIRKHIL, RAMGUNJ POST, NOAKHALI DISTRICT, CAMP: CHANDIPUR, January [2/6] 1, 1947
('93', 238, 6, 7, 481831) Your registered letter is in front of me.
('93', 238, 6, 8, 481873) The news will be given to you by Parasuram together with this letter.
('93', 238, 6, 9, 481943) I simply dictate to say that the position you adumbrate is the correct thing.
('93', 238, 6, 10, 482021) Everything depends upon one’s purity in thought, word and deed, using the word ‘purity’ in its widest sense.
('93', 238, 6, 11, 482130) Then there may be no cause for even so much as a headache.
('93', 238, 6, 12, 482189) Only get hold of this fundamental fact.
('93', 238, 6, 13, 482229) We often loosely use the word ‘purity’ and excuse all sorts of lapses.
('93', 238, 6, 14, 482300) Do not ever worry how I am faring or what I am doing here.
('93', 238, 6, 15, 482359) If I succeed in emptying myself utterly, God will possess me.
('93', 238, 6, 16, 482421) Then I know that everything will come true but it is a serious question when I shall have reduced myself to zero.
('93', 238, 6, 17, 482535) Think of ‘I’ and ‘O’ in juxtaposition and you have the whole problem of life in two signs.
('93', 238, 6, 18, 482626) In this process you have helped me considerably for, though at a distance, you seem to be doing your duty to the fullest extent possible in your field 2 of work.
('93', 238, 6, 19, 482788) This was dictated four days ago when I was resting in bed.
('93', 238, 6, 20, 482847) But it remained untyped.
('93', 238, 6, 21, 482872) Meantime your another letter and samples of khadi have been received.
('93', 238, 6, 22, 482942) Have you any khadi to spare for sale?
('93', 238, 6, 23, 482980) I make this inquiry for the sake of the refugees.
('93', 238, 6, 24, 483030) Do not overdo things.
('93', 238, 6, 25, 483052) Do not overwork.
('93', 238, 6, 26, 483069) “Be careful for nothing.” 3
('93', 238, 7, 27, 483097) The pilgrimage on foot commences tomorrow.
('93', 238, 7, 28, 483140) There may be then no letter to you.
('93', 238, 7, 29, 483176) A bulletin will be sent to you.
('93', 238, 7, 30, 483208) This I am scribbling in the

('93', 239, 5, 6, 483573) 325. LETTER TO M. A. ABDULLAH January 6, 1947
('93', 239, 6, 7, 483619) DEAR ABDULLAH SAHEB, I have carefully read your letter.
('93', 239, 6, 8, 483675) The answer is obvious.
('93', 239, 6, 9, 483698) My non co operation was purely non violent in conception as also in effect.
('93', 239, 6, 10, 483774) This does not mean that practice was always perfect.
('93', 239, 6, 11, 483827) Theory and practice hardly ever coincide even as Euclid’s line in practice never coincides with his theoretical definition.
('93', 239, 6, 12, 483951) The non fraternization policy of the Allies led to disastrous results, which he who runs may see and the pity of it is that the disaster is not yet completed.
('93', 239, 6, 13, 484110) No one knows where it will lead to.
('93', 239, 6, 14, 484146) I thought it better to send you the reply of which you may make any use you like.
('93', 239, 6, 15, 484228) But if you prefer that I should send a public letter in answer to your letter used as an anonymous letter, I shall gladly do so.
('93', 239, 6, 16, 484357) I hope you are doing well in your new place.
('93', 239, 6, 17, 484402) H. ABDULLA SAHEB, I.P. C/O. KHAN SAHEB, SUPERINTENDENT OF POLICE, NOAKHALI

('93', 242, 5, 17, 488563) 331. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 242, 6, 18, 488595) CHANDIPUR, January 6, 1947 My weekly silence will come to an end at about 7 o’clock.
('93', 242, 6, 19, 488680) Therefore, I am writing down whatever I want to say.
('93', 242, 6, 20, 488733) I pray to God that the tour which I begin tomorrow may be duly completed and produce the intended result.
('93', 242, 6, 21, 488839) All of you should join me in this prayer.
('93', 242, 6, 22, 488881) But before offering the prayer you should know why I have undertaken this tour.
('93', 242, 6, 23, 488961) There is only one purpose behind this tour and it is very clear.
('93', 242, 6, 24, 489026) May God cleanse and purify the hearts of Hindus and Muslims and may the people of the two communities give up mistrust and fear of each other.
('93', 242, 6, 25, 489169) All of you should join me in this prayer and say that God is our Lord and may He give us success.
('93', 242, 6, 26, 489267) One may ask, where is the need for a tour to achieve this object?
('93', 242, 6, 27, 489333) How can one whose heart is not pure tell others to be pure?
('93', 242, 6, 28, 489393) How can one who lacks courage, inspire courage in others?
('93', 242, 6, 29, 489451) How can one who is himself fully armed, advise others to give up arms?
('93', 242, 6, 30, 489522) These are all relevant questions, and such questions have also been put to me.
('93', 242, 6, 31, 489601) During this tour I shall try my best to convey to every villager that there is no impurity in my heart at all.
('93', 242, 6, 32, 489712) I can prove all that only when I live and move among those who distrust me.
('93', 242, 6, 33, 489788) The third question is difficult to answer because I myself move under police protection.
('93', 242, 7, 34, 489877) 1 Vide “Letter to Amtussalaam”, 5 1 1947 2 This appeared under the title “Why Walking Tour?” with an editorial note that it was written by Gandhiji in Hindustani and rendered into Bengali by N. K. Bose.
('93', 243, 0, 1, 490080) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 243, 1, 2, 490122) Fully armed police and military personnel are with me.
('93', 243, 1, 3, 490177) They are alert and always respectfully guard me.
('93', 243, 1, 4, 490226) All this is entirely in the hands of the Government.
('93', 243, 1, 5, 490279) Our Government is of the view that it is its duty to provide me police protection during my tour.
('93', 243, 1, 6, 490377) How can I stop this?
('93', 243, 1, 7, 490398) I can only say that none but God is my protector.
('93', 243, 1, 8, 490448) I do not know if you will believe me.
('93', 243, 1, 9, 490486) I am speaking the truth.
('93', 243, 1, 10, 490511) God alone knows a man’s heart; none else can know it.
('93', 243, 1, 11, 490565) It is the duty of every believer in God to obey the dictates of his heart.
('93', 243, 1, 12, 490640) It is my claim that I act in this way.
('93', 243, 1, 13, 490679) But the Sikhs have not been deputed by the Government.
('93', 243, 1, 14, 490734) Can I not prevent their accompanying me?
('93', 243, 1, 15, 490775) You should better know that they are also accompanying me on my tour with the permission of the Government.
('93', 243, 1, 16, 490883) They have not come here with the intention to fight.
('93', 243, 1, 17, 490936) They have even left behind their kirpans.
('93', 243, 1, 18, 490978) They have come here to serve the two communities without any discrimination.
('93', 243, 1, 19, 491055) The first lesson of the Indian National Army, which Netaji had formed, was that people belonging to all religions, Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis, etc., should regard India as their own country and should all work in such a way as to bring about unity.
('93', 243, 1, 20, 491313) The Sikhs want to serve both the communities and they wish to do so under my guidance.
('93', 243, 1, 21, 491400) How can I reject such friends, and why should I?
('93', 243, 1, 22, 491449) They are serving because they have vowed to serve and not to show off.
('93', 243, 1, 23, 491520) If I refuse to accept their service, I shall go down in my own estimation and shall prove a coward.
('93', 243, 1, 24, 491620) It is my request to you that you also should trust these brothers of ours and, by treating them as brothers, take advantage of their help.
('93', 243, 1, 25, 491759) They can help a lot; they have a great deal of experience.
('93', 243, 1, 26, 491818) God has given them health and honesty.
('93', 243, 1, 27, 491857) If what I have said about them is proved false, they will go away from here; and if I am keeping them here with any evil intention, I shall myself be doomed and the experiment for which I have come here will fail.

('93', 245, 3, 5, 494850) 335. TALK AT MEETING OF MASIMPUR MEROA GRAM SEVA SANGH 1
('93', 245, 4, 6, 494907) MASIMPUR, January 7, 1947
('93', 245, 5, 7, 494933) People should try to purify themselves and their religion from within and not indulge in outward show, said Mahatma Gandhi.
('93', 245, 6, 8, 495057) Replying to a question regarding the wearing of the sacred thread which, the questioner said, the Arya Samaj wanted every Hindu to wear, Gandhiji said that anyone who liked might wear the sacred thread but there should not be any movement or propaganda in this behalf.
('93', 245, 6, 9, 495326) No good would be done by wearing the sacred thread alone as it could not remove the defects of the Hindu religion.
('93', 245, 7, 10, 495441) Replying to another question as to whether there was difference between his ideals and those of the Arya Samajists, as the latter were telling the people, Gandhiji said there were differences in Arya Samaj itself, as there were several branches of it.
('93', 245, 7, 11, 495693) Some of their ideals tallied with his, but with regard to others he differed from the Arya Samaj.
('93', 245, 7, 12, 495791) For instance, while he had no difference as to ideals with Arya Samajists like Ghanshyam Gupta, Speaker of the Central Provinces Assembly, the same could not be said of every Arya Samajist.
('93', 245, 8, 13, 495981) Asked for his advice as to how people should earn a living, Gandhiji said his advice was spinning for all people.
('93', 245, 8, 14, 496095) He would also suggest weaving and carpentry.
('93', 245, 8, 15, 496140) The people should devote themselves more and more to these professions, thereby leading a pure life.
('93', 245, 9, 16, 496241) Gandhiji again stressed the importance of supply of pure drinking water in every village.

('93', 247, 0, 1, 498720) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 247, 1, 2, 498762) Muslim friends should have been upset at the singing of Ramdhun.
('93', 247, 1, 3, 498827) It indicated the nature of obstacles that must be faced and overcome if the country was to make progress.
('93', 247, 1, 4, 498933) The nature of propaganda carried on here has been such that the Muslims could not even bear to hear Ramdhun sung by Hindu devotees.
('93', 247, 1, 5, 499065) I am sorry because some of my friends had not been able to bear any name of God except Khuda but I am glad because they have had the courage of expressing their dissent openly and plainly.
('93', 247, 1, 6, 499254) This small incident probably gives an inkling of the mentality which had prevailed during the fateful October disturbances in the district.
('93', 247, 1, 7, 499394) I am extremely careful not to wound the susceptibilities of anyone unneces sarily.
('93', 247, 1, 8, 499477) It is essential that my Muslim brethren should realize as also the Hindus that it does not matter by what name God is addressed.
('93', 247, 1, 9, 499606) It is the same Creator whom people worship through many tongues.
('93', 247, 1, 10, 499671) I appeal to the Muslim brethren to assure me of that freedom which is true to the noblest traditions of Islam.
('93', 247, 1, 11, 499782) Even from the Muslim League platforms it has been repeatedly said that in Pakistan there will be full tolerance of the practice of their faiths by the minorities and that they will enjoy freedom of worship equally with the majority.
('93', 247, 2, 12, 500015) Gandhiji observed that Pakistan did not and could not mean that Hindus in Bengal and Sind should give up their religion and follow the practice of the majority community in order not to rouse the latter’s displeasure.
('93', 247, 2, 13, 500233) God could be approached through namaz as well as Ramdhun and there could not be a quarrel among branches of the same tree.
('93', 247, 3, 14, 500356) Gandhiji said that there was nothing to quarrel over the Hindus, Muslims and Christians.
('93', 247, 3, 15, 500445) When Gandhiji started from Chandipur, it was proposed that all through his way Ramdhun would be sung.
('93', 247, 3, 16, 500547) But he thought better of it lest it displeased the Muslims.
('93', 247, 3, 17, 500607) Although Ramdhun was very dear to him he did not like the idea that his Muslim brothers should think their Hindu brothers to be so arrogant as to march singing Ramdhun because of Gandhiji’s presence.
('93', 247, 4, 18, 500807) Gandhiji added that he had been very careful in his speeches and deeds not to offend his Muslim brethren.
('93', 247, 4, 19, 500913) He would desist from anything that displaced their sentiments or offended their religion.
('93', 247, 4, 20, 501003) But he could never give up his Ramdhun which brought him so much mental peace.
('93', 247, 4, 21, 501082) He had come to Noakhali to serve all communities, to help them to live together peacefully and in healthy atmosphere.
('93', 247, 4, 22, 501200) Every day during prayer, he not only recited from the Bhagavad Gita but also from the Koran, and religious differences simply did not exist for him.
('93', 247, 5, 23, 501349) He had come to Noakhali, Gandhiji said, to serve Hindus and Muslims alike.
('93', 247, 5, 24, 501424) But he would be helpless if Muslims wanted him to forgo the name of his God in exchange.
('93', 247, 5, 25, 501513) As he did not like to parade his religion, so also he could not forgo his
('93', 248, 0, 1, 501587) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 249
('93', 248, 1, 2, 501635) religious belief.
('93', 248, 1, 3, 501653) It was the unity of God and religion that he had come to preach.
('93', 248, 1, 4, 501718) He could not give it up, Gandhiji said, so long as he lived.
('93', 248, 2, 5, 501779) Concluding, Gandhiji pleaded for tolerance from the majority community and urged and minority community not to give up reciting Ramdhun in all humility and without any feeling of hostility towards others.
('93', 248, 2, 6, 501984) With proper understanding of each other’s religion, Gandhiji said, Muslim progress would be repaid and certain.

('93', 251, 6, 24, 508684) 344. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 251, 7, 25, 508716) FATEHPUR, January 8, 1947 I am so happy to see so many of you here this evening.
('93', 251, 7, 26, 508797) It is a grand day for me.
('93', 251, 8, 27, 508823) 1 Manu Gandhi 1 The reports in the various sources have been collated.
('93', 252, 0, 1, 508894) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 253
('93', 252, 1, 2, 508942) When he reached Fatehpur in the morning, Gandhiji said, he had been surrounded by affection all round, and among the messages received were also some from sisters.
('93', 252, 1, 3, 509106) They wanted to present him with sweets specially prepared by them, but Gandhiji had replied that he was hungering not for sweets for the tongue but for sweets for the heart.
('93', 252, 1, 4, 509280) He was grateful for the accommodation offered by the village, that was all that he needed.
('93', 252, 1, 5, 509371) Gandhiji did not want to be a burden on any village through which he was passing.
('93', 252, 1, 6, 509453) His own food was carried along with him while the expenses of the whole party had already been defrayed by loving friends.
('93', 252, 1, 7, 509576) Some Muslim friends had asked him why a feeling of estrangement was growing between the two communities in spite of the able leadership around, more specially in the Congress and the League.
('93', 252, 1, 8, 509767) Gandhiji confessed that it was indeed true that the people in general always followed the lead which came from above.
('93', 252, 1, 9, 509885) Therefore, it was not enough that leadership was able but it was necessary that there was accurate knowledge of the wants of the people.
('93', 252, 1, 10, 510022) For himself he was only trying to depend wholly upon God and work at the task which came naturally to him.
('93', 252, 1, 11, 510129) He commended the same course to everyone.
('93', 252, 1, 12, 510171) Today I am going through the greatest test of my life.
('93', 252, 1, 13, 510226) I am now to find if the road that I follow is really the true road for all people of this country.
('93', 252, 1, 14, 510325) I will not leave Noakhali unless I am assured by members of both communities that they would live like brothers in perfect unity.
('93', 252, 1, 15, 510455) If success does not come to me, I will not go away from Noakhali a defeated man, but would rather die in the achievement of my mission.
('93', 252, 1, 16, 510591) Gandhiji told his audience that some Muslims had come to him to seek his advice as to which was the right road he should ask them to follow.
('93', 252, 1, 17, 510732) He told them that he himself was in darkness and was searching for the right road and unless he found the same, he could not show them that path.
('93', 252, 1, 18, 510878) The road that he was searching today was the road of unity but he could not tell them how to reach that road.
('93', 252, 1, 19, 510988) He wanted them all to pray for success of his mission so that he might show to the country the right road to follow.

('93', 253, 2, 9, 512112) Yesterday was a pleasing contract.

('93', 261, 2, 10, 527831) Blessings from BAPU
('93', 261, 3, 11, 527851) From a photostat of the Hindi: G. N. 558
('93', 261, 4, 12, 527892) 358. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 261, 5, 13, 527922) JAGATPUR, January 10, 1947
('93', 261, 6, 14, 527949) Gandhiji said he had been hearing for some time—and more insistently since yesterday—that if Muslims asked Hindus to accept Islam if they wanted to save themselves or their property, and if the latter responded, there was no compulsion.
('93', 261, 6, 15, 528186) Gandhiji said he was not concerned for a moment with the truth or otherwise of that statement.
('93', 261, 6, 16, 528281) What he wanted to say was that this was acceptance of Islam under all the threat of force.
('93', 261, 7, 17, 528372) Conversion, Gandhiji held, was made of sterner stuff.
('93', 261, 7, 18, 528426) The statement reminded him of the days when Christian missionaries so called used to buy children in days of famine and bring them up as Christians.
('93', 261, 7, 19, 528575) This was surely no acceptance of Christianity.
('93', 261, 7, 20, 528622) Similarly, acceptance of Islam, to be real and valid, should be wholly voluntary and must be based on proper knowledge of the two faiths—one’s own and the one presented for acceptance.
('93', 261, 7, 21, 528807) Gandhiji could not conceive of the possibility of such acceptance of Islam by the women in front of him or children.
('93', 261, 7, 22, 528924) This was the view Gandhiji had held all his life.
('93', 261, 7, 23, 528974) He did not believe in conversion as an institution.
('93', 261, 7, 24, 529026) He would not ask his friends to accept Hinduism because he happened to be a Hindu.
('93', 261, 7, 25, 529109) Those who came to him with such a mind were recommended proper study of Hinduism and were told to incorporate in their own religion what was considered good in Hinduism.
('93', 261, 7, 26, 529279) He called himself not merely a Hindu but a Christian, a Muslim, a Jew, a Sikh, a Parsee, a Jain or a man of any other sect, meaning thereby that he had absorbed all that was commendable in all other religions and sub religions.
('93', 261, 7, 27, 529507) In this way, he avoided any clash and expanded his own conception of religion.
('93', 261, 8, 28, 529586) What he had said might not commend itself to everybody.
('93', 261, 8, 29, 529642) But he would like every Muslim to consider whether from what he had said it was not possible for them to see that Islam was much superior to what had been described to him during his pilgrimage.
('93', 261, 8, 30, 529837) He had prayerfully studied as much as he could in his busy life of Islam’s
('93', 261, 9, 31, 529912) 1 Muslim gentleman sent by Gandhiji to look after the addressee
('93', 262, 0, 1, 529976) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 263
('93', 262, 1, 2, 530024) history written by Muslim divines and he had not found a single passage in condonation of forcible conversion such as he had described.
('93', 262, 1, 3, 530160) Real conversion proceeded from the heart and a heart conversion was impossible without an intelligent grasp of one’s own faith and of that recommended for adoption.
('93', 262, 2, 4, 530325) Concluding, Gandhiji said that he was not going to be satisfied without a heart understanding between the two communities and this was not possible unless the Hindus and Muslims were prepared to respect each other’s religion leaving the process of conversion absolutely free and voluntary.
('93', 262, 2, 5, 530615) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 14 1 1947

('93', 265, 4, 9, 534910) 366. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 265, 5, 10, 534940) LAMCHAR, January 11, 1947
('93', 265, 6, 11, 534966) Gandhiji began his after prayer speech at Lamchar by saying that he would confine himself to a question that had been facing him for the last few days.
('93', 265, 6, 12, 535118) He gathered that a large number of artisans had lost both their homes as well as their instruments of trade which had either been destroyed or stolen.
('93', 265, 6, 13, 535269) What was going to be done about these people?
('93', 265, 7, 14, 535315) There was a time, he said, when our villages had a full complement of artisans serving farmers.
('93', 265, 7, 15, 535411) The latter were the centre of gravity of village economy.
('93', 265, 7, 16, 535469) Payment was then made in kind, and it was in conformity with the needs of the producers, just as production itself was strictly related to the needs of the people.
('93', 265, 7, 17, 535633) Different occupations were knit together by a bond of interdependence into an integrated whole.
('93', 265, 7, 18, 535729) This was India’s village economy in pre British days and in it all communities, including the Mussalmans shared to the fullest extent.
('93', 265, 7, 19, 535864) Under its dispensation, no man could go without food, shelter and clothing in a village.
('93', 265, 8, 20, 535953) But the problem which faced the villagers in this part of the country today was what should be done about the artisans whose life had been dislocated by riots.
('93', 265, 8, 21, 536113) Gandhiji expressed his hope that it would even now be possible to restore village economy to a sufficient extent to cope with the problem of unemployment.
('93', 265, 8, 22, 536268) It was the first duty of the Government to provide the artisans with dwelling houses as well as to supply them with instruments and raw materials needed for plying their trade.
('93', 265, 8, 23, 536445) Cash loans may be arranged; these should be free of interest and the payment spread conveniently over a long term.
('93', 265, 8, 24, 536560) Naturally the question of security should not arise.
('93', 265, 8, 25, 536613) The Government should be prepared to lose their money if any artisans died before full recovery of loans.
('93', 265, 9, 26, 536719) But if the Government did not perform its obvious duty, then moneyed men should come forward for the same purpose.
('93', 265, 9, 27, 536834) They should help the artisans on the same terms as sketched above.
('93', 265, 9, 28, 536901) Indeed, it was their duty to do so.
('93', 265, 9, 29, 536937) The bond of co operation which would thus be created between different classes of population, was a necessary
('93', 266, 0, 1, 537047) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 267
('93', 266, 1, 2, 537095) factor if our object was once more to restore healthy village life.
('93', 266, 2, 3, 537163) He advised the evacuees to brave all hardships and return home quickly.
('93', 266, 2, 4, 537235) By means of their own labour they must be determined to rebuild their ruined homes as well as their lives.
('93', 266, 3, 5, 537342) The Hindu, 14 1 1947; and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 20 1 1947

('93', 270, 5, 7, 543653) 376. INTERVIEW TO A MUSLIM VISITOR
('93', 270, 6, 8, 543688) KARPARA, January 12, 1947
('93', 270, 7, 9, 543714) The visitor had asked which of the two alternatives for a solution of the present situation in India would be preferable—Pakistan or civil war.
('93', 270, 8, 10, 543858) Gandhiji is reported to have said that he would approach the problem differently.
('93', 270, 8, 11, 543940) Neither of the two suggested solutions would be good.
('93', 270, 8, 12, 543994) It was wrong to think that Pakistan could be achieved through civil war.
('93', 270, 9, 13, 544067) The interviewer asked what kind of Government would be good for a free India.
('93', 270, 10, 14, 544145) Gandhiji’s reply to this was that it was not a question for him to answer.
('93', 270, 10, 15, 544220) The question would be ripe for answer after freedom had been achieved.
('93', 270, 11, 16, 544291) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 16 1 1947; also Harijan, 2 2 1947
('93', 270, 12, 17, 544347) 377. SPEECH AT KARPARA January 12, 1947 I have come to bring about heart unity between the two communities and if necessary to lay down my life in that attempt.
('93', 270, 12, 18, 544508) The Hindus and Muslims should remember that they are nourished by the same corn and live under the same sky, quench their thirst by the same water, in calamities that overtake the country are afflicted in the same way, irrespective of their religious beliefs.
('93', 270, 12, 19, 544768) It is very essential that both the communities should bury their differences and live in peace.

('93', 277, 1, 2, 555160) 389. TALK WITH MUSLIM YOUTHS 1
('93', 277, 2, 3, 555191) BHATIALPUR, January 14, 1947
('93', 277, 3, 4, 555220) Gandhiji thanked them and said : If your words come from your heart and not merely from your lips, then their effect will not be confined merely to India but will spread over the whole world.
('93', 277, 4, 5, 555412) They asked what his objection was to the setting up of a separate Muslim State after the events in Bihar.
('93', 277, 4, 6, 555518) Gandhiji replied : If a Muslim State implied freedom to make unfriendly treaties with foreign powers to the detriment of the country, then obviously it cannot be a matter of agreement.
('93', 277, 4, 7, 555703) No one can be asked to sign an agreement granting freedom to another to launch hostilities against himself; it would be suicidal policy.
('93', 277, 5, 8, 555840) On the young men asking whether Gandhiji did not think it advisable to concede Pakistan since it was holding back the issue of Indian independence, Gandhiji said: Only after independence has been won can there be a question of granting Pakistan.
('93', 277, 5, 9, 556086) To reverse the process was to invite foreign help.
('93', 277, 5, 10, 556137) Azadi and Pakistan require the exclusion of all foreign powers.
('93', 277, 5, 11, 556201) Until and unless India is free, there cannot be any other question.
('93', 277, 5, 12, 556269) When you think of establishing Pakistan first you think in terms of getting it with the aid of a third power.
('93', 277, 5, 13, 556379) When I think of the freedom of India, I think in terms of achieving it without any foreign aid, be it Russian, Chinese or any other, but on the basis of our own inner strength.
('93', 277, 5, 14, 556556) Then only will freedom be real and lasting.
('93', 277, 5, 15, 556600) Once freedom is secured for the country as a whole then we can decide about Pakistan or Hindustan.
('93', 277, 6, 16, 556699) Gandhiji was then asked why he should not go to Bihar where the tragedy was on a colossal scale compared to Noakhali.
('93', 277, 6, 17, 556817) His reply was : What has happened in Bihar is shameful enough.
('93', 277, 6, 18, 556880) But the people

('93', 278, 5, 12, 558240) 390. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 278, 6, 13, 558270) BHATIALPUR, January 14, 1947 It has been said that Pakistan did not imply curtailment of liberty to practise one’s own religion and pursue trade or profession after one’s own heart.
('93', 278, 6, 14, 558452) Therefore, it would be wrong on your part to think in terms of boycotting the minorty community and thus making it impossible for them to carry on their normal life.
('93', 278, 7, 15, 558618) Gandhiji further observed that boycott implied intolerance and the assumption of an attitude of superiority by some over others and said : We are sinners because we look down upon Harijans as untouchables.
('93', 278, 7, 16, 558824) But Islam is great because it made no distinction whatever between man and man.
('93', 278, 7, 17, 558904) If, however, you look down upon Hindus because they worship the same God under other names, then you are practising the same untouchability which is definitely a violation of a fundamental principle of Islam.
('93', 278, 8, 18, 559113) The number of Muslims who attended the meeting, Gandhiji said, was not in direct proportion to their population in the locality.
('93', 278, 8, 19, 559242) When women were not afraid of him, he was puzzled why men should be afraid to meet him.
('93', 278, 8, 20, 559330) Islam, Gandhiji emphasized, taught fear of only God and not man.
('93', 278, 8, 21, 559395) One should be afraid to commit sin, but having committed it, one should surrender oneself to God and cheerfully bear any punishment that might be meted out.
('93', 278, 8, 22, 559552) Gandhiji made a passing reference to the purdah system and urged that it should be scrapped.
('93', 278, 8, 23, 559645) The system kept women in complete
('93', 279, 0, 1, 559679) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 279, 1, 2, 559721) darkness in every respect.
('93', 279, 1, 3, 559748) The women of both communities should mix more freely and get to understand each other better.
('93', 279, 2, 4, 559842) Gandhiji repeated his request to the Muslims to write to H. S. Suhrawardy, the Bengal Premier, for withdrawal of Military and Police giving him protection.
('93', 279, 3, 5, 559998) Gandhiji made a reference to his visit to Muslim houses that morning.
('93', 279, 3, 6, 560068) He found that the Muslim women hesitated to come out in his presence.
('93', 279, 3, 7, 560138) He recalled the days of the Ali Brothers.
('93', 279, 3, 8, 560180) At a Muslim women’s meeting the Ali Brothers had tied their eyes with a piece of cloth and delivered their lecture but Gandhiji was allowed to address the meeting with open eyes.
('93', 279, 3, 9, 560359) Gandhiji added that real purdah was not of the body but the mind.
('93', 279, 3, 10, 560425) What was needed was real education among women, more so among Muslim women.
('93', 279, 3, 11, 560501) If darkness of their mind was not removed they could not do anything with outward purdah.

('93', 279, 3, 16, 560946) This was the lesson he would impress upon the audience.

('93', 283, 2, 3, 567165) NARAYANPUR, January 15, 1947
('93', 283, 3, 4, 567194) Gandhiji said that it was their primary duty to remove untouchability.
('93', 283, 3, 5, 567265) Unless this virus was removed from their society, there could not be any real progress in this country.
('93', 283, 3, 6, 567369) Secondly Hindu Muslim unity should be effected.
('93', 283, 3, 7, 567417) Both the Hindus and the Muslims should be eager to achieve this end.
('93', 283, 3, 8, 567486) They took water from the same tank and rice from the same paddy fields.
('93', 283, 3, 9, 567558) For the time being, they should forget politics and devote their sole attention to improve villages, spread education, develop industries and other constructive work.
('93', 283, 3, 10, 567725) For this purpose, workers must be prepared to die.
('93', 283, 3, 11, 567776) Replying to a question whether the refugees should now return home, Gandhiji said that they must return home at the earliest.
('93', 283, 3, 12, 567902) They must, however, shed fear.
('93', 283, 3, 13, 567933) Spinning also should form an important part of the duty of the workers.
('93', 283, 3, 14, 568005) If they span at least one hour a day, they could supply yarn to weavers who were now looking up to the Government for such supply for their handlooms.
('93', 283, 3, 15, 568156) The cloth problem would consequently be easier in this way.

('93', 287, 0, 1, 574109) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 287, 1, 2, 574151) 403. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 287, 2, 3, 574183) RAMDEBPUR, January 16, 1947
('93', 287, 3, 4, 574211) Gandhiji said that he had received certain questions from some Muslims while he was in Narayanpur yesterday.
('93', 287, 4, 5, 574320) [The first question was :] How could he advise 2 Assam and the Sikhs in the Punjab to stay out of Groups if his aim was Hindu Muslim unity and how, after this, was it possible for the Muslim League to join the Constituent Assembly?
('93', 287, 5, 6, 574552) Gandhiji said there was no “if” about his aim.
('93', 287, 5, 7, 574599) Hindu Muslim unity had been his aim from his youth upward, that is, for an unbroken period of 60 years.
('93', 287, 5, 8, 574703) He saw no contradiction between his aim and his advice to the people of Assam, the Sikhs and, for that matter, the Frontier and those who felt like it, to stay out of Groups or from the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 287, 5, 9, 574911) The Cabinet Mission’s Paper was of a voluntary nature and no party could be compelled to join the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 287, 5, 10, 575031) They had no force to back their resolution or wishes except the force of public opinion.
('93', 287, 6, 11, 575120) He had, therefore, given no advice which should make it impossible for the Muslim League to join the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 287, 6, 12, 575243) So far as he had read the resolution passed at the recent A. I. C. C. meeting, 3 the Congress had completely identified itself with the Cabinet Mission’s Paper.
('93', 287, 7, 13, 575404) Gandhiji hoped that the Muslim League would join the Constituent Assembly in which it was open to it to make good its position by an appeal to reason.
('93', 287, 7, 14, 575555) Otherwise the Constituent Assembly, because it was a voluntary organization brought into being by the only party that had force behind it, was like a house of cards.
('93', 287, 7, 15, 575721) It could only become a solid structure if it was backed by the opinion of the Indian masses.
('93', 287, 7, 16, 575814) Staying out by certain provines or groups could not and should not be a hindrance to the proceedings of the Constituent Assembly, if it was otherwise good.
('93', 287, 8, 17, 575970) Gandhiji would ask: Why should Assam be absorbed in Bengal against its will or the Frontier Province or the Sikhs into the Punjab and Sind?
('93', 287, 8, 18, 576110) The Congress or the League, as the case may be, should make their programme and policy intrinsically attractive so as to appeal to the reason of the recalcitrant Province or Group.
('93', 287, 9, 19, 576291) The second question put to him was: Gandhiji claimed to be a friend of both the communities, but he had been nursing back his own community for the last two months in Noakhali.
('93', 287, 9, 20, 576468) What about the Muslims of Bihar, who have lost their all?
('93', 287, 10, 21, 576526) He would say the question ignored facts.
('93', 287, 10, 22, 576567) He was not “nursing back” his own
('93', 287, 11, 23, 576601) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary” 2Vide “Letter to S. Rahdakrishnan”, 17 9 1946 3Vide “A. I. C. C. REsolution”
('93', 288, 0, 1, 576713) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 289
('93', 288, 1, 2, 576761) community.
('93', 288, 1, 3, 576772) He had no community of his own except in the sense that he belonged to all communities.
('93', 288, 1, 4, 576860) His record spoke for itself.
('93', 288, 1, 5, 576889) He freely admitted that he was trying to bring comfort to the Hindus of Noakhali, but not at the expense of the Muslims.
('93', 288, 1, 6, 577010) If there was a sick member in his family and he seemed to attend to the sick member, it surely did not mean that he neglected the others.
('93', 288, 2, 7, 577148) He had had repeated an insistent advice from Muslim friends that his place was more in Bihar, where the Muslims were, in point of numbers, much greater sufferers than the Hindus in Noakhali.
('93', 288, 2, 8, 577339) He was sorry that he had hitherto failed to make his Muslim critics see that he had sufficiently affected the Hindus of Bihar in favour of the Muslim sufferers.
('93', 288, 2, 9, 577500) If he listened to his critics against his own better reason and went to Bihar, it was just likely that he might injure the Muslim cause rather than serve it.
('93', 288, 3, 10, 577658) Thus, for instance, he might not find corroboration for the many charges brought against the Bihar Hindus and the Bihar Government and, in order to be able to make such a declaration, he had accepted the better course, namely, to advise the Bihar Ministry, which had accepted his advice, that they should jointly with the Bengal Government or by themselves, appoint an impartial commission of inquiry.
('93', 288, 4, 11, 578060) [The third question was :] Why cannot the apostle of non violence, the modern Buddha stop internecine war and blood bath in the country?
('93', 288, 5, 12, 578197) Gandhiji, replying to this question, acquitted himself from the charge of being the modern Buddha.
('93', 288, 5, 13, 578296) He was and claimed to be a simple man having extensive experience at his back, but on that account claimed to be no better than any member of the audience.
('93', 288, 5, 14, 578452) He was an equal servant of both the communities or all the communities of India.
('93', 288, 5, 15, 578533) He wished he had the power to stop ‘internecine war’ and consequent ‘blood bath’.
('93', 288, 5, 16, 578615) The Buddha or the prophets that followed him had gone the way they went in order to stop wars.
('93', 288, 5, 17, 578710) The fact that he could not do so was proof positive that he had no superior power at his back.
('93', 288, 5, 18, 578805) It was true that he swore by non violence and so he had come to Noakhali in order to test the power of his non violence.
('93', 288, 5, 19, 578926) As he had repeatedly said ever since his arrival in Bengal, he had no desire to leave Bengal unless both the communities showed by their action that they were like blood brothers living together in perfect peace and amity.
('93', 288, 5, 20, 579149) Gandhiji also dealt with a question that was raised by the Muslim friends who had seen him before the prayer meeting.
('93', 288, 5, 21, 579267) They had asked him how he expected friendly relations between the two communities when the Hindus agitated for the arrest and trial of those who were guilty of murders, arson and loot during the disturbances.
('93', 288, 5, 22, 579476) The speaker confessed that he did not like these complaints.
('93', 288, 5, 23, 579537) But he sympathized with the complainants so long as the wrongdoers avoided arrest and trial and so long as Muslim opinion in Noakhali did not insist upon the guilty parties
('93', 288, 6, 24, 579710) 1 What follows is reproduced from Harijan, 9 2 1947.
('93', 289, 0, 1, 579763) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 289, 1, 2, 579805) disclosing themselves.
('93', 289, 1, 3, 579828) He would be glad to see Muslim opinion working actively to bring the offenders not before the court of justice but before the court of public opinion.
('93', 289, 1, 4, 579979) Let the offenders show contrition and let them return the looted property.
('93', 289, 1, 5, 580054) Let them also show to those against whom offences were committed that they need fear no molestation, that the days of frenzy were over.
('93', 289, 1, 6, 580190) Muslim public opinion should be such as to guarantee that miscreants would not dare to offend against any individual and only then could Hindus be asked to return safely to their villages.
('93', 289, 1, 7, 580379) The speaker was sure that such purging before the court of public opinion was infinitely superior to a trial before a court of law.
('93', 289, 1, 8, 580511) What was wanted was not vengeance but reformation.
('93', 289, 1, 9, 580562) Harijan, 2 2 1947 and 9 2 1947
('93', 289, 2, 10, 580593) 404. LETTER TO T. PRAKASAM KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., January 17, 1947
('93', 289, 3, 11, 580679) DEAR PRAKASAM, I got yesterday your air mail letter of 9th instant.
('93', 289, 3, 12, 580747) This means six days and you will know for your information how far I am from the haunts of so called civilization.

('93', 290, 1, 2, 582005) 405. LETTER TO HAMIDUDDIN AHMED 1
('93', 290, 2, 3, 582039) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., January 17/19, 1947
('93', 290, 3, 4, 582101) DEAR HAMIDUDDIN SAHEB, I thank you for your letter of 10th instant received by me only yesterday.
('93', 290, 3, 5, 582199) I understand the cause of delay that took place in replying to my letter.
('93', 290, 3, 6, 582273) I do not propose to enter into any controversy with you.
('93', 290, 3, 7, 582330) But I propose to confine myself to removing misunderstanding that lurks in your letter.
('93', 290, 3, 8, 582418) A statement of mine about the happenings in Noakhali would have been premature, for the impressions formed have been damaging and facts that come to me even now are disturbing, if they are true as at least some of them seem to me to be.
('93', 290, 3, 9, 582655) The volunteers who are working are not under my guidance or discipline.
('93', 290, 3, 10, 582727) Their removal is surely the function of the Government.
('93', 290, 3, 11, 582783) I can only remove those whom I have brought with me.
('93', 290, 3, 12, 582836) I have already told Saheed Saheb that if for any reason whatsoever he finds the presence of anyone of them to be harmful to the country, he has but to serve a notice on them and they will go away without a murmur.
('93', 290, 3, 13, 583050) I have excepted from the category only myself and a grand daughter of mine who is with me.
('93', 290, 3, 14, 583141) Of course I know nothing of the subversive activities of any of the volunteers.
('93', 290, 3, 15, 583221) But if the report received by you is true and I were in your place I would certainly see to it that those responsible for such activities were summarily removed.
('93', 290, 3, 16, 583383) I have no recollection of your having ever suggested to me to get rid of any volunteer.
('93', 290, 3, 17, 583471) I would like you to tell me what I have said in public about the Bihar Government or the report of the Bihar Muslim League.
('93', 290, 3, 18, 583595) I have been most reticent about these things.
('93', 290, 3, 19, 583641) I have certainly entered into correspondence with Saheed Saheb and others.
('93', 290, 3, 20, 583716) But I am not aware of having said much in public.
('93', 290, 3, 21, 583766) I am sorry that I cannot accept your advice about Bihar nor can I endorse your estimate of the situation if I were in Bihar.
('93', 290, 3, 22, 583891) My firm opinion is that I could not do service to the Muslim cause by going to Bihar.
('93', 290, 3, 23, 583977) Immediately I feel that I could, I assure you that I would not

('93', 292, 5, 9, 586235) 408. SPEECH TO WOMEN
('93', 292, 6, 10, 586256) PARKOTE, January 17, 1947 What has happened in Noakhali is God’s curse, not only for Bengal but for the whole of India and it is high time that our outlook was changed.
('93', 292, 7, 11, 586425) Gandhiji said that Hindu women should give up the habit of differen tiating between high and low and between caste and caste.
('93', 292, 7, 12, 586551) They should move with all women on a basis of equality.
('93', 292, 7, 13, 586607) In particular Gandhiji advised Hindu women to mix freely with their Muslim sisters.
('93', 292, 7, 14, 586691) If the women of the two communities had been on terms of friendship and if Hindu women were in close touch with their Muslim sisters, much of what happened in Noakhali could have been prevented.
('93', 292, 8, 15, 586886) Gandhiji also advised women in the villages not to waste any of their spare time but to take to spinning and other subsidiary work, such as keeping their villages clean and the water in their tanks pure.
('93', 292, 9, 16, 587090) Gandhiji also said that his advice to the Hindu women applied to the men also and they should move as friends among the Muslims.
('93', 292, 9, 17, 587219) By friendly contact misunderstandings were cleared and chances of quarrels were eliminated.
('93', 292, 9, 18, 587311) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 20 1 1947
('93', 292, 10, 19, 587343) 409. SPEECH TO GRAM SEVA SANGH VOLUNTEERS
('93', 292, 11, 20, 587385) PARKOTE, January 17, 1947 The sword can be met by the sword but that will lead to nothing.
('93', 292, 11, 21, 587476) Remain non violent and harbour no fear.
('93', 292, 11, 22, 587516) If every one of you sheds fear, then the forty two of you will be as strong as 4200.
('93', 292, 12, 23, 587601) After the talk Gandhiji asked the volunteers whether they were free from fear.
('93', 293, 0, 1, 587680) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 293, 1, 2, 587722) One of the volunteers said they felt no fear—but only when all forty two of them were together.
('93', 293, 1, 3, 587818) That means that each of you is still possessed by fear, which means that all of you are.
('93', 293, 1, 4, 587907) Volunteers should have no fear even individually.
('93', 293, 1, 5, 587957) Whatever may happen, you should never bow down your heads and succumb to fear and dishonour.
('93', 293, 2, 6, 588050) Gandhiji asked the volunteers to engage themselves in work beneficial to the village.
('93', 293, 2, 7, 588136) They should mix with the Muslims as brothers and friends.
('93', 293, 2, 8, 588194) He deprecated the taking up of the lathi to fight the lathi and said this would never solve the problem.
('93', 293, 2, 9, 588299) He said : You cannot defeat anyone with the help of the lathi, but only with love.
('93', 293, 3, 10, 588382) When the volunteers asked Mahatma Gandhi to give them his blessings, Gandhiji said : You have my blessings, but only if you follow my advice.
('93', 293, 3, 11, 588524) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 20 1 1947
('93', 293, 4, 12, 588556) 410. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 293, 5, 13, 588588) PARKOTE, January 17, 1947
('93', 293, 6, 14, 588614) At Parkote, on the morning of the 17th, Gandhiji had read a speech delivered by the Qaid e Azam on the occasion of the foundation ceremony of a Girls’ High School by his sister, Miss Fatima Jinnah.
('93', 293, 6, 15, 588812) During the after prayer speech in the evening, he translated a portion of that speech in which Mr. Jinnah was reported to have said that Muslims should develop a high sense of responsibility, justice and integrity.
('93', 293, 6, 16, 589027) Wrong was not to be imitated.
('93', 293, 6, 17, 589057) If after consulting one’s conscience one felt that a contemplated action was wrong, one should never do it irrespective of any consideration or influence.
('93', 293, 6, 18, 589212) If people acted up to this rule, no one would be able to prevent them from attaining Pakistan.
('93', 293, 7, 19, 589307) Commenting upon this, Gandhiji said that as there was no question of force here and if Pakistan was going to be established by sterling qualities of character, everybody would welcome such a State, no matter by what name it was called.
('93', 293, 8, 20, 589543) No one could agree, he said, that loot, arson or forcible conversion,
('93', 293, 9, 21, 589613) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary” 2 The following three paragraphs are reproduced from Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('93', 294, 0, 1, 589723) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 295
('93', 294, 1, 2, 589771) no matter where committed, could ever be supported by the awakened conscience of man.
('93', 294, 2, 3, 589857) Gandhiji referred to the fact that the celebration was in connection with a girls’ school and recalled that Mr. Jinnah had advised the Education Minister in Sind to launch a determined drive against illiteracy.
('93', 294, 2, 4, 590068) In this lay the secret of future peace and unity.
('93', 294, 2, 5, 590118) Literary education by itself did not carry one far for there never had been any dearth of literary men.
('93', 294, 2, 6, 590222) What was needed was education for life.
('93', 294, 2, 7, 590262) Men and women, he continued, were two limbs of the social body and if one limb was atrophied then the whole body would suffer in consequence.
('93', 294, 2, 8, 590404) It was, therefore, very unfortunate that our sisters should be left in darkness and ignorance.
('93', 294, 3, 9, 590499) Hindu women joined the prayer in large numbers.
('93', 294, 3, 10, 590547) Why should not Muslim girls, if not women, find it possible to join the prayer?
('93', 294, 3, 11, 590627) The obvious duty of the Hindu sisters, Gandhiji continued, was to go to their Muslim sisters purely in a spirit of service.
('93', 294, 3, 12, 590751) Gandhiji added that they ought to remember Qaid e Azam Jinnah’s advice and act up to it; for it was advice not confined to any particular community; it was of universal significance.
('93', 294, 3, 13, 590934) The qualities which he had advised people to develop were not combativeness but a sense of justice and truth; and this implied that whenever justice was at stake, people ought to appeal to reason instead of taking recourse to barbarous methods of settling disputes whether private or public.
('93', 294, 4, 14, 591226) Harijan, 9 2 1947; and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 20 1 1947

('93', 298, 1, 2, 597212) 417. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 298, 2, 3, 597244) BADALKOT, January 18, 1947
('93', 298, 3, 4, 597271) Gandhiji’s answer was that he did not maintain illusion and never ascribed to himself any superior powers.
('93', 298, 3, 5, 597378) He had met Mr. Jinnah many times, as they knew, and their meetings had been marked by nothing but friendliness.
('93', 298, 3, 6, 597490) Yet the results were negative as they all knew.
('93', 298, 4, 7, 597538) The fact was, continued Gandhiji, that a leader was made by his fol lowers.
('93', 298, 4, 8, 597614) He reflected in a clearer manner the aspirations lying dormant among the masses.
('93', 298, 4, 9, 597695) This was true not only of India but of all the world.
('93', 298, 4, 10, 597749) What he would therefore suggest to both Hindus and Mussalmans was that they should not look to the Muslim League or the Congress or the Hindu Mahasabha for the solution of their daily problems of life.
('93', 298, 4, 11, 597951) For that they should look towards themselves; and if they did that then their desire for neighbourly peace would be reflected by the leaders.
('93', 298, 4, 12, 598093) The political institutions might be left to deal with specifically political questions but how much did they know about the daily needs of individuals?
('93', 298, 4, 13, 598245) If a neighbour was ailing, would they run to the Congress or the League to ask them what should be done?
('93', 298, 4, 14, 598350) That was an unthinkable proposition.
('93', 298, 5, 15, 598387) On the previous evening Gandhiji had quoted Mr. Jinnah’s advice that women should rapidly be rescued from illiteracy.
('93', 298, 5, 16, 598505) But Gandhiji said that that was not enough.
('93', 298, 5, 17, 598549) Was the condition of the literate men any better for their literacy?
('93', 298, 5, 18, 598618) Were they not, he asked, subject to the passing fashions of the political world?
('93', 298, 5, 19, 598699) Germany, which had lain so long under Hitler, proved what he meant; as all knew it was in a sorry plight today.
('93', 298, 5, 20, 598811) It was not literacy or learning which made a man, but education for real life.
('93', 298, 5, 21, 598890) What did it matter if they knew everything but did not know how to live as brothers with their neighbours?
('93', 298, 6, 22, 598997) Gandhiji continued that if some people had committed grievous mistakes in their dealings with their neighbours, they should repent and ask God to forgive them.
('93', 298, 6, 23, 599157) If He forgave them but the world did not, even then it did not matter to a man who had learnt to depend on God; such punishment nobly borne served to elevate a man.
('93', 298, 6, 24, 599322) Gandhiji then said that in a book of sayings of the Prophet he had found that a man should never leave an error uncorrected.
('93', 298, 6, 25, 599447) If he did, he would be hauled up on the Day of judgment and find no favour in the eyes of God.
('93', 298, 7, 26, 599542) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”.
('93', 298, 7, 27, 599578) The report explains : “A short while before prayer the Muslim friend at whose house Gandhiji had halted on his way to Badalkot, approached him and said that if there was a settlement between Mr. Jinnah and him, peace would be established in the country.”
('93', 299, 0, 1, 599833) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 299, 1, 2, 599875) It was not enough that they acquired the art of reading, writing, etc.
('93', 299, 1, 3, 599946) It was necessary that they should learn the art of living on friendly terms with their neighbours.
('93', 299, 1, 4, 600045) They should rescue the womenfolk, who formed half their numbers, from the thraldom of ignorance and superstition.
('93', 299, 1, 5, 600159) Men should live in co operation and work for the common good.
('93', 299, 1, 6, 600221) For this, they should not look up to political parties for direction, but to their own souls or God.
('93', 299, 2, 7, 600322) Personally, Gandhiji said, he had addressed himself wholly to that task.
('93', 299, 2, 8, 600395) He would not leave this part of the country alive if the work remained unaccomplished.
('93', 299, 2, 9, 600482) If he succeeded in overcoming the distrust of his Muslim brethren, and in establishing the fact that, after all, it was the daily things of life such as he had mentioned which mattered most, then its effect would be felt not merely in this part of the country but over the whole of India; and as such might even deeply affect the future peace of the world.
('93', 299, 2, 10, 600839) Harijan, 2 2 1947
('93', 299, 3, 11, 600857) 418. NOTE TO R. R. DIWAKAR 1
('93', 299, 4, 12, 600886) January 19, 1947 I am becoming more and more convinced that the four anna membership should go.
('93', 299, 4, 13, 600982) The membership of the Congress should be forty crores, the whole of the population, no matter to what sect, religion or Province or State or the so called independent possessions a particular individual belongs.
('93', 299, 4, 14, 601194) The members have an equal right with all to service by the Congress Organization.
('93', 299, 4, 15, 601276) These forty crore member will exercise no privilege by reason of their recognition as such by the Congress.
('93', 299, 4, 16, 601384) The organization will be worked by those who have been habitual wearers of khaddar one year before the date of commen cement, who have renounced untouchability in all its forms and who are not dealers in foreign cloth or intoxicants, who have full belief in the constructive programme of the Congress and who are prepared and willing to do work referred to in schedule A hereto and who have passed a probation period of six months in doing that work.
('93', 299, 4, 17, 601835) All committees and sub committees shall be formed from the workers above named.
('93', 299, 4, 18, 601915) The schedule to be prepared by you.

('93', 301, 11, 24, 604629) No man is a true believer unless he desireth for his brother that which he desireth for himself.

('93', 302, 1, 2, 604971) He is not of me, but a rebel at heart who when he speaketh, speaketh falsely, who when he promiseth, breaketh his promises and who when trust is reposed in him, faileth in his trust.
('93', 302, 2, 3, 605154) Muslims are those who perform their trust and fail not in their word and keep their pledge.
('93', 302, 3, 4, 605246) Whoever is kind to His creatures, God is kind to him.
('93', 302, 4, 5, 605300) A perfect Muslim is he from whose tongue and hands mankind is safe.
('93', 302, 5, 6, 605368) The worst of men is a bad learned man and a good learned man is the best.
('93', 302, 6, 7, 605442) When a man committeth adultery iman leaveth him.
('93', 302, 7, 8, 605491) He is not a Momin who commiteth adultery or stealeth, or who drinketh liquor or who plundereth or who embezzleth; beware, beware.
('93', 302, 8, 9, 605621) The most excellent jehad is that for the conquest of self.
('93', 302, 9, 10, 605680) Assist any person oppressed, whether Muslim or non Muslim.

('93', 302, 11, 12, 605817) Women are the twin halves of men.

('93', 302, 13, 14, 605898) The most valuable thing in the world is a virtuous woman.
('93', 302, 14, 15, 605956) Give your wife good counsel; if she has goodness in her she will soon take it; leave off idle thinking and do not beat your noble wife like a slave.
('93', 302, 15, 16, 606105) Gandhiji said that certain Muslims had asked him: ‘Who is this Muslim woman Amtussalaam who is fasting at Sirandi?’ Gandhiji said Amtussalaam had been with him for a long time.
('93', 302, 15, 17, 606282) She was a true Muslim.

('93', 303, 1, 2, 606767) 424. DRAFT PLEDGE FOR MUSLIMS 1
('93', 303, 2, 3, 606799) January 20, 1947 With God as witness, we solemnly declare that we bear no antagonism towards the Hindus or members of any other community.
('93', 303, 2, 4, 606938) To each one, to whatever faith he might belong, his religion is as dear as Islam is to us.
('93', 303, 2, 5, 607029) There can, therefore, be no question of interference by anybody in the observance of the religious practices of others.
('93', 303, 2, 6, 607149) We understand that Bibi Amtussalaam’s object is the establishment of Hindu Muslim unity.
('93', 303, 2, 7, 607238) The object is gained by the signing of this pledge.
('93', 303, 2, 8, 607290) We wish, therefore, that she should give up her fast.
('93', 303, 2, 9, 607344) 2 We realize that if we are found to have acted with any mental reservations in this matter we shall have to face a fast on Gandhiji’s part.
('93', 303, 2, 10, 607485) Our endeavour for the recovery of the remaining sword shall continue.
('93', 303, 3, 11, 607555) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book II, pp.
('93', 303, 4, 12, 607607) 425. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('93', 303, 5, 13, 607635) A correspondent writes to me to say that the strained relations between the Hindus and the Muslims bid fair, if timely warning is not taken, to replace Nagari and Urdu scripts with Roman.
('93', 303, 5, 14, 607823) There are undoubtedly protagonists of the Roman as the universal script.
('93', 303, 5, 15, 607896) It seems to me that it would be a great human tragedy if such a result comes about.
('93', 303, 5, 16, 607980) Time saving devices are good up to a certain point.
('93', 303, 5, 17, 608032) But they take the form of a mania when they destroy human relations and desirable restraints.
('93', 303, 5, 18, 608126) I must not tarry to examine what they are.
('93', 303, 5, 19, 608169) Suffice it to say that lovers of the Nagari script, which is scientifically almost perfect, and the Urdu script, which is so graceful, will not be carried away by the lazy craze for the Roman script.
('93', 303, 5, 20, 608369) Would that both the communities will be sane enough to realize that the mutual dislike is not allowed to replace the two Indian scripts.
('93', 303, 5, 21, 608506) But if that happy consummation does not take place, let those few or many who have regard for sacred human understanding assiduously learn both the scripts and thus enrich the Indian national language, Hindustani, as the

('93', 305, 7, 21, 612107) 428. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 305, 8, 22, 612139) KETHURI, January 21, 1947
('93', 305, 9, 23, 612165) Gandhiji explained the reasons which actuated the twenty five days’ fast of Bibi Amtussalaam and the reasons which brought it to an end.
('93', 305, 9, 24, 612302) The fast was broken at 9.30 last evening after the recital of the Al Fateha in a powerful and melodious voice by a Muslim gentleman who happened to be at the meeting.
('93', 305, 9, 25, 612469) Many Muslim friends including Abdulla Saheb and his lieutenant exerted themselves during the day to find out how the fast could be ended while Gandhiji was present in Sirandi.
('93', 305, 9, 26, 612645) It was common cause that the khadag for which the fast was said to have been undertaken could not, in spite of strenuous and honest efforts by many persons, be traced.
('93', 305, 9, 27, 612813) And if Amtussalaambehn persisted in wanting the production of the khadag, she must die.
('93', 305, 9, 28, 612901) But Gandhiji had explained to her that that could not be the real object of the fast; it must be a symbol of something behind it.
('93', 305, 9, 29, 613031) Gandhiji then said that the lady’s whole
('93', 305, 10, 30, 613072) 1 One word here is illegible.
('93', 305, 10, 31, 613102) 2 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”
('93', 306, 0, 1, 613137) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 307
('93', 306, 1, 2, 613185) life was devoted to a heart unity between the Hindus and the Muslims.
('93', 306, 1, 3, 613255) Therefore if there was a real prospect of such unity at least within the area where she was working, there was every prospect of the fast being ended.
('93', 306, 2, 4, 613406) After full and complete deliberation, a document was signed laying down the principle that to each one his religion was equally dear with any other person’s and that therefore different religions were to be mutually respected.
('93', 306, 2, 5, 613633) To this end the signatories to the agreement have pledged themselves.
('93', 306, 2, 6, 613703) Naturally, any wilful breach of the promise would implicate me in a fast.
('93', 306, 2, 7, 613777) On the document being interpreted to Amtul Salaambehn, the lady broke the fast as said before.
('93', 306, 3, 8, 613872) Gandhiji assured the signatories that he would help to the best of his ability in the matter of preserving the just rights of each community even as he expected them actively to implement their promise.
('93', 306, 4, 9, 614075) Gandhiji also expressed his desire that any development of any kind within the area mentioned in the document must be brought to his notice and convinced them that he would actively assist in the settlement of all disputes.
('93', 306, 4, 10, 614299) Gandhiji told the Hindus and Muslims of his dislike of matters being rushed to police and law courts.
('93', 306, 4, 11, 614401) Any surrender of its legitimate rights by the majority community or even the minority community for the sake of reaching an agreement, Gandhiji warned, would not lead to a lasting peace.
('93', 306, 5, 12, 614588) Harijan, 9 2 1947; and The Hindu, 23 1 1947
