('93', 308, 9, 17, 617180) 435. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 308, 10, 18, 617212) PANIALA, January 22, 1947
('93', 308, 11, 19, 617238) Gandhiji was happy that at last he had been able to visit the village of Paniala.
('93', 308, 11, 20, 617320) 2 But that was not enough; he would feel happier still if the Hindus and the Mussalmans succeeded in establishing unity and friendship between themselves.
('93', 308, 12, 21, 617475) Amtussalaam had undertaken her fast, as they all knew, with the same object.
('93', 308, 12, 22, 617552) And the assurance that the villagers in her neighbourhood had given to her should go a long way in healing the wound which tore the face of Bengal.
('93', 308, 13, 23, 617700) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”.
('93', 308, 13, 24, 617736) The report explains that the “gathering was .
('93', 308, 13, 25, 617782) of the largest size so far encountered”.
('93', 308, 13, 26, 617823) 2 Gandhiji had desired to visit Paniala in December; vide “Message to the People of Paniala Union”, 22 12 1946
('93', 309, 0, 1, 617934) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 309, 1, 2, 617976) One problem, continued Gandhiji, which had been recently exercising him was in connection with the families of those who had lost their all in the course of the disturbances.
('93', 309, 1, 3, 618151) There were many families which had lost their earning members.
('93', 309, 1, 4, 618214) The survivors had to be looked after, while the children had to be educated and given adequate protection.
('93', 309, 1, 5, 618321) That undoubtedly was the duty of the Government.
('93', 309, 1, 6, 618370) Both he and they if they wanted heart peace should look at the question from a broader standpoint.
('93', 309, 1, 7, 618469) In his humble opinion, where the wrong was done by some Muslims, reasonable arrangements for the above purpose should be made by the Muslims of the neighbourhood.
('93', 309, 2, 8, 618632) Government would only act through force while the common citizen would act through persuasion and agreement.
('93', 309, 2, 9, 618741) Through the establishment of good human relations, citizens should try to tide over the disasters which might overwhelm the social body.
('93', 309, 2, 10, 618878) It was not good to depend on an organization based on force like the State for the above purpose.
('93', 309, 3, 11, 618976) Gandhiji then referred to two more matters, namely, the duty of volun teers and the rehabilitation of artisans.
('93', 309, 3, 12, 619088) With regard to the volunteers his advice was that they should never discriminate between one type of duty and another, have no preferences, but should stick to their post even at the cost of their lives.
('93', 309, 3, 13, 619292) It was the quality of discipline and sacrifice which made small things great in organized action.
('93', 309, 3, 14, 619390) Then, referring to the pro blem of the artisans, he continued, they ought not to depend upon charity however well intended but on their own resources in order to tide over their present difficulties.
('93', 309, 3, 15, 619590) In this connection he referred to his view supported by the scriptures of the world that he who ate his food without returning its equivalent by means of body labour was no better than a thief.
('93', 309, 3, 16, 619784) Permanent peace would come in the world only when the bond of labour shared in common held together different units of the social body.
('93', 309, 4, 17, 619920) The first question was: “You said that Muslim majority provinces if they so chose had Pakistan already.
('93', 309, 4, 18, 620024) What did you mean by this?”
('93', 309, 5, 19, 620052) Gandhiji replied that he fully meant what he had said.
('93', 309, 5, 20, 620107) Whilst there was an outside power ruling India there was neither Pakistan nor Hindustan, but bare slavery was their lot.
('93', 309, 5, 21, 620228) And if anybody maintained that the measure of provincial autonomy they enjoyed was equal to independence, they were unaware of the contents of Independence.
('93', 309, 5, 22, 620385) It was true that the British power was certain to go.
('93', 309, 5, 23, 620439) But if they could not patch up their quarrels and indulged in blood baths, a combination of powers was certain to hold them in bondage.
('93', 309, 5, 24, 620575) Those powers would not tolerate a country so vast and populous as India and so rich in potential resources to rot away because of internal disturbances.
('93', 309, 5, 25, 620728) Every country had to live for the rest.
('93', 309, 5, 26, 620768) Days when they could
('93', 309, 6, 27, 620789) 1 Gandhiji then answered questions by Muslim Leaguers.

('93', 310, 1, 2, 620892) drag on the frog in the well existence were gone.
('93', 310, 1, 3, 620942) Even before the Congress had taken up non violent non co operation as the official policy for the whole of India, that is, before 1920, a resolutionto that effect was passed in Gujarat under the chairmanship of the late Abbas Tyabji Saheb.
('93', 310, 1, 4, 621182) The speaker had said that it was open even to one province to vindicate its position and become wholly independent of the British power.
('93', 310, 1, 5, 621319) Thus supposing that following the prescription, Bengal alone became truly and completely independent, there would be complete Pakistan of his defi nition in Bengal.
('93', 310, 1, 6, 621484) Islam was nothing if it did not spell complete democracy.
('93', 310, 1, 7, 621542) Therefore, there would be one man one vote and one woman one vote irrespective of religion.
('93', 310, 1, 8, 621634) Naturally, therefore, there would be a true Muslim majority in the Province.
('93', 310, 1, 9, 621711) Had not Jinnah Saheb declared that in Pakistan minorities would, if possible, be even better off than the majority; therefore, there would be no underdog?
('93', 310, 2, 10, 621866) Gandhiji reiterated that if such a State was established by sheer merit and so long as the qualities of truth and justice were emphasized, as had been done by him (Gandhiji), nobody would raise any objection, call it Pakistan or by any other name.
('93', 310, 2, 11, 622114) If the Muslims felt that in their contemplated Pakistan, Muslims alone would be allowed to remain, Gandhiji thought he must say that it was something un Islamic.
('93', 310, 2, 12, 622276) Islam, he said, was based on the fundamental principle of democracy and toleration of other faiths.
('93', 310, 2, 13, 622376) If any individual, be he Hindu or Muslim or Christian, disobeyed the fundamental basis of others’ religion, it was he who fell, and not the religion.
('93', 310, 2, 14, 622526) If Pakistan meant anything more, the speaker did not know; and if it did, so far as he knew, it would make no appeal to his reason.
('93', 310, 3, 15, 622658) The second question was: “How did your ahimsa work in Bihar?”
('93', 310, 4, 16, 622720) Gandhiji said that it did not work at all.
('93', 310, 4, 17, 622763) It failed miserably.
('93', 310, 4, 18, 622784) But, if the reports received by him from responsible quarters were to be relied upon, the Bihar Government was making full amends and the general population in Bihar also had realized the heinousness of the crimes committed by large masses of Biharis in certain portions of that Province.
('93', 310, 5, 19, 623073) One of the Bihar Ministers came to Noakhali with the promise from the Bihar Government that they would spare no pains for rehabilitating the people.
('93', 310, 5, 20, 623222) Gandhiji said he was receiving letters and resolutions passed by the Muslim League and he was conversant with the case referred to by them.
('93', 310, 5, 21, 623362) He sent every case for immediate attention and thorough investigation by the Bihar Government.
('93', 310, 5, 22, 623457) To the Bihar Government Gandhiji had suggested the setting up of an impartial tribunal to enquire into the happenings and the Bihar Government had promised to abide by its findings in toto.
('93', 310, 6, 23, 623647) The third question was: “Why are you silent about the eviction of Bengalis by
('93', 310, 7, 24, 623725) 1 The following paragraph is reproduced from The Hindu.
('93', 310, 7, 25, 623781) 2 This paragraph is reproduced from The Hindu.
('93', 311, 0, 1, 623828) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 311, 1, 2, 623870) the Assam Government?”
('93', 311, 2, 3, 623893) Gandhiji said that he was not deliberately silent.
('93', 311, 2, 4, 623944) The question was not new for him.
('93', 311, 2, 5, 623978) Gandhiji said that he had it in his programme during his last visit to Assam.
('93', 311, 2, 6, 624056) So far as his information went, Assam Government’s objection was to those who had settled in different parts of that Province without permission of the Assam Government.
('93', 311, 3, 7, 624226) When some years ago he went to Assam he was taken to the very spot where Muslims from Mymensingh had migrated and taken possession of vacant lands.
('93', 311, 3, 8, 624374) He had then given his opinion and held it even now that it was not open to persons to usurp vacant land wherever it may be, that is, whether in their own Province or in another.
('93', 311, 3, 9, 624552) For him it was not a Hindu Muslim question.
('93', 311, 3, 10, 624596) What he had said was of universal application.
('93', 311, 3, 11, 624643) If Assam attempted to evict lawful possessors, it would be guilty of crime against humanity.
('93', 311, 3, 12, 624736) What he had heard was quite the contrary.
('93', 311, 3, 13, 624778) But if there was a question of unlawful eviction, the Assam Government would not be above law and it was open also to the Bengal Government to vindicate the position of evicted Bengalis, here happening to be Muslims.
('93', 311, 4, 14, 624995) Gandhiji said that if the friends here had another tale to narrate he was ready to hear it.
('93', 311, 4, 15, 625087) Most he could do was to advise the Assam Ministry to set up an impartial commission of inquiry as in Bihar and refer the whole subject to it.
('93', 311, 4, 16, 625229) As a matter of fact the present Ministry of Assam was pursuing a policy chalked out by the Ministry previously in office.
('93', 311, 5, 17, 625351) The next question was: “What in your opinion is the cause of communal riots?”
('93', 311, 6, 18, 625429) Gandhiji said that in his opinion the riots were due to the idiocy of both the communities.
('93', 311, 7, 19, 625521) No one party could create a riot, he said, if the other party remained non violent and honest.
('93', 311, 7, 20, 625616) Referring to the recent outbreaks in Bombay and other places, Gandhiji said he had seen how an “eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth” policy had been pursued to its bitter end in these places.
('93', 311, 7, 21, 625811) One day one Muslim was stabbed and the following day a Hindu was found stabbed and vice versa.
('93', 311, 7, 22, 625906) What else could it be called, Gandhiji asked.
('93', 311, 7, 23, 625952) It was the same outlook that lay at the root of all communal riots.
('93', 311, 7, 24, 626020) Gandhiji asked : We are children of the same soil and have the same origin and if any of my brothers provoked me to commit some evil act, why shall I submit to him?
('93', 311, 7, 25, 626185) If anybody tried to force a change of religion or if
('93', 311, 8, 26, 626238) 1 The rest of the paragraph is reproduced from Hindustan Standard.
('93', 311, 8, 27, 626305) 2 This paragraph is reproduced from Hindustan Standard.

('93', 312, 1, 2, 626473) anyone tried to molest a woman, why should he or she submit before this brute force?
('93', 312, 2, 3, 626558) He added it was incumbent upon anyone to court death non violently in resisting such force.
('93', 312, 2, 4, 626650) How long would an oppressor continue in acts of violence if he found non violent people who were determined to face death instead of surrendering?
('93', 312, 2, 5, 626797) Retaliation, according to Gandhiji, was not the remedy and it was non violence alone which could counteract wrong and put an end to the madness that was inherent in communal riots.
('93', 312, 3, 6, 626978) The fifth question was: “Do you think that you would be successful in bringing peace to Noakhali without having it at the Centre?”
('93', 312, 4, 7, 627109) Gandhiji replied that if by the Centre was meant a pact between Jinnah Saheb, President of the Muslim League and Acharya Kripalani, President of the Indian National Congress, he certainly held that such a pact was not necessary in order to bring about harmonious relations between the Hindus and the Muslims in Noakhali.
('93', 312, 4, 8, 627430) So far as he knew neither the President of the Congress nor the President of the Muslim League desired discord between the two.
('93', 312, 4, 9, 627558) They had their political quarrel.
('93', 312, 4, 10, 627592) But the disturbances in India whether in Bengal, Bihar or elsewhere were insensate and hindered political progress.
('93', 312, 4, 11, 627708) He, therefore, felt that it was open to the Hindus and the Muslims in Noakhali to behave like men and cultivate peaceful relations among themselves.
('93', 312, 5, 12, 627857) The last question was: “Who according to your opinion have saved the Hindus and Hindu property in Noakhali?
('93', 312, 5, 13, 627965) Do you not think that Muslim neighbours saved them?”
('93', 312, 6, 14, 628018) Gandhiji replied that the question assumed a subtle pride.
('93', 312, 6, 15, 628077) What was wanted was a spirit of humility and repentance that there were enough Muslims found in Noakhali who had lost their heads to the extent of committing loot, arson and murder and resorting to forcible conversions, etc.
('93', 312, 6, 16, 628302) If more mischief was not done, God alone was to be thanked, not man.
('93', 312, 6, 17, 628371) At the same time the speaker was free to confess that be it said to their honour, there were Muslims who afforded protection to Hindus.

('93', 313, 10, 25, 629964) DALTA, January 23, 1947
('93', 313, 11, 26, 629988) Gandhiji announced that the Chowdharis of the village had decided to give him the plot of ground on which the meeting was being held.
('93', 313, 11, 27, 630122) He congratulated the Chowdharis on their generous action.
('93', 313, 11, 28, 630180) The gift to him carried no meaning beyond that it was presented for public use irrespective of caste or party.
('93', 313, 11, 29, 630291) Naturally there would be a proper document setting out the grant.
('93', 313, 11, 30, 630357) He hoped that the donors would carry out the full purpose of the gift.
('93', 313, 11, 31, 630428) The further cause for congratulation was that he was accom modated in the house of Rai Mohan Mali.
('93', 313, 11, 32, 630527) He did not consider himself to belong to any caste.
('93', 313, 11, 33, 630579) He belonged to the lowest rung of the Hindu ladder.
('93', 313, 11, 34, 630631) In reality there was no ladder; no high, no low.
('93', 313, 11, 35, 630680) All were equal in the eyes of God as of law.
('93', 313, 11, 36, 630725) It was a happy
('93', 313, 12, 37, 630740) 1 Extracted from “Srirampur Diary”
('93', 314, 0, 1, 630775) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 315
('93', 314, 1, 2, 630823) conjunction of events that it happened to be Netaji’s birthday.
('93', 314, 1, 3, 630887) What could be happier than that the Chowdharis should make their gift on this day and that a Scheduled Class friend, Rai Mohan Mali, should provide him habitation?
('93', 314, 1, 4, 631051) In the speaker’s opinion the great and most lasting act of Netaji was that he abolished all distinctions of caste and class.
('93', 314, 1, 5, 631176) He was not a mere Hindu, nor a mere Bengali; he never thought of himself as a caste Hindu.
('93', 314, 1, 6, 631267) He was Indian first and last.
('93', 314, 1, 7, 631297) What was more, he fired all under him with the same zeal so that they forgot in his presence all distinctions and acted as one man.
('93', 314, 1, 8, 631429) No doubt there was much else to be credited to Netaji.
('93', 314, 1, 9, 631484) Thus he had sacrificed a brilliant career for the sake of the country’s service and enlisted himself under the late Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das.
('93', 314, 1, 10, 631629) He suffered various imprisonments, twice became President of the Congress and at last by great strategy gave the slip to the guard put over him by the then Government of Bengal and by sheer courage and resourcefulness reached Kabul and passed through European countries and finally found himself in Japan, collected from scattered material an army of brilliant young men drawn from all communities and from all parts of India and dared to give battle to a mighty Government.
('93', 314, 1, 11, 632104) A lesser man would have succumbed under the trials that Netaji went through; but he in his life verified the saying of Tulsidas that “all becomes right for the brave”.
('93', 314, 1, 12, 632272) Gandhiji ended by saying that the Hindus should progress by forgetting all distinctions of caste and both the communities should develop unity of heart.
('93', 314, 1, 13, 632425) He was reminded of a saying of the Prophet in which it was said that a man would be judged on the Day of Judgment not by what he professed by his lips, nor by whom he followed, but by what he had himself done to implement the teachings received by him.
('93', 314, 1, 14, 632678) Harijan, 9 2 1947

('93', 317, 6, 30, 638289) 444. TALK TO REPRESENTATIVES OF KRISHAK SAMITI 2
('93', 317, 7, 31, 638338) MURIYAM, January 24, 1947
('93', 317, 8, 32, 638364) Representatives of the Krishak Samiti, Hashnabad People’s Relief Committee, informed Gandhiji about the way in which Hindus and Muslims of Hashnabad raised a
('93', 317, 9, 33, 638522) 1 Vide “Telegram to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 15 1 1947 2 This appeared under the title “Self help to Avoid Food Crisis”.
('93', 318, 0, 1, 638637) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 319
('93', 318, 1, 2, 638685) volunteer corps of about twelve hundred strong to defend the area from an onslaught of communal riots.
('93', 318, 1, 3, 638788) Gandhiji remarked : I heard of Hashnabad some time ago as the bright spot of Hindu Muslim unity during the riot period.
('93', 318, 2, 4, 638908) The interviewers then told him of a food cricis developing in that area and asked him if he would say something about it in his speeches so as to draw the attention of the Bengal Government.
('93', 318, 2, 5, 639099) Gandhiji replied : Though I am not saying anything about the coming food crisis, I am aware of the situation.
('93', 318, 2, 6, 639209) I am trying to solve it in my own way.
('93', 318, 2, 7, 639248) I do not see why the people should depend upon Government or other agencies for help.
('93', 318, 2, 8, 639334) We hear nowadays of people trying to secure foodstuffs from foreign countries.
('93', 318, 2, 9, 639413) As a matter of fact if people will help themselves, then the Government is bound to move and this is what I will call real democracy, which is built up from below.
('93', 318, 2, 10, 639577) Bengal possesses rich lands.
('93', 318, 2, 11, 639606) They can produce edible roots.
('93', 318, 2, 12, 639637) But again it is difficult to induce people to revise their tastes and old habits.
('93', 318, 2, 13, 639719) Look at these coconut trees.
('93', 318, 2, 14, 639748) Coconut makes a good nutritious food.
('93', 318, 2, 15, 639786) I am trying to accustom myself to it.
('93', 318, 2, 16, 639824) Of course, I extract the oil from it and the remaining portion as you know, contains good protein.
('93', 318, 2, 17, 639923) Then take the many kinds of roots in the soil of Bengal which belong to the potato tribe and these can be used as good food.
('93', 318, 2, 18, 640048) Then again, you have abundance of fish.
('93', 318, 2, 19, 640088) Fish, coconuts and these roots can easily take the place of rice.
('93', 318, 3, 20, 640154) Incidentally Gandhiji mentioned the general supineness of the people.
('93', 318, 3, 21, 640224) As an instance he mentioned the water hyacinth which, if the people en masse volunteered their services for a week without any aid from Government, they could get rid of within a week’s time, causing a saving of thousands of rupees.
('93', 318, 4, 22, 640457) Gandhiji was asked his opinion about the Tebhaga Movement 1 in Bengal.
('93', 318, 4, 23, 640528) Gandhiji confessed his ignorance about the movement and asked for a note on the subject which the questioners have undertaken to supply.
('93', 318, 5, 24, 640665) QUESTION: Can we not build up Hindu Muslim unity through a concrete political programme?
('93', 318, 6, 25, 640754) GANDHIJI: Probably you can.
('93', 318, 6, 26, 640782) But I have got my own ways.
('93', 318, 6, 27, 640810) I think if people help themselves, then politics will take care of themselves.
('93', 318, 7, 28, 640889) 1 The movement was for reduction of the landlord’s share in the produce of land.
('93', 318, 7, 29, 640970) For Gandhiji’s views on the movement, vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 31 1 1947
('93', 319, 0, 1, 641051) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('93', 319, 2, 3, 641167) G. Yes, yes, all good movements have my blessings.

('93', 319, 3, 5, 641236) 445. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 319, 4, 6, 641268) MURIYAM, January 24, 1947
('93', 319, 5, 7, 641294) Gandhiji began by saying that he felt much pleasure in being housed in a Muslim 2 house.
('93', 319, 5, 8, 641383) He and his party had received every attention.
('93', 319, 5, 9, 641430) The Muslim friends went so far as to find a maidan large enough to hold the largest number of visitors possible.
('93', 319, 5, 10, 641543) And it so happened that the meeting was the largest of all during his pilgrimage.
('93', 319, 5, 11, 641625) He attributed the largeness of the meeting to the fast of Bibi Amtussalaam which had a happy ending because of the sincere labours of Abdullah Saheb and his assistance and that of the leading Muslims of the villages concerned.
('93', 319, 5, 12, 641852) Whether his inference was justified or not, he flattered himself with the belief he had expressed.
('93', 319, 6, 13, 641951) He was sorry that there was poison administered to the public by some newspapers.
('93', 319, 6, 14, 642033) Newspapers today had almost replaced the Bible, the Koran, the Gita and the other religious scriptures.
('93', 319, 6, 15, 642137) It was wrong but the fact had to be faced.
('93', 319, 6, 16, 642180) Such being the case, he held it to be the duty of newspapermen to give nothing but facts to their readers.
('93', 319, 7, 17, 642287) He was also of opinion that the movement of minorities to the majority provinces was an impracticable proposition.
('93', 319, 7, 18, 642402) He knew the time when the late two Imam brothers 3 and the late Mazharul Haq 4 Saheb led both the communities and the leading Hindus, such as the late Brajkishore Prasad and Dr. Rajendra Prasad gladly worked under them.
('93', 319, 7, 19, 642622) Muslims of that Bihar must not leave Bihar.
('93', 319, 7, 20, 642666) It was true that some Bihar Hindus had acted inhumanly but that aberration ought not to deflect the Muslims from their clear duty bravely to stick to their homes which were theirs by right.
('93', 319, 7, 21, 642856) And the Bihari Hindus had to make all possible amends for the misdeeds of the Hindus who had become insane.
('93', 319, 7, 22, 642964) He would say the same to Noakhali Hindus and Muslims.
('93', 319, 7, 23, 643018) It was therefore a good omen that there were Muslims in the village to harbour him.
('93', 319, 7, 24, 643102) It was their duty to make even a solitary Hindu absolutely safe in their midst and Hindus should have faith enough to stay in Noakhali.
('93', 319, 7, 25, 643238) Harijan, 9 2 1947

('93', 322, 12, 22, 647904) If they were out of tune outside, they were likely to be out of tune within.
('93', 322, 12, 23, 647981) He then alluded to two telegrams received from the Jamiat ul Ulema e Islam in Madras and Bombay respectively.
('93', 322, 12, 24, 648091) They said that he, an unbeliever, had no right to interfere in the Islamic Law.
('93', 322, 12, 25, 648171) He submitted that the telegrams were based on ignorance of facts.
('93', 322, 12, 26, 648237) He had not interfered at all in the practice of religion.
('93', 322, 12, 27, 648295) He had neither the right nor the wish to do so.
('93', 322, 12, 28, 648343) All he had done was to tender advice and that based on his reading of the Prophet’s sayings, etc.
('93', 322, 12, 29, 648441) What was more, he had observed in many cultured Muslim families total

('93', 328, 8, 18, 659452) 461. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 328, 9, 19, 659482) BANSA, January 26, 1947 Today is the 26th of January, the day of our freedom.
('93', 328, 9, 20, 659560) When Congress was born, India obtained a new lease of life.
('93', 328, 9, 21, 659620) Only a few Indians at the time were aware of the political significance of this, but gradually the Congress grew strong and it awakened freedom consciousness in every village by starting mass agitation.
('93', 328, 9, 22, 659823) In the days when there was no communal hatred no one cared whether a person
('93', 328, 10, 23, 659899) 1 According to Manu Gandhi, an A. P. I. representative who came up with a proposal for celebration of independence.
('93', 328, 10, 24, 660015) The flag salutation was performed by Niranjan Gill and Gandhiji merely attended the function.
('93', 328, 10, 25, 660109) Vide also the following item.
('93', 329, 0, 1, 660139) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 329, 1, 2, 660181) was a Hindu or a Muslim.
('93', 329, 1, 3, 660206) It is a sad thing to have to say that there are two opinions now where there was only one before.
('93', 329, 1, 4, 660304) But for the poisoned atmosphere prevalant here, I would have unfurled the tricolour flag myself.
('93', 329, 1, 5, 660401) Some friends suggested that I should perform the ceremony, but I refused.
('93', 329, 1, 6, 660475) Had an English officer, however, decreed that there should be no flag hoisting here, I would certainly have unfurled the flag, even if it cost my life.
('93', 329, 1, 7, 660627) But to whom may I appeal today.
('93', 329, 1, 8, 660659) Suppose I unfurled the flag and even my Muslim brothers accepted it but in sullen silence, I would not want that.
('93', 329, 1, 9, 660773) At the same time, I must say what is in my heart.
('93', 329, 1, 10, 660823) When the question of our having a flag of our own came up, I thought it unjust to have only one colour for it, as there are not one but many communities in India.
('93', 329, 1, 11, 660986) A day there certainly was, when all the communities of India—Hindu, Muslim, Parsi and others—cherished this flag as their own.
('93', 329, 1, 12, 661113) Even lives were sacrificed for it.
('93', 329, 1, 13, 661148) Today many flags have come into being.
('93', 329, 1, 14, 661187) But the tricolour should stand alone as the Union Jack did at one time.
('93', 329, 1, 15, 661259) But that golden day of unity unfortu nately now belongs to the past.

('93', 329, 1, 17, 661356) With whom shall I fight?
('93', 329, 1, 18, 661381) We are all sons of India and hence are brothers.

('93', 329, 1, 20, 661505) But proclaiming unity is as absurd as building castles in the air.

('93', 329, 1, 25, 661787) And who knows what kind of freedom we shall have?
('93', 329, 1, 26, 661837) The Britisher is certain to quit.
('93', 329, 1, 27, 661871) But America and Russia are not yet out of the picture.
('93', 329, 1, 28, 661926) If we are not alert we are lost.

('93', 330, 0, 1, 662654) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 331
('93', 330, 1, 2, 662702) 462. A WOMAN’S DILEMMA
('93', 330, 2, 3, 662725) Q. What is a woman to do when attacked by miscreants—run away or resist with violence?
('93', 330, 2, 4, 662812) Have boats in readiness to fly or prepare to defend with weapons?
('93', 330, 3, 5, 662878) A. My answer to this question is very simple.
('93', 330, 3, 6, 662924) For me there can be no preparation for violence.
('93', 330, 3, 7, 662973) All preparation must be for non violence if courage of the highest type is to be developed.
('93', 330, 3, 8, 663065) Violence can only be tolerated as being preferable always to cowardice.
('93', 330, 3, 9, 663137) Therefore I would have no boats ready for flight in emergency.
('93', 330, 3, 10, 663200) For a non violent person there is no emergency but quiet dignified preparation for death.
('93', 330, 3, 11, 663290) Hence whether it is a man or a woman he or she will defy death even when he or she is unassisted; for the real assistance is from God.
('93', 330, 3, 12, 663425) I can preach no other thing and I am here to practise what I preach.
('93', 330, 3, 13, 663494) Whether such an opportunity will come to me or be given to me I do not know.
('93', 330, 3, 14, 663571) If there are women who when assailed by miscreants cannot resist without arms they do not need to be advised to carry arms.
('93', 330, 3, 15, 663695) They will do so.
('93', 330, 3, 16, 663712) There is something wrong in this constant enquiry as to whether to bear arms or not.
('93', 330, 3, 17, 663797) People have to learn to be naturally independent.
('93', 330, 3, 18, 663847) If they will remember the central teaching, namely, that the real effective resistance lies in non violence, they will model their conduct accordingly.
('93', 330, 3, 19, 663999) And that is what the world has been doing although unthinkingly.
('93', 330, 3, 20, 664064) Since it has not the highest courage, namely courage born of non violence, it arms itself even unto the atom bomb.
('93', 330, 3, 21, 664179) Those who do not see in it the futility of violence will naturally arm themselves to the best of their ability.
('93', 330, 3, 22, 664291) In India, since my return from South Africa, there has been conscious and constant training in non violence with the result we have seen.
('93', 330, 4, 23, 664429) Q. Can a woman be advised to take her own life rather than surrender?
('93', 330, 5, 24, 664499) A. This question requires a definite answer.
('93', 330, 5, 25, 664544) I answered it in Delhi just before leaving for Noakhali.
('93', 330, 5, 26, 664601) A woman should most certainly take her own life rather than surrender.
('93', 330, 5, 27, 664672) In other words, surrender has no room in my plan of life.
('93', 330, 5, 28, 664730) But I was asked in what way to take one’s own life.
('93', 330, 5, 29, 664782) I promptly said it was not for me to prescribe the means and behind the approval of suicide under such circumstances was and is the belief that one whose mind is prepared for even suicide will have requisite courage for such mental resistance and such internal purity that her assailant will be disarmed.
('93', 330, 5, 30, 665087) I could not carry the argument any further because it does not admit of further development.
('93', 330, 5, 31, 665180) It requires positive proof which, I own, is lacking.
('93', 331, 0, 1, 665233) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 331, 1, 2, 665275) Q. If the choice is between taking one’s own life or that of the assailant, which would you advise?
('93', 331, 2, 3, 665375) A. When it is a question of choice between killing oneself or the assailant, I have no doubt in my mind that the first should be the choice.
('93', 331, 2, 4, 665516) PALLA, January 27, 1947 Harijan, 9 2 1947
('93', 331, 3, 5, 665558) 463. LETTER TO S. G. A. AGHA
('93', 331, 4, 6, 665587) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., January 27, 1947
('93', 331, 5, 7, 665646) DEAR FRIEND, This is in answer to your question.
('93', 331, 5, 8, 665695) 1. It is a fact that I was hurt at the behaviour of many Muslims who sat out during the prayer and left when I commenced my address.
('93', 331, 5, 9, 665828) 2. I did say that I could not give up Ramanama at the bidding of any person or even if the kingdom of the world was offered to me; for Ramanama was to me the same as Allah, Khuda or God.
('93', 331, 5, 10, 666015) 3. I do hold that the God of Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsees, Jews and others is one and the same, no matter by what name a votary mentions Him or recognizes Him.
('93', 331, 5, 11, 666183) The idea is not my own.
('93', 331, 5, 12, 666207) But I have learnt to believe that it is universal.
('93', 331, 5, 13, 666258) 4. I do believe that all religions have equal status and that they are like leaves of the same tree.
('93', 331, 5, 14, 666359) No two leaves are identical though they are from the same source.
('93', 331, 5, 15, 666425) 5. It is a fact that in my daily prayers the Gita, the Koran and the other religious texts find place.
('93', 331, 5, 16, 666528) You have but to procure a copy of the prayer book published by the Navajivan Press, Ahmedabad and others to find what they are.
('93', 331, 5, 17, 666656) Nothing is my composition.
('93', 331, 5, 18, 666683) 6. My religion embraces Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, etc., for the simple reason that I believe them to have an equal status.
('93', 331, 5, 19, 666811) It is not a combination sweet or otherwise.
('93', 331, 5, 20, 666855) Every religion has its own place even
('93', 332, 0, 1, 666893) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 333
('93', 332, 1, 2, 666941) as every leaf has.
('93', 332, 1, 3, 666960) If I believe in the equal status of all the leaves of a tree, it is not a combination of my make but a recognition of a scientific fact.
('93', 332, 2, 4, 667097) Yours sincerely, ADVOCAT ES.
('93', 332, 2, 5, 667126) G. A. AGHA ZAMINDAR DADY (SIND)

('93', 334, 3, 6, 671200) 467. LETTER TO J. B. KRIPALANI Confidential January 28, 1947

('93', 336, 5, 9, 674815) 470. INTERVIEW TO MUSLIM DEPUTATION 1
('93', 336, 6, 10, 674853) PANCHGAON, January 28, 1947 I have come here with the greatest goodwill in the world.
('93', 336, 6, 11, 674939) I know if I fail in Noakhali my whole non violence fails.
('93', 336, 7, 12, 674997) Gandhiji said that he had always been a man of the masses and a man for the masses and he wanted to identify himself completely with the masses.
('93', 336, 7, 13, 675142) If they could tell him the way how he could reach more effectively the hearts of Muslims, he was ready to listen.
('93', 336, 7, 14, 675256) But on no account could he leave Noakhali.
('93', 336, 8, 15, 675299) So far as others working in Noakhali were concerned it was the duty of the Government to find out if they were really standing in the way of restoration of peace.
('93', 336, 9, 16, 675462) Referring to the question of his going to Bihar, Gandhiji said that he knew that it was the opinion of the Muslim League circles that he should go to Bihar.
('93', 336, 9, 17, 675619) He was, however, doing his best for the Muslims of Bihar from Noakhali.
('93', 336, 9, 18, 675691) He was in constant touch with the Bihar Government in this respect and a representative of that Government was now travelling with him.
('93', 336, 9, 19, 675827) If he went now to Bihar and found that the Bihar Government had left nothing undone, he would have to say it without any reserve which in his opinion might not help the Muslim League case.
('93', 336, 10, 20, 676016) With reference to the question of large scale arrests of Muslims here, Gandhiji said that the duty of a reformer was to try to replace corporal punishment by awakening of the conscience.
('93', 336, 10, 21, 676203) He had tried to do it in his life and succeeded though not
('93', 336, 11, 22, 676262) 1 The deputation, which was led by Mujibur Rahman, Secretary, Noakhali District Muslim League, met Gandhiji in the evening.
('93', 336, 11, 23, 676386) The report said that the deputationists wanted Gandhiji to visit Bihar.
('93', 336, 11, 24, 676458) They also pointed out that Gandhiji being a Hindu, recitation from the Koran at his prayer meetings was not appreciated by the Muslims.
('93', 337, 0, 1, 676594) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 337, 1, 2, 676636) in many cases.
('93', 337, 1, 3, 676651) Their duty also should be to try to awaken this conscience so that culprits would come forward and own up their guilt.
('93', 337, 1, 4, 676770) So long as this was not done, the ring leaders should be arrested.
('93', 337, 2, 5, 676837) With regard to conducting of prayers, Gandhiji said that if there was so much intolerance that one could not hold one’s prayers as one liked he did not know what lay in store for poor India.
('93', 337, 2, 6, 677028) It was at the request of a devout Muslim friend that he had included verses from the Koran in his prayer.
('93', 337, 2, 7, 677134) Of course, he never wanted to go against the tenets of Islam but he could not also listen to one particular person or half a dozen persons to whom they might refer him as to whether he was going against Islam by reciting from the Koran.

('93', 337, 3, 9, 677401) 471. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 337, 4, 10, 677431) PANCHGAON, January 28, 1947 On my way here I was taken to three homes, one Hindu and two Muslim.
('93', 337, 4, 11, 677528) It gave me very great pleasure as all I crave for is love.
('93', 337, 4, 12, 677587) I was not informed in advance of the places I would be taken to, but I saw love in the eyes of those who invited me, and so I went.
('93', 337, 4, 13, 677719) At all the three places I was offered something or other to eat, but it was not the time when I usually ate, so I said I would gladly accept some fruit if they sent any to my next halt.
('93', 337, 4, 14, 677905) My granddaughter accompanies me.
('93', 337, 4, 15, 677938) The women welcomed her with love and an old lady embraced her on knowing who she was.
('93', 337, 4, 16, 678024) A Muslim sister who had made fish curry and rotis at the time, pressed her to partake of the fare.
('93', 337, 4, 17, 678123) What was the poor girl to do?
('93', 337, 4, 18, 678153) She refused the offer on the ground that she did not take anything at that early hour.
('93', 337, 4, 19, 678240) The Muslim women thereupon suspected that this Hindu girl was not willing to eat, because at heart she felt she would be polluted.
('93', 337, 4, 20, 678371) So, to allay their suspicion, she broke a piece from their roti and ate it.
('93', 337, 4, 21, 678447) The sisters were satisfied.
('93', 337, 4, 22, 678475) Neither I nor those who associate with me make any distinctions of caste or creed and we have no inhibitions against dining with anybody.
('93', 337, 4, 23, 678613) But I appeal to my Muslim friends to look kindly upon those Hindus who think they would lose their religion if they ate at the hands of a Muslim.
('93', 337, 4, 24, 678759) I understand that that belief is wrong.
('93', 337, 4, 25, 678799) But the test of brotherly love does not lie only in eating together.
('93', 337, 4, 26, 678868) This erroneous belief is sure to wear off with time.
('93', 337, 4, 27, 678921) Much has been achieved already in this direction.
('93', 337, 4, 28, 678971) But till that attitude changes please learn to appreciate love wherever you find it.
('93', 337, 4, 29, 679056) Only in this way will you come near one another.
('93', 338, 0, 1, 679105) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 339
('93', 338, 1, 2, 679153) The Pressmen who follow me had arranged a mass dinner of all castes and creeds.
('93', 338, 1, 3, 679233) Muslim brothers did not join in it.
('93', 338, 1, 4, 679269) But the host of the Pressmen begged them earnestly not to insist on his participation in the common dinner.
('93', 338, 1, 5, 679377) ‘You will leave me in a day’, he said ‘but calamity will beset me after you go.
('93', 338, 1, 6, 679457) The people here will bring pressure to bear upon me saying that I had lost caste by eating with you and so I must become a Muslim.
('93', 338, 1, 7, 679588) I felt that the man’s fear was well founded.
('93', 338, 1, 8, 679633) So I had to request the Pressmen not to hold the common dinner in the poor man’s hut.
('93', 338, 1, 9, 679719) I don’t know when Hindus and Muslims will shed their weakness and come close to one another.
('93', 338, 1, 10, 679812) But I am prepared to give up my very life, if need be, to see this object realized, and I appeal to you all to pray with me: “O!
('93', 338, 1, 11, 679941) bring that golden day soon.” [From Gujarati]

('93', 339, 9, 27, 681905) 475. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 339, 10, 28, 681937) JAYAG, January 29, 1947
('93', 339, 11, 29, 681961) Gandhiji at the outset dealt with a question that was raised by some Muslim friends.
('93', 339, 11, 30, 682046) Did he want Muslims to attend his prayer meetings?
('93', 339, 11, 31, 682097) The reply was that he insisted on neither the Muslims nor the Hindus attending the prayer meetings.
('93', 339, 12, 32, 682197) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('93', 340, 0, 1, 682246) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 341
('93', 340, 1, 2, 682294) questioner meant to ask whether he would like the Muslims to attend such meetings, he had no hesitation in saying that he would certainly like them to attend.
('93', 340, 1, 3, 682453) What was more, numerous Muslims had attended his prayer meetings which had gone on for years.
('93', 340, 1, 4, 682547) The next question was whether he, the speaker, did not consider it wrong for him, a non Muslim, to recite anything from the Koran or to couple Rama and Krishna with Rahim and Karim.
('93', 340, 1, 5, 682729) They said it offended Muslim ears.
('93', 340, 1, 6, 682764) The speaker replied that the objection gave him a painful surprise.
('93', 340, 1, 7, 682832) He thought that the objection betrayed narrowness of mind.
('93', 340, 1, 8, 682891) They should know that he had introduced the recital from the Koran through Raihana Tyabjee, a devoted Muslim with a religious mind.
('93', 340, 1, 9, 683023) She had no political motive behind the proposal.
('93', 340, 1, 10, 683072) He was no avatar as was suggested.
('93', 340, 1, 11, 683107) He claimed to be a man of God humbler than the humblest man or woman.
('93', 340, 1, 12, 683177) His object ever was to make Muslims better Muslims, Hindus better Hindus, Christians better Christians, Parsis better Parsis.
('93', 340, 1, 13, 683303) He never invited anybody to change his or her religion.
('93', 340, 1, 14, 683359) He had thought, therefore, that the questioners would be glad to find that his religion was so expansive as to include readings from the religious scriptures of the world.
('93', 340, 2, 15, 683531) The next thing was that some friends had said that all prosecutions initiated by the Hindus against the Muslim offenders interfered with the progress of the work of peace between the two.
('93', 340, 2, 16, 683719) It surprised him.
('93', 340, 2, 17, 683737) What had peace between gentlemen to do with the prosecution of criminals.
('93', 340, 2, 18, 683811) He could understand the objection if it meant that false prosecutions should be withdrawn.
('93', 340, 2, 19, 683902) He would be whole heartedly with the objectors.
('93', 340, 2, 20, 683950) He went further and said that all such persons should be brought to book as perjurers.
('93', 340, 2, 21, 684037) He said also that the proper course to avoid court procedure was for the guilty persons in all humility to make an open confession of their guilt and accept the judgment of the public.
('93', 340, 2, 22, 684222) He would gladly help any such movement.
('93', 340, 3, 23, 684262) The third thing was that young men who had gone to Calcutta and other places in search of a career were bound to give a portion of their time to the villages.
('93', 340, 3, 24, 684421) The easiest thing for them to do would be to meet together and make an arrangement by which, say, half of them would take leave from office and serve for a stipulated number of months, at the end of which their place would be taken by the next batch.
('93', 340, 3, 25, 684672) If they had a will, there would surely be some way also for serving the cause of the villagers.
('93', 340, 3, 26, 684768) Those who did not find it possible to offer personal service might help by cash.
('93', 340, 4, 27, 684849) Gandhiji ended by citing the example of England, Russia and other countries where every family had sent as many able bodied men and women as possible for the defence of their country.
('93', 340, 4, 28, 685033) This was how unity of heart was actually achieved in the world and he hoped that we in our country would be able to rise above small selfish considerations and create that unity without which life itself would not be worth living.
('93', 340, 4, 29, 685264) Harijan, 23 2 1947
('93', 341, 0, 1, 685283) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 341, 1, 2, 685325) 476. FOREWORD TO “SELECTIONS FROM GANDHI”
('93', 341, 2, 3, 685367) The following pages represent a labour of love.
('93', 341, 2, 4, 685415) Professor Nirmal Kumar Bose first published his selections in 1934 1 and they contained extracts from my writings up to 1934. But my writings have never ceased and so the Professor felt that he should bring up his selections to as late a date as possible, i.
('93', 341, 2, 5, 685674) e., up to 1942 with isolated later additions.
('93', 341, 2, 6, 685720) Though therefore this is called a new edition, it is in reality a new book.
('93', 341, 2, 7, 685796) The earliest and most elaborate attempt was made by the late Amulakhrai in Gujarati.
('93', 341, 2, 8, 685881) But that was years ago.
('93', 341, 2, 9, 685905) He covered my writings in Gujarati and Hindi too.
('93', 341, 2, 10, 685955) The volumes being in Gujarati never attracted much attention.
('93', 341, 2, 11, 686017) Such is our disregard of our own languages.
('93', 341, 2, 12, 686061) But I have known nothing so thorough of its kind as these volumes.
('93', 341, 2, 13, 686128) Professor N. K. Bose’s is such an attempt.
('93', 341, 2, 14, 686171) He gave me his manuscript early in 1946 when I was in Bengal to do with it what I liked.
('93', 341, 2, 15, 686260) But my preoccupations left me no time to look at them till for very shame I was compelled to do so.
('93', 341, 2, 16, 686360) The selections made by the author show the thoroughness with which he has gone into his subject.
('93', 341, 2, 17, 686457) Those who are interested in my writings will not fail to appreciate the author’s labours.
('93', 341, 3, 18, 686547) M. K. GANDHI AMKI, NOAKHALI, January 30, 1947

('93', 343, 5, 14, 689079) I had sent for Kulranjan, a Bengali naturopath, for you; he has arrived here today.

('93', 343, 10, 30, 689883) It was due to his having been occupied with Zaman Saheb and Yusuf Saheb.
('93', 343, 10, 31, 689956) These officers took him to a model cottage they had had erected.
('93', 343, 10, 32, 690021) It was a good house but in his opinion unfit for
('93', 343, 11, 33, 690070) 1 According to the source, this was addressed “to an ailing sister”.

('93', 344, 1, 2, 690236) human habitation in the Indian climate.
('93', 344, 1, 3, 690276) Such a house could well be described as a box.
('93', 344, 1, 4, 690323) The inmates would be baked as in an oven and they would be suffocated when they closed their doors and windows as had become their habit.
('93', 344, 1, 5, 690461) He, therefore, suggested comfortable cottage of bamboo, straw and thatch.
('93', 344, 1, 6, 690535) Such cottages will be airy, cool and artistic in the Indian setting, especially in the midst of stately palms of coconut and supari.
('93', 344, 2, 7, 690668) He was also pleased when these officers informed him that the refugees had commenced to return from the places where they had taken refuge.
('93', 344, 2, 8, 690808) He hoped that this return would continue with unabated zeal.
('93', 344, 2, 9, 690869) He was of opinion that the people should dismiss all fear from their minds and feel safe in the midst of their own countrymen, whether Hindus or Muslims.
('93', 344, 2, 10, 691023) When they learnt to fear their Maker alone they would cease to fear their fellows.
('93', 344, 2, 11, 691106) They would find that there were none to frighten them if they were not afraid themselves.
('93', 344, 2, 12, 691196) This had been his uniform experience in the course of the last sixty years of his life.
('93', 344, 3, 13, 691284) The third question taken up by him was in connection with some fishermen who had met him on the previous evening.
('93', 344, 3, 14, 691398) They had complained that in this country where fishing was confined to privately owned ponds for the major part of the year, it was impossible for them to live if they were boycotted by the majority community.
('93', 344, 3, 15, 691608) Gandhiji expressed his surprise at this state of affairs and suggested that unless the Hindus and Muslims could rise above their present political differences and reasserted their common humanity and common brotherhood, life would become an impossibility where nature had designed otherwise.
('93', 344, 3, 16, 691900) He hoped, therefore, that the alleged conditions would be corrected by the joint efforts of the people concerned and real peace restored in the countryside.

('93', 346, 1, 2, 694328) 485. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING 1
('93', 346, 2, 3, 694361) NABAGRAM, January 31, 1947
('93', 346, 3, 4, 694388) An old lady asked Gandhiji what they should do in case they were threatened with conversion.
('93', 346, 4, 5, 694481) Gandhiji said that to him the answer was simple : Religion is the breath of one’s life and as no one could agree to forgo the right of breathing under any threat or compulsion, so no one should forsake his faith even if it be an alternative to death.
('93', 346, 5, 6, 694732) Be it man or woman, if one forsook one’s faith at anyone’s command, one had no religion.
('93', 346, 5, 7, 694821) Unfortunately, Gandhiji continued, India had come to such a stage that some Indians easily abandoned their supposedly cherished faith.
('93', 346, 5, 8, 694956) Religion was one’s breath of life.
('93', 346, 5, 9, 694991) If anyone agreed to forgo his religion under threat, he would reduce himself to a brute.
('93', 346, 6, 10, 695080) One of them asked what a woman, whose husband had turned a recluse, should do.
('93', 346, 6, 11, 695159) Gandhiji said : Such a woman should lead a very chaste life.
('93', 346, 6, 12, 695220) She should work for her livelihood.
('93', 346, 6, 13, 695256) She should not hoard anything but only keep that which is absolutely necessary.
('93', 346, 6, 14, 695336) It is wrong to assume that a person is a true hermit simply because he wears an ochre robe.
('93', 346, 6, 15, 695428) If the desolate woman is at a loss to know what to do, she could take to spinning.
('93', 346, 6, 16, 695511) I have called the spinning wheel the kamadhenu.
('93', 346, 6, 17, 695559) She should also chant God’s name as she spins.
('93', 346, 6, 18, 695606) In my opinion this type of renunciation will surpass that of her husband.
('93', 346, 6, 19, 695680) She should constantly keep herself occupied in altruistic work such as sweeping the village streets, giving bath to dirty children, etc.
('93', 346, 6, 20, 695817) There is a proverb saying an idle mind is the devil’s workshop.
('93', 346, 6, 21, 695881) There must be a similar proverb in Bengali.
('93', 346, 6, 22, 695925) If we sit idle, doing nothing, a thousand unhealthy thoughts will crowd our mind.
('93', 346, 6, 23, 696007) So one should never be without some sort of work at all times.
('93', 346, 6, 24, 696070) This is the best solution for the problem.

('93', 347, 1, 2, 696364) 486. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 347, 2, 3, 696396) NABAGRAM, January 31, 1947
('93', 347, 3, 4, 696423) Gandhiji congratulated the audience, which was exceptionally large, on the perfect quiet they observed throughout the prayer.
('93', 347, 3, 5, 696549) He then referred to two communications he had received from Muslim writers who consoled him against his critics who questioned his right to speak about the purdah or other things pertaining to Islam.
('93', 347, 3, 6, 696749) The writers asserted, quoting from the Koran, that Islam was broad based and was exceptionally tolerant.
('93', 347, 3, 7, 696854) It welcomed criticism and invited the world to study the Koran.
('93', 347, 3, 8, 696918) One of them also held that no group or nation had remained without a prophet or teacher.
('93', 347, 3, 9, 697007) He mentioned these communications to show that all Muslims did not hold what he considered to be intolerant views.
('93', 347, 3, 10, 697122) He hoped too that the audience which contained a large number of Muslims would appreciate the testimony of the two writers who did not appear to be biased.
('93', 347, 4, 11, 697278) He then dealt with the following question addressed to him by some of the workers :
('93', 347, 5, 12, 697362) The Muslims were boycotting Hindu artisans and craftsmen and were taking to occupations like fishing, fir trade, pan 2 cultivation, etc.
('93', 347, 5, 13, 697499) Workers who desired to bring about peace between the two communities did not know what to do under the circumstances.
('93', 347, 6, 14, 697617) Gandhiji said he hoped that the news was exaggerated and that the boycott was confined to the fewest Muslims possible.
('93', 347, 6, 15, 697736) He thought that it could not be sustained.
('93', 347, 6, 16, 697779) The logical result was that any such move would be a compulsory exodus of the Hindus from the Muslim majority provinces, a result he had not heard a single leader encourage or contemplate.
('93', 347, 6, 17, 697968) He invited his informants to bring the matter to the notice of the authorities, not with a view to having anyone punished but with a view to having an authoritative pronouncement from them.
('93', 347, 6, 18, 698158) He further advised the audience to pray for wisdom to both the communities.
('93', 347, 7, 19, 698234) The second question was: There is a movement 3 for reducing the share of the owner from half to one third of the agricultural produce.
('93', 347, 7, 20, 698369) What is your opinion about this?
('93', 347, 8, 21, 698402) Gandhiji welcomed the move for the reduction of the landlord’s share from half
('93', 347, 9, 22, 698481) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 2 Betel leaf 3 Popularly known as Tebhaga movement; vide also “Talk to Representatives of Krishak Samiti”, 24 1 1947
('93', 348, 0, 1, 698647) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 349
('93', 348, 1, 2, 698695) to one third.
('93', 348, 1, 3, 698709) He thought the move was substantial.
('93', 348, 1, 4, 698746) 1 He was prepared to go further and concede the entire produce to the tillers of the soil.
('93', 348, 1, 5, 698837) He believed that no one could claim ownership of land, which belonged to God alone.
('93', 348, 1, 6, 698921) He further believed that no one who did not till the land had any claim to the produce.
('93', 348, 1, 7, 699009) Only those who toiled should have a share in the output.
('93', 348, 1, 8, 699066) But in no case should anybody claim proprietorship of the land itself.
('93', 348, 1, 9, 699137) The land belonged to the Lord of us all and therefore to the worker on it.
('93', 348, 1, 10, 699212) But till that ideal state of things came about, the movement towards the reduction of the landlord’s portion was in the right direction.
('93', 348, 1, 11, 699349) But he warned the people against the use of compulsion or violence.
('93', 348, 1, 12, 699417) He could have no part or share in violence.
('93', 348, 1, 13, 699461) It was a reform to be brought about only by the cultivation of healthy public opinion.
('93', 348, 1, 14, 699548) The reformers must have patience.
('93', 348, 1, 15, 699582) He believed implicity in the aphorism: ‘As the end so the means’.

('93', 348, 1, 17, 699776) Many movements had come to grief by reliance on doubtful means.

('93', 351, 4, 14, 704942) 493. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('93', 351, 5, 15, 704972) NABAGRAM, February 1, 1947 I will consider my mission fulfilled if I see heart unity among Hindus and Muslims and until this is achieved, I must be moving about in this area.
('93', 351, 6, 16, 705147) Gandhiji emphasized to me that this was the first opportunity he had had of testing whether the ahimsa he had been practising was really of the brave.
('93', 351, 6, 17, 705298) He said that in the past he had successfully tested the efficacy of his non violence in his struggle with the British Government but he felt that his ahimsa was really not of the brave as somewhere in the background lurked the feeling that superiority in numbers would tend to sway the balance in such a struggle.
('93', 351, 6, 18, 705612) Gandhiji does not think that real bravery has ever been brought into full play so far in his practice of ahimsa.
('93', 351, 6, 19, 705725) Noakhali, Gandhiji said, offered an almost ideal situation for testing whether ahimsa could effectively be used by a small number of people against an almost sullen if not hostile majority all round.
('93', 351, 6, 20, 705925) The problem here was also complicated by the fact of the existence of a popular Government controlling the destinies of the people.
('93', 351, 6, 21, 706057) Even if he differed from the politics of those running the Bengal Government he was definite that if democratic Government was good for one Province it was equally good for another and, therefore, he must not do or say anything which would in any way
('93', 351, 7, 22, 706308) 1 The letter is incomplete.
('93', 352, 0, 1, 706336) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 353
('93', 352, 1, 2, 706384) derogate from the prestige and authority of the Government.
('93', 352, 1, 3, 706444) A straight fight with the alien ruling power was one thing for him, but a struggle with his own countrymen, however recalcitrant unwilling they might be in doing the right thing by those under their care, was a thing too difficult for him to contemplate.
('93', 352, 1, 4, 706699) It was this difficulty that had induced him to keep the Bengal Premier posted with everything he saw or did in and about Noakhali.
('93', 352, 2, 5, 706830) Ever since the commencement of his walking tour, Gandhiji has been moving amidst a sullen population on the one side and a frightened one on the other.
('93', 352, 2, 6, 706982) He is, therefore, engaging himself in the dual task of infusing courage into the frightened Hindus and at the same time convincing the majority community of the right to protection of the minorities.
('93', 352, 2, 7, 707182) He is placing before both communities his ideal of brotherly living and also a programme of sanitation and rural economy calculated to help both communities to better and healthier living.
('93', 352, 3, 8, 707371) Asked if he would regard the return of all refugees to their villages as a sign of success of his ahimsa, Gandhiji replied in the negative and said that it would not be impossible to persuade all refugees to return home within a few days.
('93', 352, 3, 9, 707610) But this would not be any indication of the success of the ahimsa of the brave; for the refugees would then be relying for protection on those who persuaded them to return.
('93', 352, 3, 10, 707783) It would be real success if men and women picked up courage and decided of their own accord to return, willing to face cheerfully even death and starvation in preference to surrender or fight.
('93', 352, 3, 11, 707976) It was towards achieving this that Gandhiji had been addressing Hindus.
('93', 352, 3, 12, 708048) The Hindu, 2 1 1947
('93', 352, 4, 13, 708068) 494. TALK WITH A DOCTOR 1

('93', 352, 6, 15, 708123) Gandhiji said that he wished to live up to the age of 125 and humorously enquired of the doctor if he could suggest any recipe for that.
('93', 352, 6, 16, 708260) In reply to a suggestion by the doctor that he should spend some time in Calcutta to recoup his health, Gandhiji said that he could not leave Noakhali until communal amity had been established there.

('93', 353, 4, 8, 708993) 496. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 3
('93', 353, 5, 9, 709025) AMISHAPARA, February 1, 1947
('93', 353, 6, 10, 709054) Gandhiji drew the attention of the audience to the fact that the universal law applicable to all meetings was that the visitors should be perfectly still and observe silence no matter how vast the audience was.
('93', 353, 7, 11, 709265) Yesterday evening a Maulvi had wanted to speak for a short time.
('93', 353, 7, 12, 709330) Gandhiji had sensed what he wanted to say.
('93', 353, 7, 13, 709373) He therefore, contrary to his wont, allowed him to speak for the five minutes which he wanted by the watch.
('93', 353, 7, 14, 709481) The Maulvi took no more than three minutes but said what he had wanted to say.
('93', 353, 7, 15, 709560) He resented Gandhiji’s remark on the purdah system in vogue in Bengal as according to him, Gandhiji had no right to speak on the Islamic Law.
('93', 353, 8, 16, 709702) Gandhiji thought this was a narrow view of religion.
('93', 353, 8, 17, 709755) He claimed the right to study and interpret the message of Islam.
('93', 353, 8, 18, 709821) Gandhiji said that throughout his long life he had had the privilege of mixing with many.
('93', 353, 8, 19, 709911) Muslims in and out of India but he had nowhere heard anybody say that.
('93', 353, 8, 20, 709982) Denouncing the system of purdah, which varied from country to country, Gandhiji said that he was certain it had little to do with the Koran.
('93', 353, 8, 21, 710123) He was not inclined to believe that Islam was so susceptible to damage as to be confined within a narrow space beyond other people’s view.
('93', 353, 8, 22, 710262) Gandhiji was sure that it was contrary to Islamic teaching.
('93', 353, 9, 23, 710322) The Maulvi had further resented coupling of the name of Rama, a mere young king, with Rahim, name of God; similarly of Krishna with Karim.
('93', 353, 9, 24, 710461) Gandhiji said this was a narrow view of Islam.
('93', 353, 9, 25, 710508) This erroneous view had emanated from his wrong notion that Rama and Krishna were names of ordinary human beings.
('93', 353, 9, 26, 710622) Man worshipped the same God under different names and the Koran was not opposed to it.
('93', 353, 9, 27, 710709) Rama and
('93', 353, 10, 28, 710718) 1 Eight British Army officers met Gandhiji in the afternoon to convey their good wishes on his peace mission in Noakhali.
('93', 353, 10, 29, 710840) 2 One of the officers was a young Australian, who introduced himself as a journalist.
('93', 353, 10, 30, 710926) 3 The reports in the various sources have been collated.
('93', 354, 0, 1, 710983) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 355
('93', 354, 1, 2, 711031) Krishna were names of God and there was no bar in worshipping God as such, it certainly did not offend Islam.
('93', 354, 1, 3, 711141) Islam was not a creed to be preserved in a box.
('93', 354, 1, 4, 711189) It was open to mankind to examine it and accept or reject its tenets.
('93', 354, 1, 5, 711259) He hoped that this narrow view was not shared by the Muslims of Bengal or India.
('93', 354, 2, 6, 711340) Purity of heart was the criterion of a religious man but persons who looted other people’s properties, killed fellow beings and took God’s name at the same time were irreligious.
('93', 354, 2, 7, 711519) In this connection Gandhiji wanted to draw the attention of the audience to the work.
('93', 354, 2, 8, 711605) Dr. Sushila Nayyar was doing in Changirgaon.
('93', 354, 2, 9, 711650) She wanted to go to Sevagram to attend to the hospital for whose management she was responsible, but her Muslim patients would not let her go till they were restored to health.
('93', 354, 2, 10, 711827) She had also mentioned that in the village those, who had shared in the loot of October last were of their own accord bringing back some of the looted property.
('93', 354, 2, 11, 711988) He was of opinion that this was a happy omen.
('93', 354, 2, 12, 712034) If the infection spread, the courts would have no work to do so far as public loot was concerned.
('93', 354, 2, 13, 712132) He for one would ask Government to waive the right of prosecution if the looted property was returned.
('93', 354, 2, 14, 712235) But he said the return must be sincere and full, whether by the guilty one or the public, and not a mere token to avoid prosecution.
('93', 354, 2, 15, 712368) What he aimed at was a change of heart and not a truce superimposed by the military or the police.
('93', 354, 2, 16, 712467) A popular ministry could not impose its will on the people.
('93', 354, 2, 17, 712527) Gandhiji said : I shall most gladly leave Noakhali when I am certain that all are acting with amity and sincerity, but I shall lay down my life here for the fulfilment of my mission.
('93', 354, 3, 18, 712710) Gandhiji then answered the following question :
('93', 354, 4, 19, 712758) You have asked rich men to be trustees.
('93', 354, 4, 20, 712798) Is it implied that they should give up private ownership of their property and create out of it a trust valid in the eyes of the law and managed democratically?
('93', 354, 4, 21, 712959) How will the successor of the present incumbent be determined on his demise?
('93', 354, 5, 22, 713036) In answer Gandhiji said that he adhered to the position taken by him years ago that everything belonged to God and was from God.
('93', 354, 5, 23, 713165) Therefore it was for His people as a whole, not for a particular individual.
('93', 354, 5, 24, 713242) When an individual had more than his proportionate portion he became a trustee of that portion for God’s people.
('93', 354, 5, 25, 713355) God who was all powerful had no need to store.
('93', 354, 5, 26, 713402) He created from day to day.
('93', 354, 5, 27, 713430) Hence men also should in theory live day to day and not stock things.
('93', 354, 5, 28, 713500) If this truth was imbibed by the people generally, it would become legalized and trusteeship would become a legalized institution.
('93', 354, 5, 29, 713631) He wished it became a gift from India to the world.
('93', 354, 5, 30, 713683) Then there would be no exploitation and no reserves as in Australia and other countries for white men and their posterity.
('93', 354, 5, 31, 713806) In these distinctions lay the seeds of a war more virulent than the last two.
('93', 354, 5, 32, 713884) As to the successor, the trustee in office would have the right to nominate his successor subject to legal sanction.
('93', 355, 0, 1, 714001) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 355, 1, 2, 714043) Gandhiji referred to “small talks, whispers and innuendos” going round of which he had become aware.
('93', 355, 1, 3, 714144) He was already in the midst of so much suspicion and distrust, he told the gathering, that he did not want his most innocent acts to be misunderstood and misrepresented.
('93', 355, 1, 4, 714314) He had his granddaughter with him.
('93', 355, 1, 5, 714349) She shared the same bed with him.
('93', 355, 1, 6, 714383) The Prophet had discounted eunuchs who became such by an operation.
('93', 355, 1, 7, 714451) But he welcomed eunuchs made such through prayer by God.
('93', 355, 1, 8, 714508) His was that aspiration.
('93', 355, 1, 9, 714533) It was in the spirit of God’s eunuch that he had approached what he considered was his duty.
('93', 355, 1, 10, 714626) It was an integral part of the yajna he was performing and he invited them to bless the effort.
('93', 355, 1, 11, 714722) He knew that his action had excited criticism even among his friends.
('93', 355, 1, 12, 714792) But a duty could not be shirked even for the sake of the most intimate friends.
('93', 355, 2, 13, 714872) Harijan, 23 2 1947; Hindustan Standard, 3 2 1947. and Mahatma Gandhi— The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book II, pp.

('93', 358, 1, 2, 719023) 503. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 358, 2, 3, 719055) SATGHARIA, February 2, 1947
('93', 358, 3, 4, 719083) Gandhiji deliberately referred to his private life because he had never thought that the private life of individuals did not affect the course of the public activities of those individuals.
('93', 358, 3, 5, 719273) Thus he did not believe that he could be immoral in private life and yet be an efficient public servant.
('93', 358, 3, 6, 719378) His public conduct was bound to be affected by his private.
('93', 358, 3, 7, 719438) He held that much mischief was made throughout the world by divorce between public and private conduct.
('93', 358, 3, 8, 719542) And when he was engaged in the supreme test of non violence in his life, he wished to be judged before God and man by the sum total of his activities, both private and public.
('93', 358, 3, 9, 719718) As he had said years ago, non violent life was an act of self examination and self purification whether by an individual, a group or a nation.
('93', 358, 4, 10, 719861) This led him to the answers of some questions addressed to him and arising out of his remarks on trusteeship.
('93', 358, 5, 11, 719971) Q. Was it possible to defend by means of non violence anything which could only be gained through violence?
('93', 358, 6, 12, 720079) A. It followed from what he had said above that what was gained by violence could not only be defended by non violence but the latter required the abandonment of the ill gotten gains.
('93', 358, 7, 13, 720263) Q. Was the accumulation of capital possible except through violence whether open or tacit ?
('93', 358, 8, 14, 720355) A. Such accumulation by private persons was impossible except through violent means but accumulation by the State in a non violent society was not only possible, it was desirable and inevitable.
('93', 358, 9, 15, 720550) Q. Whether a man accumulated material or moral wealth he did so only through the help or co operation of other members of society.
('93', 358, 9, 16, 720681) Had he then the moral right to use any of it mainly for personal advantage?
('93', 358, 10, 17, 720757) A. No, he had no moral right.
('93', 358, 11, 18, 720787) Q. How would the successor of a trustee be determined?
('93', 358, 11, 19, 720842) Would he only have the right of proposing a name, the right of finalization vested in the State?
('93', 358, 12, 20, 720939) A. As he had said 2 yesterday, choice should be given to the original owner
('93', 358, 13, 21, 721015) 1 This appeared under the title “Gandhiji on Trusteeship”.
('93', 358, 13, 22, 721074) Gandhiji began his weekly silence as the prayer started.
('93', 358, 13, 23, 721131) His written speech was rendered into Bengali and read out by Nirmal Kumar Bose.
('93', 358, 13, 24, 721211) 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 1 2 1947
('93', 359, 0, 1, 721255) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 359, 1, 2, 721297) who became the first trustee, but the choice must be finalized by the State.
('93', 359, 1, 3, 721374) Such arrangement puts a check on the State as well as the individual.
('93', 359, 2, 4, 721444) Q. When the replacement of private by public property thus took place through the operation of the theory of trusteeship, would the ownership vest in the State, which was an instrument of violence or in associations of a voluntary character like village communes and municipalities, which might of course derive their final authority from State made laws?
('93', 359, 3, 5, 721800) A. That question involved some confusion of thought.
('93', 359, 3, 6, 721853) Legal ownership in the transformed condition vested in the trustee, not in the State.
('93', 359, 3, 7, 721939) It was to avoid confiscation that the doctrine of trusteeship came into play retaining for the society the ability of the original owner in his own right.
('93', 359, 3, 8, 722094) Nor did he, the speaker, hold that the state must always be based on violence.
('93', 359, 3, 9, 722173) It might be so in theory but the practice of the theory demanded a State which would for the most part be based on non violence.
('93', 359, 3, 10, 722302) Harijan, 16 2 1947

('93', 361, 7, 15, 725818) 508. TALK WITH A CORRESPONDENT SADHURKHIL, February 3, 1947 A pilgrim has to bear every kind of life.

('93', 361, 8, 20, 726093) 509. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 361, 9, 21, 726125) SADHURKHIL, February 3, 1947
('93', 361, 10, 22, 726154) At the outset, Gandhiji said that what he had said about his private life was not for blind imitation.
('93', 361, 10, 23, 726257) He never claimed to have extraordinary powers.
('93', 361, 10, 24, 726304) What he did was
('93', 361, 11, 25, 726320) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”.
('93', 361, 11, 26, 726370) The first paragraph is reproduced from Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('93', 362, 0, 1, 726431) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 363
('93', 362, 1, 2, 726479) for all to do if they conformed to conditions observed by him.
('93', 362, 1, 3, 726542) If that was not done, those who pretended to imitate his practice were doomed to perdition.
('93', 362, 1, 4, 726634) What he was doing was undoubtedly dangerous, but it ceased to be so, if the conditions were rightly observed.
('93', 362, 2, 5, 726744) Gandhiji referred with hesitation to the resolution passed by the Muslim League 1 on the Constituent Assembly.
('93', 362, 2, 6, 726855) It considered the Congress resolution to be dishonest and that it did not mean what it said.
('93', 362, 2, 7, 726948) It was also said that the elections and other dealings of the Assembly were illegal.
('93', 362, 2, 8, 727033) The speaker pleaded that there should be no imputation of dishonesty by one party to the other.
('93', 362, 2, 9, 727129) It was not good for the great organization which they both were.
('93', 362, 2, 10, 727194) There was no reason why they should regard each other as enemies.
('93', 362, 2, 11, 727260) That practice would not lead them to independence.
('93', 362, 2, 12, 727311) If the elections and proceedings were illegal their legality should be challenged in a court of law.
('93', 362, 2, 13, 727412) Otherwise, the charge had no meaning.
('93', 362, 2, 14, 727450) If they did not wish to recognize the courts as he did in 1920 and later, then the talk of illegality should cease.
('93', 362, 2, 15, 727566) He would plead with the League that they should go into the Assembly and state their case and influence the proceedings.
('93', 362, 2, 16, 727687) But if they did not, he would advise them to test the sincerity of the Assembly and see how it dealt with the Muslim problem.
('93', 362, 2, 17, 727813) It was due to themselves and the rest of the country unless they wanted to rely upon the law of the sword which he was sure they did not wish to do.
('93', 362, 2, 18, 727962) Then the League had said that the Assembly represented only the caste Hindus.
('93', 362, 2, 19, 728040) Surely there were in the Assembly the Scheduled Classes, the Christians, the Parsis, the Anglo Indians and all those who considered themselves sons of India.
('93', 362, 2, 20, 728198) Then Dr. Ambedkar 2 was good enough to attend the Assembly, not to mention the other large number of the Scheduled Classes.
('93', 362, 2, 21, 728322) The Sikhs too were still there.
('93', 362, 2, 22, 728354) It was open to the League to put up their fight within the Assembly.
('93', 362, 3, 23, 728423) As to the British Government who the League contended should dismiss the Assembly, he entertained the hope, though he admitted it was somewhat shaken, that they would honestly carry to the end the voluntary document.
('93', 362, 3, 24, 728640) He submitted that the British Government was bound to act according to the State Paper even if a few Provinces chose to establish their independence in accordance with the Paper.
('93', 362, 3, 25, 728819) He hoped that the British would not forfeit all credit for honest dealing with India.
('93', 362, 4, 26, 728905) Gandhiji concluded by saying that whilst he felt obliged to refer to League politics, he warned the audience against inferring that the Hindus and Muslims were to regard each other as enemies.
('93', 362, 4, 27, 729098) The League had made no such announcement.
('93', 362, 4, 28, 729140) Let the political quarrel be confined to the politicians at the top.
('93', 362, 4, 29, 729209) It would be a disaster if the

('93', 364, 5, 8, 731675) At the time of Gandhiji’s speech some Muslim friends wished to read an address in Bengali which Gandhiji said might be read if it pleased the friends.
('93', 364, 5, 9, 731826) It referred to the music before mosques, cow slaughter, etc.
('93', 364, 5, 10, 731887) Gandhiji said he was not concerned with these questions.
('93', 364, 5, 11, 731944) They were questions of law.
('93', 364, 5, 12, 731972) He wanted to capture their hearts and see them welded into one.
('93', 364, 5, 13, 732036) If that was attained, everything else would right itself.
('93', 364, 5, 14, 732094) If their hearts were not united, nothing could be right.
('93', 364, 5, 15, 732151) Their unfortunate lot would then be slavery.
('93', 364, 5, 16, 732196) He asked them to accept the slavery of the one Omnipotent God no matter by what name they addressed Him.
('93', 364, 5, 17, 732301) Then they would bend the knee to no man or men.
('93', 364, 5, 18, 732349) It was ignorance to say that he coupled Rama, a mere man, with God.
('93', 364, 5, 19, 732417) He had repeatedly made it clear that his Rama was the same as God.
('93', 364, 5, 20, 732484) His Rama was before, is present now and would be for all time.
('93', 364, 5, 21, 732547) He was Unborn and Uncreated.
('93', 364, 5, 22, 732576) Therefore, let them tolerate and respect the different faiths.
('93', 364, 5, 23, 732639) He was himself an iconoclast but he had equal regard for the so called idolaters.
('93', 364, 5, 24, 732721) Those who worshipped idols also worshipped the same God who was everywhere, even in a clod of earth, even in a nail that was pared off.
('93', 364, 5, 25, 732857) He had Muslim friends whose names were Rahim, Rahman, Karim.
('93', 364, 5, 26, 732918) Would he therefore join on to the name of God when he addressed them as Rahim, Karim or Rahman?
('93', 364, 6, 27, 733014) Let them beware of the thought that all was well in Noakhali or the neighbouring parts.
('93', 364, 6, 28, 733102) If the reports he received were at all true, things had not quite settled down.
('93', 364, 6, 29, 733182) He did not refer to these things or the destruction that had been wrought because he did not wish to excite passion.
('93', 364, 6, 30, 733299) He did not believe in retaliation.
('93', 364, 6, 31, 733334) He had lived with Pathans.
('93', 364, 6, 32, 733361) Badshah Khan 4, being tired of retaliation which had descended from generation to generation, had learnt the virtue of non violence.
('93', 364, 6, 33, 733494) He did not claim perfection for him.
('93', 364, 6, 34, 733531) He could be angered.
('93', 364, 6, 35, 733552) But he did claim for his friend the wisdom that dictated to him restraint on one’s love of vengeance.
('93', 364, 6, 36, 733654) He wanted the same thing in Noakhali.
('93', 364, 6, 37, 733692) Unless they sincerely believed that without real peace between the communities there was neither Pakistan nor Hindustan, slavery was their lot.

('93', 370, 8, 22, 744104) They have lost the confidence of the Bihar Muslims.
