('93', 371, 0, 1, 744345) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 371, 1, 2, 744387) 522. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 371, 2, 3, 744419) SRINAGAR, February 5, 1947
('93', 371, 3, 4, 744446) Gandhiji began his remarks by asking the volunteers to refrain from providing decorations and a kind of ornamental shade where he sat.
('93', 371, 3, 5, 744581) He was averse to all these things.
('93', 371, 3, 6, 744616) It was a waste of labour and money.
('93', 371, 3, 7, 744652) All that was needed was a raised seat with something clean and soft to rest his fatless and muscleless bones.
('93', 371, 3, 8, 744762) He wanted to deal that evening with a question that arose out of the meeting of the third instant but he could not deal with on the fourth as he had to deal with the statement read to him by the Muslim friends.
('93', 371, 3, 9, 744973) The question was as follows :
('93', 371, 4, 10, 745003) You have asked those provinces which have the necessary courage to frame their own constitutions and then ask the British army to quit their territory as proof of the attainment of independence.
('93', 371, 4, 11, 745198) What, in your opinion, should be the basis of the franchise in those free Provinces of India?
('93', 371, 4, 12, 745292) Should communal electorates be replaced by functional ones in the Assemblies?
('93', 371, 4, 13, 745370) Should there be functional instead of communal representation?
('93', 371, 4, 14, 745433) Should there be joint electorates with reservation of seats for communal minorities or functional groups?
('93', 371, 4, 15, 745539) Should there be favoured representation of any group for the time being?
('93', 371, 4, 16, 745612) If so, of what group?
('93', 371, 4, 17, 745634) Should we have joint electorate, and full adult franchise?
('93', 371, 5, 18, 745693) Gandhiji’s answer was unequivocal.
('93', 371, 5, 19, 745728) Even one Province could frame its own constitution and enforce it, provided that it was backed not by a majority of one but by an overwhelming majority.
('93', 371, 5, 20, 745881) Gandhiji held that no power on earth could resist the lovers of liberty who were ready not to kill opponents but to be killed by them.
('93', 371, 5, 21, 746016) This was the view that he had enunciated at one time.
('93', 371, 5, 22, 746070) 2 But today they had made considerable progress.
('93', 371, 5, 23, 746119) He put a favourable interpretation on the Cabinet Mission’s State Paper.
('93', 371, 5, 24, 746192) So far as he could see they could not resist the declared wish of a single province.
('93', 371, 5, 25, 746277) If that was true of one province, say Bengal, how much more was it so for a number of provinces which the Constituent Assembly undoubtedly represented?
('93', 371, 5, 26, 746429) But he was indifferent as to what the British Government said so far as India’s independence was concerned.
('93', 371, 5, 27, 746537) That rested with the people and with no outside power.
('93', 371, 5, 28, 746592) Nor was there any question as to what India would do if the State Paper was withdrawn.
('93', 371, 5, 29, 746679) India had been accustomed to a life in the wilderness.
('93', 371, 5, 30, 746734) When Pandit Nehru and his friends accepted office he had said that it was not a bed of roses but a bed of thorns.
('93', 371, 5, 31, 746848) Their goal was liberty and liberty they would have no matter what happened.
('93', 371, 6, 32, 746924) Naturally he could speak with confidence when the people had only non violence in view as a steadfast simple policy without reservation.
('93', 371, 6, 33, 747061) If, on the other
('93', 371, 7, 34, 747078) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 2 Amrita Bazar Patrika, 8 2 1947 here has “in 1919”.
('93', 372, 0, 1, 747180) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 373
('93', 372, 1, 2, 747228) hand, they thought they could drive away the English by the sword they were vastly mistaken.
('93', 372, 1, 3, 747321) They did not know the determination and courage of the British.
('93', 372, 1, 4, 747385) They would not yield to the power of the sword.
('93', 372, 1, 5, 747433) But they could not withstand the courage of non violence which disdained to deal death against death.
('93', 372, 1, 6, 747535) He knew no other power higher than non violence.
('93', 372, 1, 7, 747584) And if they were still without real independence, it was, he was sure, because the people had not developed sufficient non violence.
('93', 372, 1, 8, 747717) Anyway, the State Paper in his opinion was in answer to the non violent strength that India had so far developed.
('93', 372, 2, 9, 747831) If they contemplated the last War, they would plainly see that whilst the enemy powers so called were crushed, the Allied Powers had won but an empty victory.
('93', 372, 2, 10, 747990) Apart from the wanton destruction of human heads, they had—between the Allies and the enemies—succeeded in draining the world of its food materials and cloth.
('93', 372, 2, 11, 748149) And the former seemed to be so dehumanized that they entertained the vain hope of reducing the enemies to helotry.
('93', 372, 2, 12, 748264) It was a question whom to pity more—the Allies or the enemies.
('93', 372, 2, 13, 748327) Therefore he asked the people bravely to face the consequence whatever it was, feeling secure in the confidence born of non violence, be it as an honest policy.
('93', 372, 3, 14, 748488) As to the franchise he swore by the franchise of all adults, males and females, above the age of twenty one or even eighteen.
('93', 372, 3, 15, 748614) He would bar old men like himself.
('93', 372, 3, 16, 748649) They were of no use as voters.
('93', 372, 3, 17, 748680) India and the rest of the world did not belong to those who were on the point of dying.
('93', 372, 3, 18, 748768) To them belonged death, life to the young.
('93', 372, 3, 19, 748811) Thus he would have a bar against persons beyond a certain age, say fifty, as he would against youngsters below eighteen.
('93', 372, 3, 20, 748932) Of course, he would debar lunatics and loafers.
('93', 372, 3, 21, 748980) Of course, in India free, he could not contemplate communal franchise.
('93', 372, 3, 22, 749051) It must be joint electorate, perhaps with reservation of seats.
('93', 372, 3, 23, 749115) Nor could he contemplate favouritism for anyone, say Muslims, Sikhs or Parsis, for example.
('93', 372, 3, 24, 749207) If there was to be favouritism he would single out physical lepers.
('93', 372, 3, 25, 749275) They were an outcome of the crimes of society.
('93', 372, 3, 26, 749322) If moral lepers would ban themselves, the physical lepers would soon be extinct.
('93', 372, 3, 27, 749403) And they, poor men, were so frightened of modern society that they put forth no claims.
('93', 372, 3, 28, 749491) Educate them truly and they would make ideal citizens.
('93', 372, 3, 29, 749546) Anyway, side by side with adult franchise or even before that he pleaded for universal education, not necessarily literary except perhaps as an aid.
('93', 372, 3, 30, 749695) English education, he was convinced, had starved their minds, enervated them and never prepared them for brave citizenship.
('93', 372, 3, 31, 749819) He would give them all sufficient knowledge in the rich languages of which any country would be proud.
('93', 372, 3, 32, 749922) Education in the understanding of the rights of citizenship was a short term affair if they were honest and earnest.
('93', 372, 3, 33, 750039) Harijan, 2 3 1947

('93', 373, 7, 10, 750435) 524. QUESTION BOX INTELLECTUAL AND MANUAL WORK
('93', 373, 8, 11, 750482) Q. Why should we insist on a Rabindranath 4 or a Raman 5 earning his bread by manual labour?
('93', 373, 8, 12, 750575) Is it not sheer wastage?
('93', 373, 8, 13, 750600) Why should not brain workers be considered on a par with manual workers, for both of them perform useful social work?
('93', 373, 9, 14, 750718) A. Intellectual work is important and has an undoubted place in the scheme of life.
('93', 373, 9, 15, 750802) But what I insist on is the necessity of physical labour.
('93', 373, 9, 16, 750860) No man, I claim, ought to be free from that obligation.
('93', 373, 9, 17, 750916) It will serve to improve even the quality of his intellectual output.
('93', 373, 9, 18, 750986) I venture to say that in ancient times Brahmins worked with their body as with their mind.
('93', 373, 9, 19, 751077) But even if they did not, body labour is a proved necessity at the present time.
('93', 373, 9, 20, 751158) In this connection I would refer to the life of Tolstoy and how he made famous the theory of bread labour first propounded in his country by the Russian peasant Bondaref.

('93', 376, 4, 9, 755830) 531. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 376, 5, 10, 755862) DHARAMPUR, February 6, 1947
('93', 376, 6, 11, 755890) Gandhiji referred to a letter he had received from the Medical Superintendent of the Marwari Relief Society.
('93', 376, 6, 12, 755999) The doctor said that he treated both Hindus and Mussa lmans without any distinction.
('93', 376, 6, 13, 756084) Muslim men and women gladly accepted his services.
('93', 376, 6, 14, 756135) He noticed that in this part of the world the Muslims were poor.
('93', 376, 6, 15, 756200) There was dirt and insanitation wherever he went.
('93', 376, 6, 16, 756250) Would he (Gandhiji) say something about it?
('93', 376, 7, 17, 756294) He (Gandhiji) would gladly do so.
('93', 376, 7, 18, 756328) For he had been a lover of cleanliness and sanitation for over fifty years.
('93', 376, 7, 19, 756404) He had to speak much in disparagement of the West.
('93', 376, 7, 20, 756455) It was therefore a pleasure to him to be able to say that he had learnt the laws of cleanliness from Englishmen.
('93', 376, 7, 21, 756568) He was pained to see the same tanks in Noakhali used for drinking and cleaning purposes.
('93', 376, 7, 22, 756657) It was wrong.
('93', 376, 7, 23, 756671) The people thoughtlessly dirtied the streets, lanes and footpaths by spitting everywhere and clearing their noses.
('93', 376, 7, 24, 756786) This was the cause of many diseases in India.
('93', 376, 7, 25, 756832) No doubt, their chronic poverty was responsible for the diseases.
('93', 376, 7, 26, 756898) But their chronic breach of the laws of sanitation was no less responsible.
('93', 376, 7, 27, 756974) It was surprising that India lived at all.
('93', 376, 7, 28, 757017) But it was worst in point of high death rate.
('93', 376, 7, 29, 757063) America was probably the first in the list.
('93', 376, 7, 30, 757107) And then those that lived were specimens of living death.
('93', 376, 7, 31, 757165) The sooner therefore the inhabitants of Noakhali attended to the laws of sanitation the better for them.
('93', 376, 7, 32, 757270) Poverty was no bar to perfect sanitation.
('93', 376, 8, 33, 757312) Then there was an invasion of Pressmen from far and near.
('93', 376, 8, 34, 757370) The expression, Press Camp, was an attractive expression.
('93', 376, 8, 35, 757428) But this Press Camp was in keeping with the village surroundings and that too with his.
('93', 376, 8, 36, 757516) His surroundings were inconsistent with pomp.
('93', 376, 8, 37, 757562) The Pressmen who accompanied him were living under difficult conditions.
('93', 376, 8, 38, 757635) They had to live in such huts as the villagers were able to provide.
('93', 376, 9, 39, 757704) 1Vide also the following item.
('93', 376, 9, 40, 757735) 2 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('93', 377, 0, 1, 757784) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 377, 1, 2, 757826) had no unlimited accommodation.
('93', 377, 1, 3, 757858) He would advise them not to venture out but be satisfied with the news that the five or six were able to provide.
('93', 377, 1, 4, 757972) His barefoot walk need not provide sensation.
('93', 377, 1, 5, 758018) It ought not to excite people.
('93', 377, 1, 6, 758049) It was no difficulty for him.
('93', 377, 1, 7, 758079) The earth of Noakhali was like velvet and the green grass was a magnificent carpet to walk on.
('93', 377, 1, 8, 758174) It reminded him of the soft English grass he had noticed in England.
('93', 377, 1, 9, 758243) It was wholly unnecessary to wear sandals to be able to walk on the Noakhali earth and grass.
('93', 377, 1, 10, 758337) He could not probably have done it in Gujarat, and then he had inherited the traditions of his country.
('93', 377, 1, 11, 758441) A pilgrimage was always performed barefoot.
('93', 377, 1, 12, 758485) For him this tour was a pilgrimage pure and simple.
('93', 377, 1, 13, 758537) But that should be no attraction to Pressmen and others.
('93', 377, 1, 14, 758594) He considered it as no strain on him.
('93', 377, 1, 15, 758632) And if God willed it, He would allow him to pull through it.
('93', 377, 1, 16, 758693) Let the Pressmen save the time and money; the latter they could contribute to the Noakhali Relief Fund or the never to end Harijan Fund.
('93', 377, 2, 17, 758830) He then came to the questions put to him.
('93', 377, 3, 18, 758872) Q. Supposing one or the other of the provinces wishes to declare its independence, what kind of constitution would you advise them to prepare?
('93', 377, 3, 19, 759015) In 1925, you declared that in the Free India of your dreams only those would have voting rights who had contributed by manual labour to the service of the State.
('93', 377, 3, 20, 759177) Do you adhere to that advice today with regard to the above provinces?
('93', 377, 4, 21, 759248) A. Independence could be the same as for the whole of India.
('93', 377, 4, 22, 759309) He adhered to what he had said in 1925, viz., that all adults above a certain age, male or female, who would contribute some body labour to the State would be entitled to the vote.
('93', 377, 4, 23, 759490) Thus a simple labourer would easily be a voter whereas a millionaire or a lawyer or a merchant and the like would find it hard if they did not do some body labour for the State.
('93', 377, 5, 24, 759668) Q. If contiguous provinces in India do not declare such independence but scattered ones do so, would not the presence of the non federating units create difficulties for the rest in the matter of common action?
('93', 377, 6, 25, 759879) A. He saw no difficulty if the society was of his conception, that is, based on non violence.
('93', 377, 6, 26, 759973) Thus supposing populous Bengal with its gifted Tagores and Suhrawardys framed a constitution based on independence and Assam with its opium habit dreamed away life, Orissa with its skeletons had no wish and Bihar was occupied in family slaughter, they would all three be affected and covered by Bengal.
('93', 377, 6, 27, 760276) Such infectiousness was inherent in his scheme of independence which was friend to all and enemy to none.
('93', 377, 6, 28, 760382) It might well be that his was a voice in the wilderness.
('93', 377, 6, 29, 760439) If so, it was India’s misfortune.
('93', 377, 7, 30, 760473) Q. Do you expect the constitution of the free provinces to be made so attractive that others would voluntarily be drawn into it?
('93', 378, 0, 1, 760602) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 379
('93', 378, 1, 2, 760650) A. Attractiveness was inherent in everything that was inherently good.
('93', 378, 2, 3, 760721) Q. Supposing the whole of Group A forms a common constitution, do you think provinces which are now under Group B or C will be able to join A if they so desired?
('93', 378, 3, 4, 760883) A. It went without saying that if the Group A succeeded in framing a good constitution not only would it be open to B and C to join, they would irresistibly be drawn to it.
('93', 378, 4, 5, 761056) Q. What about the States?
('93', 378, 4, 6, 761082) Who will decide whether a State should join the Union or not: the present rulers or the people?
('93', 378, 4, 7, 761178) If it is to be the latter then what changes would you expect to be first made in the constitutions of the present States?
('93', 378, 5, 8, 761300) A. He was a mere humble ryot but he belonged to the many crores.
('93', 378, 5, 9, 761365) The Rajas were nominally 640, in reality they were probably less than 100. Whatever the number was, they were so few that in an awakened India, they could only exist as servants of the ryots not in name but in actual practice.
('93', 378, 5, 10, 761592) He did not share the fear underlying the question that the British would be so dishonest as to play the Rajas against the ryots.
('93', 378, 5, 11, 761721) That was not the note of the Cabinet Mission Paper.
('93', 378, 5, 12, 761773) But why should India depend upon the British Cabinet?
('93', 378, 5, 13, 761827) When India was ready, neither the British nor the Rajas, nor any combination of the Powers could keep India from her destined goal, her birthright, as the Lokamanya 1 would have said.
('93', 378, 5, 14, 762011) Harijan, 2 3 1947
('93', 378, 6, 15, 762029) 532. LETTER TO N. K. BOSE February 7, 1947
('93', 378, 7, 16, 762072) NIRMALBABU, I never succeeded in writing to you on your first personal letter.
('93', 378, 7, 17, 762151) The second on B’s relation with A now comes.
('93', 378, 7, 18, 762196) I must undertake this second today.
('93', 378, 7, 19, 762232) I sent your letter to A. You left it open for me to do so.
('93', 378, 7, 20, 762291) My loyalty to him demanded that I should.
('93', 378, 7, 21, 762333) B has led you into doing an injustice to A. I discussed it with her.
('93', 378, 7, 22, 762402) She saw the truth of it.
('93', 378, 7, 23, 762427) A’s love is wholly free from animal passion.
('93', 378, 7, 24, 762472) I have called it poetic.
('93', 378, 7, 25, 762497) It is not a perfect adjective but I can find no better.
('93', 378, 7, 26, 762553) He loved once a girl with the same passion with which he loves B. In either case, it was philanthropic.

('93', 380, 4, 8, 764916) 535. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 380, 5, 9, 764948) PRASADPUR, February 7, 1947
('93', 380, 6, 10, 764976) QUESTION: You have always been against charity and have preached the doctrine that no man is free from the obligation of bread labour.
('93', 380, 6, 11, 765111) What is your advice for people who are engaged in sedentary occupations but lost their all in the last riots?
('93', 380, 6, 12, 765221) Should they migrate and try to find a place where they can go back to their old accustomed habits of life or should they try to remodel their life in conformity with your ideal of bread labour for everybody?
('93', 380, 6, 13, 765429) What use shall their special talents be in that case?
('93', 380, 7, 14, 765483) In reply, Gandhiji said that it was true that for years he had been against charity as it was understood and that he had for years preached the duty of bread labour.
('93', 380, 7, 15, 765649) In this connection he mentioned the visit he had had from the District Magistrate and Zaman Saheb along with a police officer.
('93', 380, 7, 16, 765776) They wanted his opinion about giving doles to the refugees.
('93', 380, 7, 17, 765836) They had already decided to put before them the work of removal of the water hyacinth, repair of roads, village reconstruction or straightening out their own plots of land or building on their lands.
('93', 380, 7, 18, 766036) Those who did any one of these things had a perfect right to rations.
('93', 380, 7, 19, 766106) He said that he liked the idea.
('93', 380, 7, 20, 766138) But as a practical idealist he would not take the refugees by storm.
('93', 380, 7, 21, 766207) A variety of work should be put before the people and they should have one month’s notice that if they made no choice of the occupations suggested, nor did they suggest some other acceptable occupation but declined to do any work though their bodies were fit, they would be reluctantly obliged to tell the refugees that they would not be able to give them doles after the expiry of the notice.
('93', 380, 7, 22, 766601) He advised the refugees and their friends to render full co operation to the Government in such a scheme of work.
('93', 380, 7, 23, 766715) It was wrong for any citizen to expect rations without doing some physical work.
('93', 380, 8, 24, 766796) He could never advise people to leave their homes.
('93', 380, 8, 25, 766847) He would like even one solitary Hindu to feel safe under any circumstances and would expect the Muslims to make him perfectly safe in their midst.
('93', 380, 8, 26, 766994) He should welcome them to worship God in
('93', 380, 9, 27, 767035) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('93', 381, 0, 1, 767084) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 381, 1, 2, 767126) the way they knew.
('93', 381, 1, 3, 767145) He certainly did not consider money got through speculation as rightly gained.
('93', 381, 1, 4, 767224) Nor did he consider it impossible for man to shed bad or evil habits at any time.
('93', 381, 1, 5, 767306) If everybody lived by the sweat of his brow, the earth would become a paradise.
('93', 381, 1, 6, 767386) The question of the use of special talents hardly needed separate consideration.
('93', 381, 1, 7, 767467) If everyone laboured physically for his bread, it followed that poets, doctors, lawyers, etc., would regard it their duty to use those talents gratis for the service of humanity.
('93', 381, 1, 8, 767646) Their output will be all the better and richer for their selfless devotion to duty.

('93', 384, 5, 8, 773103) 540. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 384, 6, 9, 773135) NANDIGRAM, February 8, 1947
('93', 384, 7, 10, 773163) Q. The Mussalmans are boycotting the Hindus.
('93', 384, 7, 11, 773208) Those Hindus who possess more land than they can till themselves are in a serious difficulty.
('93', 384, 7, 12, 773302) What is your advice to them?
('93', 384, 7, 13, 773331) What will they do about the surplus land which they hold but cannot till themselves, even if they take up the plough themselves?
('93', 384, 8, 14, 773460) A. In answer Gandhiji said that he had heard of the boycott and had made some remarks at previous meetings.
('93', 384, 8, 15, 773568) He hoped, indeed he knew, that the boycott was not universal in Noakhali.
('93', 384, 8, 16, 773642) It was probably confined to a few.
('93', 384, 8, 17, 773677) Whatever the extent, he had no doubt that it was wrong and would do no good to the boycotters as it could not to those against whom it was directed.
('93', 384, 8, 18, 773826) That opinion was held by him for a large number of years, say sixty.
('93', 384, 8, 19, 773895) But there was a condition in which he would conceive it possible, i.
('93', 384, 8, 20, 773964) e., if the Muslims regarded the Hindus as their enemies and wished to avoid their presence in Noakhali.
('93', 384, 8, 21, 774068) That would amount to a declaration of war from which every Indian would recoil with horror.
('93', 384, 8, 22, 774160) In isolated cases, his opinion was emphatic.
('93', 384, 8, 23, 774205) The Hindu under the boycott would allow his land to lie fallow like the Australians or he would sell the surplus land.
('93', 384, 8, 24, 774324) What was best was that nobody should possess more than he could himself use.
('93', 384, 8, 25, 774401) That was the ideal the society should strive to reach.
('93', 384, 9, 26, 774456) Q. You have been working here for the last three months.
('93', 384, 9, 27, 774513) Has there been any appreciable change in the mentality of the Hindus?
('93', 384, 10, 28, 774583) A. The question could best be answered by the Hindus concerned.
('93', 384, 10, 29, 774647) He flattered himself with the belief that the Hindus had, at least for the time being, shed their cowardice to an extent.
('93', 384, 11, 30, 774769) Q. There is certainly a peace loving section among the Mussalmans.
('93', 384, 11, 31, 774836) After your presence in their midst, have they been influenced to such an extent that they are able to assert themselves against the worse element in their own community?
('93', 384, 12, 32, 775006) A. As to this third question he was glad that the questioner admitted that
('93', 384, 13, 33, 775081) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('93', 385, 0, 1, 775130) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 385, 1, 2, 775172) there was a peace loving section among the Muslims of Noakhali.
('93', 385, 1, 3, 775236) It would be monstrous if there was not.
('93', 385, 1, 4, 775276) Whether they had developed courage to oppose the bad and mischievous element in Muslim society, he would give the same answer that he gave to the second question.
('93', 385, 1, 5, 775439) The Muslim friends could reply with certainty.
('93', 385, 1, 6, 775486) But he was vain enough to believe that several Muslim friends had been so affected.
('93', 385, 1, 7, 775570) As for instance, the Muslim witnesses in Bhatialpur declared that the destroyed mandir 1 he had opened 2 they would defend against destruction in future with their lives.
('93', 385, 1, 8, 775741) There were other consoling instances he had met with during his tour.
('93', 385, 2, 9, 775811) Q. Several workers are engaged in village work according to your direction.
('93', 385, 2, 10, 775887) what had been the result of their work on the local Hindu or Muslim population?
('93', 385, 2, 11, 775967) If you had not been here, would their influence have been equal to what it is at present?
('93', 385, 2, 12, 776057) Will the present influence of your workers be of a lasting character?
('93', 385, 3, 13, 776127) A. As to this fourth question Gandhiji said that if he was pure and meant what he said, his work was bound to survive his death.
('93', 385, 3, 14, 776256) He believed that there must be perfect correspondence between private and public conduct.
('93', 385, 3, 15, 776346) Similarly, if his associates were actuated purely by the spirit of service and were pure within and without and were not dominated by the glamour that surrounded him, they would work on with unabated zeal and their joint work would flourish with time.
('93', 385, 3, 16, 776598) He had never subscribed to the superstition that any good work died with the worker’s death.
('93', 385, 3, 17, 776691) On the contrary, all true and solid work made the worker immortal by the survival of his work after his death.
('93', 385, 3, 18, 776802) Harijan, 2 3 1947

('93', 386, 9, 22, 778269) 543. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 386, 10, 23, 778301) BIJOYNAGAR, February 9, 1947
('93', 386, 11, 24, 778330) Q. It has been our experience that a worker becomes power loving after some time.
('93', 386, 11, 25, 778412) How are the rest of his co workers to keep him in check?
('93', 386, 11, 26, 778469) In other words, how are we to preserve the democratic character of the organization?
('93', 386, 11, 27, 778554) We have found that non co operation with the party in question does not help.
('93', 386, 11, 28, 778632) The work of the organization itself suffers.
('93', 386, 12, 29, 778677) A. This is not your experience alone; it is almost universal.
('93', 386, 12, 30, 778739) Love of power is usual in man and often it only dies with his death.
('93', 386, 13, 31, 778808) 1 This appeared under the title, “Some Important Questions” with the following editorial note : “Gandhiji dealt with some questions that were sent to him during the day.
('93', 386, 13, 32, 778978) It being his day of silence, he wrote out the answers which were read out at the prayer meeting.”
('93', 387, 0, 1, 779076) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 387, 1, 2, 779118) Therefore, it is difficult for co workers to keep him in check, if only because they are more likely than not to have the same human frailty; and so long as we do not know a single completely non violent organization in the world, we cannot claim to know the utterly democratic character of an organization because, as can be definitely proved, no perfect democracy is possible without perfect non violence at the back of it.
('93', 387, 1, 3, 779544) The question would be proper if non co operation was violent as it often, if not invariably, is.
('93', 387, 1, 4, 779641) Claiming to know somewhat from experience the non violent character of non co operation, I suggest that given a good cause, non violent non co operation must succeed and no organization can suffer through offering non violent non co operation.
('93', 387, 1, 5, 779885) The questioner labours under the difficulty of having experience of non co operation, at best partially non violent, at its worst bare faced violence sailing under the name of non violence.
('93', 387, 1, 6, 780075) The pages of the Harijan and Young India are filled with instances of abortive non co operation, because of these two vital defects, non violence being partial or totally absent.
('93', 387, 1, 7, 780254) During my long experience, I also noticed that those who complain of others being ambitious of holding power are no less ambitious themselves, and when it is a question of distinguishing between half a dozen and six, it becomes a thankless task.
('93', 387, 2, 8, 780500) Q. In almost all villages there are parties and factions.
('93', 387, 2, 9, 780558) When we draft local help, whether we wish it or not, we become involved in local power politics.
('93', 387, 2, 10, 780655) How can we steer clear of this difficulty?
('93', 387, 2, 11, 780698) Should we try to bypass both parties and carry on work with the help of outside workers?
('93', 387, 2, 12, 780787) Our experience has been that such work becomes entirely contingent upon outside aid and crumbles down as soon as the latter is withdrawn.
('93', 387, 2, 13, 780925) What should we do then to develop local initiative and foster local co operation?
('93', 387, 3, 14, 781007) A. Alas for India that parties and factions are to be found in the villages as they are to be found in our cities.
('93', 387, 3, 15, 781122) And when power politics enters our villages with less thought of the welfare of the villages and more of using them for increasing the parties’ own power, this becomes a hindrance to the progress of the villagers rather than a help.
('93', 387, 3, 16, 781355) I would say that whatever be the consequence, we must make use as much as possible of local help and if we are free from the taint of power politics, we are not likely to go wrong.
('93', 387, 3, 17, 781536) Let us remember that the English educated men and women from the cities have criminally neglected the villages of India which are the backbone of the country.
('93', 387, 3, 18, 781695) The process of remembering our neglect will induce patience.
('93', 387, 3, 19, 781756) I have never gone to a single village which is devoid of an honest worker.
('93', 388, 0, 1, 781831) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 389
('93', 388, 1, 2, 781879) fail to find him when we are not humble enough to recognize any merit in our villagers.
('93', 388, 1, 3, 781967) Of course, we are to steer clear of local politics and this we shall learn to do when we accept help from all parties and no parties, wherever it is really good.
('93', 388, 1, 4, 782129) I would regard it as fatal for success to bypass villagers.
('93', 388, 1, 5, 782189) As I knew this very difficulty, I have tried rigidly to observe the rule of one village one worker, except that where he or she does not know Bengali, an interpreter’s help has been given.
('93', 388, 1, 6, 782378) I can only say that this system has so far answered the purpose.
('93', 388, 1, 7, 782443) I must, therefore, discount your experiences.
('93', 388, 1, 8, 782489) I would further suggest that we have got into the vicious habit of coming to hasty conclusions.
('93', 388, 1, 9, 782585) Before pronouncing such a sweeping condemnation as is implied in the sentence that ‘work becomes entirely contingent upon outside aid and crumbles down as soon as the latter is withdrawn’, I would go so far as to say that even a few years’ experience of residence in a single village, trying to work through local workers, should not be regarded as conclusive proof that work could not be done through and by local workers.
('93', 388, 1, 10, 783009) The contrary is obviously true.
('93', 388, 1, 11, 783041) It now becomes unnecessary for me to examine the last sentence in detail.
('93', 388, 1, 12, 783115) I can categorically say to the principal worker: ‘If you have any outside help, get rid of it.
('93', 388, 1, 13, 783210) Work singly, courageously, intelligently with all local help you can get and, if you do not succeed, blame only yourself and no one else and nothing else.’
('93', 388, 2, 14, 783366) Q. If we are to start khadi work in the devastated areas in Noakhali, should we begin with financial and technical aid from outside or slowly build up the whole structure with local men and money alone?
('93', 388, 3, 15, 783569) A. I will say in your own words: ‘Slowly build up the whole structure with local men and money’ taking care to make yourself sure that you know the whole art of spinning in the widest sense I have given to the term.
('93', 388, 3, 16, 783785) What that sense is you should learn from my writings in the Harijan which you will do if you have the requisite eagerness.
('93', 388, 4, 17, 783908) Q. The cultivators and land owners who used to have their land tilled by Muslim labour have lost two crops namely mircha (long pepper), til seeds and mustard seeds owing to the loot of agricultural implements and bullocks and want of labour from Muslims.
('93', 388, 4, 18, 784163) The time for ploughing fields for the next boro and aus crop is impending and unless the cultivators get these within fifteen days, they will almost lose that crop also.
('93', 388, 5, 19, 784333) A. This is most unfortunate if it is true.
('93', 388, 5, 20, 784376) I have no doubt that all such land should be put under cultivation not only for the sake of the
('93', 389, 0, 1, 784472) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 389, 1, 2, 784514) owners but also for the State, which is or should be more concerned with the cultivation of food crops even than the owners.
('93', 389, 1, 3, 784639) Therefore the owners should ask the authorities for this assistance and the State should see to it that all such land is beneficially cultivated.
('93', 389, 1, 4, 784785) It is the duty of the State to ask and encourage Muslim labour to render this essential service whether the owner be a Muslim or a Hindu.
('93', 389, 1, 5, 784923) The State should certainly see that all labour is adequately paid by fixing the wages.

('93', 390, 1, 2, 786203) 546. LETTER TO VINOBA BHAVE February 10, 1947
('93', 390, 2, 3, 786249) VINOBA, I do not at all feel happy in having to take your time, but you are being drawn into this.
('93', 390, 2, 4, 786348) The friends in our circle have been very much upset because of Manu’s sleeping with me.
('93', 390, 2, 5, 786436) Kishorelal’s agony is difficult to bear.
('93', 390, 2, 6, 786477) He is so upset that he is on the verge of breaking down.
('93', 390, 2, 7, 786534) The same is the case with Narahari and Swami 1. I do not know how the women at Sevagram and elsewhere must be suffering.
('93', 390, 2, 8, 786655) Here, on the contrary, everybody knows what is happening but I see no sign of its having any effect.
('93', 390, 2, 9, 786756) Maybe that prevents me from feeling the full impact of people’s reactions.
('93', 390, 2, 10, 786831) I keep playing with such fancies, for the co workers’ pain makes me lose confidence in myself.
('93', 390, 2, 11, 786926) My own mind, however, is becoming firmer than ever, for it has been my belief for a long time that that alone is true brahmacharya which requires no hedges.
('93', 390, 2, 12, 787083) My experiments arose from this belief.
('93', 390, 2, 13, 787122) I did make mistakes inthem.
('93', 390, 2, 14, 787150) Unthinking imitation may also have harmed the persons concerned.
('93', 390, 2, 15, 787215) But I am not conscious of myself having fallen.
('93', 390, 2, 16, 787263) Manu’s sleeping with me is not a part of my experiment, but is a part of the present yajna.
('93', 390, 2, 17, 787355) My mind daily sleeps in an innocent manner with millions of women, and Manu also, who is a blood relation to me, sleeps with me as one of these millions.
('93', 390, 2, 18, 787509) If she stops doing that out of deference to custom or to please co workers, would I not be a hypocrite of the type described in chapter III [of the Gita]?
('93', 390, 2, 19, 787664) If I do not appear to people exactly as I am within, wouldn’t that be a blot on my non violence?
('93', 390, 2, 20, 787761) I go to this length: Suppose that non violence has no effect on the people here and I die.
('93', 390, 2, 21, 787852) If I don’t let Manu sleep with me, though I regard it as essential that she should, wouldn’t that be a sign of weakness in me, and in that case would not my death, since I would have failed to realize perfect ahimsa, be the best thing for me?
('93', 390, 2, 22, 788095) In other words, would not my experiment in ahimsa and truth remain incomplete or be tainted?
('93', 390, 2, 23, 788188) Perhaps I have not expressed this last thought clearly.
('93', 390, 2, 24, 788244) I referred to the subject in three speeches 2 of mine.

('93', 391, 10, 28, 789451) At the outset Gandhiji referred to the fact that he was to go to Gopinathpur and was assured that it was no more than one and a half miles.
('93', 391, 10, 29, 789591) He began his trek but Gopinathpur seemed to be receding from view.
('93', 391, 10, 30, 789658) When they had walked for forty five minutes he said he should go no further if he was not to collapse.
('93', 391, 10, 31, 789761) He therefore, retraced his steps.
('93', 391, 10, 32, 789795) It took full one hour and twenty minutes which was too much for
('93', 391, 11, 33, 789859) 1 The addressee in his letter dated February 25, 1947, replied that he did not agree with Gandhiji on this issue, as any consciousness of the difference between man and woman was contrary to ideal brahmacharya.
('93', 391, 11, 34, 790070) But he did not wish to argue.
('93', 391, 11, 35, 790100) 2 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('93', 392, 0, 1, 790149) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 393
('93', 392, 1, 2, 790197) In future, those who invited him to walk to a place should measure the time taken by a leisurely walk.
('93', 392, 1, 3, 790300) He tendered his apology to the Hindus and Muslims of Gopinathpur and they owed an apology to Noakhali for not having been accurate and precise in their speech.
('93', 392, 1, 4, 790460) He incidentally mentioned that the people were found to have blown their noses on the path.
('93', 392, 1, 5, 790552) This was dangerous and dirty, especially for a people who had the habit of walking barefoot.
('93', 392, 1, 6, 790645) A friend had told him that he found a Muslim trader who had proper scales and a Hindu who had improper scales and asked him whether it wasnot true that the Muslim traders were honest and the Hindu traders dishonest.
('93', 392, 1, 7, 790861) He was sure that the inference was wrong.
('93', 392, 1, 8, 790903) In this imperfect world no community was wholly honest or dishonest.
('93', 392, 1, 9, 790972) All he could say was that a man who sported false scales for deceiving his customers was a criminal.
('93', 392, 1, 10, 791073) But he could not take it upon himself to condemn the whole group or community.
('93', 392, 2, 11, 791152) Q. You have said that you will stay here as long as perfect peace and amity between the two communities was not established and that you will die here if necessary.
('93', 392, 2, 12, 791317) Do you not think that such a long stay here will unnecessarily focus Indian and world attention on Noakhali, leading people to think that excesses still continued to be committed here, whereas on the contrary no unseemly acts have been committed by Mussalmans for sometime now?
('93', 392, 3, 13, 791595) A. No impartial observer could draw the mischievous inference from his presence.
('93', 392, 3, 14, 791676) He was there as their friend and servant.
('93', 392, 3, 15, 791718) His presence had certainly advertised Noakhali as a beautiful place which would be a paradise on earth if the Hindus and the Muslims lived in hearty friendship.
('93', 392, 3, 16, 791879) It may be that at the end of the chapter he might be noted down as a failure who knew very little about ahimsa.
('93', 392, 3, 17, 791991) Moreover, it was impossible for him to stay in Noakhali if the Hindus and the Muslims satisfied him that they had established hearty friendship between themselves.
('93', 392, 3, 18, 792155) He was sorry to tell them that he had evidence to show that things were not quite as they should be.
('93', 392, 4, 19, 792256) Q. Don’t you think that the Hindus are artificially keeping up the appearance of tension by staying away from their homes in spite of promises of good behaviour by the Mussalmans which they have also made good in cases where they have been given an opportunity?
('93', 392, 5, 20, 792518) A. He did not think that many Hindus were wilfully staying away from their homes.
('93', 392, 5, 21, 792600) No one would want to be away from his home without attractive inducements.
('93', 392, 5, 22, 792675) He had heard nothing of such inducements.
('93', 392, 5, 23, 792717) But he knew that fright and the absence of the wherewithal were keeping them back.
('93', 392, 5, 24, 792800) Nevertheless, he was assured by the officials that the number returning was satisfactory.
('93', 392, 5, 25, 792890) They could not cope with a greater number.
('93', 392, 5, 26, 792933) When these obvious causes were present there was no occasion to draw far fetched inferences which could not be proved.
('93', 392, 5, 27, 793052) If, however, there were any
('93', 393, 0, 1, 793080) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 393, 1, 2, 793122) instigators keeping them back, the law was there to punish them.
('93', 393, 1, 3, 793187) The proof of the pudding was in the eating.
('93', 393, 1, 4, 793231) If it was true that the general body of the Muslims really wanted the refugees back, he was quite sure they would gladly return.
('93', 393, 1, 5, 793360) But the picture was not so rosy as was painted by the questioner.
('93', 393, 2, 6, 793426) Q. Don’t you think that the dictates of non violence and friendship to all demand withdrawal or dropping of cases against the Mussalmans?
('93', 393, 3, 7, 793564) A. He did not know that there was much non violence in the air.
('93', 393, 3, 8, 793628) Even non violent conduct could not arrest the course of law.
('93', 393, 3, 9, 793689) And non violent conduct on the part of the frightened injured party could not operate until the culprits declared themselves and were penitent.
('93', 393, 3, 10, 793833) The fact was that not only was there no penitence on their part, but they were absconding.
('93', 393, 3, 11, 793924) He was averse to mass arrests.
('93', 393, 3, 12, 793955) And he was for severe punishment of those who were proved to have manufactured complaints.
('93', 393, 4, 13, 794046) Q. Is not the double faced policy of the Cabinet Mission at the root of the present trouble between the League and the Congress and ultimately between the Muslims and the Hindus?
('93', 393, 5, 14, 794225) A. He would not accuse the Cabinet Mission of double dealing.
('93', 393, 5, 15, 794287) They had honestly suggested a solution which in their opinion was fair.
('93', 393, 5, 16, 794359) The beauty of the Paper was that it contained no compulsion.
('93', 393, 5, 17, 794420) Naturally, after acceptance the clauses became obligatory for the accepting party.
('93', 393, 5, 18, 794503) But any party could refuse acceptance.
('93', 393, 5, 19, 794542) Thus if Assam in the east and Baluchistan in the west rejected the Grouping, no power on earth could compel them under the Cabinet Mission Paper.
('93', 393, 5, 20, 794688) Lastly, assuming that the Cabinet Mission Paper was a trap, why should the Congress and the League fall into it?
('93', 393, 6, 21, 794801) Q. Pakistan means complete independence for the Muslims in the Muslim majority Provinces and for the Hindus in Hindu majority Provinces.
('93', 393, 6, 22, 794938) Why then does the Congress object to it?
('93', 393, 7, 23, 794979) A. The answer was simple.
('93', 393, 7, 24, 795005) If Pakistan meant independence only to the Muslims in the Muslim majority provinces and vice versa, it was summarily rejected.
('93', 393, 7, 25, 795132) Happily not one Muslim leader, certainly not the Qaid e Azam, had ever given that meaning.
('93', 393, 7, 26, 795223) Were the Hindus in Bihar to be independent and the Muslims helots?
('93', 393, 7, 27, 795290) Or were the Hindus to be helots in Bengal?
('93', 393, 7, 28, 795333) He hoped not.
('93', 393, 8, 29, 795347) Q. Can there be any hope of establishing Hindu Muslim unity here in spite of the Congress League differences which are at the root of all the troubles everywhere?
('93', 393, 8, 30, 795510) Even if it is established, how long can it be expected to last?
('93', 393, 9, 31, 795574) A. He admitted that Hindu Muslim unity could not be sustained in the face of Congress League differences.
('93', 393, 9, 32, 795680) He hoped, however, that apart from party politics, whilst there was time, the Hindus and the Muslims in Noakhali would act together as real friends.
('93', 393, 9, 33, 795829) They should set an example to all India and especially to the League and the Congress.
('93', 393, 9, 34, 795916) Anyway, that was the mission that brought him to Noakhali.
('93', 394, 0, 1, 795975) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 395
('93', 394, 1, 2, 796023) wanted to pass his examination in pure ahimsa.
('93', 394, 1, 3, 796070) If it was pure, it must result in establishing that friendship which he desired at heart.
('93', 394, 1, 4, 796160) Therefore, if it was not established, the failure would be his.

('93', 394, 3, 9, 796430) HAMCHANDI, February 11, 1947
('93', 394, 4, 10, 796459) QUESTION: A Bill 1 has been introduced in the Bengal Assembly which contemplates reduction of the landlord’s share from one half to one third of the crop in certain cases.
('93', 394, 4, 11, 796631) According to the new proposal, a farmer who has been in service on his master’s land on or after December 22, 1946 cannot be ousted from the land for a term of three years.
('93', 394, 4, 12, 796804) Muslim farmers on the char lands have suddenly developed extraordinary enthusiasm for securing land on the barga system from Hindu land owners.
('93', 394, 4, 13, 796948) Many of the so called owners in char lands are in fact farmers themselves, only they left the land in charge of the bargadars (tenants) when they fled during the riots in October last.
('93', 394, 4, 14, 797133) Muslim farmers cannot just now be ousted from the land as the crop will not mature till about the month of June.
('93', 394, 4, 15, 797246) Hindus will, therefore, lose possession of the land for the next three years at least if the Bill becomes law.
('93', 394, 4, 16, 797357) Now that Hindu farmers are once more coming back to their lands, what should they do in order not to lose their agricultural occupation through the vagaries of the law?
('93', 394, 5, 17, 797526) ANSWER: It is improper to die before one’s death.
('93', 394, 5, 18, 797576) Let them wait till the Bill becomes law.
('93', 394, 5, 19, 797617) Yet, I would advise them to welcome reduction of the landlord’s share from one half to one third.
('93', 394, 5, 20, 797715) The time is coming when all lands will belong to the State, that is, to the labourer on the land.
('93', 394, 5, 21, 797813) This is not to be looked upon as a communal question.
('93', 394, 5, 22, 797867) It may be that the landlords are Hindus in Noakhali.
('93', 394, 5, 23, 797920) But if the legislation is sound, it should not matter whom it affects.
('93', 394, 5, 24, 797991) I have serious doubts as to the propriety of not ousting labourers for a period of three years.
('93', 394, 5, 25, 798087) I would want to see the proposed legislation.
('93', 394, 5, 26, 798133) As to the alleged usurpation of land by the Muslims, in my opinion, that is indefensible, if true.
('93', 394, 5, 27, 798232) Let there be authentic instances and I have no doubt that the grievances would be remedied.
('93', 394, 5, 28, 798324) No Government of the people can, for a moment, tolerate usurpation.
('93', 394, 5, 29, 798392) If there are Muslims who had tilled the land that was unoccupied by reason of the
('93', 394, 6, 30, 798474) 1 Bargadars (Land Tenancy) Bill
('93', 395, 0, 1, 798506) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 395, 1, 2, 798548) disturbances, all that the tiller could claim is wages for the work done on the land.
('93', 395, 1, 3, 798634) In reality, if he tilled the land for his neighbour who was in adversity, it would be a neighbourly act for which there could be no remuneration.
('93', 395, 1, 4, 798780) Any such proved usurpation has to be reported to get remedied.
('93', 395, 2, 5, 798843) Q. You have advised both men and women to turn into voluntary labourers to hold no more land than they can till themselves.
('93', 395, 2, 6, 798967) But under our present social system in which the State does not take responsibility for the education of the young and the maintenance of the aged and the infirm when there is none else to look after them, these expenses are paid out of rent received from the land or from profits derived from private ownership.
('93', 395, 2, 7, 799280) What will happen to the above persons when land and capital are taken away from them?
('93', 395, 2, 8, 799366) Could not suffering be avoided and adequate provision made for the education of the young and the maintenance of the aged or infirm?
('93', 395, 2, 9, 799499) A. I admit I gave the advice and I still adhere to it.
('93', 395, 2, 10, 799554) I laid down a universal proposition for an ideal society.
('93', 395, 2, 11, 799612) In the present case it is a virtue of necessity for it is said that they cannot get labour which is principally Muslim.
('93', 395, 2, 12, 799732) The question about the education of the young and maintenance of the old and the infirm should not arise.
('93', 395, 2, 13, 799838) The young would get education at home and persons who work willingly will find that the old and infirm would be supported.
('93', 395, 2, 14, 799961) I am, however, free to confess that it is the business of the State to provide suitable education for the young and support for the aged and infirm.
('93', 395, 2, 15, 800110) It should also be remembered that I have not suggested that owners should give up their land free of price.
('93', 395, 2, 16, 800218) They would sell it on suitable terms or hold on to it and let it lie fallow.
('93', 395, 2, 17, 800295) It will not hurt.
('93', 395, 2, 18, 800313) The Hindu, 14 2 1947
('93', 395, 3, 19, 800334) 550. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO ABUL KALAM AZAD February 12, 1947 If the ahimsa about which I have written so much and which I have striven to realize in practice all these years does not answer in a crisis, it ceases to have any value in my eyes.
('93', 395, 3, 20, 800578) Your affection prompts you to say that if only I were near you, all would be well.
('93', 395, 3, 21, 800661) 1 The truth however is that so long as I cannot make good here, I can be of no use anywhere.

('93', 396, 2, 6, 801396) I do hope that you will act quickly, for in such cases quickness is the essence of the thing if a breakdown is to be avoided.

('93', 397, 1, 2, 803029) 553. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('93', 397, 2, 3, 803059) KAFILATALI, February 12, 1947
('93', 397, 3, 4, 803089) Gandhiji said that when he was studying in London over 45 years ago, he had read of the bravery of the Manipuris.
('93', 397, 3, 5, 803203) The members of the delegation 1, Gandhiji said, had complained to him that although caste Hindus in Assam considered the Manipuris part of themselves, yet they did not look after the interests of the Manipuris who had a separate language, a separate culture and a separate tradition of their own.
('93', 397, 3, 6, 803500) The caste Hindus, the delegation had complained, took advantage of the presence of the Manipuris in their midst only to swell their votes.
('93', 397, 3, 7, 803639) But none either understood or cared for the Manipuris’ interests.
('93', 397, 3, 8, 803705) Therefore, they thought, some arrangement should be made for safeguarding their interests.
('93', 397, 4, 9, 803796) Gandhiji said that all that he wanted to say on this was that if Hinduism was to survive, it would have to be casteless.
('93', 397, 4, 10, 803917) He had long since forgotten that he belonged to any caste.
('93', 397, 4, 11, 803976) Therefore, he delighted in calling himself a Bhangi and acting like one.
('93', 397, 4, 12, 804049) He did not believe in any artificial divisions.
('93', 397, 5, 13, 804097) If caste Hindus meant Brahmin, Kshatriya and Vaishya, these three were a hopeless minority which, when the British had wholly withdrawn and independence was truly established would, as the three superior castes, be wholly extinct.
('93', 397, 5, 14, 804328) Gandhiji hoped that all inequalities would be a thing of the past.
('93', 397, 5, 15, 804395) Then the so called downtrodden would come into their own.
('93', 397, 6, 16, 804453) Gandhiji said that, when untouchability was really gone, there would be no caste.
('93', 397, 6, 17, 804535) But while the caste system was in vogue, the untouchables would naturally want to belong to the higher castes.
('93', 397, 6, 18, 804646) But that was an impossibility.
('93', 397, 6, 19, 804677) Therefore any such attempt, according to Mahatma Gandhi, meant war among caste members on the one hand and the untouchables on the other.
('93', 397, 6, 20, 804815) But when castes disappeared, all would be Hindus pure and simple.
('93', 397, 6, 21, 804881) What he would say to the untouchables was that they should abolish all distinctions among themselves and observe the laws of cleanliness better than the so called caste Hindus.
('93', 397, 6, 22, 805058) And instead of working for separate treatment for themselves they should endeavour to merge themselves in the ocean of Hindu humanity.
('93', 397, 7, 23, 805193) Gandhiji, replying to a question, said he was emphatically of the opinion that the Hindus of Noakhali should not live in a special centre in Noakhali and erect factories where they could work.
('93', 397, 7, 24, 805386) Apart from his views on cottage industries, he could
('93', 397, 8, 25, 805439) 1The delegation which met Gandhiji on February 11 had come from Cachar District; it claimed for the two Lakhs of Manipuris in Assam minority representation in the Assam Assembly.
('93', 398, 0, 1, 805618) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 399
('93', 398, 1, 2, 805666) not contemplate separate quarters and separate industries for them.
('93', 398, 1, 3, 805734) That was the way to establish poisonous Pakistan all over India.
('93', 398, 2, 4, 805799) He could not approve of the idea anywhere in India.
('93', 398, 2, 5, 805851) That was the way to create wars among themselves.
('93', 398, 2, 6, 805901) It was not the way to independence.
('93', 398, 2, 7, 805937) He could not approve of separate “quarters”, for communities professing different religions.
('93', 398, 2, 8, 806030) Independent India, as conceived by me, will have all Indians belonging to different religions living in perfect friendship.
('93', 398, 2, 9, 806154) There need be no millionaires and no paupers; all would belong to the State, for the State belonged to them.
('93', 398, 2, 10, 806263) I will die in the act of realizing this dream.
('93', 398, 2, 11, 806310) I would not wish to live to see India torn asunder by civil strife.
('93', 398, 2, 12, 806378) The Hindu, 13 2 1947 and 15 2 1947

('93', 399, 4, 9, 807950) 556. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 4
('93', 399, 5, 10, 807982) EAST KEROA, February 13, 1947
('93', 399, 6, 11, 808012) After congratulating the audience on the manner in which they had kept time during the Ramdhun, Gandhiji dealt with the two questions which had been put to him in course of the day.
('93', 399, 7, 12, 808194) Q. We agree that intrinsically a movement for reducing the share of the owner from half to a third of the crop is justified.
('93', 399, 7, 13, 808319) 5 But could not the present Tebhaga movement in Bengal be postponed until such time as when the affected persons can be smoothly absorbed in other occupations according to some long term plan sponsored by the State?
('93', 399, 7, 14, 808535) We know you have said that the only way to effect such a radical transformation in society is through non violence.
('93', 399, 7, 15, 808651) But interested parties will sleep over that portion of your advice and parade your moral support to their demand and carry on the movement in their own violent way.
('93', 399, 7, 16, 808816) Hence is it not wrong for you to lend support to the Movement under the present circumstances when there is every chance of the entire middle class of Bengal being completely ruined as a result?
('93', 399, 7, 17, 809011) The common villager will also suffer no less because he will also be deprived of the services now being rendered to the village economy by them.
('93', 399, 8, 18, 809156) A. In reply, Gandhiji uttered the warning that he only dealt with principles as he knew them.
('93', 399, 8, 19, 809250) He had not studied the local question.
('93', 399, 8, 20, 809289) Therefore, the questioner ran the risk of his ignorance causing injustice.
('93', 399, 9, 21, 809364) He felt that the question betrayed exaggeration on the part of the questioner.
('93', 399, 10, 22, 809443) 1 The source has 14, which appears to be a printer’s error.
('93', 399, 10, 23, 809503) 2 Omissions as in the source 3 ibid 4 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 5 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 11 2 1947
('93', 400, 0, 1, 809633) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 401
('93', 400, 1, 2, 809681) There was no ruin impending for the landlord.
('93', 400, 1, 3, 809727) His land was not being confiscated.
('93', 400, 1, 4, 809763) His portion, which he could take even if he was in Timbuktu, was merely to be reduced from 50% to 33%.
('93', 400, 1, 5, 809866) He could see no ruin in the proposal.
('93', 400, 1, 6, 809904) He was afraid they were too much obsessed by the communal question.
('93', 400, 1, 7, 809972) They should rise above it and examine every problem strictly on merits.
('93', 400, 1, 8, 810044) Then they would never go wrong.
('93', 400, 1, 9, 810076) Therefore they should accept the moral principle underlying the demand for reduction of the owner’s share and work for solid amendments in which they were likely to succeed.
('93', 400, 1, 10, 810250) Let them not face confiscation rather than moderate reduction.
('93', 400, 1, 11, 810313) Let them remember that for years past India had lived through confiscation.
('93', 400, 1, 12, 810389) Industry after industry had been ruined and both the artisans as well as the farmers of India had been progressively reduced to poverty.
('93', 400, 2, 13, 810526) If the desired changes were brought about through non violent means, the world would not be deprived of the talents of the classes, but then the latter would not exercise them at the expense of the labourers.
('93', 400, 2, 14, 810735) In the non violent order of the future, the land would belong to the State, for had it not been said ‘sabhi bhumi Gopalki’ 1?
('93', 400, 2, 15, 810861) Under such dispensation, there would be no waste of talents and labour.
('93', 400, 2, 16, 810933) This would be impossible through violent means.
('93', 400, 2, 17, 810981) It was therefore a truism to say that the utter ruin of the land owners brought about through violence would also involve the ruin of the labourers in the end.
('93', 400, 2, 18, 811141) If the land owners, therefore, acted wisely, no party would lose.
('93', 400, 3, 19, 811207) Q. Some women workers who earn part of their living by weaving mats were advised by you the other day to work on co operative principles.
('93', 400, 3, 20, 811345) Bengal’s agriculture has been reduced to an uneconomic proposition through extreme fragmentation of holdings.
('93', 400, 3, 21, 811455) Would you advise farmers also to adopt co operative methods?
('93', 400, 3, 22, 811516) If so, how are they to effect this under the present system of land ownership?
('93', 400, 3, 23, 811595) Should the State make the necessary changes in the law?
('93', 400, 3, 24, 811651) If the State is not ready, but the people so desire, how are they to work through their own organizations to this end?
('93', 400, 4, 25, 811770) A. Replying to the first part of the question, Gandhiji said that he had no doubt that the system of co operation was far more necessary for the agriculturists than for the mat weavers.
('93', 400, 4, 26, 811956) The land, as he maintained, belonged to the State; therefore, it yielded the largest return when it was worked co operatively.
('93', 400, 4, 27, 812083) Let it be remembered that co operation should be based on strict non violence.
('93', 400, 4, 28, 812162) There was no such thing as success of violent co operation.
('93', 400, 4, 29, 812222) Hitler was a forcible example of the latter.
('93', 400, 4, 30, 812267) He also talked vainly of co operation which was forced upon the people and everyone knew where Germany had been led as a result.
('93', 400, 5, 31, 812396) Gandhiji concluded by saying that it would be a sad thing if India also tried to build up the new society based on co operation by means of violence.
('93', 400, 5, 32, 812546) Good brought about through force destroyed individuality.
('93', 400, 5, 33, 812604) Only when the change was effected
('93', 400, 6, 34, 812638) 1 All land belongs to God.
('93', 401, 0, 1, 812665) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 401, 1, 2, 812707) through the persuasive power of non violent non co operation, i.
('93', 401, 1, 3, 812772) e., love, could the foundation of individuality be preserved and real abiding progress be assured for the world.
('93', 401, 1, 4, 812885) Harijan, 9 3 1947

('93', 402, 4, 7, 814234) 560. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('93', 402, 5, 8, 814266) WEST KEROA, February 14, 1947
('93', 402, 6, 9, 814296) Gandhiji read two passages from Abdullah Suhrawardy’s collections of the sayings of the Prophet.
('93', 402, 6, 10, 814393) Three Muslim friends of the place had come to him and asked him to pray that God might make both [Hindus and Muslims] live in peace and friendship.
('93', 402, 6, 11, 814541) When these friends came he was reading the sayings which he proposed to read to them.
('93', 402, 6, 12, 814627) They were as follows :
('93', 402, 7, 13, 814650) Be in the world like a traveller, or like a passer on, and reckon yourself as of the dead.
('93', 402, 8, 14, 814741) He considered it as a gem of gems.
('93', 402, 8, 15, 814776) They knew that death might overtake them any moment.
('93', 402, 8, 16, 814829) What a fine preparation for the event if all became as dead.
('93', 402, 8, 17, 814890) The very next question was who was the best man and who was the worst.
('93', 402, 8, 18, 814961) The Prophet considered him to be the best who lived long and performed good acts and him the worst who did bad acts.
('93', 402, 8, 19, 815078) It was a striking saying that man was to be judged by what he did, and not by what he said.
('93', 402, 9, 20, 815170) These sayings were for all men and women and not merely for those who called themselves Muslims.
('93', 402, 9, 21, 815267) Was the Hindu part of the audience doing good acts?
('93', 402, 9, 22, 815319) Was untouchability a good act?
('93', 402, 9, 23, 815350) He had shouted from the house tops that it was a blot on Hinduism.
('93', 402, 9, 24, 815417) So long as that blot remained, there was no peace and freedom for India.
('93', 402, 9, 25, 815490) The British would go but their freedom would not come without the complete removal of untouchability.
('93', 402, 9, 26, 815592) Harijan, 9 3 1947

('93', 404, 1, 28, 818926) You will not find any open accusation made in these letters, though in Devdas’s letter it is openly made.
('93', 404, 1, 29, 819032) Whether or not I am free from physical desire will probably be known only after my death.
('93', 404, 1, 30, 819122) The term ‘probably’ is deliberately used, because it does not always happen that we are able to correctly judge a man after his death.
('93', 404, 1, 31, 819257) Only God understands the heart of man.
('93', 404, 1, 32, 819296) When I cannot say with any certainty about myself that I do not feel the weight of whatever is happening, who can say that about Manu ?
('93', 404, 1, 33, 819432) She appears to be unconcerned, but she herself may not be fully aware of the turmoil in her mind.
('93', 404, 1, 34, 819530) I am not bothering her about it.
('93', 404, 1, 35, 819563) I am carrying on, leaving everything in the hands of God.
('93', 404, 1, 36, 819621) For me, all this is an inseparable part of the yajna and it remains to be seen how far my non–attachment can carry.
('93', 404, 1, 37, 819737) I have read both your papers.
('93', 404, 1, 38, 819767) I am sending them back, though you have said that it is not necessary to return the second paper.

('93', 405, 1, 2, 820306) 563. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('93', 405, 2, 3, 820333) RAIPURA, February 15, 1947
('93', 405, 3, 4, 820360) GHANSHYAMDAS, I sent you a letter through Sushila.
('93', 405, 3, 5, 820411) But I have been upset somewhat by Sardar’s letter.
('93', 405, 3, 6, 820462) Devdas’s letter is still ringing in my ears.
('93', 405, 3, 7, 820507) I do not remember what I wrote to you, for I have not kept a copy of it.
('93', 405, 3, 8, 820580) All I wish today to write is that you should give up your attitude of neutrality.
('93', 405, 3, 9, 820662) Sardar is quite clear in his mind that what I look upon as my dharma is really adharma.
('93', 405, 3, 10, 820750) Devdas of course has written as much.
('93', 405, 3, 11, 820788) I have great faith in Sardar’s judgment.
('93', 405, 3, 12, 820829) I have faith in Devdas’s judgment too, but then, though grown up, in my eyes he is still a child.
('93', 405, 3, 13, 820927) This cannot be said of Sardar.
('93', 405, 3, 14, 820958) Kishorelal and Narahari too are grown ups; but it is not difficult for me to understand their opposition.
('93', 405, 3, 15, 821064) The link between you and me is your faith that my life is pure, spotless and wholly dedicated to the performance of dharma.
('93', 405, 3, 16, 821188) If that is not so, very little else remains.
('93', 405, 3, 17, 821233) I would, therefore, like you to take full part in this discussion, though not necessarily publicly—for I certainly do not want your business to suffer.
('93', 405, 3, 18, 821385) But if I am conducting myself sinfully, it becomes the duty of all friends to oppose me vehemently.
('93', 405, 3, 19, 821485) A satyagrahi may end up as a duragrahi if he comes to regard untruth as truth—that being the only distinction between the two.
('93', 405, 3, 20, 821612) I believe that is not the case with me; but that means little, for after all I am not God.
('93', 405, 3, 21, 821703) I can commit mistakes; I have committed mistakes; this may prove to be my biggest at the fag end of my life.
('93', 405, 3, 22, 821812) If that be so, all my well wishers can open my eyes if they oppose me.
('93', 405, 3, 23, 821883) If they do not I shall go from here even as I am.
('93', 405, 3, 24, 821933) Whatever I am doing here is as a part of my yajna.
('93', 405, 3, 25, 821984) There is nothing I do knowingly which is not a part and parcel of that yajna.
('93', 405, 3, 26, 822062) Even the rest I take is as a part of that yajna.
('93', 405, 3, 27, 822111) I am dictating this with a mud pack over my eyes and abdomen.
('93', 405, 3, 28, 822173) Shortly afterwards I shall be going to the evening prayer meeting.
('93', 405, 3, 29, 822240) This business about Manu is taking up a lot of my time, but I do not mind it because even her presence here is for the sake of that yajna.
('93', 405, 3, 30, 822379) Her test constitutes a part of that yajna.
('93', 405, 3, 31, 822422) I may not be able to explain it to you—that is a different matter.
('93', 405, 3, 32, 822489) The point I must make my friends grasp is this: When I take Manu in my lap, do I do so as a pure hearted father or as a father who has strayed from the path of virtue?
('93', 406, 0, 1, 822657) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 407
('93', 406, 1, 2, 822705) What I am doing is nothing new to me; in thought I have done it over the last 50 years; in action, in varying degrees, over quite a number of years.
('93', 406, 1, 3, 822854) Even if you sever all connection with me, I would not feel hurt.
('93', 406, 1, 4, 822919) Just as I want to stick to my dharma, you have to stick to yours.
('93', 406, 1, 5, 822985) To come to another matter, the Hindu weavers here—known as tantis—are very angry.
('93', 406, 1, 6, 823067) Their spinning wheels and houses have been for the most part burnt.
('93', 406, 1, 7, 823135) If they do not get a supply of yarn they have either to be idle or take to earth work as labourers.

('93', 407, 0, 1, 824377) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('93', 407, 1, 2, 824419) 565. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 407, 2, 3, 824451) RAIPURA, February 15, 1947
('93', 407, 3, 4, 824478) The first question was: All over the district of Noakhali there is talk that the Muslim population should boycott the Hindus in every way.
('93', 407, 3, 5, 824617) Some Muslims who have worked for the Hindus recently or helped them during the riots report that they are under threat of boycott.
('93', 407, 3, 6, 824748) In this context what should be the duty of those Muslims who genuinely desire peace.
('93', 407, 4, 7, 824833) Gandhiji replied that he had heard of the boycott before.
('93', 407, 4, 8, 824891) But he entertained the hope that such was not the case on any extensive scale.
('93', 407, 4, 9, 824970) He had one case brought to his notice three or four days ago by a Muslim traveller from Gujarat who had come to see him.
('93', 407, 4, 10, 825091) He was rebuked for daring to want to see him.
('93', 407, 4, 11, 825137) The traveller stood his ground and came out of the ordeal safely.
('93', 407, 4, 12, 825203) Another poor Muslim who had come today was threatened with dire penalty if he dared to go to him.
('93', 407, 4, 13, 825301) He did not know what truth there was in the report.
('93', 407, 4, 14, 825353) The speaker then instanced printed leaflets that were pasted on the walls in the name of the Muslim pituni 2 Party.
('93', 407, 4, 15, 825469) These instances gave colour to the question.
('93', 407, 4, 16, 825514) He would say to the Muslim friends and others that these things should not frighten or disturb them.
('93', 407, 4, 17, 825615) They should ignore these things if they were isolated instances.
('93', 407, 4, 18, 825680) If they were on an extensive scale, probably the Government would deal with the situation.
('93', 407, 4, 19, 825771) If unfortunately boycott became the policy of the Government, it would be a serious matter.
('93', 407, 4, 20, 825863) He could only think non violently.
('93', 407, 4, 21, 825898) If they gave proper compensation he would probably advise acceptance.
('93', 407, 4, 22, 825968) He could not think out there and then the pros and cons.
('93', 407, 4, 23, 826025) If, on the other hand, they resorted to confiscation, he would advise people to stand their ground and refuse to leave their homesteads even on pain of death.
('93', 407, 4, 24, 826184) This he would say of all provinces whether Muslim majority or Hindu majority.
('93', 407, 4, 25, 826262) He however hoped that no Government would be mad enough to subscribe to the policy of boycott whether with or without compensation.
('93', 407, 4, 26, 826394) Those who belonged to the land for ages could not be removed from their homesteads merely for the reason that they found themselves in a minority.
('93', 407, 4, 27, 826541) That was no religion, Hindu, Muslim, Christian or any other.
('93', 407, 4, 28, 826602) It was intolerance.
('93', 407, 5, 29, 826622) The second question was: At East Keroa you advised 3 peasants to work co operatively in their fields.
('93', 407, 5, 30, 826724) Should they pool together their land and divide the crop in proportion to the area of the fields they held?
('93', 407, 5, 31, 826832) Would you give us an outline of the idea of how exactly they are to work in a co operative manner?
('93', 407, 6, 32, 826931) Gandhiji said that the question was good and admitted of a simple answer.
('93', 407, 7, 33, 827005) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 2 Violent 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 13 2 1947
('93', 408, 0, 1, 827109) VOL. 93: 7 NOVEMBER, 1946 16 FEBRUARY, 1947 409
('93', 408, 1, 2, 827157) notion of co operation was that the land would be held in co operation by the owners and tilled and cultivated also in co operation.
('93', 408, 1, 3, 827290) This would cause a saving of labour, capital, tools, etc.
('93', 408, 1, 4, 827348) The owners would work in co operation and own capital, tools, animals and seeds etc., in co operation.
('93', 408, 1, 5, 827451) Co operative farming of his conception would change the face of the land and banish poverty and idleness from their midst.
('93', 408, 1, 6, 827574) All this was only possible if people became friends of one another and as one family.
('93', 408, 1, 7, 827660) When that happy event took place, there would be no ugly sore in the form of communal problem.
('93', 408, 1, 8, 827755) Harijan, 9 3 1947
('93', 408, 2, 9, 827773) 566. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('93', 408, 3, 10, 827805) RAIPURA, February 16, 1947
('93', 408, 4, 11, 827832) Gandhiji referred to the two visits 2 and expressed his gratefulness for being able to pay them.
('93', 408, 4, 12, 827929) He then referred briefly to the speech reported to have been made by the ex Premier Maulvi Fazlul Huq.
('93', 408, 4, 13, 828032) He was reported to have said that as a non Muslim Gandhi should not preach the teachings of Islam, that instead of Hindu Muslim unity he was creating bitterness between the two communities and that had he (Gandhiji) gone to Barisal 3 he would have driven him into the canal.
('93', 408, 4, 14, 828307) He also wondered how the Muslims of Noakhali and Tippera could tolerate Gandhi’s presence so long.
('93', 408, 5, 15, 828406) Gandhiji said that he had grave doubts about the accuracy of the report.
('93', 408, 5, 16, 828479) If it was the correct summary of the speech, he would consider it to be most unfortunate coming from a man holding the responsible position that the Maulvi Saheb held and aspiring to be the President of the Muslim League.
('93', 408, 5, 17, 828701) He was not aware of having done anything to create bitterness between the two communities.
('93', 408, 5, 18, 828792) The speaker had never claimed to preach Islam.
('93', 408, 5, 19, 828839) What he had undoubtedly done was to interpret the teachings of the Prophet and refer to them in his own speeches.
('93', 408, 5, 20, 828953) His interpretation was submitted for acceptance or rejection.
('93', 408, 6, 21, 829015) In the same speech Fazlul Huq had said that when Gandhiji returned from South Africa he had asked him (Gandhiji) to embrace Islam, whereupon Gandhiji had said that he was a Muslim in the true sense of the term.
('93', 408, 6, 22, 829226) Mr. Huq had requested him to proclaim it publicly, but Gandhiji refused to do so.
('93', 408, 6, 23, 829308) He said that he had no recollection whatsoever of the conversation and he was never in the habit of suppressing from the public what he had said privately.
('93', 408, 6, 24, 829464) The audience, however, knew that he had stated in

('93', 409, 1, 3, 829884) That such a claim would be rejected and on some occasions was rejected, he knew.
('93', 409, 1, 4, 829965) That, however, did not affect his fundamental position and if he had said what was attributed to him by Fazlul Huq, Gandhiji would gladly declare his repentance if he would believe what was represented to him.
('93', 409, 1, 5, 830175) Indeed he had put forth the claim in South Africa to be a good Mussalman simultaneously with being a good member of the other religions of the world.
